description:
Yummy place to explore, another mucho excellentè diverse cuisine the bay has to offer. 
.....................
Must TRY:
author: Cheyenne L.

description:
In short  very, very unprofessional, bad service, food was dry and barely warm, overpriced.
The long version: .I think it's safe to say that this was by far my worst restaurant experience ever ... and I'm in my 50s and have lived at and traveled to many places. I went to Borobudur with my husband and our two teenagers. When we arrived, the place wasn't very busy but it took a while to take our orders. We hadn't been asked for drinks until we ordered our food. And while we ordered, a young woman (I really can't call her a waitress) managed to bring us 4 glasses with water (we had ordered sodas) without a tray, which was almost artistic and would be the only thing that impressed me during this evening. 
About 20 minutes later we still didn't have our drinks, the place started to fill up and we realized that the young man and young woman were the only staff. While she had no idea what to do, filling and delivering glasses with water was the only thing she had under controle. He was seating guests, taking plenty of phone orders, took orders at the tables and it was obvios that he was sort of lost in a choas. We reminded him of our drinks and finally the woman dropped off glasses and the sodas ... in cans. After a very long wait, we then got the crab chips that we had asked for - very disappointing they were not fresh but from a bag - and the food for our daughter. Our food was nowhere to be seen and they didn't tell us anThing about when we might get it. After a while our daughter started eating. 5 minutes later she got a huge bowl of rice. Still no word about our food. Our daughter lost her apetite because she didn't like to be the only one with food. 20 minutes later our food made it to the tiny desk where the two tried to figure out what it is and where it has to go. 
We finally got our food and my husband asked for new rice since the rice bowl was already cold but we only got the little coconut rice that I had ordered for me. I had also ordered the honey beef which came with a flower but without any sauce. The meat had the size of my palm (see picture) but I had no knife and had to pull it appart with a fork and spoon. It was so dry and chewy that I realky asked my husband if he still knows the Heimlich maneuver ... just in case. The rest of the family wasn't too impressed if their food either, especially since it was barely warm. Not once did they ask us if everything was ok or if we need more drinks. They didn't even look at our table nore did they talk to us when they brought ou food. This behaviour made it impossible to ask for the check - we would have had to yell through the room or jump up and down at our table to maybe get their attention. So after trying and waiting for a long time again, we felt the only way out was to get up and go to the desk to pay there. We ended up paying almost $90 for food that came barely warm ond absolutely uncoordinated, and that we eventually barely touched because we've lost our apetite over the bad service. We came in with " The menue looks great, we might come here more often" and we left with "never again".
author: Barb S.

description:
A great Indonesian restaurant in the heart of SF! I took some friends here as they were visiting from abroad. Definitely not the normal Asian food that people eat when they come to SF, so it's a nice change.

We had ordered Tahu & Terong Balado, and it was amazing! Two of us did the Rijsttafel, which was a nice way to get a taste of many different items, without having to settle on one. I'd definitely recommend this so that you get a broad taste of what they have to offer.

The food is a bit on the pricey side, so be prepared to shell out a little extra!

Food: 5/5
Staff: 4/5
Atmosphere: 4/5
Value: 3/5
Overall: 4/5
author: Evan K.

description:
I love Indonesian food and was excited to try this restaurant as it is the only Indonesian restaurant I have ever seen in the Bay Area. The restaurant has been open for 27 years which is amazing considering the challenges of keeping a restaurant open in SF. 
The food we tried was all good but did not standout. However, I will happily return because Indonesian dishes are unique and cannot be found elsewhere.
author: Lauren B.

description: The best Indonesian restaurant in San Francisco...period... authentic food ... we got nasigoreng ... it was soo good.. I highly recommend this authentic indonesian restaurant
author: Madhu J.

description:
Definitely 5 STARS quality and authenticity! Many of the food taste very similar to the ones that you can find in Jakarta, Indonesia. 

Some of the food taste are very complex that use many great ingredients. I love their Mie Tek-Tek Kuah (soupy) that reminds me of those guys selling from the 'street trucks" of Jakarta at night, Martabak Telor Beef is very good, and Fried Chicken Siomay is comparable to the ones from Jakarta. 

Bravo Borobudur! I will come back next time Im in San Francisco..
author: Marson S.

description:
3.5* $$
This was my first time trying Indonesian food ever and it was very close to a mix of Indian and Asian for me. 

This place is accessible from the Bart and has a very grown up feel to it somehow. I'm sure it's the lighting and the way the Interiors are. The decor had elements which try to highlight the culture but mostly it's hard to tell if there is a specific food type in focus here. 

We got a variety of dishes as recommend by my Indonesian friend and the sever. We started with an assortment of fried tofu and corn cakes which was ok ok 4/10. The main course had Fried rice 8/10, a beef curry dish 10/10, vegetable stir fry 5/10 and a chicken dish (assorted pieces on the bone ) 7/10 and noodles 7/10. 

The meal overall was good and flavourful. The beef particularly was tender and packed a punch of flavour. That was the winner for me. 

We were a big table and shared everything to eat.  Just the food was approx $21.00 each so it's a medium price place.  The staff was efficient and the food tasted fresh and delicious. I do recommend it if you want to try the flavours and are in the area !
author: Shivani B.

description:
Came here for business lunch and was pleased with such a wide selection of lunch options.

It was not that crowded which made it a great spot to chat and have room to spread out.

When I asked what dishes the server suggested, she went to noodles and rice but I wanted to be slightly healthier so I opted for the spicy eggplant and tofu dish.

I also ordered the jackfruit coconut drink.

The eggplant dish was pretty good but the ratio was about 70% tofu and 30% eggplant so I was a bit disappointed.

The coconut drink was good but way too sweet.

Our server also accidentally gave us 2 entrees when my boss was deciding between 2 which was awkward.

I'd go back to try some of the more traditional dishes.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
I happened to pass by Borobudur Restaurant a couple of days ago. It seemed to be a genuine Indonesian restaurant and as you don't see too many Indonesian restaurants around I decided to give it a try even though it did not have very high ratings on Yelp. I generally get Nasi Bungkus at any new Indonesian restaurant that I try as that allows you to get a pretty good understanding of how the food is compared to others. Unfortunately Borobudur did not have Nasi Bungkus on the menu so I decided to get another rice based dish called Nasi Uduk Lenkap ($12.95) to-go using the online ordering app on Yelp.

After ordering, I landed up after about 20 minutes to find the restaurant half full with one large party waiting for a table. The servers and hostess were busy running around, taking orders and busing tables so I walked over to the counter to see if my order was ready. Well it was ready so I was literally handed a to-go container. No bag, no silverware nothing just a box and I was to be on my way. Just as I was about to leave some other lady stepped in took the box from my hand and put it in a bag and provided silverware. It's nice that she did this else I would have been very upset. They had charged me 25c for the SF bag fee, which is just wrong. SF bag fee is only 10c and that too if they are providing a thick plastic bag.

Anyway, let's come to the food. As per the menu Nasi Uduk Lenkap consists of rice cooked in coconut milk, served with honey beef, fried chicken, spicy tofu, scrambled egg and shrimp crackers. What I got definitely covered all ingredients. It was neatly packaged which showed the chefs pride in what was being served along with care for the customer. Taste wise everything was fresh including the spicy beef (I've always found the beef to be stale in Indonesian restaurants that I've been too). The fried chicken could have been a little crispier and all the flavors were a little mild for my taste. I haven't been to many Indonesian restaurants and a couple of trips "back home" were a long time ago, so I can't definitively say how the flavors should be, but you would have to concentrate hard to pick up the different tastes in this dish. Overall it was not terrific, but still pretty good.
 
Price wise it is cheaper than what you would pay for a small pizza in (S)Nob hill. I liked with what I got, so I'll be back to try the beef rending and other rice dishes off their menu in due course. Generous 3.5 stars rounded up to 4 is how I'd rate this place.
author: Ahmad J.

description: Came here with a friend for an early dinner because I'm traveling to Bali and wanted to experience Indonesian food. When I entered the beautiful restaurant, I immediately felt cozy and at home. We got the roti prata and the beef rendang. You can never go wrong with roti, and the curry dip was amazing. It wasn't too thick and it wasn't too watery either! The rendang was tender. I expected it to be more spicy from my research, but nonetheless, it was amazing and had a lot of tasty sauce. The waittress was really nice and service/speed was fine.
author: Skyler G.

description: This place was awesome. it was my first time eating indonesian food and it was amazing. All of the food was amazing and flavorful. I recommend
author: Marigny L.

description:
Tasteful food 
4.5 Stars! Recommended!
Excellent service- arranged hot Indonesian coffee as I preferred though not in menu!
5 stars if with nice music!
author: Lau P.

description:
Recommended by friend from Florida who were here last night so we decided to check it out
Excellent service. The staff took time to explain the menu to us as we wanted a mixture of spiced and not too spiced
Had a great meal of # 56 and #48. Check it out!
author: Cecil W.

description:
Good food marred by bad service.

We ordered the Mie Tek Tek Goreng with chicken (chicken stir fried noodles with eggs and veggies), Ayam Panggang Baumbu Rujak (grilled chicken in spicy coconut milk), and Tumis Kangkung Terasi Pedas (sautéed water spinach with shrimp paste chili). We were warned that the water spinach has the shrimp paste, and that it would be a very strong flavor. We appreciated that our server alerted us of this, but we knew that was what we wanted.

All of the food was really good. The noodles has so much flavor - sweet, salty, sour, spicy - all of my favorite flavors! It's kinda reminded me of a more saucy pad thai without the peanut seasoning. The chicken was very moist, and I loved the addition of the shrimp paste to the water spinach. The flavor is very strong if you aren't used to it, but I thought it kept it from being too boring and bland.

While the food was certainly good, the service was bad. 
- 10 minutes after we ordered, our server came back to our table to re-take our order because he lost our slip. 
- Our table didn't have any napkins, so I had to ask. When I asked, our server grab those cheap paper napkins that you get in take-out, while all of the other tables that were set had cloth napkins.
- They didn't come back to check on us or to refill our waters. (The dishes were spicy, too!)
- Owner(?) or someone kept going to the empty booth behind me and hammering something into the booth, which shook my seat and created a bad vibe.
- Took forever to flag down someone to get boxes and our check. Mind you, there were only like 4 other tables in the restaurant. 

I would probably eat the food here again, but only if I was getting take out.
author: Jacqueline V.

description: Every dish we ordered tasted very good! The soup tasted like home cooked soup. The stir fried noodles were tasty as well as the curry chicken. We ordered hot sweetened ginger tea and it was very good!
author: CP B.

description:
When you think of Indonesian food, most think of...ummm...well...that's my reaction too.  I was pleasantly surprised to find that Indonesian cuisine is much like Malaysian, which I have had many times.  

I stuck to what was familiar to me, like the gado gado, the Otak Otak Panggang fish, and one of the currys.  I'll have to come back and get a bit more adventurous next time.
author: Ron L.

description:
As an Indonesian I think this is one of the most convenient place to get an Indo food. Staff is usually busy, and it depends, sometimes friendly sometimes not. The food is on the pricier side for what you get (guess it's because of the high rent or something). 

Credit to them is that they have been here for a while, changed owners over time and they used to do deliveries, and now you can just order through Postmates. 

My recommendation to what to get here is the Shomay Bandung, Terasi fried rice (do try anchovies if you're up for it), Kerupuk (side crackers), Es Cendol (as a dessert), Beef Rendang, Pempek (fish cakes) or the Mie Tek Tek goreng (fried noodle).

Food is not that authentic, and... clean (to me). Though I've had some friends (less than 3) who didn't feel well the day after eating here. 

To me, if you're willing to travel more, there is another option in Berkeley (Djayakarta I'm talking to you) that I think does a little better job, but for what you get in the city, this is fine.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I'm sure they changed the recipes or the ingredient quality. I used to love this place, but this time around the nasi goring and sate just wasn't up to par. It tasted more like junk food than real food. 
My other problem was that, on Yelp, it said I could have it delivered. I ordered it for delivery and received a receipt through Grubhub that my order was placed, but it never asked for an address. I contacted Grubhub, and the representative discovered that Borobudur claims they deliver, so Grubhub can't. However, they don't deliver. So I ended up tipping 15% to no one, and then had to pay $10 to Lyft over there and pick it. Waste of money.
author: H M.

description:
My son would have given this place 10 stars!
We had the trout: Amazing
We had the bread with curry sauce: Yummy
We had the spicy noodles: Mmmhhh
My kids had some of their funky drinks.
The service was friendly also!
Make sure you order the trout.
author: Doris S.

description: Awesome Asian food near Union Square. They have excellent Indonesian dishes like Nasi Rames and Rendang beef. Mix the sauce that is a bit spicy with rice. Great service and easy to find.
author: Ray K.

description:
Perhaps I shouldn't have tried to find Indonesian food a week after returning from a trip to Bali/Java.  

But I had the itch for Mie Goreng.  I need my fried noods. 

Brought my GF here for an early dinner, got a Mie Goreng and the chef's selection multi course menu to share. 

It was fine, but bland, and I'm sad that the food just didn't hit the spot. 

The Mie Goreng was prepared and tasted more like a Chow Mein dish at a Chinese restaurant. And after eating Mie Goreng all over Indonesia for a month it just didn't feel like the noodles were right in terms of taste, texture, spice, anything.  

The chef selection was good, but again, didnt have the same spice and tastiness compared to the food in Indonesia.  

Service was slow.  

3 stars for the food, plus 1 star because its the only Indonesian place in SF minus 1 star for slow service and general uninspired taste. 

so really 2 stars, but i'll put 3.
author: Justin C.

description:
I went here because apparently they have 23 stars on Zagat. I am intrigued by the relative Zagat-Yelp discrepancy here; Borobudur served utterly unremarkable food and I am now vaguely less inclined to visit Indonesia in the near future. 

To start, I had the Tohu Goreng, a platter of Fried Tofu served with a hot garlic/peanut sauce. The Tofu was boiling hot inside (no kidding, fried indeed) and otherwise cut into perfect cubes and served with a leaf of lettuce. This mostly reminded me of Tater Tots in my college dining halls, which I assure you were a subject of great scorn.

Subsequently I had the Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak, a BBQ marinated chicken prepared with a kind of spicy coconut milk sauce. There were bones everywhere in the chicken, which made it mildly cumbersome to eat (not aided by the fact that I was not given a knife), and the BBQ marinade was kind of uninteresting. The coconut milk sauce was more thin than one would expect from this kind of dish. I don't remember my exact decision-making process, but roughly halfway through this dish I said to myself "okay, I'm tired of this" and left. I had not eaten all day and was very hungry, so interpret this as a mostly-scathing remark.
author: John L.

description: I was so excited to have some Indonesian desserts when venturing the city, and I wanted to get some food to go as well because I miss indonesian food, even though we already ate lunch.  Unfortunately, all of this excitement was kicked out by this rude waiter. After hearing our request, he was visibly upset, took away our napkins and rudely said that this is not allowed. At the end, he ended up allowing us to order anyway, BUT basically service became nonexistent! At the time we were there, the restaurany was almost empty. The nonexistent service is not because they are busy! We were not even given napkins!! I will never come here again. The desert did jot even taste that good. Maybe the rude service made everything taste bad! For those who want to eat indonesian food, skip this sad restaurant with rude waiter and just go to the one in East bay.
author: Monica S.

description:
I had been coming to Borobudur since 1995 while I lived in Chicago. Every time i visited to SF, I came to Borobudur to eat and celebrate. Finally, I moved to SF in 2016 to call home. Borobudur is my favorite Indonesian restaurant in Bay area. The food is very good. My favorite dishes: Bakmi Goreng Ayam, Nasi Uduk Lengkap, Nasi Rames, Empal Goreng (must try), Ayam Kalasan (must try), Daging Balado, Oseng Oseng Tahu Tempe, Kangkung, Bayam, Martabak Sapi, Lumpia, Sate Ayam.  
The service is very good. No need to be shy when you need any thing just raise your hand (Raising hand to get help is kind of Indonesian tradition) and the waiter will come to you. 
I am so glad SF has a very good Indonesia restaurant.
author: L L.

description:
**UPDATED

This place is hit or miss with the service - sometimes, a bit cold. But it all changed with Mary! She was super sweet, despite working the entire room to herself, and never showed any signs of stress to the customers - so important when working a service job!!

Thank you for taking such great care of us - we'll be back to see you!
author: Tiba G.

description: One of my favorite restuarant in SF. Everything you could ask for for a relaxing meal- amazing food, comfortable ambiance, and friendly staff. The menu has great variety, all at reasonable prices. I had the fried rice and fried honey chicken and both were amazing. The chicken was extremely flavorful and unbelievably juicy. Fried rice might have been the best I've ever had. I'll definitely be back...planning to recommend this place for our next corporate team dinner.
author: Justin H.

description: Lovely food, full of flavor, wonderful presentation. Yes they are a bit slow. Our wait on the fried plantains was a good 15 or more minutes, so I recommend ordering the dessert before you are finished eating if you are going anywhere. Service was attentive and pleasant however. Did have to drive around a bit for parking but it was also a Friday at dinnertime. Will go again!
author: Susan F.

description:
A quality introduction to Indonesian cuisine, at least if I compare the menu against the opinions of the hive mind as reported by Mr. W. Pedia. Their website will tell you it's "the best Indonesian food in the Bay Area" according to Asia Week. I wasn't aware there was a publication called Asian Week, or that Borobudur had much competition in that regard.

In any event. I saw the Rijsttafel feast arrive on two tables and next time I forget to eat for a week, that looks like a delectable and very efficient splurge. I've actually eaten here twice now and had a great time.

And it for sure has to be said: This is a great place to go when you don't have three hours of your life to devote to Burma Superstar.

I'd say the Gado-Gado is worth doing at least once. Beyond that it seems you mostly can't go wrong. The Nasi Uduk ("Aromatic Rice") is for sure essential, and compares well against most versions I've had elsewhere. And both times the veggie side dish was the best thing I ordered: Try out the Tumis Bayam Bawang Putih, or the Tumis Kangkang Bawang Putih. Apparently those mean "sauteed spinach with garlic and tofu" and "sauteed water spinach with garlic." In any event, it's wonderful to enjoy something fresh and green to increase the ANDI score, and the garlic score. Good times.
author: James D.

description:
Tried their roti prata, soto ayum soup and Nasi Goreng Ayum. Roti prata & soto soup are both good and filling. Asked for an extra fried egg on the fried rice. The fried rice has a great flavor to it and the chicken pieces are slightly marinated and fried before adding to the rice which tastes awesumm!!

Service wasn't that great, or else it is a 5 star experience. Will be back soon.
author: Raghu Varma B.

description: I ordered the curry noodles and they were delicious! A lady stoped my friend and I on the street and insisted that we had to go there for dinner and I'm glad we did! It was fresh tasting and just the perfect amount of spice! The service was not the best but the food made up for it!
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Note: This is really a 3.5 star restaurant.

This was my first experience with Indonesian cuisine and I quite enjoyed it. I tried the veggie rice plate and roti prata. My dinner companion had martabak sapi and some sort of seafood medley in spicy sauce. 

None of the food was inherently bad, so why the three stars, you ask? It was the timing--it's in need of improvement. 

The martabak sapi was brought out first. It was the veggie option, so it was filled with bits of broccoli, carrots, egg, etc. with a small side of mixed pickle--good. Not ultra flavorful, but you can't go wrong with anything coated in egg roll wrappers and fried.

The roti prata showed up about ten minutes afterward. This was the stand-out of the entire meal. Marvelous! Crisp, flaky, golden, piping hot, perfectly tender and chewy at the center, and the curry dipping sauce added a complementary kick. It was a large enough portion to share. If you try nothing else at Borobudur, try this.

I'd scarcely started on my appetizer when my entree arrived. My friend's did not, which made eating mine rather awkward. His dish took about 10 minutes more to show up, but he said it was excellent. The sauce was mad spicy--a chili pepper and tomato base.

The rice plate consisted of: spicy tofu, coconut curry, seasoned tempe, two tiny corn fritters, and, of course, a small, temple-shaped mound of rice. The spicy tofu and tempe were my favorites; both were seasoned well and the tempe had a much more appetizing texture than the stuff sold at natural foods stores. The coconut curry was lacking heat and the veggies could have used a few more minutes in the pot; they were a bit toothsome for my taste. I suspect the corn fritters would have been better had they been fresher; they were room temperature and gummy rather than crispy. In fact, none of the food on my plate was actually hot, an indication that it may have been left sitting about for some time before reaching the table. 

Service was friendly. I just wish they'd been more consistent. The checks also took a while to show up and water glasses weren't filled as often as they could have been.

Prices weren't outrageous, but I discovered they are $1-$2 higher than the ones listed on their website.

I don't regret the meal--it was wonderful to try something new--but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat there again. However, if I was in the neighborhood, I might easily stop in for some roti prata.
author: Ellery D.

description:
Borobodur is now my favorite Indonesia restaurant in the Bay Area.  This is exactly the kind of family run restaurant you want to support.  Great food and a really nice staff.

My favorites were the roti prata and rendang!

You won't be disappointed if you eat here.  Enjoy!
author: Aaron L.

description: The food was good, not excellent.  I would have given it four stars, but the menu doesn't list all items in some of the dishes, so I accidentally ordered a noodle dish containing eggs (I'm allergic), even though it doesn't mention eggs in the description.  When I explained this to the server, she took the dish back and replaced it with an eggless one, but she seemed annoyed.  So I would recommend asking about ingredients even if the description on the menu looks allergen-free.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Would I come back here? Probably. After exhausting all other restaurants in the area. Don't let that discourage you from trying it out though. It is TOTALLY worth it to try the Rendang. Yes, the Rendang is the dish to get at this establishment!

We came before a show at The Masonic and made reservations for 6:30 though I don't think that was necessary. Hard to tell what it would be like on a weeknight but we came on a Saturday. Good to know they take reservations, though.

Since the Rendang doesn't come with veg, we ordered one vegetarian dish and the Rendang to share and get a good balance. The veggie dish was the Capcai. If you are looking for something plain but a little salty - go for it. I wasn't impressed but was glad to get some vegetables into my dinner. And there were plenty! Cabbage, carrots, bell pepper, cauliflower, green beans, broccoli. I am sure I am forgetting something but there was no shortage of quantity or variety here. If I come back, I will probably try the Kari Sayuran instead.

We got one order of the coconut lemon grass rice which was a little dry but still pretty good. It didn't have a strong coconut flavor (they probably cut it with water) but the lemongrass was a nice compliment to the dishes we ordered. 

We spent about $30 altogether (not including tip) so it is definitely affordable.

I would agree with some of the other reviews that said the interior is not the cleanest, windows are dirty, floors are a bit grimey. And they only had one server for the entire restaurant so don't expect great service. They have a very interesting way of bringing the food out. They do everything by hand, writing out the orders, then as the items are ready, they check the ticket, take it to the right table, and check it off the order list. Because of this, we got our veggie item first, then the Rendang about 10 minutes later. We actually thought they may have forgotten about it.

Worth a try but don't have high expectations is what this reviewer suggests. And don't forget to get the Rendang!
author: Jess A.

description:
Came for lunch, service was slow, menu was way too big, no customers and food was mediocre at best. Redeeming factor - a nice waiter and the roti

Food:
- Chicken noodle soup (#52) came disassembled. Noodles were like ramen, sautéed and didn't come with a lot of chicken. The soup was tiny to go with it... 
- Roti: nice flaky, crusty and very rich (buttery). it's a hefty portion, good for sharing.

Overall I won't be coming back, but it's not the worst
author: Kristie C.

description:
I was recently introduced to Indonesian food while visiting Amsterdam.  When I got back home, I found Borobudur.  

My friend and I arrived at about 6:30pm (no reservation) and were seated immediately.  We ordered the Rijstaffel (Rice Table) and waited patiently for the dishes to start coming.  The first were lumpia with a spicy peanut sauce, and lemongrass chicken soup.  My friend, who has never had Indonesian food before, gave two thumbs up and said he couldn't wait for the rest of the food to arrive. 

All-in-all, everything was delicious.  Although they use the word "spicy" on a few descriptions, it really wasn't that hot at all - it had a good kick, but nothing crazy hot.  There was plenty of food left over for a nice doggie bag.  This is a great place and I will gladly return.  Conveniently enough it's only about 5 blocks from my job.    

The staff couldn't have been more lovely.  Every time they came to the table they had smiles on their faces, and were very polite.  They slowly described each dish and politely answered our questions.

I've read others' comments about the servers being rude.  I didn't find that at all, but then again, I work in the hospitality industry and understand what it takes to run a restaurant.  It is hands down THE most difficult industry in which to work.  In my book, they get 5 stars for service.  

Give Brobudur a try, and order the Rijstaffel!
author: Jody R.

description:
This restaurant is busy most of the time.
The owner is friendly. The food?
It's okay. I heard from a lot of people Borobudur is excellent, but, as an Indonesian, I think Borobudur is not that authentic. It's clean, absolutely.

My suggestion,
get the Rendang or Soto Betawi.
If you like Pempek, theirs is pretty good.
I always got martabak for dessert. I forgot what they called it. Either martabak or prata.
author: Candice L.

description:
Roti prata was delicious as was the Kari noodles

Es teler was phenomenal to drink as well.

Overall very solid, would recommend
author: Anant V.

description: I have been a SF native for awhile but only recently discovered this gem of a restaurant. Always hits the spot when I am looking for authentic Indo food. I would highly recommend the roti prata and rendang. If you are not familiar with the cuisine, I would go for the rijsttafel. It is a full Indonesian dinner with a large variety of eight popular small dishes and dessert that come on an elegant looking warmer. Check out this place if you haven't already!
author: Kevin T.

description:
Scammy menu prices. Their online menu, delivery service menu, menu outside their window, and in-restaurant menu all have different prices. 

Their online menu has the cheapest prices, followed by the menu they keep outside their window. Their delivery menu (doordash, ubereats) is a bit more expensive, but not as expensive as when you actually go into the restaurant and order food there. 

For comparison, their online menu lists their Roti Prata as $7.50, the menu outside their door says $8.50, but inside, it's $9.99. Not a big difference, but everything on their restaurant menu is 20%-30% more.
author: Eric Z.

description:
2 of us, a frequent visitor to Indonesia and 1 an Indonesian citizen, went twice to dinner at this restaurant while visiting San Francisco. We had different appetizers, entrees and deserts. We had rice and noodle dishes, chicken & seafood, vegetables and more.  We found all to taste very good and very close to what we would find in family and restaurant cooked food in Indonesia, in Java. Our service was very good; they were attentive without being annoying. We think the prices are very fair for the quality and location. We walked about 10 blocks from our hotel to the restaurant and had no safety issues.
We would go here again.
author: Jeff C.

description: I have only had one dish here: the Nasi Goreng with brown rice and chicken, and each time I make a vow to not slam the whole thing in one sitting because there's definitely enough for two meals on the plate...but alas, I walk away another time having inhaled the whole thing with total delight.
author: Olya S.

description: Wow, I wish I could put less than one star! The food was not good, but it was also slow; the service was absent- we had to ask for silverware! (There weren't even five other tables there...) It was overpriced, sad, and I left hungry. I recommend skipping Borobudur if you are looking for a positive experience. There are so many better food options in this beautiful abundant city.
author: Emily S.

description:
Borobudur is an Indonesian restaurant serving up a storm. Most of their dishes are intense and robust exuding vibrant and zesty flavors. Their diverse menu is designed for those who love Indonesia's natural abundance of exotic spices, peanuts, coconuts, (to name a few). Some of their distinctive dishes would surely tease and tantalize while others were not as glorious. There were minor to major hiccups all along the way.

Dining solo, I was recommended Rijsttafel ($29.50), a complete Indon rice table where one can sample a wide variety of small courses. I wasn't particularly thrilled with the first course, Lumpia Semarang (Indon Spring Roll). It had some nondescript fillings and a side of watered-down peanut sauce. (1/5) After the dismal start, they redeemed themselves almost instantly with a cup of Soto Ayam, a smooth lemon grass soup with chicken. It started off with a subtle blandness and the soup gradually blossomed into an interesting medley of flavors ranging from sweet and sour to fragrant.  Tip: To upgrade the taste, Borobudur sprinkled some deep-fried onions on the soup and it worked wonders! Try doing this at home! (5/5)

The rest were served together and attractively presented in a huge platter.
 
1. The first course was Gado Gado, an Indon salad tossed with peanut dressing and topped with shrimp crackers.  The dressing was light, tangy and refreshing, a vast improvement over the spring roll's sauce. (4/5)
2. Sate Ayam (grilled marinated chicken on skewers with peanut sauce) required high heat and good grilling skills. The aroma can then be smelled from blocks away! Problem with Borobudur's sate was it lacked aroma even when I placed it under my nose! There was no charring (sigh); the meat was dried out and the chewy texture felt like calamari. Not impressed! (2/5)
3. Now kudos to the cook for not drying out my chicken in the Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak described as BBQ marinated chicken cooked with spicy coconut milk sauce. Firstly, I love the richness and aroma of coconut milk. Secondly, it restored my faith in chicken as if it can be cooked right, it need not be dry! (4/5)
4. Kari phonetically sounds like curry and so Kari Udang is simply shrimp curry ("udang" means shrimps in Indon).  In true Indon style, the curry was simmered in coconut milk and cooked in some secret curry powder or paste. It was hard to believe how the natural sweetness of fresh shrimps blended so tastily with coconut milk and excellent over rice. (4/5)
5. Oseng Oseng Tahu Tempe described as "Sautéed Java soy bean and tofu" was foreign to me. Tempe is a traditional soy product originating from Indon and I am sure available in heath food stores. I figured this must be an acquired taste though not inedible but just not my favorite. (2/5)
6. Beef Rendang is for sure the tastiest and most iconic Indon dish!  The symphony of tastes was incredible. Without knowing the recipe, my guess the ingredients were sugar, coconut cloves, cinnamon sticks and of course coconut milk that were slow boiled and simmered until the meat was aromatic and amazingly tender. This luscious Indon beef stew was perfect with rice. (5/5)

Everything considered, if you really enjoy the taste of peanuts and coconut milk, I do recommend you give Borobudur a try keeping one eye closed to some inconsistencies in the peanut sauce. I did notice the décor wasn't overbearing but instead quite fascinating and intriguing with traditional woodcarvings hung on the wall with other Indon knickknacks and kitschy artifacts. My server, Valentine, is a young Chinese Indonesian and acted as my capable mentor for the evening!
author: Geoff G.

description:
Legit Indonesian food!!!

Came in 30 mins before closing time, we opted to take our orders home.
We ordered nasi uduk, bakmie goreng, nasi rames, and nasi padang.

Our order came in transparent boxes with elaborate presentation despite being in a box. The Nasi Uduk was authentic and nice, you can feel the umami flavor of the rice coming from coconut milk. They provided peanut sauce to balance the rice, the way I like it. The nasi uduk comes with fried chicken, beef, tofu and crackers! 

Nasi padang was also good according to my friend. She said the gulai (curry) looked like they took their time preparing it instead of going the instant way.

Nasi rames and bakmie goreng were good too!

Service was good. The lady (maybe she's the owner) was nice and friendly.

Definitely one of the best Indonesian food I've tried in America.
author: Renaldy S.

description:
This place has been here for long time since my son was born 22 years ago when we started to come here. Passing by today to have lunch with my wife n youngest son . We walk in n there were 4 different group also behind us.
We all sit down according to order as we came. 
We have order first and they have served water to people behind us. 
We also order drink n came same time as people who behind us.
I really lost my appetite how this place treat different race with different attitudes.
Shame of them. This world is enough of hate going where we all have to start respect others.
I sat here n my wife n done eating and I can't even at one bite. 
I came here because  my wife missed Indonesia's food which we both loves.
There are few good Indonesia's in Bay Area which we been going so.
Unfortunately these 2 tables guests were non Asian.
author: Peter L.

description:
Went in with a group of 10. Made advanced reservation a couple months in ahead. Finding parking like everywhere in SF is tricky but not impossible. 
Food is delectable, many home-style options. Delicious and well presented. Portions a little small for sharing - you would think they know Asian food is consumed in a communal manner? But if you order the "Rijstaffel" - the total amount of food is sufficient to feed everyone except not everyone might have the chance to try every offering. We added a few more dishes to the set.
They are always busy but its is possible to get attention of wait staff if try.
For the authentic flavors this restaurant offers, this is pretty good!
author: Dr. Shannon B.

description: Food was good, made fresh to order.  Service was fine, except for one missed order item which we had to cancel in the end because it was taking too long.  Overall, a good neighborhood place with friendly service.
author: Polly T.

description:
Decided to check out this place because my Burmese go-to place was closed today (FYI- if you haven't tried Yamo yet, you don't know what you're missing!!!) I decided to call in my order so that I could take it home and veg out with my favorite reality trash tv. Anyhow, I digress. The guy that picked up the phone to take my order appeared to be in a rush. I tried explaining my order to him, asking questions about things (as this was my first try at Indonesian) and he responded with "are you almost ready, because I've got errands to run". Whoa, dude. Slow your roll. Your restaurant just opened at 1pm, so cool it with the icy customer service. I tried to chock it up to the place being super busy, and tried not to think too much else about it. 

Based on previous reviews and a quick purview of the menu, I settled with the Roti Prata (Indonesian version of naan) and the Kari Udang (shrimp curry dish). The icy dude told me it would be 25 minutes to make. Twenty-five minutes later, I headed a block up the street to the restaurant. The restaurant is off Post street and pretty centrally located, being on a Muni line and about 5-6 blocks (more or less) from BART. As soon I came into the restaurant, I couldn't help but chuckle. There wasn't a soul in that place. Not even someone at the cashiers. Hotmess indeed.
The cashier appeared to be pretty nice, which made up for the first dude. Solid B for customer service.

Overall, the Kari Udang was just okay. I was actually expecting a bit more flavor. But the Roti Prata?!? Oh em gee. Best thing ever!!! The outside is slightly crisp and the inside is nice and doughy. And the curry sauce on the side...absolute deliciousness!!! I would go back to this place just for that bread. And it would totally be worth it.

Highly recommend that my vegetarian brethren check to see if something has beef or chicken broth. Some things on the menu are listed as vegetables or beef, but when I went to place my order, the icy dude didn't give me the option for either/or. For my meat eaters, feel free to go to town on this place. 

Overall grade: C+.
author: Tracy T.

description:
Time : Thursday night. There was a short line after 7:30pm.

Place : Clean, tables are slightly tightly spaced.

Food : I've tried Indonesian food in midwest, east coast, LA and Bali; so I am comparing it to that standart. It's not bad but it's nothing special either. The coconut rice and the side dishes can use more spices and enveloping flavors. It's like one of those lukewarm parties.

Service : Our waiter was attentive and friendly. Makes you feel welcomed and big plus for the great smile!

The vicinity, place and the service earn 4 stars. Minus 1 for the food.
author: Jenny T.

description:
One of the only places that actually serve authentic food !
5 STAR taste !
author: Ted L.

description:
I really liked going to this restaurant everytime I'm in San Francisco but I'll likely never again go here. Just showed up to lunch where it was kinda quiet, but I was treated so rudely I left immediately after.

The lady who came to take my order hurried me up in blurting out what I wanted, and then when I asked if she could make a drink w/o sugar she didn't even wait for me to finish my sentence before saying 'we don't have it' and took my plate without a word and clanged it on the counter next to her. 

I tried to order another drink but she left abruptly after that. I've never experienced service that rude, and this is the first time I'm writing on yelp but I really just felt insulted.
author: Vanya E.

description: Cold and pricey exotic spot with pleasant but uneven service.  Walked into this bright restaurant expecting warm and spicy food but was very disappointed.
author: david f.

description: The only Indonesian Restaurant that meet my appetite in Bay Area. Try Gado-gado which is Indonesian Salad and Ketoprak don't forget Ayam Kalasan yummy
author: Willy W.

description:
Borobudur makes the best Southeastern Asian food in San Francisco.  There.  I said it.  Come fight me.

Seriously, there is not a single place that can match the freshness of their produce, the delicacy of their spices, the friendliness of their servers, let alone all three of those things.  Do yourself a favor and go for lunch here today.
author: Ryan O.

description: this place is a tourist trap. yep, i said it. it's too expensive and all the food is on the sweet side. the most tragic thing, however, is that most of the food has been watered down for a white palette. real indonesian food is full of complex, in-depth flavors that comes from several hours of cooking. this place just survives on location. as others have mentioned, the service is not good. they need to hire more waiters! the indonesian in me is sad having to write this review.
author: Alyssa L.

description: This place is just awful. Having recently been in Indonesia, this food is anything but authentic. Everything was super sweet and the noodles were so overcooked in the Bakmi Goreng that they were like baby food. It was busy, which just confused us, as there is no good reason to eat there.
author: Wilma G.

description:
It is so good the food and the ambience too!! Thank you for the good service from the staffs! We're from Dallas,TX and hope you can open it in Dallas. See you again. 
if you wanna order the food, please pick Ayam Goreng Bumbu Rujak and Nasi Uduk! they're really good!! 
For dessert, I picked Es Cendol! 
Overall, Great foods and great staffs!!
author: Budisetia Y.

description: Yikes!...just a downright awful experience. Restaurant was about half-full on a mid week night. Servers were impossible to get over to the table, took over 1 hour to receive our food, and when it arrived it was cold. When we complained about the food being cold, we were yelled at by the owners for not sending it back to the kitchen right away - see first comment regarding waiters. Disappointing at best in terms of quality, service and overall experience.
author: Ollie N.

description: Authentic Indo food. This is the 2nd time my boyfriend & i went here & never disappoint us! I am Indonesian & the food here is as close as it gets to the real stuff! My boyfriend is a picky eater & he loves this place! I would recommend their cendol & pempek! Their otak-otak isn't bad either.
author: Liony H.

description:
Being a Chinese-Indonesian who just moved to the Bay Area from the Midwest, I was excited to try this Indonesian restaurant in the city! This is the third Indonesian restaurant I have tried in the Bay Area (the first one was Jayakarta in Berkeley,!and the second one was an Indonesian restaurant in Palo Alto).

Borobudur restaurant was pretty good. Having had many kinds of Indonesian food in Indonesia during my childhood, and being Chinese-Indonesian, I  think the food here is more Chinese-inspired kind of Indonesian food. 

Their egg foo young is definitely Chinese-Indonesian style (because the sauce is a red sauce, rather than the white chicken or brown beef sauce that you would find in typical Chinese egg foo young). It's just like the way my Chinese-Indonesian grandma makes it! Although, of course my grandma's taste better, but Borobudur's is good too!

I think their martabak (the egg martabak a.k.a "martabak telur", although this restaurant just calls it "martabak") is really good. I tried both the vegetable and the beef martabak. This martabak is also a favorite dish of my non-Indonesian friends when they eat at this restaurant!

The Beef Rendang- I think they can use more apices on this dish- I don't mean make it spicy, but I just think it's a little bland. 

I think the food here is pretty authentic. I do wish though  that they had more authenic Indonesian food like Nasi Lemak, Gudeg, Nasi Bungkus, etc.

The staff here is friendly. I like that they speak both Indonesian and English fluently with no weird accent.

Overall I would still go back and eat here.!
author: Lusiana H.

description: Horrible! I think the Michelin sticker needs to be peeled off the front door. Food seems reheated and some veggies seemed canned. The water was good. I might be a little hard on them...maybe they are struggling to keep a float in the ever increasing expense of the City. No love in this food. Plus the health advisory on Yelp is also telling; sad I checked it after we ate.
author: Dionisio D.

description:
i ate here many times over the years but never had a meal as bad as i had tonight.
apparently the place has new owners and i will never eat here again,
for $17 i had the worst chicken and vegetable curry i have ever eaten.
i'm not even certain it was real chicken more like chicken flavored tofu.
author: John G.

description: Hands down the best Indonesian restaurant in San Francisco but man they are now pricy. Would I come back...definitely but will I come back more often...maybe not
author: Willy S.

description: Large portions and quite tasty. I'm usually a yelpaholic when it comes to choosing restaurants, but my internet was down so we had to make an uninformed decision. While reviewing the menu from the street, an older gentleman walked by and told my husband and I that we had to go in. He said that he ate there once a week and that it was well worth it. We weren't disappointed!
author: Loretta N.

description:
This is the only authentic Indonesian cuisine restaurant in the SF Bay Area. While it is not as flavorful and delicious as the actual restaurants in Indonesia, Borobudur is as close as you can get to the real thing without going on a 13 hour flight to Jakarta or Bali. All the other indonesian restaurants in the Bay Area are more fast food type where the spices are watered down and tastes diluted. 

Some of the traditional dishes to try are: sate, gado gado, beef rendang, sayur asem, nasi uduk, kang kung goreng, ikan goreng sambal, and more.
author: Felix L.

description: The noodles are great. The egg foo young is the best I've ever had. Honey beef melts in your mouth. Prata is a must.
author: Stomparella J.

description: Very very tasty food! Had the corn fritters appetizer, the number 48 noodle (tasted like a mix between pad Thai and pad see ew) very good highly recommend it and the number 60 rice plate and a beef fried rice. Everything was great I would say maybe skip the rice plate but the rest of was very tasty!
author: Karen L.

description: I came here to try some good Indonesian food, but I was disappointed the first ten minutes walking in. We waited at the sign that said please wait here to be seated and no one even acknowledged us. No offense, but that's horrible customer service and you guys should work on that so you don't hear more complaints :)
author: Lina G.

description:
Had the veg app plate w corn fritters and tofu, it all was over cooked and dry. 

Then I asked what was a good, typical Indonesian plate that wasn't the pushed "beef stew". They were not very helpful. 

I got the regular fried rice and it was okay, nothing interesting or special with the flavors. As a main I got the eggplant and tofu plate. This was also nothing special. 

The service sucked that night, a man waited on us then wandered off. We had to follow up our order with a woman, manager. 

She was very preoccupied with friends she kept sitting with. 

Not as good as I remember. Then mid meal I started to feel very ill and full. Something wasn't right. Then I see the food warning today! 

Also, we were seated at a SUPER awkward table, next to a full table in the back. The back of my chair stuck out into the isle of service. They were totally empty and I wondered why they didn't put us in the window tables, away from other people...spread us out when empty. 

So the food sucked, the service sucked, the seeting we were given sucked, WHY? 

After a few years away I was so excited to go back. 

I will not be returning.
author: B K.

description:
It was a parade of lovely delicious dishes!

The Roti Prata with the dipping sauce, and the Lumpia rolls with the peanut sauce were awesome! The seafood (breaded fish and shrimp) in a spicy sauce with a hint of sweetness was pretty good, though the fish itself was a little on the mild side.

The BBQ Chicken in sauce was delicious. The BBQ chicken was pretty good in it's own right but was greatly enhanced by the nutty thick sauce. The chicken didn't really imbibe the flavour of the sauce and I think it could have used a little more simmering in the sauce.

The fried rice with shrimp paste, eggs, and salted fish was pretty fishy, as expected, but was awesome (unless the diner doesn't like the fishy smell, not unlike salted sardines)! 

I was told the beef curry was awesome. Since I didn't have any of it, I couldn't say for sure. Unless you're an Indonesian who gets their daily fix at home, I'd highly recommend partaking in the fare that is Boroudur's.
author: Umesh T.

description: My Indonesian friend took my cousin and I here. The whole experience was nice. She ordered for us which helped because she is a a regular there. Really enjoyed what we ordered. I felt it was a mix of Chinese and Vietnamese food. I don't remember the names of what we ate. But, it a variety of was noodles, rice, meat, chicken and prawns. I enjoyed it very much!
author: Martha R.

description:
Good service.
Ambience is nice, neat and quiet.
Food taste and selections are not disappointing.
I recommend you to try this place whenever you're around SF.
author: Loraine K.

description:
One day, my boyfriend forgot to pick me up from dinner in the mission. So I took an über to get home to soma. I noticed the über drivers name was Indonesian so I asked... He confirmed and then I proceeded to do what any foodie would do (I hope) and asked him what his favorite Indonesian restaurant was in the city. He said it was this restaurant and I promptly bookmarked it and visited two weeks later.

I'm not a connoisseur of Indonesian food but I have had it multiple times before. This place was okay. It was pricey and the bf and I were pretty surprised how you can jack up noodles and rice to that expensive without giving too much meat.

We ordered four things:
1) roti (the best thing we had all night though it was a bit watery for my taste, I prefer Malaysian roti with a bit of chicken in it)
2) their famous mee mee noodles which were decent but the chicken was dry and gross in it and it was super spicy
3) their spicy shrimp paste fried rice with shrimp - this was decent and the bf loved it while I was like meh. The spicy isn't too overwhelming and leaves a good pinch but disappears after you drink some water. It was ok but kinda pricey for some fried rice... Meh
4) coconut rice bc everything was too spicy and I needed something to balance it out

We saw everyone around us get these colorful drinks too but didn't order because we were too full. Maybe those are good?

Either way, über driver, you tried.. I forgive you but this place is overpriced and just so-so. On to the next restaurant to try to find the best Indonesian food in sf - def isn't here. Service was also so-so, girl had an attitude just FYI.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Great spot!  Friendly and solicitous staff and the food was just like being back in the foothills and beaches of Bali.
author: Joe'll W.

description:
Went here for dinner on Saturday night.  While we were waiting for a table a group left one of the booths shortly after receiving their menus without ordering.  Although there was a free table, we still were not seated for about 15-20 minutes.  Service was definitely on the slow side.  

The Mie Tek Tek Goreng was delicious - it was like a fancy spicy chow mein.  Yum.  Rendang was good but to me it tasted dead on like Filipino beef mechado but the Rending was more tender than mechado but lacking accompanying vegetables.  In that regard, I felt a little ripped off because it was missing something for my Filipino ass but again the flavor was there and texture was good.  The Roti Prata texture was crispy on the exterior and very much like a croissant on the inside.  Nothing really special about the Roti but it was decent.  

I would go back for the Mie Tek Kek.
author: Hello.kitty.kat S.

description:
Great Indonesian food if you know which dishes to get!

Coming from a Southeast Asian background, this place has great appetizers, desserts and most of their main courses are also winners. For appetizers, focus on the Martabak or Roti (bomb). For the main course, try the beef rendang, water spinach, and one of the nasi gorengs. Don't be a tourist chump and get the fried noodle, curry chicken or satays - you now know better.

The only downside is that this area isn't super clean and service can sometimes be a tad slow. Otherwise, if you're already in the area, great for lunch and dinner!
author: Kevin K.

description:
Good food
Terrible service
Clues wait staff 
Go during the week
Make a res for sure
No hard booze
author: Steve S.

description: We were walking by on a Saturday evening and walked in without a reservation. They seated us within 5 minutes. We ordered the Rijsttafel, which is like a sampler of traditional cuisine. The food was good, but not spectacular. The service started out good and then fell off as they got busier.
author: Bradley H.

description:
Please don't waste your time and your money. This place is not even serving Indonesian food...I should know because I have lived in Indonesia for 5 years....pathetic food, absolutely rasteless. Ordered lamb curry which tasted like stale rubber pieces in watery sauce. Same with Gado Gado...no where close to the gado gado you can get from a roadside stall in Jakarta

To top it all rude owner....never ever ever coming back to this place
author: Andy A.

description:
There is a recent Yelp warning about cleanliness about this place but I'm hoping that it will only serve as warning and the owner will keep their place even cleaner.
Food is good, it meets the Indonesian standard. Of course it's not like the one in Indonesia but close enough. If you like Indonesian food this is a good place to go to.
author: Yen T.

description:
The food is very good for the person who missed her country food. It's authentic the sambel terasi is perfect.
Price is good for California.
author: Dedys D.

description:
My confessions for the day.  I do not necessarily need authentic food from anywhere, I just want tasty food, even if it is not strictly authentic.  Plead guilty to taste over authenticity.  Also, the subtle notes and hints of flavor in most critically acclaimed food do nothing for me.  My taste buds are not the most discerning, and do not take hints.  The flavors need to be bold (obtrusive, even, but not necessarily overpowering) to get my attention.

Borobudur is at the confluence of Snob Hill and shady Tenderloin, two starkly contrasting neighborhoods.  I don't mind walking through the Tenderloin to eat their Nasi Goreng Borobudur and Nasi Rames again, and again, and again!  The food here is bursting with flavor.
author: Kashif K.

description: Nice, helpful and friendly server, amazing food, nice atmosphere, you can see that owner cares about customer good experience. Feels like comfortable cozy home with wide windows, a lot of natural light inside. Soup are the best.
author: A. B.

description:
We were one of only two occupied tables at 6:30 p.m. on our first visit. And it was a weekend. But by 7:30 p.m. it was COMPLETELY full. We started with the lumpia which was nothing special. (On a subsequent visit it was a star of the meal.) The lemongrass soup had nice subtle flavors, but the best dish of the night was the beef rendang which had very tender and flavorful meat. The spicy noodle dish, mie tek tek goreng (stir fried noodles with egg and vegetables) with chicken was good but left us wanting more veggies.

On our second visit we sprang for the $27.50 Rijsttafel, a 9 course meal. Despite what they told us it was DEFINITELY enough to feed two people. The dishes were hit or miss. The best included the lemongrass soup (yet again), the lumpia, the shrimp curry, the barbecue chicken, the beef rendang, and the black sweet rice with coconut milk dessert. Not that there's anything wrong with a good vanilla (the other dessert choice) but at an ethnic restaurant you go with the exotic.

Then there were the clunkers. Those included the bland bean cake, the noodles and cabbage with gloppy peanut sauce also known as the gado-gado salad (however, the accompanying shrimp chips were good), and the satay, the texture of which was off-putting. Maybe it was dark meat.

Overall, I'd go again but wouldn't rush back (unlike the husband who is always ready to go back to Borobudur).
author: Kathleen M.

description: Let's be real- people who have visited Bali think they understand Indonesian food- yet they fail to realize and recognize that Indonesia is as wide as California to Georgia and the food styles is equally different. This restaurant may not be your tourist Bali rendition of food but it is clean, authentic and you leave feeling euphoric. There are not very many Indonesian restaurants around so it deserves nothing less than 5 stars!
author: Ryssby R.

description:
3 stars for food! 
It took so long to get seat, order and foods. I think it because there is only one server(and another one for taking order). 
We're not Indonesian, have no idea how to pronounce the menu. We ordered by calling the number. Seem fine but the waitress said she heard we ordered different one. Although she repleted our order before she leave our table. We said we fine, if we change to get the right one may take us forever to get food. 
However food is very good. I will think carefully before I come back. Maybe I should call to ask if they are empty,then it's good time to come.
author: Jarinya P.

description:
Popping a cherry can come with some anxiety... will I like it?...  will it be painful?  Okay, get your mind out of the gutter.
Having never tried Indonesian food, I was invited by friends to dine here on a Monday evening.  Coming before 6 pm for an early dinner, street parking was plentiful on Post Street.  It is only a few blocks from one of my favorite downtown lunch spot too and a good option for pre-theater meals.  Here's what my gracious hosts ordered:

Appetizers
 1) Tempe Goreng (fried soy bean cake) (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=LwQKt_v47NtrhUOR6mpndw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Drier that Chinese style fried tofu, this is more dense and interesting with the dipping sauce.

2) Empek Empek Palembang (Fried fish cake filled with egg in spicy vinegar) (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=1RNYxo-5nPJZb0O25cEFvw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Nice flavor contrast and textures; wish the egg was more runny, but this is done traditional style.  Favorite of the three apps.

3) Gado-gado (Steamed vegetables, tofu, potato, egg, & shrimp cracker with peanut dressing) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/borobudur-restaurant-san-francisco?select=5okBb0nmsZyG2bOedQCmIA#5okBb0nmsZyG2bOedQCmIA) - Plethora of textures and flavors.

Main
 4) Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak (B.B.Q. marinated chicken cooked with coconut milk) - Chicken (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/borobudur-restaurant-san-francisco?select=k_XrDaXKXEEzwcuQwLnejA#k_XrDaXKXEEzwcuQwLnejA) - Looks more like a curry preparation so the seasonings are unexpected; meat was tender.

5) Empal Goreng (Fried marinated honey beef) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/borobudur-restaurant-san-francisco?select=tWM2je4Z7IOuWGzh97mh3w#tWM2je4Z7IOuWGzh97mh3w) - Like the soy bean cake, this is dryer and comparable to beef jerky.

6) Tumis Kangkung Bawang Putih (Sauteed water spinach with garlic) (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q)  - Seasonal, this is my favorite Asian vegetable, cooked and seasoned just right.

7)  Ikan Bakar Sumudra / Trout fish (Grilled fish with tropical spices) (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Flaky and tasty, reminds me of smoked fish.

Desserts
 8) Bubur Ketan Hitam - Black sweet rice - Least favorite of the three desserts as very filling.

9) Es Cendol (Rice flour cake with ice & palm sugar syrup) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/borobudur-restaurant-san-francisco?select=_c9VJLJZ5chJ0ar_l2IEjw#_c9VJLJZ5chJ0ar_l2IEjw) - Think of an icy Thai iced tea with grass jelly and gelatinous textured accompaniments.

10) Es Campur (Mixed tropical fruits with shave ice, condensed milk, chocolate & raspberry syrup) (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Shave ice - My favorite of the three desserts, the chocolate and raspberry flavors are unexpected.

Being my maiden voyage in Indonesian cuisine, the variety highlighted this roller coaster of a meal as many of the foods did not taste like they "looked".  My gracious host, being born in Indonesia, kindly gave me a taste of local authentic foods from his home country.  Unlike Cantonese cuisine where most local restaurants predominantly use soy sauce or oyster sauce, the flavor profile adds the sour and sweet elements and different textures in unexpected ways.  If you are adventurous and not afraid to try something new, you will likely enjoy this, but make sure you bring someone in the know to guide you. The food ranks 3.5 stars with an added 0.5 star for the authenticity of the cuisine.
author: Mike C.

description: This place has incredible food. Had the Rijsttafel Dinner which is a fixed price for a number of courses. Every course was an amazing taste extravaganza!! The Indonesian Spring rolls and soup were incredible. I was there with 4 people total and they brought 8 different main dished to sample. All were great. And a great desert to finish as part of the fixed price. Highly recommended.
author: Thomas W.

description: Yummy yummy yummy. I'm a vegetarian and this place was heavenly. We got the roti prata and the tofu with peanut garlic sauce apps. Both were absolutely delicious. For hard core vegetarians/ vegans, the sauce with the roti pratha has chicken broth. For mains we got the nasi goreng kari with veggies and tofu and the Bakmi goreng kari. Both were heavenly. So highly recommended. And SO reasonably priced. Love it
author: Ashmita V.

description: This place is outstanding! I had never tried Indonesian food before trying this place and I have definitely missed out. My good friend took me here, and we had a few dishes that were all unbelievably delicious. We had the martabak sapi with beef, beef rendang, the nasi goreng, the spicy green bean with shrimp paste, and the bihun goreng. Can you say flavor explosion? It was amazing, I have never had flavors and food like this before. Indonesian food is truly unique and very flavorful, it's one of my favorite cuisines after trying this restaurant. The service was also very good, our water glasses were never empty and the staff was all very welcoming and kind. The martabak sapi was a great starter: crispy dough and flavorful beef. Next we had the rendang; which is a personal favorite. The beef is slow simmered in coconut milk and spices and it just melts in your mouth. It's a must try if you're going here. The nasi goreng was very good, I always love fried rice done right. The green beans were very flavorful and a good addition to our meal. They were very addicting and I couldn't stop eating them. The bihun goreng was my second favorite, the noodles were perfectly cooked and we added shrimp which was a perfect compliment to our dish.  All of our dishes were flavorful and delicious, and I will definitely be back.
author: Beth G.

description: I'm not sure why there are not more positive reviews.  We had an enjoyable dinner in the Dutch/Indonesian tradition of rijsttafel or 'rice table.'  I have no idea exactly what we ate, but we got enough food for 3 dinners for our family of 3!  The flavors were wonderful, fragrant, and complex.  We'll definitely go again for a fun family style dinner out!
author: Keeley M.

description: Most everything I've tasted here has been very tasty. Atmosphere is nice but casual - Above diner-level, but short of having any implicit dress code. Price is maybe a bit higher than one would guess.
author: Kyle C.

description:
Yelp loves this place so of course I figure why not?  I'm fairly confident there aren't any Indonesian restaurants in my home town, but I'm always up to try something different after my fellow yelpers rave.

The decor was about what you'd expect.  It's in an older building, so the details around the corners feel and look a little worn.  There are bamboo type accents and decent cleanliness inside, so nothing too alarming with the atmosphere. 

The waitstaff is responsive, although we were also the first people in the place, so I certainly would have expected nothing but...

My disappointment honestly came from the food.  Instead of going with a single entree, my dining partner and I attacked the starter menu and ordered a bunch to share.  We ordered the Roti Pota, Tahu Goreng, Siomay Bandung and Siomay Ayam.  The Siomay Ayam, which was basically a pan fried chicken dumpling with a mildly spicy peanut sauce was easily the highlight of the sampled dishes.  I hate to say it, but I was completely disappointed with everything else.  

The other Siomay was coated in the peanut sauce, so I could not get any type of flavor from the ingredients.  The Roti Pota was like a fried bread with a curry-like sauce to dip it in, and was only okay.  I mean, fried bread that's only OK?  like where am?  what year is this?  The Tofu was very forgettable.

I wouldn't come back.  Not because I had a horrible experience, but because my experience was only so-so, the food wasn't much better, and there are quite a few alternative places only blocks away that have yet to be explored.
author: Brendon T.

description: Cool place but you need to come with 2+ people to make it worthwhile just like any other Asian restaurant. So many dishes to share and split the bill with . Good flavors and service .
author: Mete C.

description:
Given the amazing diversity of culinary choices in the SF Bay Area, I'm surprised that there aren't more places that offer rijsttafel, an Indonesian small plate meal that takes its name from the Dutch word for "rice table".  Despite the colonial overtones of the name, the food very distinctly Southeast Asian in nature.

I came here for lunch with a good friend while attending a conference nearby.  She had never heard of this type of cuisine (indeed, I suspect that it's probably unknown to a lot of people) and was intrigued to give it a try.  When we arrived there was only one other table occupied, even though it was the lunch hour of a regular business day.

The rijsttafel menu was varied both in food and quality.  It wasn't quite as extensive as what I recall from the Netherlands, where we seemed to have about twice as many dishes but in smaller quantities.  Nevertheless, it was a still an excellent sampling of Indonesian dishes.

Lumpia appetizer - crisp and hot, delicious but not particularly distinctive.
Soto ayam - lemongrass soup.  I usually can't stand lemongrass because I think most places overdo it, but this was well done.
Gado gado salad - nice flavor, vegetables perhaps a little overcooked and soft, but still enjoyable.
Satay ayam - standard chicken skewer, similar to what you find in the dime-a-dozen Thai restaurants.
Kari Udang - really excellent shrimp/curry dish; subtle flavors and aromas.
Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak - chicken in coconut milk sauce, very tasty.
Rendang - beef stew-like dish.  The waitress said that it was one of the most popular dishes, but I found it to be the least appealing.  Beef texture was a bit off, perhaps from being a little overcooked.
Oseng Oseng Tahu Tempe - my favorite dish by far.  Tofu-based dish with great flavors and texture and just the right amount of spiciness.
Black sweet rice in coconut milk dessert - very good.  Served warm, cleans the palate very nicely.

We also ordered the roti prata that others have raved about.  It's not on the rijsttafel menu, so that came at a small extra cost.  Pretty good, but not as overwhelming as I had expected it to be.  Perhaps I built up my expectations too much.

The price of our meal, including the extra roti, nonalcoholic beverage, and tip was less that $40 per person.  Though perhaps a little more than most would like to spend on lunch, for us it was well worth the cost for a unique dining experience.

One quibble: service was really, really slow.  Good thing we had two hours for lunch otherwise we would have felt rushed at the end.  The waitress, however, was very attentive and answered all our questions.  She was also almost irresistibly beautiful.
author: Lee L.

description: I went for dinner on a saturday night with my family after making a phone reservation. When we got there the host said there was no reservation under my name and that we would have to wait, even though there were plenty of open tables and we waited for about 25 mins before she sat us down. We ordered roti prata, gado gado, gulai kambing (lamb curry), eggplant & tofu, and ayam bakar. The only somewhat edible and tasty food was the roti prata. Gado gado didnt have much flavor, the lamb curry had meat that was extremely tough and chewy. The eggplant and tofu had no salt and tasted like tomato paste. The ayam bakar was burnt and dry. Staff and the owner was extremely rude throughout our time there, did not check in with us about the food, and was not at all apologetic for the poor service and poor quality of food. Honestly giving this a one-star because I have to give it something, but overrated, overpriced, and does not meet expectations one bit.
author: Apoorva G.

description:
Food was nutritional and did not poison me.

Twenty years ago there were a number of restaurants who did Rijsttafel, but this is the only I count.

When I am not in Amsterdam, I have a moment a crave for Rijsttafel. I am afraid I am going to have to look on.

For Rijsttafel I expect a special moment, especially for $30/person. Sorry, not even close.

I have eaten here before when it was special, but that is not now.

Indifferent, slow service, just OK food.

I don't expect OK. Maybe lack of competition, means bad value. :(
author: BigJohnS F.

description: Ordered the $32 Rice Sampler. Food not so good except for Shrimp soup dish. Too much food. Had entered a full review but Yelp lost it.
author: George D.

description: We were having dinner for couple.  We went for the Rijsttafel, a complete Indonesian rice table dinner that was delicious and full of different kinds of dishes. It was great however we could not finish it.
author: Renana M.

description: I was looking for an Indonesian restaurant in the area and found this place. I ordered the pempak which was the fried fish with cucumber and clear noodles. This dish was delicious! My favorite Indonesian food dish. We also ordered two rice dishes: #58 and some other dish Idr, but something very similar. The curry and tofu on the dishes were food. They were very flavorful, very satisfying. However, the meat were a bit dry inside despite the amount of sauce on top. The service was okay. They were friendly but sort of slow.
author: Katelyn N.

description:
3.5 stars!

We had a reservation at 7pm on a Friday night. There was absolutely no wait, and there were quite a few open tables. I got there first, and decided to look to yelp to see what to order.

My friends arrived shortly, and waters were brought out for us. After waters were brought out, we were pretty much left alone. We ended up deciding on 3 dishes, but got really engaged in conversation, we forgot to order, and nobody came by to take our order. When I realized this, I paused our conversation and waved somebody down, who had to take care of something else and then return to take our order. 

We ordered the:
#1 Roti Prata - $7.50 - This dish came our first, as it should. The roti was a wonderful mix of crispiness and fluffiness. The dipping sauce I thought lacked. It didn't stand out as anything spectacular. It was just a sauce. 

#30 Rendang - $14.50 - This dish was recommended by yelp highlights. The beef was very very tender, and fell apart nicely. The sauce was very good. I was a little surprised this dish wasn't more "saucy". We ordered a bowl of rice with it, but it wasn't very necessary. There wasn't enough sauce for a bowl of rice. The sauce itself was good though.

#61 Nasi Goreng with Chicken and Shrimp - $10.50 - This dish was severely lacking in flavour. It was bland despite having stuff in it. I don't know what else to say. It's a fried rice that just lacked all around. I wouldn't recommend it.

#47 Bakmi Goreng with Shrimp and Beef - $10.95 - One of my friends came here before and was looking for an egg noodle dish. This one ended up being my favourite dish of the ones we ordered. Completely opposite of the fried rice, this one was very flavourful and tastey. Good chunks of meat in it too.

Overall food was decent. It seems to be hit or miss, but nothing too exceptional.

Service was spotty. My experience was definitely not as bad as other yelper's experiences. Our waters were always refilled. As for ordering beers. My friend ordered a second beer after he finished his first one, and it just took a long time. Then while he was waiting for his, I ordered one, and mine came almost immediately while he was still waiting for his. We had to wave down another waiter to check on it. It still didn't come out. Then we asked again, and it finally came out. 

All in all, this wasn't really an experience that'll last in my memory. I can't recommend this place, and I don't think I'll return.
author: Kaje Y.

description: The food was interesting. The service was a bit slow ,but the staff was friendly.
author: Tammy R.

description:
I love the food here but it isnt exactly spot on from a authenticity stand point. I am not Indonesian but have traveled there so I know a bit about the food. Everything they make here, especially the Java noodles tastes great but it is much different than what I have had in different parts of Indonesia. The service is ok, not speedy or especially attentive but I think it is fine overall. The setting is casual and usually I can get a table without waiting very long. Mostly the tables are meant for 2 - 4 people but I have seen them setup the center tables together for larger groups. 

If you havent had Indonesian food and want to try it this is a good place to start. If you dont mind spicy stuff then try the Java noodles! Otherwise there is a wide gamut of options to choose from. So far I havent found any duds on the menu.
author: Luis M.

description:
I'm currently in the restaurant waiting for my to go order. They quoted me 25 minutes and I'm fully expecting it to be longer. So why am I here? The food is pretty damn good. If I was rating just that, then this place would get 5 stars. My absolute favorite things on the menu are the roti prata and the bakmi goreng Kari. The latter is a spicy curry noodle and I can't do spice. I always order a 2, sometimes 3, out of a scale of 10 for spiciness level. You can't control the spice for this dish and i will freaking fight through it because it's that good. All the other things I've tried have been delicious as well. 

The service here is terrible. Super awful. There isn't much of an acknowledgement when you walk in and if you don't have a rezzie on a Friday/Saturday night, the wait can take forever. Oh you may be seated but you are not necessarily getting water until 15 minutes in. And then they may take your order 20 minutes after that. I've been here when it's fairly empty and it takes forever for food to come out. No one comes by to check on drinks. There are no pleasantries and I don't need that if the food is coming out in a timely manner (pho places are a great example!). I think it's a family-run joint and I respect that. But to wait an hour before even getting your first bite is just too long. If I were to rate service alone, it would be a 2. 

Held off on posting until after I got my food. Total time waiting before I got my to go order: 30 minutes. Not as bad as I anticipated.
author: Serena N.

description: Having searched for an Indonesian rice table in San Francisco we weren't disappointed. Very tasty dishes, very colourful and interesting combinations made for a wonderful lunchtime treat. It was quiet and relaxed on a Saturday afternoon allowing everyone to enjoy great food and great conversation. We will be back !
author: Andrew P.

description:
