This place has the prix fixe menu for $27.50 per person and it's worth it.  It comes with soup, appetizer (eggroll) and 6 main dishes including braised beef, shrimp curry, veggies in peanut sauce, chicken skewers, bbq chicken and fried tofu.  And rice.  And dessert.  Service is like what you would get in Holland - slow unless you ask for things.  Can I have a menu?  Can we get some water?  Can we have the check now?  

This would be a good place for a large party.  Reservations during the holidays are recommended.  We got there a bit early and it was ok.
author: Chris L.

description:
I was born in Jakarta, so I'd like to think I know a thing or two about Indonesian cuisine. Let me tell you, the flavors here are AMAZING. Although not as traditional as the food I grew up with, every dish I've had has its own spin and is F-L-A-V-O-R-F-U-L. My go to dishes: 

1) Roti Prata
-Crispy, flaky, full of texture. Perfect curry side dip with a tiny hint of heat. great for two or three 
 people, or in my case, one. Seriously just get it.

2) Bakmi Ayam
-Definitely not "traditional mi," but still absolutely delicious. Meat is marinated so well and the
 natural taste of the chicken comes through. 

3) Rijjstafel 
-For days i am feeling especially hungry and bougie. Yes, it is pricy, but what can beat an entire assortment of my favorite foods with amazing presentation? Comes on a super cute metal heater.

I don't think I'll ever get tired of coming here.
author: yohana c.

description:
This was my first experience with Indonesian cuisine and it was great!  We ordered the Rendang Beef, which was sort of like a curry, but with a different flavor profile (more allspicey, very earthy).  Notably, the beef was cut into these ginormous cubes so I initially thought they were bone-in, but they were all meat and incredibly tender.  Secondly, we ordered the Cumi Pedas Selera, a spicy battered squid dish.  I was initially concerned about the spice level of this dish, but our server was like, "It's not that spicy" so we went ahead and ordered it.  I don't know what she was talking about because man, that dish was on fire!  She probably figured Asians should be able to handle the heat but I happen to have a pathetic spice tolerance.  So, I painstakingly scraped off the seeds and fragments of chili pepper but it was worth the extra work - that dish was also delicious with a hint of sweetness, and the squid was tender, not tough and chewy.

I'd definitely return to try more dishes, but just one thing to note: All the menu prices are about $1 more than the prices listed online.  Both of our dishes cost $15.50 instead of $14.50 and the jasmine rice was $2.25 instead of $1.75.
author: Beatrice W.

description: Indonesian food is rare to find back home. We were delighted to come across this wonderful restaurant. The decor was beautiful. The menu was extensive. We settled on the BBQ marinated chicken in coconut milk, honey marinated beef and rice dish with fried chicken, spicy beef, tofu, and egg. The food was amazingly good. We also got ginger teas and a shaved ice drink with coconut milk and assorted fruit. The portions and prices were reasonable. We left feeling full and satisfied.
author: Anna C.

description: Went here again and the waiter's now more friendly! Ordered Ayam Bakar and Nasi Uduk and they were really good.
author: Amanda W.

description:
In San Fran & looking for an ethnic lunch.  Thanks to the amazing Yelpers in the area, I had tons of options!  I have never been to an  Indonesian restaurant before and was willing to try something new, as always.

We were the only diners when we entered.  Our waitress was very sweet.  The soup and salad were both very good.  I got the spicy beef, which was not as spicy as I thought, but still delicious.

So many options for Vegans!  I would go again, for sure!
author: Kim K.

description:
Borobudur restaurant is the only real Indonesian restaurant in San Francisco. Unfortunately if you are craving Indonesian food, you have basically no choice (unless you are ready to take the Bart to Jayakarta over in Berkeley). The food is not terrible - the rendang is edible; the pempek is ok; etc. Each dish is passable. But this restaurant makes a few critical mistakes in their cooking:

- Too much salt - so much that the salt overwhelms the many spices in Indonesian cooking
- Too much oil - the best Indonesian food is not greasy. It is well-spiced.

Overall, the flavor is too salty, and the food is too heavy. Nothing like the wonderful food you get in Indonesia.
author: Seth H.

description:
I love trying new foods and Indonesian food was on my to do list. My extended family and I came here to enjoy a new experience. When we arrived, there was ample seating and they were able to accommodate a table of 10 quickly. We ordered many dishes for a family style dinner: 
Roti prata- pan fried bread with a curry dipping sauce- It's the BEST thing here! it's fluffy bread, resembles naan
bakwan jagung- fried corn fritters with tangy sauce- just ok
kari undang- curry with shrimp and vegetables- pretty good, a good amount of shrimp and vegetables, spices add more taste to the curry
satay ayam-  delicious satay chicken with peanut sauce- tasty 
rendang - sumatra beef stew with coconut milk- just ok 
soto betawi- beef with cabbage, potato, tomato in coconut milk- something is terribly terribly wrong with this soup. It tastes like someone cut up vegetables, boiled it and poured coconut water all over. DON'T GET THIS SOUP. I took a few bites and I left the rest of the bowl untouched.
My favorite item was the soda susu gembira. It is sparkling water, raspberry syrup and condensed milk combined into a sweet and fruity beverage. I think the food quality is mediocre with OK taste. Great customer service. For my first time trying Indonesian food, it was palatable. I would love to try a different place for a better experience. I felt like mine was lacking.
author: Camellia P.

description:
This restaurant was amazing! It was delicious food and wonderful experience! I recommend it to all who are passing by. 

If you come here make sure to order the Roti Prata. It was heavenly. The Soto Ayam soup was also perfect. We will make sure to make another visit to here before leaving the city. The place was so good that I decided to write my first review on Yelp!
author: S A.

description:
Great food.We ordered the Rijsttafel (complete rice plate) for three people. It costs 27.50 per person, and trust me that is a lot of delicious options. You get 1 appetizer, a soup, 6 main dishes and a choice among three desserts.
My favorite was beef rendang and the Soto ayam.
I also got the green iced coconut water which I love.
Great food presentation and service.
author: Amrita G.

description:
i'd wanted to check this place out for a long time since i love indonesian food - but our visit on a tuesday night was pretty bad - the chicken in the satay tasted like it had been frozen and defrosted too often, and the peanut sauce was straight out of a jar of peanut butter from your local grocery - the spicy noodles were better (they're spicy, but not incredibly so - don't be put off by the 2 chili peppers on the menu and warning from the waiter - if you like spicy, you'll like these) - the spicy (i was lucky to be eating with people who like hot foods as much as i do!) seafood dish was another disappointment - the shrimp and calamari(? (not sure what that was even after cutting into it) again tasted defrosted and mushy, as did the coating
service was friendly so no complaint there, but i don't think i'll go back again, as it was such a come-down from my expectations!
author: Nancy M.

description: Sungguh sangat menyenangkan kalau dalam perjalanan ke LN bisa ketemu makanan Indonesia, resto ini menyediakan banyak ragam menu dan rasanya menurut saya ckp enak. Tentunya jangan berhatap rasa yg identik dgn aslinya mengingat resto ini adanya di SF bukan Indonesia, demikian juga dengan harganya jangan dibandingkan dgn Indonesia ttp nikmati saja sebagai pemuas kerinduan kita. Lokasinya tidak terlalu jauh dr Union Square, tempatnya tidak terlalu besar jadi kadang harus antri.
author: Rino T.

description: This was the first time trying Indonesian food and it was amazing. I really enjoyed by fried noodles. I would recommend this place to friends and look forward to returning.
author: Alison G.

description:
Seemed like a decent place. I usually give lot of places with 3 stars or more the benefit of doubt. I was pumped up to try Nasi Goreng fried rice after watching it on a food show. I called them up to see if they had a vegetarian option and they did. So I drove for 30mins to pick up my order. After another 30min drive back home, I was excited to try this out. 

But after few spoons I realized that I was eating chicken and not Tofu. I was pretty disappointed, had to throw the whole thing out and order food from another place. So much for the 60min round trip drive. How can you screw up an order with just one fried rice?

Besides, the fried rice tasted okay, very similar to what you would find in a Thai restaurant. Nothing great really. I would give a 3 star for the food. 

Giving 1 star for not getting the order right.
author: Venkata A.

description: Had the Nasi Soto Ayam and Pisang Goreng and both were spot on. Being from East Java, I'm rather particular about the cuisine from this area but it definitely did not disappoint. Wish they had a location in Portland!
author: Randy T.

description:
I normally really like Indonesian/Malaysian (I'm sorry if those are actually totally different categories, just an ignorant Chinese girl here!), but this is the first in the Bay Area to really wow me. They take all these dishes I normally like and just give them that extra boost of flavor/texture - have already recommended this to several people and will continue doing so!

MUST-HAVES: Roti prata, beef rendang, Tahu Goreng

1.  Roti Prata - 4.5 stars!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/borobudur-restaurant-san-francisco?select=wJo3ZT3o-W9-pM-LkLcyNA#5YifVDAKfuIoop4hWSIAOw
(Pan fried layered bread served with curry dipping sauce. $7.50)
I was almost against getting this because it's such a standard dish - always good, but never amazing. Well this was amazing! The bread had this wonderfully slight crisp and had all this fluff & layers - when you tear it apart, it's not like one big oily blob of bread, which I never complained about at other restaurants - I just didn't know it COULD be any better!

30.  Rendang - 4.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/borobudur-restaurant-san-francisco?select=wJo3ZT3o-W9-pM-LkLcyNA#0HFtEv0UuhmPlx1Uo15asw
(Sumatra beef stew cooked with spices in coconut milk sauce. $12.95)
Also amazing. The beef was RIDICULOUSLY soft and tender, almost like a pulled meat kind of quality. The dish was big, filling (in a good way), and also had great flavors.

4.  Tahu Goreng - 4.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/borobudur-restaurant-san-francisco?select=wJo3ZT3o-W9-pM-LkLcyNA#FRuDgBKwpL4n6NjOSkCRkg
Fried tofu served with hot garlic peanut sauce. $4.95)
We all said something along the lines of, "This is how tofu SHOULD be cooked." I don't know how they retained the soft inner texture of the tofu while creating such a nice even breaded crisp on the outside. Oh and the sauce was spectacular - like melty crunchy peanut butter with south asian spices =).

50.  Veggie Rice Plate - 2.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/borobudur-restaurant-san-francisco?select=wJo3ZT3o-W9-pM-LkLcyNA#wJo3ZT3o-W9-pM-LkLcyNA
(Combination of Java soy bean cake, corn fritter, vegetables in coconut curry sauce & steamed rice. $10.50)
This was the outlier dish. I am to blame, as those corn fritters looked really great and my veggie friends wanted to include that somehow in our order, so this seemed like a good compromise. The fritter, which I thought would be like a corn bread, was more like an oily mush with a few kernels of corn. Big disappointment. The other parts of this plate - the veggies, soy bean cake, were overly spicy and not well flavored.

54.  Bakmi Goreng / Bihun Goreng - 4 stars
(Stir fried (egg noodle/rice stick noodle) with egg & vegetables with mixed vegetables. $9.95)
As simple as this dish was, it was actually really tasty! I loved that the noodles were really fat and soft. And Chinese broccoli was one of the veggies mixed in - I loved that, have never had it in a noodle that way!
author: Ziyan C.

description: Came here last minutes on a Saturday night.  Restaurant had a line but we got our seat in about half an hour. Food was delicious.  The food was kind of slow coming out.  We waited a good one hour before we had any food.  The owner realized it and offered us some prawn crackers.  Nice gesture but they can definitely do much better than this.  Good place to bring your significant someone here bon apetit
author: J N.

description:
I don't know anything about Indonesian food, but I was brought here by a friend and I just kind of let her choose all the 'good stuff' on the menu.

I have to say that everything was pretty good.
Food took a while but I guess that means they ain't microwaving anything right.
author: Mario K.

description:
What a diamond in the rough. Never thought it would be much, but stumbled upon with a recommendation and boy did it surprise!

Roti prata is quite amazing! Share that with one side of nasi goreng with rice if you so choose and you'll have a very full and delicious meal. On the edge of getting sketchy, but really start here and hit up some T'loin bars after and you'll be great. Another unexpected great find. I'll definitely come back for some great food someday soon.
author: Joseph L.

description: My Indonisian friend said it's so so, but for a non Indonesian person, I gotta say it's pretty good. I love the Roti Prata here. The roti is very cruchy outside and chewy inside. LOVE IT! Nasi Goreng Kari is good too, not spicy but a tge kari add a little more flavor too the dish. The chicken satay is so tender too!!
author: Nuntanat R.

description:
If you can't handle the heat get off the court. 

That's what the girls volley ball team would tell me in High School, as they pummeled me and took my lunch money. 

Same message applies here. If you can take heat be wary, the food provides some serious spice.

Meal number four of the day was at Borobudur, after a friend from Yelp suggested the spot.

Indonesian was a nice change of pace from everything else I was eating that weekend. 

My friend and I split the Roti Prata, which was some of the best Roti I ever ate. 

Next up was the Sambal Goreng Daging. My waiter asked if I liked it spicy. I looked at him puzzled, wondering if this man thought I didn't know how to live life. Of course I want it spicy!

Woah, it was spicy! It's cooked beef in a special chili sauce. After awhile my friend said "No Mas", or however you'd say no more in Indonesian. I kept eating away as if I had nothing to lose. 

In the end it's some amazing Indonesian food and worth a visit!
author: Mitch E.

description:
I love the foods. Siomay Bandung and Mie Yamin are my favorites. Staffs are friendly. 
I had funny experience, the waitress  thought I am a tourist and she added the tips automatically to my bill and she did not say anything to me, I almost tip her again. This was never happened before on my previous visit, I thought this is a new policy from the Restaurant. After I asked her about the service charge in my bill, and if I need to tips her again on top of this, she then explained to me about the service charge system in USA, as of I am a tourist :)  However, I appreciated she was being honest, she mentioned that I do not need to tips her again. I did not tell her that I came here couple times and I am not a tourist. Let's just keep it the ways it is, :)
author: Maria S.

description:
I went to Borobudur for the second time this weekend, and like last time, had a very enjoyable experience.  We ordered hot ginger tea and a Thai iced tea to quench our thirst--I would recommend both! The Roti here is my choice appetizer and beats the roti at other Indonesian restaurants in terms of texture and flavor, although the accompanying curry dip/sauce is slightly too salty. We also ordered the martabak, savory square cubes with vegetable and egg filling. 
We tried a variety of entrees, but my favorite was the mie tek tek.  Mie tek tek can be a challenge for those who cannot handle a fair degree of spiciness.
author: Margaret H.

description: I'm Indonesian and I love Indonesian food. I've been coming to this place forever as I've been living here for 13 years already. I love the food. The Rice Plates for lunch is super awesome. I always bring people to this place, but lately I've been very disappointed with the staff. The waitress messed up my orders twice already. The first time, I kept it quite although I wasn't agreed the way her hair was all over her face and she kept touching her hair and serve customers afterwards. Today I came back with someone. It wasn't even busy. It was around 3:30 PM and she only had two tables. She messed my order again and she wasn't able to figure how to fix the problem. Enough said I'm not going back to this place.
author: Damien S.

description:
It was my first time getting Indonesian food and I have to say, I was definitely impressed! The roti prata was so good (but careful not to stuff yourself before the rest of your dishes come!). There was also this beef dish that we got that was really good... can't really remember the name of it, but I would highly recommend asking your waiter/waitress. 

Lots of their dishes had a peanut sauce base, so if you're into that, then this if your place! I would also recommend getting the dessert drinks... they're absolutely delicious :)
author: Jessica X.

description:
Holy crap this place is good! My partner and I just wandered in here on a whim, and it's fortunate that we did.

I ordered the noodles with curry topped with shrimp and chicken. I like relatively spicy food and this was maybe a little above my comfort zone for spice. It was also delicious, a huge plate (I'm a guy with a big appetite...this and a few bites of my partner's dish left me quite full), and it cost $11! 

My partner ordered the lamb with curry. It was a very different curry from mine - still delicious, but a totally different flavor and much milder. Combining her dish with a bowl of rice made for a perfect meal.

Update: I went there for a second time tonight and I had the rendang (beef stew) with the aromatic rice. It's not a spicy dish, but it's delicious! The beef was cooked to perfection as well.

A few minor warnings:
- The descriptions are kind of vague. I got "noodles with curry" and my partner got "lamb with curry". Despite the similar names, one dish was super spicy while the other wasn't spicy at all, and the two curries had totally different flavors. They were both delicious, but you might want to ask your waiter for details to make sure you get something to your tastes
- Asking the waiters might not be foolproof either. Our designated waiter spoke really good English, but another waiter that we interacted with at one point spoke very broken English. If you get the second guy, getting details might be a bit tricky
- Lastly, my noodles-with-meat dish was sizeable and tasty, but there was less meat than I was expecting. If you're looking for a high-protein meal, I probably wouldn't order anything that can be described as a carb-and-meat combo

In sum, this is a great restaurant with excellent portions, low prices, and delicious foods with unique flavors. Highly recommended!
author: Dan D.

description: Great Indonesian restaurant in Union Square! Everything we had here was awesome! The roti prata, beef rendang, and lamb were all excellent.
author: Peter K.

description:
It was early morning and my friends and i waited for this place to open. 

I ordered the lamb and it was a bit dry. The lamb curry wasn't so great. I may not know how Indonesian actually taste, but I do know I don't like the overcooked lamb in the curry. 

It's a cute restaurant tho. I may try it again another time during the day being that we were the first customers.
author: Vicky L.

description:
This is a good restaurant. Would I go back? It's a hesitant yes. 
This place is nestled in the TenderNob and it's a great place for a different type of Asian meal. You just don't get that much Indonesia nor Malaysian in the City. I wish that was different because both types of cuisines have similarities that excite the palate with their unusual spices and preparation. 

What we ordered: 
Appy: Roti Prata and Martabak Sapi
Main Dishes: Rendang Beef, Bakmi Goreng Kari (noodles), Tahu & Terong Balado (Eggplant and tofu)

Roti Prata is a thick Roti Canai (like a thick tortilla) of goodness that you dip in curry sauce. Martabak was very nice with the beef and some veggies and egg. Again it's like a little burrito that you eat with pickled vegetables or curry sauce. In essence, apps were awesome  
Many Yelpers raved about the Rendang, but I can say I've had better at Lime Tree in the Sunset at half the price and double the tastiness. The entree that killed it was the noodles, Bakmi Goreng Kari. It had heat and flavor. 

Service: There are only 2 waitresses working, so service was a little slow. They're really nice, but not the fastest. As well as, pacing of the food. It felt like it took a bit of time for the first app to come before everything slowly arrived.

It's authentic Indonesia, but I wish our dishes had more flavor. It's worth a try if you're in the mood for something spicy and just a different type of Asian cuisine.
author: Harvey C.

description: Food is OK, short haired male server was very rude from the beginning (Hence the ONE star). This was our first time having Indonesian food and were very excited. We ordered spicy noodles, The noodles were FLAMING hot so we asked a different server if they could remake it to be less spicy and without hesitation he said yes and was very nice about it! Out of nowhere the rude server comes back again and tells us "i cant pay for this, what do you want to do with this" Implying that if we didn't want spicy he would of suggested something different. Unfortunately we did ask for less spicy during the order and there were no suggestions made..
author: Jayden A.

description: Super friendly staff. Vermicelli and prawns were very good, with the vermicelli having a nice kick at the end. The fried rice, unfortunately, could use some improvement.  The rice was a bit overcooked. The noodles we ordered were pretty bland and uninteresting. Might be good to make reservations if you don't want to be seated immediately under the sun as though it is rare in SF, it can get a bit uncomfortable.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Wow I love their Roti Prata. It is crispy at the edge and soft in the inside. You break a piece and dip into the curry sauce it came with, and devour the taste of South East Asia. Of course over there, people eat this as breakfast or late night supper. This costs 7.50 but the portion is pretty big. You can share this with few people as appetizer. The Gado-Gado was good too. I had mixed feeling about the creamy peanut sauce at first (I am more used to the crunchy style), but I thought it blends pretty well with the vegetables. We also had Nasi Padang and Nasi Rames, which is a good way to sample various small side dishes that come with the rice. I particularly love the Beef Rendang in Nasi Padang. The meat was tender and the coconut-based gravy was delicious. I know this take hours to cook so you can almost taste the spices deep into the meat. Here is one tip : You can ask for Sambal Terasi  (Malaysian calls this Sambal Belacan), to go with your rice. They will provide this to you (just as if you ask for ketchup) if you request. Mind you this is pretty spicy but I like the extra zing with my dish. 

Overall. Nice dining experience. The service was attentive and polite. I will definitely come here again.
author: Zuhadi Z.

description:
Went here with my family and friends for dinner. And our expectation is high since we're so hungry ^^
The food was very good. It's pretty authentic Indonesian taste. I had Nasi Uduk, Nasi Padang for my hubby and Nasi Goreng for my kids. And the price's good too. 
The only thing this place is lacking was they cook the meal a bit slow. But Indonesian food have many spices so it's no wonder. Just prepare yourself to wait a bit longer for the food to be delivered to your table
author: Devi P.

description: We went to Borobudar based on a "Check Please BayArea" review that unfortunately was done years ago!  Service was OK, but our server was very new and did not know the menu, and had language issues.  We went because of the possibility of new tastes. The sauces were disappointingly bland with a unfortunate sameness.  When I called for reservations, I was told there was a place one block away that had validated parking.  That was not the case and we had to walk several blocks and parking was $ 20.00. Unfortunately the four of us came in two cars.  I live in North Beach and there are many better restaurants!
author: Wayne L.

description: The food was OK but the place literally smelled like a dog cannel in which they havent cleaned the cages in days., Also the restrooms had fungus in them and were clearly not cleaned properly.. Yelp gave a warning before hand saying it rated extremely low on food safety..I was really dieing for some traditional indonesian food but sadly the hygiene just made it taste less good..
author: Tinka W.

description:
I've enjoyed many meals at Borobudur, but I'm afraid the quality of service has slipped. They recently left me on hold for nearly a half hour, and even then, we had to wait another 30 minutes for our food to be ready. The staff apologized, but still, it;s not the experience it used to be.

Further, there's a cleanliness issue. The floors aren't clean, and the molding around the windows and mirrors is gross, splashed with food. Their decorations are very dusty, too. It's a pity.
author: K K.

description: I loved this place! I live in the neighborhood and will definitely be back. I wanted vegetables and peanut sauce and was not disappointed. The corn fritters were chunky and crispy and came with a delicious spicy peanut sauce. The vegetable egg fu yung was like a crispy fried omelette with tons of broccoli, snap peas, carrots, and onions in it. It comes with a sort of duck sauce. Just be cautious of all the fried food here. Further, I am not an Indonesian good connoisseur so I am going on taste alone, not comparisons to the "real thing", but it seems pretty legit to me! It's also not uncomfortable to eat alone here though there's no bar- you get a table/booth. The wine pours are generous:).
author: Liza S.

description: Bakwan jagung and Ayam bakar cabe are my current favorites from Borobudur. Great price, great selection!!!! and the waitress is very friendly.
author: Frisca A.

description:
7-September, Saturday
 The rice table (or Dutch 'Rijsttafel') was an elaborate meal of Indonesian dishes developed during the Dutch colonial era. It consists of rice and small platters of food to accompany it to achieve a balance of salty, spicy, sweet, and sour accompaniments. The only time I've ever had this was abroad in Amsterdam, but there were about 25-30 different offerings for a meal that was about 2-2.5 hours.

Appetizers: 
Lemongrass Soup with Potato & Chicken: I also enjoy spooning a bit of rice and pooling in the broth so that I can taste the rich flavor of the broth. The serving size was just the right amount for a taste (about a mini-bowl's worth), but I could easily eat this as a full meal.

Lumpia Semarang, Indonesian fried spring rolls served with peanut dipping sauce. The fillings are similar to the Chinese Popiah (spring roll), but has a mixture of bamboo shoots, chicken & prawn. I really enjoyed these the first time I had them here because I found that they were a bit sweet, which complemented the earthiness of the peanut dipping sauce.

Main Course (with rice included):
1. Rendang: The Sumatra style beef stew is curried in various spices in coconut milk curry. The quality of the meat very tenderized yet intentionally dry.. yes, it sounds like a weird juxtaposition but the sauce makes it work successfully. This was very nostalgic of my childhood as my grandmother would also makes a similar 'Malaysian' version to this that was a bit spicier, and more along the level of dryness of dehydrated beef, or the American equivalent of 'Jerky.'  The dish often slightly varies from place-to-place, culture to culture.. but I always think about the dry flaky meat as being the catalyst or method of delivery for tasting the sauce (usually ginger, tumeric leaves, lemon grass, garlic, shallot, chillies, amongst other spices)

2. Oseng Oseng Tahu Tempe: sauteed & stir-fried Java soy bean cake Tempe that was caramelized on all sides & white tofu. Rather a simple dish and tasted similarly to the Tumis Kacang Panjang.

3. Sate Ayum: 4x pieces of moist BBQ marinated chicken on skewer (all thigh meat) with peanut dressing. My only critique is that the smoky flavor did not come through as much as I've had with other Indonesian Satays, I was really hoping for the charred flavor to be injected into the meat.

4. Ayum Panggang Bumbu Rujak: 2x pieces of spicy BBQ marinated chicken (with bone) contrasted nicely with the coconut milk sauce. So the end-result is a delicious spicy, yet sweet sensation on your tongue.

5.Kari Udang: prawns in a mildly spicy curry sauce, with chunks of potatoes and eggplant. It goes well with the jasmine rice, but I like to also eat this with chappati, roti chanai, or nasi minyak.

6. Gado-Gado/ Salade: blanched vegetables, tofu, potato, & egg covered in peanut dressing.. I only have had a Javanese 'Lotek' variation of this prior which is the same concept of various veggies covered in peanut sauce, except the veggies in that case are raw so you taste more of the crisp. Both topped with plain emping crackers (which are equally as tasty eaten by itself as a snack, or gently crushed into some lontong sayur). I thought that this version was a bit sauce heavy -but can easily be diluted with rice.

Dessert: 
1. Vanilla Ice Cream -creamy, lightly fragrant & sweet, garnished with a sour cherry.
2. Black Sweet Rice with Coconut Milk: short grained and dark purple in flavor, very glutinous and sticky in texture. This is always a refreshing treat for me because it is warm, creamy, sweet from the toasted coconut, and a little savory.

This was a more focused version of it, with most curried meats, and peanut dressing. I wish there were more pickled, and briney dishes because those were some of my favorite fare of the Rijsttafel.
author: Ty T.

description: Awesome Food !!! Puas banget nemu masakan Indo! Pengen gw makan semua tp perut gw gk sanggup. Lol!
author: Christina L.

description:
I came here with a part size of about 3 families for lunch. Luckily, we reserved a spot for our large group because there was one more reservations that was larger than ours that came at the same time. I am a fan of Indonesian food, and since I've been to many indo restaurants as well as eaten a lot of my family's cooking, I am very picky. It's safe to say that I'd come back here if I was in the area. We ordered a lot of dishes, all had large portions and they all tasted pretty well. FYI, I've been to Indonesia and have tried legit indo food, so I'm very picky and critical.

For an appetizer, we ordered 3 orders of ground beef Martabak Sapi. Wow were they big! It was pretty tasty and filling. The ground beef was a bit dry, but luckily the rest of the ingredients weren't. It's a great appetizer to share with others, but I'd suggest only eating one or two pieces or else you're going to get full easily.

We ordered 2 orders of my favorite Indonesian dish, beef rendang. The beef was amazingly tender, and it wasn't too dry, but the flavors weren't that strong. The sauce usually has stronger spices for flavor and spiciness. That's what I love about it. Unfortunately, this was definitely my favorite rendang. 

We ordered two orders of Soto betawi, an Indonesian coconut soup with beef, cabbage, potato & tomato. It was pretty tasty, but again, didn't have enough flavor as I'm used to. At least the potatoes, tomatoes, and other dishes were soft and easy to eat. I was just happy that I got to have some for my meal.

I was surprised to see honey chicken on the menu, and have never tried it at an Indonesian restaurant, so we ordered 3 orders of it. The chicken was sweet! I loved it! I love honey and I love chicken, so this combo just made my day! I enjoyed the honey cooked onto the chicken to perfection. To me, it felt like the honey definitely stuck on the chicken well.

Lastly, we ordered 3 dishes of some carbs: Nasi Goreng (regular Indonesian fried rice for those who cannot take spicy food, Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas (tTraditional spicy shrimp paste fried rice with egg, onion), and Bakmi Goreng (stir fried egg noodle with egg & vegetables), all with chicken. All were tasty with the spices and ingredients, but I loved the Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas the most. I like spicy and I LOVE Nasi Goreng (fried rice)!!

Overall, I'd give it a 3.5 out of 5 since my favorite Indonesian dishes weren't that great at this restaurant. I'll give it another 0.5 stars for the great and friendly service.

Tip: Order family-style so you can try different dishes. The Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas is the best rice dish to eat with other dishes, but make sure you can take spicy food.
author: Kevin S.

description: This was my first time having Indonesian food.  I was not disappointed.  There were four of us and we shared the meal that has appetizers, entrees and dessert at a fixed price.  It was well worth the price and there was food left over to take home.  The eggrolls were crispy and hot.  The entrees were good, especially the beef (I think it was barbecued), but the best part was the black rice dessert.  It was something like a rice pudding in coconut milk.  Save room for it.
author: Sharon F.

description:
Some friends and I met up to grab some Indonesian food here.  Overall, we really enjoyed the dishes that we ordered and were annoyed with the service.  Note that the review rating is specifically for the food.  

Late on a Friday night, we had reservations for a group of 5. A few people in my party were not on time to get to the table. Once we were all seated, the staff seemed eager to get us to order right away.  One staff member especially had a really snappy attitude and seemed to rush us in ordering saying their "kitchen was busy". Now, had there been lots of people waiting to be seated, I would understand.  But, all groups awaiting a table were 2-3 people and their smaller tables were turning over quickly.  So needless to say, I was less than impressed by his demeanor!
 
We ordered appetizers and main dishes.  Each dish was flavorful and unique. I loved the food so much that I would consider going back (realllly hope service is better next time!!) or taking food to go. 
- Roti Prata (Pan fried layered bread served with curry dipping sauce),
  This flaky goodness reminds me of biscuits but with the crunch of fried food! Dipping it in curry adds a blast of flavor on this comfort food.

- Sate Kombinasi (Combination of grilled marinated chicken & beef on skewers served with peanut sauce),
  Both chicken and steak were juicy and steaming hot. I love me some succulent meaat.  

- Combination Spicy Seafood AKA "Seafood Pedas Selera" (Sauteed squid, fish fillet & shrimp cooked with traditional spicy sauce)
  We ordered this because we saw it on a nearby table and it looked pretty good! It's a bit on the spicy side (6.5 on a 10 spice heat scale).  

- Rendang (Sumatra beef stew cooked with spices in coconut milk sauce)
  Perfectly simmered beef stew.  It simply melts in your mouth! 

- BBQ Chicken Curry AKA "Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak" (B.B.Q. marinated chicken cooked with coconut milk) 
  Very flavorful chicken curry! 

- Nasi Goreng w/ chicken and shrimp (Indonesian fried rice with egg, onion, and meat) 
  This fried rice was the perfect accompaniment for all the other flavorful main courses. 

- Mie Tek Tek Goreng w/ chicken + mixed vegetables (Spicy Java Stir fried noodle with egg & vegetables)  
  Loved these noodles! They've got a kick to them, but go really well with main curries.
author: Shubhra S.

description: Absolutely delicious and delightful, and I am difficult to please. The server recommended wonderful dishes that exceeded my expectations in every way. Spicy but not too spicy. A beef-stew like dish that was so tender. An appetizer of fish cake-wrapped egg in a spicy vinegar that was slightly sweet, slightly sour, crispy and to die for. Don't leave san francisco without visiting.
author: Pam P.

description:
I went here in a group to the restaurant, and the food was pretty good! We ordered a few curries, one vegetarian and one shrimp, and both were well cooked and had great flavor. We also loved the Roti Prata, a must-have. We also really liked the fried plantain with ice cream, it had great texture and flavor.

The service was very quick and kind.

Only thing is, maybe don't sit in the booths, because the inside, down below, there is a ton of mystery gunk... I mean, I didn't really want to mention it, but it really bothered me. :( I'm sure your experience will be awesome at the tables in the middle, though! :)
author: G. N.

description: The quality of food wasn't great. The food was alright. I might give it another shot some other time maybe.
author: Sabareesh K.

description:
I won't pretend to be an expert on Indonesian cuisine, but I did grow up in a city with a substantial population of immigrants from that region. I didn't think the food was bad here, but there was something off about it. 

My friend and I split the Nasi Goreng Kari and Roti. I love Nasi Goreng and its many incarnations in different restaurants. The version here was fluffy but lacking in flavor. The Roti was not paper-thin (like I'm used to), but was well-fried and crisp in all the right places.

Service was deliberate and slow, though not unfriendly. I don't think this is the place to go if you're looking for a quick meal, but if you want to take your time, it's not a bad choice in sketchy TenderNob.
author: Josephine L.

description:
5 stars for the tasty food, fast service and being a gem of a place in the Tenderloin! Came here for dinner with hubs and Niket before going out on a Sat. night.

FOOD:
You HAVE to get the
- #1   Roti Prata (tasty, flaky bread with dipping sauce)
- #55 Bakmi Goreng with Vegetables and Tofu (I'm not a veg but it was DELICIOUS)
- #68 Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak- B.B.Q. marinated chicken cooked with coconut milk

finger lickin' good!

SERVICE:
We made reservations on a Saturday night an hour before we got there and we were seated immediately. Staff is friendly and helpful with recommendations.

AMBIENCE:
Nice authentic Indonesian decor on the walls. Makes you forget that you are in the tenderloin for a little bit. Only downside is that they were doing sewer construction when we went and the foul smell kept seeping into the restaurant.

Would come back again and this is now officially my favorite Indonesian restaurant in the bay!

-Hungry Hungry Pongy
author: Sangita A.

description:
To start with,  the staff is very friendly and courteous which gave us a good starting impression. Secondly the ambience was simply great with the decor and lighting. And last but not the least the food was simply amazing. 

Only thing they need to work on is their flooring since it has a lot of footprints and smudges maybe because it's newly created.
author: Mihir D.

description: Saw the segment of the restaurant on "Check, Please" and decided to take a group of friends to try it.  The service was terrible - the host/waiter didn't want to help with the menu and talked me out of the rice table!  He said it was $29 and that was only a one person serving so our group would not get much.  Later when we saw other patrons eating and enjoying it we were very disappointed not to have tried it.  Our waiter,  thanks to his indifference and lack of caring, ended up "helping" us to get redundant entries with the same sauces: mainly tofu dishes even though I told him my friends were meat lovers.  He also talked us out of the green beans scrimp paste.  He was just sour and unhelpful.  No knives on the table, disjointed serving of dishes and general confusion of the waitstaff.  The tofu dishes were extremely mediocre.
author: Ryann W.

description:
I was a bit concern in going after reading the mixed reviews but I'm glad we went. 

Menus:
Make sure you come with your Indonesian friend, or someone who's travelled there and know what's good. 

Let's just say as someone who grew up as half Indonesian, is say their food is decent but by no means better than my mum's cooking. 

We tried variety of appetisers:
- Roti Prata (good and crunchy on the right side)
- Mixed plate of Tempe (soybean cake), Tofu and corn fritters - decent 
- Lumpia (spring rolls) are pretty decent
- Sate Ayam (chicken skewers) with peanut sauce -- pretty good
- Side order of Nasi Uduk (coconut rice) - delicious, I liked it. 
- Tumis Kangkung (morning glory) with garlic - pretty good and crunchy
- and for drink we had Es Campur (mixed fruit with shaved ice) -  pretty good

Service:
We came for early dinner around 17.30 so service was pretty efficient even though they only have two waiters. But the place got packed soon enough toward dinner time. 

You don't really need reservation as they accept walk-ins. 

Bonus point if you being someone who speaks Indonesian. They'd love chatting with you :-)

---

I give three stars only because their food is pretty decent but not mind-blowingly amazing. But if you need an occasional fix of Indo food while in San Francisco, this ain't bad.
author: Viv S.

description:
OpenTable.com and Yelp should strongly consider NOT ALLOWING a customers to make reservations with Borobudur. In multiple occasions we've made reservations through Yelp only to show up and have a massive wait for a table. 

Borobudur consistently over packs the place with reservations. This time around, when we came in for our 8pm, they flat out refused to seat us. They blamed it on the open table and yelp computer system and simply said the wait is 45 minutes and your reservation doesn't count. 

I don't think they quite grasp how a reservation system works.
author: Tawheed K.

description: We were a group of three people so ordered veggie rice plate, Indonesian veggie fried rice (nasi goreng but with no fish/shrimp/egg) and chicken noodles (mie tek tek goreng). Food overall was ok but the quantity was more than enough. We had a ten minute wait despite the reservation and had some difficulty getting a parking spot but that's applicable for many restaurants in the city, so not really a concern.
author: P B.

description:
Having lived in South East Asia all my life I was excited to remember my childhood eating lovely good.

This place however was horrible.

The food was clearly days old and/or frozen.

I left very dissatisfied and will never be returning.

What they are passing off is not authentic in the slightest.
avoid
author: Benedikt L.

description: The food looks good, but this place is terribly understaffed and the service is super slow, like 30 minutes wait to get your appetizer, when the restaurant is only 60% full, plan accordingly.
author: Tian W.

description:
I scored free access to a LMFAO concert and my little group needed a quick bite before the concert started at Ruby Skye.  My friend suggested we try the Indonesian place at the corner nearby so we walked over to try it out.

I ordered the rice plate called Nasi Uduk Lengkap which featured the aromatic rice, fried chicken, honey beef, spicy tofu, scrambled egg, and shrimp chips with peanut sauce.  The whole plate was delicious and I especially liked their basics in the rice and peanut sauce.  For about $11, there was just enough food to make for a comfy meal and the flavors reminded me a lot of Thai food.  I would definitely go back and I'm actually going to try to make their aromatic rice at home with some coconut milk and lemongrass.

Service was pretty good though the food took some time to come out because of the multiple components.  However, it was worth the wait and we even made the show just on time.  The prix fixe meal is a bit on the expensive side, but definitely something I want to try next time too!

Food: 8/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
The bathroom game is not on lock. I feel if you can't keep a bathroom clean then there must be someone running the place that just doesn't care.
It speaks to overall cleanliness of an establishment. 

The food on the other hand comes out fast and looks delicious. We ordered the lumpia, trout fish, chicken satay and prawns on skewers. The lumpia was excellent, served with peanut sauce and some parsley. The parsley made the lumpia fresh and light. The fish was smoky and sweet. Amazingly prepared. Our prawns were also good, smoky and sweet. The prawns came with a sweet sauce but wasn't necessary. 
Both the fish and prawns came with a small bowl of pickles. They were tangy and sweet. Indonesian foods are sweet in general so all the sweetness wasn't surprising. The chicken skewers fell way short of the mark. They were rally bad. It may be that they too were sweet but didn't have any depth. They could have used some ginger or garlic.

Overall I loved the place and the prices were very reasonable. 
I just really hope they could do us all a favor and make the bathrooms worthy of the food.
author: keith g.

description: Super delicious Indonesian food, and lots of vegetarian options!  I tried the veggie rice plate when they first opened at 11am, and was really impressed.  If you're a fan of variety, order this!  You get 4 or 5 different types of foods.  Each was really tasty.  It came with a spicy tofu dish, a curry, some sort of fried starchy thing, tempeh, and more.  Great service as well.  I'd definitely give this a solid recommendation.  I found a new local favorite!
author: Zach S.

description: I was excited to try an Indonesian place after visiting the country last year. Food was in all honestly underwhelming. It's decent, but nothing that stands out from the thousands of Thai and southeast asian restaurants around. Even more so, the service was aloof, especially for the world renown hospitality of Indonesians.
author: Howe L.

description:
So very disappointing. 
Boring.
No fresh exciting flavors here.
The food seemed sad it was so dull.
And I wasted time and money and valuable stomach space on depressing soup and Panda Express noodles and curry dipping sauce watered down to nothing.
What a waste.
Go to Burmese instead.
author: Cheska Tangerina G.

description: We ordered corn fritters, chicken fried rice and yellow curry chicken with vegetables. Portions were large. Service was super fast.  Quiet comfortable atmosphere. Easy to access.
author: Mary G.

description:
Food was good, BUT the customer service was plain horrible!  The wait staff rarely comes to you.  Asked for lemon for our water and the girl comes 30 minutes later for it, even though we asked another girl for it, since she forgot.  The staff that brings out the meal, didn't even ask who ordered the dish and place it in front of them.  It was placed further down the table.  So you had to bring the "hot" plate closer to you.  

The kicker was that they never came back after we were done with our meal to remove the plates and bring the check.  We waited 10 minutes and then we were anxious to leave, so we started gathering our stuff and if we were not decent people, we would have dined and dash!  But told them that we need the check so we could pay and leave.  Took them even longer to charge the card.  

Needless to say, if you could do take out, that's better!  The waiters which it seemed they were fully staffed rarely acknowledge and see if you are doing ok or if you need a refill on water.  Again, food was decent and tasty, but if you want to expect any customer service at all, this will not be a good spot.
author: Maria J.

description:
TLDR: A couple items are good, but not enough to make a special trip for, and don't expect focused service. Here's why:

My wife and came in to see if we could relive some of our Bali trips via indo food. The krupuk and gado gado definitely brought us back. The fried rice borobodur wasn't as advertised (no egg)

The service was weird and unfocused, despite a full staff and only two other occupied tables.  We were greeted and seated with menus upon arrival, 15 minutes later another server came to take our order. After that, another server brought two items, and a different server brought the third item, and other servers refilled water, tea, &c. The sheer number of different servers ended up subtracting from the service.. I can see where a full house would overwhelm their "system". 

Side note: I don't care about externalities much as long as the food's good, but here it matters in that there's not much in the way of decor or ambience (70's pop hits mixtape and a few indo tchotchkes here and there)
author: Kevin J.

description:
As our last night in the US before heading back to work overseas, my boyfriend and I were looking something unique for dinner and, upon the advice of Google + and Yelp reviewers alike, we gave Borobudur a try.

For an appetizer, we ordered the Roti Prata (Option #1) simply because so many previous reviewers raved about its awesomeness - it certainly did not disappoint. The Roti (aka "pan fried bread") was moist-yet-crisp and the Prata (aka "curry dipping sauce") was heaven in a bowl. As a final and incredibly important side note, the addition of the cilantro (which was served as a garnish) took the bread-curry-sauce combo from "excellent" to "orgasmic." If you find yourself staring down a Roti Prata, add a sliver of cilantro to each bite and thank me later.

For our main course, I ordered the Mie Tek Tek (Option #49) - it is offered as a soup or as a stir fry and, although my initial inclination was to order it as a soup, my boyfriend pursuaded me to order the stir fry option as it "would be easier to share." Although the stir fry tasted better-than-average, I would have found it more appealing had I been starving, stoned, or drunk as the stir fry noodles were quite heavy and, post-Roti Prata, I was feeling pretty stuffed. If I had to do it over again, I would have ignored my boyfriend and ordered it as a soup and likely been perfectly satisfied.

My boyfriend ordered the Nasi Padang (Option #54) and was surprised when the beef stew, spicy tofu, chicken, and vegetables were served in several separate, small, neat sections on his plate (he had imagined them all engaging in a food orgy as one delicious dish). Still, each individual component tasted very good  with the coconut curry vegetables ranking as the number one favorite part of the dish. 

All of the above plus 2 perfectly paired Tiger Beers came to a grand total of $42 - not bad for dinner-for-2 in San Francisco.

My boyfriend and I agree that this a 4 rather than 5 star experience simply because, although the food was "tasty," for Southeast Asian food category, it wasn't spicy enough to make the jump to "excellent" - when I see 2 out of 2 "chillies" on the menu, I expect my food to have a little more "oomph."
author: Philippa L.

description: Seriously good food here. It's hard to find Indonesian food wherever you go, let alone good Indonesian food. Their spicy food is not for the faint of heart. Great prices and good service (Theodore is the best!). One of my favorite places to eat in SF.
author: Josh L.

description:
Man oh man... the last time I had Indonesian food was when I was with friends in Amsterdam a dozen years back. We were kinda st-t-t... well, not quite ourselves since we were enjoying some local... uhhh...libations... yeah, that's it, libations. I just remember the swirling patterns on the wallpaper in the restaurant were all kinda swirling, and when all the dishes of the rijsttafel (Indonesian rice dinner) came out one at a time, I think they started to talk to me. Yeah, the dishes. Man, I was so hi-i-i... high on life since I was in Europe. Yep, Europe. 

I think one of the reasons I haven't come back to Indonesian food is that I always thought you had to have a gaggle of people to enjoy all the little dishes. I don't know a gaggle, maybe a small herd but not a gaggle. So here I was by myself after a doctor's appointment thinking I could be easy and go to Pearl's Deluxe Burgers next door or throw caution to the wind and come here. As it turned out, there are plenty of choices for a solitary diner, and coming in at 4 in the afternoon certainly meant inattentive service was not going to be an issue. 

In a peckish mood, I ordered two things. First up was the $5.50 Siomay Ayam, a small appetizer which consisted of three steamed chicken dumplings blended with seafood and best of all, accompanied by a hot garlic peanut sauce (see photo). I forgot how much kick some of those Indonesian sauces had, but it provides a nice contrast to the quite dense, meatball-like dumplings. My main dish was a house specialty, the $10.95 Nasi Uduk Lengkap. It was a cornucopia of goodies on a rectangular platter anchored by a bowl-shaped serving of rice cooked with coconut milk.

Surrounding it were pieces of fried chicken, strands of scrambled egg that looked like pasta, a very spicy wedge of tofu, an overly dried-out chunk of honey, and some shrimp crackers (see photo). Most of it was tasty, some of it - like the beef - which just wasn't edible. The service was nice, always smiling since they probably don't expect business at that hour of the day. Maybe dinnertime offers more consistent quality. In the meantime, I gotta listen to some Doobie Brothers. 

FOOD - 3 stars...good, solid Indonesian for a solitary man, some inconsistencies in quality 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...nice setting on the edge of the Tenderloin 
SERVICE - 4 stars...all smiles 
TOTAL - 3 stars...I'll give it a try once I get a gaggle of friends...do you want to be my friend?... well, do you, punk?
author: Ed U.

description:
I pass by this place all the time and have been wanting to try Indonesian cuisine for a minute! The interior reminds me of so many Southeast Asian restaurants in New York - nice, but still down to earth, and just quiet enough inside to feel like you can enjoy a peaceful meal with a friend. There's also super cool artwork on the walls!

We ordered the corn fritter appetizer (delish), a vegetable curry, and a fried rice, and everything was scrumptious. Service is also great. Loved this place and will definitely return.
author: Shendi X.

description:
This place suffers from Yelp bias. If your idea of a good dinner is something that a 5 year old would eat up, then stay away, and save them from some needless bad reviews.

Otherwise, this place is great. Go with someone who knows the food if you can. If you can't, don't get anything that looks familiar; experiment. You will have fun.

The service can be slow... when the place is packed. If this is unacceptable, consider moving to somewhere rural.
author: Chris J.

description: Tasty Indo food. I had the shaved ice and Bakmi chicken noodle. Tasted authentic Indo like back home.
author: Raymond I.

description:
Spectacular. A top ten meal and excellent staff. 
This was my first Indonesian meal and it exceeded all expectations. I ordered the Rijsttafel so as to have a sample of dishes for the future. I loved the opening soup, all the meat dishes and especially the Ren Dang and the dessert if black rice and coconut milk was to die for.
author: Mic T.

description: Great food! I got #57, the rice plate with chicken, beef and tofu. Seasoned very well, although smaller portion than I'm used to. Very clean and great for lunch. Overall great experience with observant server and nice atmosphere. If I lived in San Francisco, I'd definitely come back!
author: Linda H.

description:
Saw this place on Check Please and wanted to try it, finally got around to it last night.

Food:
It wasn't as different as I'd imagined it to be. Spices were strong, but flavors were not very bold. Here's what we ordered: Sate Kombinasi (Combo Skewers), Rendang (Curry Beef Stew), Oseng Oseng Tahu Tempe (Java Soybean Cake, Veggies, Tofu), Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas (Shrimp Paste Fried Rice), and Mie Tek Tek (Java Noodles - Stir Fry). 

Overall, there were some unique points to each dish, but presentation wise, I was disappointed. Our stir fry looked like scrapings from the bottom of the wok (burnt toppings and broken noodles) and our beef stew looked like it had been sitting for a while prior to being served. All the dishes were on the salty side as well.


Service:
Mismanaged. And help needed. Seriously. 

1. While waiting for our dishes (which took well over 30 minutes for the first to arrive) my thai tea separated into layers between the milk, tea, and water. 

2. We didn't have napkins until halfway through our meal. We tried waving down the waiter multiple times to ask, but he just walked by over and over again.

3. They added an 18% gratituity to our party of 4. I pointed it out and they tried to dispute it as a "weekend policy"...I pointed out the print on their menu which stated it was only for parties of 5 or more before the waitress graciously took it off. 

4. At one point, a man sitting alone (at a table for 2) requested to be moved to a booth that could sit 4. The waiter allowed it, which would not have been a problem if there weren't people waiting....that family waiting ended up leaving shortly after.


All in all for the price and food quality, I don't see myself coming back soon.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I was lucky to stumble onto this place, while staying a place in Lower Nob Hill. I arrived early on a Friday night, and it was pretty empty.  By the time I finished my meal, the place was packed.

I ordered the Bakmi Goreng - the stir fried noodle with egg & vegetables (and shrimp).  The dish arrived quickly and was very flavorful, but almost on the edge of salty... but still very good.  I would come back here again if I was in the area.
author: Amy K.

description:
One of the more authentic Indonesian restaurant this site of the Pacific! I always get the rice plates with the various curries/sauces/rendang just so I can try them all. Service is impeccable as always. I seldom see a crowd - not because the food isn't good but probably because authentic Indonesian food is underappreciated here. 

I would recommend Borobudur to anyone who wants to try something Asian that's not Vietnamese or Chinese. Good Indonesian food is really hard to find here and this is a rare gem of a restaurant in the Bay Area.

For first timers, I recommend the Nasi Padang or any of the rice plates that have a variety of meats/veges (don't get the fried rice - fried rice is fried rice everywhere) - if you've never been or had food from the Malaysian or Indonesian archipelago, I guarantee the sauces and taste will be different from the Viet / Thai / Chinese food you've had before!
author: Mingwei S.

description:
Wanted to try something in the city and we stumbled upon this new GO TO SPOT!!!!!!

Indonesian food? Who would have thought I'd try something totally new and out of the norm. I'm glad we did because the aromas you smell as you enter the restaurant is going hit you in the face and a 20 minute suddenly doesn't sound so bad! 

Another couple eating for their seat with us recommended the Honey Beef! Man I am glad they did because that it is the BOMB! 

Reminds me of TOCINO which is a sweet meat dish we have in the Phillippines but (can't believe I'm saying this) it's better!!! 

Will be coming back again! 

BUT PLEASE HAVE A SEATING LIST NEXT TIME SO THAT PEOPLE DON'T FIGHT OVER WHO'S NEXT!! Lol Minor detail.
author: Mr G.

description:
Borobudur was pretty good, but I didn't love it. I went for lunch and had a grilled fish entree.  Bizarrely, it didn't come with rice or anything, just a big fish on a plate, and you have to buy rice separately.  The fish was not bad, but it didn't wow me, and I've definitely had better Indonesian food.

The worst part was the sambal (chili sauce) on the table, which was way too weak and vinegary to be real sambal.  Maybe they just use a bottled hot sauce?

I'd be willing to try Borobudur again and order something different, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: Nadine F.

description:
Having lived in Jakarta Indonesia for 5 years growing up, I obviously have a bit of a bias towards Indonesia food, which is hard to get, even in the bay area (let alone the rest of the country!).  For that, Borobudur is a godsend.

Last night was my 4th or 5th time eating there, and each time I have walked away neck-deep in nostalgia for Indonesia and the food.  Sate ayam, ayam bakar, bakmi goreng...all done very well, all with a smile, all amazing to share.

I will admit that when it fills up, they could use another server or two - and the food isn't quick. but that's because each order is made fresh upon order.  So don't go if you're in a rush, go if you have time to enjoy your food, share, talk, and enjoy the company of someone special.

Terimah kasih banyak Borobudur!  Tetapi kamu perlu Bir Bintang!
author: Andrew S.

description:
Not really impressed. Saw this on the local Bay Area show called "Check Please!" It is very possible that I didn't order the best dishes, but I would have expected that the ones we ordered wouldn't be so meh.

The roti prata was mediocre, though I did appreciate the extremely large piece of flaky roti provided (more than I've seen offered anywhere else). However, the curry dipping sauce was rather watery and could use some more flavor.

The chicken soup with potatoes was also blah and lacking in flavor. I did, however, really enjoy the yogurt soda with raspberry syrup. Overall, I don't think I'd return unless I brought an Indonesian friend.
author: Ariel Z.

description:
Came here on an unusually warm evening. Parking in SF is always difficult and I wish that they had told me earlier that they validate parking at one of the lots close by to the restaurant. Better call and ask is my recommendation since I can't remember now.

We had a few dishes and by far the nasi goreng (indonesian fried rice) was the winner. It was flavorful and definitely hit the spots among the other dishes that we had. I always say that for an Indonesian restaurant, if you can't get the nasi g right then that will tell you about the rest of the dishes. 

I'd also recommend the roti prata which was excellent. Warm, chewy but flaky on the outside, just the way you like it. That was definitely a winner.

Hoping to come back sometime soon!
author: Ander C.

description:
I went in with high hopes because I'd seen a positive review on "Check, Please" or another source so maybe I was expecting too much or possibly management or owners have changed since the review was given. I was met with a gruff greeting when I arrived and motioned to a table. The restaurant was pretty empty but I assumed because it was a Monday even though other restaurants in the area seem to be doing well in this thriving SF economy. I ordered the Siomay Ayam (chicken dumpling) steamed and after a fairly long wait received three hard and rubbery "dumplings" with peanut sauce. (I'm adventurous and will eat about anything but found these nearly inedible.) I got the Kari Ayam (chicken, vegetable curry) entree which was totally unremarkable and tasted over salted. 
Overall Disappointing.
author: Jeff Z.

description: Love the food but the guy that handles take out orders can improve on his interaction with customers. Always sounds gruff.
author: W H.

description:
I was really eager for some Indonesian food, having had it in Holland and New York.  I found the food to be just good but not great.  The beef rendang was quite rich , but the sauce was not as flavorful as I was expecting.  The nasi goreng didn't really have any character, and basically seemed like fried rice you would get at any Chinese restaurant.  The roti was tasty and fresh.

The service left a lot to be desired. The staff didn't seem particularly interested in taking our drink order, whether we liked the food or not, or asking us if we wanted anything else after our initial order. We had to go back to find someone to take our money when we had waited quite a long while for someone to take the check back.

So the meal was just good, the service was meh.
author: rik p.

description:
This was the first Indonesian restaurant I ever visited - and I thought it was pretty good but my Indonesian stepmother kept criticizing the staff for being Chinese (instead of Indonesian).  Some good vegan options here, just make sure that they are clear that you don't want fish sauce or fish/chicken stock in any of your dishes.

Indonesian food is like Malaysian food - sort of a combination of Chinese & Indian.  Lots of noodles and good fried appetizers.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Excellent! Excellent! Excellent! My parents were visiting from Atlanta and we were going to go back to the Korean restaurant we went to on their first day here. On our way, we passed this place and wow, did we make the best decision. Everything was so tasty and the restaurant had a great ambience where we could talk. My mom got the Gado Gado, I got the Mei Tik Tik, and my Dad got beef and chicken skewers. 

Very delicious and enough for some leftovers too ;)
author: Jessica D.

description: Your service suck!!!! you guys charge tips for $15 without my permission...   The foods is not even delicious.. is hard to find parking.... Mpek mpek not even goods... I will never come here again...
author: Anastasia G.

description: Indonesian food is a lot like Thai. Peanut sauce and curry in everything! The Rijsttafel is a set Indonesian table meal that gives you a taste of everything. Think of it as Indonesian dim sum with a bunch of small plates. It is a good way to experience the variety from appetizers to dessert. I rather stick with Thai food for my money but check this off the low priority bucket list.
author: Ed L.

description: The meals were good, but nothing special.. Service was not so great, had to ask several time for water or extra sauce. It was ok but I wouldn't come back here
author: Alexandra T.

description: My friend is a vegetarian and I am a huge meat lover. So we needed to find a place they provided a good mixture of both. They have really good food and the service was great. The price was good for SF. Definitely coming back. I forgot what I ordered for appetizers but there was this one dish- it was like a flakey pancake - it was so yummy.
author: Dani N.

description:
Meh.. Such disappointment.. 

Since this was the only Indonesian restaurant  that I can find in the city, I decided to give it a try. Don't get me wrong but I grew up eating "authentic" Indonesian food.. I was actually quite excited to bring my bf here.. but I failed to impress him w/ the food of my origin. 

We arrived around 6:30pm crossing our fingers and toes that it wouldn't be packed. TADAA, It was not packed and there were lots of empty tables.. The waiter refused to seat us because we didn't have a reservation. So we pointed out that there were lots of empty tables and that it wasn't busy.. and his co worker decided to seat us immediately. 
It was obviously our first time trying this restaurant, but the MALE WAITER (with glasses) KEPT coming back to our table every 5 minutes saying " ready? ready? ready? what would you like? ready to order yet?" DUDE, NO! WE ARE NOT READY! can I at least have the wine menu??? By this point, I wasn't excited to try their food anymore. 
Later on, a waitress approached us and was very helpful with our orders. The food here did not meet my expectation.. I felt like I was eating cheap Chinese food ... I'm sorry. but I don't think I will be back. t
author: Annie Y.

description: try the rice table has bunch of small dishes it comes with, lemongrass chicken soup, green beans with shrimp paste, reddel curry , corn fritters, fruit drink has shaved ice coconut milk, avg $20 each to eat well, check please!
author: Syrah F.

description:
You get a lot of flavor for your buck at Borobudur. It was so awesome to taste all the familiar flavor profiles from South East Asia and even better to share it with my mom who was visiting. Dinner here was truly a nostalgic treat. 

We started with the otak otak, which is grilled fish cake wrapped in banana leaves. The plain fish cake accompanied by a peanut dipping sauce is a variation from what I'm used to but it was still good with an open mind. I'm just used to a spicy fish cake.

We followed it up with 2 rice plates - Nasi Rames and Nasi Padang.  Each plate had a nice variety of dishes from spicy beef rendang to sweet and sour tempeh. They were a steal at just over $10 each. If this is your first Indonesian experience, consider these rice plates as they give you a pretty good sampling of the complex flavors that make up the cuisine of the Indonesian archipelago.
author: Jon L.

description:
"Have you ever had Indonesian food before, Jen?" 

Finally, I get to try a cuisine with someone of that culture! Now I can go wild with the menu, be open minded and not stick to the ingredients that I'm familiar and comfortable with. 

God knows I'm willing to eat almost anything once. And as I imagined, the menu was completely foreign to me. I told my friend to take charge of the order and even told him not to be considerate of my palate. Just like I would not order spring rolls, orange chicken, lemon chicken, or any  "chinese food modified to the American's taste" at a Chinese restaurant, I expected him to order the dishes that an average Indonesian would order at their native restaurant. 

I'm so grateful that he listened because I was able to enjoy a wonderful meal with some of the most common Indonesian dishes. 

"It's our comfort food, Jen. It's delicious."

Amen. 

The orders:
-Otak Otak Panggang: B.B.Q fish cake wrapped in banana leaf
-Siomay Bandung: Steamed chicken dumpling, fishcake, tofu potato, cabbage & egg in spicy peanut dressing
-Roti Prata: Pan fried layered bread served with curry dipping sauce
-Sate Ayam: Grilled chicken on skewers served with peanut sauce
-Rendang: Beef stew cooked with spices in coconut milk sauce
-Tumis Kangkung Bawang Putih: Sauteed spinach with garlic
-Ayam Bakar Cabe: B.B.Q. spicy chicken in special chili sauce
-Nasi Uduk: Rice cooked with coconut milk & lemon grass

My favorite dishes are: Roti Prata, Rendang, sauteed spinach with garlic, the B.B.Q. chicken and the coconut & lemon grass rice. If you like nann and the curry dip then you will enjoy roti prata. If you love beef stew, then the rendang would complete your craving.

It was a feast with plenty of left over to take home for a second feast. It reminded me of a mix of Thai food and Burmese food. The spices used to cook food in all three cultures are very much alike. So if you enjoy Thai food or Burmese food, I can promise that you will like Borobudur.

What a wonderful experience! I will definitely go back to share the experience with friends who are new the the cuisine.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Three stars for great food but not so great service. My friend recommended the place as one of her favorites in the neighborhood. I probably wouldn't go so far to call it that, but it's not the worst.

We shared a variety of appetizers and entrees, everything had a good amount of heat. The honey chicken was unreal, so tender and yummy. When we were there, the place was pretty full but they only had two wait staff. One of them seemed to be doing all the work. So, naturally it took awhile to get our drinks, food, bill, etc. I would get take-out, for sure, but I am not looking forward to dining in again.
author: Halley S.

description:
Very good food.
Very busy place you can tell its so popular.
Very clean toilet.
Very easy to find.

I rated 3 because the people were not so very friendly, food: excellent! but we weren't so comfortable because of the workers att, what's the point?
author: Octa V.

description: This place is Zagat rated and very nicely decorated. Dinner came to about $45 for me and my friend. The food was good but I couldn't distinguish it from other south Asian cuisines. We had some fried tofu cubes with peanut sauce, some honey BBQ chicken that was really delicious and soft (seemed like it was slow cooked for a long time) and some spicy green beans that were a little on the salty side and not super spicy. They probably gave us "white people" spicy level.
author: Levi P.

description: Sure, Borobudur might be in a semi-sketchy neighborhood but get over it. The food is delish! The paratha and curry sauce appetizer is so money. I wanted to order a second (but who does that?! so I refrained!). The shrimp paste fried rice was good, too. I was expecting a bolder shrimp paste flavor, but it was still yum. We also ordered a rice-stick noodle dish (can't remember the name) and it had a great sweet/ salty flavor to it. Service - not so good. But then again, this is your typical mom & pop Asian restaurant. You don't go for the service.
author: Denise H.

description: I have been going to this restaurant for many years. On this last visit, we waited AN HOUR for our food! 1st time we asked the server, she said it was coming without checking. 2nd time we asked the other server went into the kitchen, came back and said they forgot our order! To make things worse they were extremely rude and not apologetic at all. I love Indonesian food but they just lost a long time customer. I'm never going back here!!
author: Lyn D.

description: Tried a couple of dishes - roti prata and a mixed vegetable noodles. Both were very tasty. Compared to some of the Thai restaurants, the roti felt less greasy and with more chew. The portion sizes prevented us from trying anything else, but we definitely want to go back!
author: Manjesh N.

description:
(See pics)

Came back for lunch a couple times. Food was consistently good.

On a note, the Roti Prata Manis (dessert) is an interesting dessert that was with roti sandwiched with with condensed milk, cheese, chopped peanuts and rice chocolate. Fairly sweet with a hint of savory taste.

Service could be a bit slow especially sometimes they have tour groups eating there as well.
author: T L.

description:
A gorgeous sunny San Francisco day prompted us to forage outside the immediate FiDi area.

Just went one time and I'm hooked.

Ikan Bakar Samudra: grilled trout with tropical spices. When it arrived, it looked like a masterpiece. The butterflied trout was grilled perfectly: the fillet was tender, meaty and spiced just right. Not hot spicy, but exotic spicy. Nom nom.

Kari Udang: shrimp & veggies in a light curry sauce : Scrumptious, succulent tender shrimp with skinny string beans, thin slices of red bell pepper in a flavorful curry sauce.

Rendang: the classic beef dish, sauteed for hours w/ aromatic spices in rich coconut milk. Deeply beefy flavour. 

Coconut rice: very good too.

As soon as you get your food, you can see it's fine quality.

Best Indonesian food I've had; a tad pricey, but worth it.

I will frequent this place.

Yummy food; a must visit place.

Quick service in like twelve minutes.

Decor: lots of windows, go here on a sunny San Francisco day! Nice plates, white table cloth. Otherwise, a homestyle humble place.

Customer service: Courteous prompt service.

The above lunch which fed 3 hungry people was $65 including tax and tip and worth it. We barely had any left over. =)

Tip: hard to park around here; picturesque during the day. Sketchy after 10 pm.
author: Bert K.

description:
Mie Tektek: 8/10
Nasi Padang: 7/10
Bakmi Ayam : 6/10
Sate Ayam: 5/10

Really hard to find parking. I could make better sate ayam, it tasted bland
Nasi padang, the rice was too plain
author: Monalisa Z.

description:
Borobudur opened in 1993. I moved back here in '91. I can't believe I did not eat here until this last weekend. It is really good. How's that for a concise opinion?

We skipped the Rijstaffael so we could pick at the vast and yummy-sounding menu on our own. The Roti Prata was as good as I remembered from Singapore, beef rending was very rich and flavorful, mie tek tek noodles were a highlight, and the green beans with dried shrimp made us think we'd never had green beans before.

Another thing I appreciate is that they seem to have figured out the right amount of hot. The "hot" dishes actually had some heat that lit our mouths up without knocking us out of our chairs.

We'll be going back here.
author: Rick H.

description:
My girlfriend and I ordered no.53 and no.32 respectively.no.32 came out as a soup of beef, potato and coconut mix with surprising delicious taste  that we were not expecting. No.53. Was noodles with chicken and vegie on the side was great too. 
But, did not like the beef meatball on the side for extra on no.53. Thai ice tea was great too.Overall, we were satisfied with the food and service. Must go place for great food.
author: Sailesh S.

description:
I would give 5 because every food item I've tried is epic and mouthwatering, however, the service is kind of not there. The staff is friendly but is in absolutely no rush to assist your table. Last time we ate here we waited a lonnggggg time to get another drink (and never did)  and we came late at night so the place wasn't packed or excusably busy.

 STILL I urge people to come here because the food is truly delicious and worth the wait.  I can't remember the name but I usually get a steamed noodle dish with chicken, peanuts and bok choy. Umm so simple and so ridiculously YUM.
author: Amy C.

description: Borobudur has the charm of old world Indonesia. The tables are set elegantly with proper tablesettings and folded napkins atop the plates. I frequent this restaurant every other week, and I even had my wedding lunch here!! It was a grand slam for me, and the wedding party had a blast with the food and presentation. Yunita the owner, Theodore and the whole staff are phenomenal. They are so friendly! The vibe is a little more laid back, which I love. The prices are fantastic for the quality of food....and the food speaks for itself. Delish!! My favs are the Bakmi Goreng and the spicy eggplant! There are wonderful options here for pescatarians and vegetarians, as well as meat eaters. I highly recommend this cozy, quaint, warm and charming restaurant!
author: Megan N.

description:
I think I know Indonesian food decently well-- I have visited Malaysia more times than I can count, once lived in Singapore for a bit, and made my third trip to Bali this past summer.  I really love this food-- and with Bali fresh in my mind, was craving some good Indonesian eats.

Unfortunately for me, Indonesian restaurants (and Malaysian, for that matter) are few and far between in San Francisco and in the Bay Area in general.  Borobudur's been around forever and not too far off from my apartment, so thought we'd give it a try.

Out of the dishes we ordered, beef rendang was easily the best.  It was actually really authentic- way cooked down beef that falls apart on the fork, in a dry curry with the perfect proportion of spices.  This with a bowl of rice is total comfort food.
