Other items were not so great.  The recommended veggies (spinach and tofu) had so much belachan that it overwhelmed the entire dish.  The grilled fish marinated in dried spices with "Indonesian salsa" was disappointing too.  The marinade tasted more like bottled sweet and sour sauce, and the salsa wasn't very interesting either. At this point I was really missing all of the delicious sambals that come with every meal in Indonesia.  (I asked about sambal and the waiter said they were out.)

So...the worst for last...dessert.  Why we ordered this, I don't know:  grilled banana with cheese and chocolate.  An adventurous thought, maybe?  What arrived was actually half a plantain absolutely smothered in shredded, unmelted cheddar, drizzled with chocolate sauce and topped with waxy chocolate sprinkles.  It tasted about as appetizing as it sounds.   Do not get this!

A little over $60 for two people made for a mildly overpriced experiment.  I'd like to come back for more rendang and maybe to try some appetizers like the fried tempe or otak otak, but really....probably won't be rushing back anytime soon.
author: Joanne G.

description:
Can't quite remember what we tried - honey beef, spicy chicken, and a noodle dish. 

The honey beef was a recommendation from someone I met earlier that evening, but it was not what I expected at all. This was my first experience with Indonesian food and the beef was really dry. I'm not sure if this is how Indonesian food is prepared, but it is not a dish I would order again. 

The spicy chicken was on the bone (maybe a thigh?) and good. 

The noodle dish was also decent, a little on the sweet side. 

The menu had a lot to offer, so I would definitely come back and explore other items.
author: NickJess S.

description:
My boyfriend and I wanted to try something new, so we hit up this Indonesian spot for a spin.

They immediately seated us around 7:30pm on a Friday night. 

We ordered the prata roti, a vegetable fried rice dish (#64), and the vegetable rice plate.

The food came out within reasonable time. The prata roti was okay, the sauce that came with it was so-so. My boyfriend's fried rice dish was spicy but not so flavorful is my opinion. I think he should have ordered something else, maybe a more unfamiliar Indonesian dish. My rice plate had cute presentation - the rice was formed into a small replica of Borobudur! I liked the small dish with tofu in red sauce on it, and the crispy cakes on it had a unique flavor. The other things on the plate were okay.

Price tag came out to 35$ for one appetizer and two entrees, which is reasonable.
author: McKenzie C.

description:
Service was great and the restaurant is clean and well organized with reasonable prices for the amount of food but the there is really nothing spectacular here. 

The food is good but not great and with over 4,000 restaurants in the city there is no need to go back.  In Hayward this would be a gem of a find but this isn't the East Bay.

Its not bad so if you are on your phone sitting in the restaurant reading this there is no need to run.
author: Justin S.

description:
My first time trying Indonesian food was at this place while we were out for a little weekend getaway.  I came here twice in a row because the food was amazing. 

My favorite is the honey chicken. It looks like regular fried chicken so I didn't really try it at first since I was busy trying everything else. Biggest mistake ever! When I finally tried it at the end of dinner, I was shocked at how juicy and tasty it was. It wasn't too sweet either. I was so full that I wish I ate that in the beginning instead. 

I also tried this drink that had condensed milk in it and it was sooooo good. I forgot the name of it.  But I would definitely recommend that. 

Most dishes that we had, had a peanutty taste. Didn't have a dish that I didn't like. 

I need to find a good spot in LA that has honey chicken!
author: Joyce M.

description:
A taste of Indonesia.. We came here for the Nasi Goreng, loved it in Bali. This place has been here forever but still
faulters on service. Food was ok, not amazing. Can't wait to go back to Bali for the real stuff. 
The Rijsttafel at Bumbu Bali, Indonesia is on another planet compared to what they serve here.

Picks:
Roti prata ($7.50) is one of the Best we have had. Hot and Huge. This is Malaysian not Indonesian!

Nasi Goreng Ayam ($9.95) was a large portion. Decent flavor but not much chicken.

OK:
Ayam Goreng Kalasan ($11.95) was recommended by server. Tender fall off the bone meat, but not very flavorful.

Pans:
None


Overall - Good
Food - Good
Decor - Good
Service - Fair
Value - Good

Would we come back - Maybe
author: Ellen H.

description: Decent spot, came here for the rijstaffel which is a great sampling of many dishes.  Flavorful dishes and a great dessert with the rice pudding which is ristebrej in Dutch... Will come back.  the house wine is fine and very reasonably priced.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Best Indonesian food I've ever had. The staff was friendly and attentive. The food was a bit slow to get to my table but well worth the wait. Came here for dinner with a friend on a rainy day so we kind of stayed longer til the rain slowed down lol. 
I recommend this place for anyone into Indonesian food very worth the bart or car ride :3 parking always sucks in the city but that ok. :3
author: Joji V.

description: Was here on a whim over the weekend. i wish I would have seen the food safety warning before I went in! Even so, the food is just ok, nothing special. The satay was fatty, which is strange for chicken breast. Service was extremely slow and erratic. But the worst was the bathrooms. Just gross! If the bathrooms are kept this dirty, imagine what the kitchen might look like.
author: Fannie B.

description: Probably one of the best Indonesian restaurant I've had in the U.S. I grew up in Indonesia and this place is the closest to my family's home-cooked meals. Friendly servant and decent price! Legit sambal terasi. My favorites are: siomay kukus, empek-empek, Mie tek-tek and ayam kalasan (honey chicken).
author: Intan K.

description: I came here for a work lunch and was excited to try it out. I spent a month in Indonesia when I was younger and loved the food.  We did a family style of ordering which was good because I was able to try a lot of different things but I love really spicy food so I wasn't able to get that in this trip.  Everything we tasted was delicious and I really loved the gado gado.  I will be back to try something spicy really soon!  The service was great.  We were a large party of about 15 and she definitely did a great job in accommodating us. The place is small so make a reservation.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Excellent food, good prices.  We had the Redeng Beef, Honey Chicken, Water Spinach with garlic, Sauteed shrimp.  All were good.  

The rice was a little dry and service was a little slow.  We were here on a Sunday night that was fairly busy.  They only had 2 servers.
author: Tracy D.

description:
Exceeds expectations!

I was recommended this place by a local during my stay, and I'm so glad I was- I've eaten here 3 times in 5 days (and the meals are big enough that you can get two meals out of them!). 

The chicken is always lovely and never fatty or gristle-y; something that normally makes me wary of ordering chicken dishes. I've had the Bakmi Goreng and the Kari Ayam and would definitely recommend both. YUM!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Holy Cow.  It is a shame that this is my first Indonesian eating experience.  Here are the issues:

1. Took forever to be seated.  After that, took forever to be brought a menu.  I will say that the food did come out quickly after I placed my order.

2. Utensils and napkins came out AFTER I got my food and had to walk up to the front to get napkins.

3. I ordered a dish on the menu with two spicy chilies beside is listing, to denote that the dish was spicy.  After I received it, it was less spicy than a cheeseburger from McDonald's.  Which, obviously, isn't spicy at all.  After being asked how everything was and responding that my spicy dish didn't taste spicy, I was met with:

"We don't do spicy...  If customers want to spice up their food, they can use the chili sauce on the table."

What the bloody hell?!? So why the chili marks on the menu?  That makes NO sense.  So either someone is lying or they need a new menu design.  I don't know which.

4. Table cloths were soiled in some places (you screw up in a few places, then I start to notice EVERYTHING).

So my experience here was not good.  All of that being said, the food was decent.  Cheers to the cook, jeers to the front staff.
author: Young F.

description:
I take all out of towners that come to visit SF to Borobudur for lunch, and I come here for three things and three things only.

1) Roti Pratha, soft n flaky with a delectable curry dipping sauce.  When you finish the last bite, you will fill a little sad inside. 

2) Bihun Goreng, glass noodles.  This dish is more flavorful and doesn't weigh you down, but somehow has to live in the shadow of it's twin Bakmi Goreng.

3) Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas, shrimp paste fried rice.  This dish is so yummers, but definitely not for everyone, especially if you're not used to pungent asian flavors.
author: Susan L.

description: Service is terrible, super slow. Fried rice with shrimp paste+salted fish is really good. Oseng2 tahu tempe is pretty good. The grilled fish has too many bones. Ayam rujak & veggie curry are just so so. They charge $2+ for white rice :/
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
Pleasant place, location right not he edge of the Loin, so be aware if walking at night.

Food was good for American standards of Indonesian food.  I am Dutch and know what a REAL Rijstaffel is, and the taste is quite mild and the spices used not good.

It was a fun night, reasonable food but not memorable.
author: JL B.

description: I had the nasi goreng kari, which was basically egg fried rice. I asked for it to be mildly spicy, but it was still way too spicy for me, and not many vegetables. I suppose, if you want a balanced diet, you have to order 3-5 dishes - which means eating with a bunch of people. Eating solo is not so good here. I'll definitely try something else next time.
author: Gerald C.

description:
Food: very good Indonesian cuisine, with large portions. Try the prefixed menu

Ambience: nice corner location but very loud

Service: slow, made us fill our own to-go containers (tacky)
author: James M.

description:
I've gone here a few more times and every time it's just been okay. I still really like the Mie Tek Tek and would recommend for take out on the way home when your wanting something a little different than Thai, but everything else I've tried since isn't really worth it.

Last time I was here I got the Kerupuk Palembang Sauce. This is just awful. Please don't order this. It looked like a funnel cake made of caulk cover in a watery brown sauce (there is an obvious joke there but I'm not going to make it). It had a consistency of Styrofoam/caulk and was so flavorless. The sauce was meh.

Between me and my date, we had the Nasi Uduk Lengkap and the Nasi Rames. Both offered a diversity of foods, but nothing in them stood out as being very good, while some of the items stood out for being kind of gross.

On the plus side, I still really love the ambiance in here at night. It's not too loud and the dim lighting feels cozy.

I may try it again sometime and order something totally different, but right now there are just too many other options close by that are guaranteed delicious.
author: Vivian A.

description: Roti parta and honey roasted chicken were beyond amazing. Price is a little above average but you're paying for the full experience, ambiance and all. The servers were great and service was quick. The food was out of this world. I can't believe I went this long without trying Indonesian food! I'll definitely be back and would recommend it to anyone! Must try!
author: Erin A.

description: When Nob hill was my old stomping grounds I used to come here & grab their roti prata for to go frequently. Their roti prata is mega delicious, a must if you visit. I was craving their food but omw there I thought maybe I was remembering through rose colored glasses since it's been hella years. But, nope, their roti prata was just as delicious as I remembered them to be. Their rice plates are pretty good too. Also, try their burbur ketan hitam, it's a black rice dessert, kinda like tapioca pudding.
author: Kero S.

description:
Terrible attitude . No idea how the food is. We showed up 5 minutes before they opened for lunch. The guy literally waved is away rudely. We waited outside. He sees us, but never cares to come back and talk to us.

We left.
Won't go back.
author: Prax Y.

description: I had the Rijsttafel (rice table).  The flavors of each dish were distinct.  I liked the beef rendang best.  The wait staff was attentive.  I highly recommend it.
author: Jack H.

description:
Everytime I'm in SF, I try to come here and eat. Being full Indonesian, I can be very picky with authentic Indonesian restaurant foods... This one just about hits close to home. ALMOST. But of course, the food here is great. This last visit i ordered Mie Tek Tek which consists of thick egg noodle, veggies, chicken, with very spicy broth. If you like spicy, this bowl is perfect for you. I ordered combination of beef and chicken satay for appetizer and Es Teler for dessert. The ambience is nice... Great for a date or for a family dinner. Service is quick and friendly... They are Indonesian fluent as well. The pricing for the food suits well, not overpriced. 
If you're coming with a car, parking can get kinda hectic... The tenderloin, or anywhere in the city, is quite difficult to find parking. I stayed at a hotel in Union Square which is only a few blocks from Borobudur, so we walked. 
Coming here made me feel close to home. It's comfort food. The Indonesian culture is so underrated, and the food is something that the taste buds will surely enjoy. I highly recommend this restaurant if you like unique spicy southeast Asian dishes.
author: Laur H.

description:
I went with my bf and we got the tasting sampler deal that's inside the front cover because we wanted to try a lot of things and it seemed like a good value. Overall, nothing was bad but EVERY dish in the sampler had a peanut-y sauce. You'd think they'd diversify their sampler a bit more.

I would definitely try this place again though because peeking around, other tables' food looked pretty good. The one dish every table seemed to have and that looked freaking amazing was the roti prata (did a little research after my visit).

So in short, do NOT get the sampler meal deal in the front. Just order a la carte. Also, while not super pricey either, this was not a budget restaurant.
author: Shawna M.

description: I always have a solid dining experience here. Not really a fan of the appetizers the Siomay Bandung (steamed chicken dumpling, fishcake, tofu potato, peanut dressing) was a miss as well as the Siomay Ayam (chicken/seafood dumpling, garlic sauce). Both were kind of dry, pasty and gross. The entrees were all excellent however. The Rendang (beef stew), Garlic Noodles and Smoked Trout were all excellent. The food was very flavorful and comforting and filled your belly quick.  I recommend this place if you are looking for something that's not Thai, Chinese or Indian but a crazy mix of everything. Love it!
author: Debbie C.

description:
For dinner here 2 weeks ago we had the satay ayam (chicken), ikan bakar samudra (trout) and jasmine rice. All were excellent!

The place was packed - every table & booth was occupied.

Although the overall ambiance was not that great and the bathrooms were not so hot, the high quality of the food certainly brings this up to 4 stars.  This may be the best Indonesian restaurant in the San Francisco area...
author: John D.

description: First time having Indonesian food, and I was impressed. I especially loved that they had the option to order a family style meal based on the number of people at the table that allowed me to try a little bit of everything. Well, it was actually a lot of everything. Yummy food and great atmosphere.
author: Samantha U.

description:
First of all, service is super slow and they didnt check with us ONCE if we were doing ok. Forgot to bring our drinks...and then the food, ordered chicken and shrimp frieds rice along with couple of other dishes . Fried rice had 2 pieces of shrimps......2pc.
Food is alright but I will not come back here again
author: Chris L.

description: It was my first time getting Indonesian food and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised! The food here was amazing. The best meal I have had in years.  The Gado Gado, Satay Ayam, Nasi Uduk, Ayam Panggang and  Bumbu Rujak were all perfect.. This food is fabulous, service was great.
author: Patrice B.

description:
I live very close to this place and have been wanting to try it forever.  Last night my boyfriend and I came here because he wanted Thai food and I was just sick of Thai food.  

There have been several comments here regarding the service, but our waitress was excellent, kind, and got my order right!  Woohoo!  The only downside was that we came in kind of late, and after she left, we were lucky if anyone bothered to look our way, as they were trying to close up shop (before 11 with patrons still in there).  I had to knock a star off for that.  We felt like we were rushed.

Now for the food, it was so flavorful and delicious.  My boyfriend and I split the Empek Empek appetizer, which was excellent.  He wanted to take the vinegar broth home with him!  I got the Mie Tek Tek soup version with vegetables (no bell peppers), and he got some glass noodle dish with beef and veggies.  For me, the spice level was perfect, not overwhelming but there was a definite kick.  The portion sizes were large; we both were unable to finish our meals, which says something because we're eaters!  The menu is huge so there's bound to be something for everyone.  I will definitely return to Borobudur; I only regret I didn't get here sooner!
author: Laura C.

description: Have eaten in the restaurant and taken to-go.  Everything has been pretty good, but haven't been blown away.  Decent spot.
author: Michael M.

description:
As someone who is part-Indonesian, it's kind of an unwritten rule that if anyone in my family sees an Indonesian restaurant then we have to eat there. So whilst wandering San Francisco with my family this last week, we happened to walk past Borobudur at about dinner time. Obviously this was meant to be, so we stopped for dinner.

It's hard to find an Indonesian restaurant that is actually Indonesian and not Malaysian or Singaporean, so my dad was pleasantly surprised by the authentic flavor of all the dishes. Everything was DELICIOUS. 

We ordered:
Veggie Sampler Platter (bakwan jagung/corn fritters, tahu goreng/fried tofu, tempe goreng/fried soy bean cake)

Rengdeng (basically a spicy beef stew) - I'm not sure how to describe this other than spicy beef stew, but it's delicious.

Nasi Goreng (fried rice) - I pretty much dislike all fried rice but not this one! There was this special buttery aspect of the rice that made it incredibly delectable.

Bakmi Ayam Yamin Pedas - so a good chunk of my childhood was spent eating IndoMie, and this, this dish was like the best IndoMie I've ever had. I could easily order two of these and eat the noodles all myself. SO GOOD.

Ayam Goreng Kalasan - it's like oven fried chicken with a sweet sauce.

Like I said, everything was delicious. I would definitely bring my Oma here for some good Indonesian comfort food and of course to let her determine the authenticity lol.

Mmm...now I'm hungry again.

Anyway, yea good Indonesian food in SF! And not that far from Union Square.
author: Claire L.

description: If I were to rate this restaurant solely on food, I would give it 5 stars.  There were vegetarians, vegans and meat eaters in our party and there were favorites with everyone.  The Roti was excellent.   I'd also recommend the prawns marinated in honey, lumpia, eggplant & tofu and vegetables in coconut curry.   The not so good was the service.  After we were seated, we had to ask to order drinks.  We had to ask to order appetizers.  We had to ask to order our entrees.   We had to ask to order more drinks.  We had to ask to order dessert.  We had to ask for the check.   The restaurant was filled to capacity but at no point during the evening did anyone approach the table on their own or check in on us.  When we did flag someone down, they were always very pleasant but the extremely slow and inattentive service led to a very looonnnnggggg evening.
author: Christina B.

description:
So finally I got a chance to eat Mie Tek Tek Kuah in both versions. I'd prefer the soup one though. So delicious with a coconut vibe in it. Fried dry version was like a mix between Chowmein in Chinese food and somewhat Pad See Ew in Thai food.

Also I tried Empek Empek Palembang and it was ridiculously delicious. Like I used to say, or I'm gonna say now, Indonesian food is like a whole new world to me and if you try EEP out, you will understand immediately what I mean.

My Indonesian friends love this restaurant, my Vietnamese friends love it, too and so do I. What else do you want to hear?
author: Tran N.

description:
We have been eating here for 3 years. Place isn't very clean and doesn't run the ac.  For Indonesia food, SF has limited choices so we eat here.  The food is good.  

After eating our appetizer, I asked for a glass of ice for my water.   Waiter brings ice with a dirty glass that has lipstick all over it.  They replaced the glass after we pointed out the flaw.  Don't think we can return here.   They have been in business awhile, but need better training on hygiene.
author: Mark P.

description:
We had a wonderful experience, the staff was extremely friendly, such a warm vibe.  The place is decorated very nicely in a holiday spirit, very tasteful indeed. 

I brought my friend who loves to eat too much with me and he REALLY loved this place. I liked it.

So we ordered  the #2 Veggie sampler plate as an appetizer ($7.95). 

For a main dish,  I ordered the #43 Tahu & Terong Baldo ($9.95) which is Eggplant and tofu cooked with spicy chili sauce and my hefty friend ordered #53 Bakmi Ayam Yamin Pedas (7.95). 

I also ordered a coffee and he had a fizzy water of some sort, with dinner.

They brought the coffee first...(?) meh on the coffee, they said it was espresso but ...anyway... The appetizer arrived pretty quickly,  very nicely cooked and a nice little presentation and yes Virginia, the corn fritters ARE screamin'.

Next and right on time, the main dishes were served. 

I actually liked the Bakmi Avam Yamin Pedas better than my own order (but I didn't tell him that) BUT (there's always a big butt Dotty) these days I am limiting my intake of all things floury aka #noodleproblems so I had to just literally TASTE his food.  Now don't get it twisted darlin'-  my eggplant and tofu dish was great, just that I was hankerin' for some noodles and those were slightly sweet and they had a great texture.

The portions are very nice, I brought half of my eggplant/tofu dish home.

We also decided to try a dessert, so we ordered this "grilled banana, covered with a mixture of shaved coconut, cheese (YES CHEESE...no honey, not ricotta, CHEDDAR) and chocolate sprinkles and the hot (not so sure it was actually grilled) banana was all-up-under there. 

Whew I have to admit, when it comes to a  banana/coconut/CHEESE/chocolate sprinkes heated banana dessert thingy,  I'm not as badass as I thought.. I could not hang.  THAT was a big banana my friends.  So my heavy buddy bellied up and did his duty to make a happy plate.

The total for all this fun was only $43 and some change!  

I am going back and next time I am going to try the shrimp and one of the soups, something with egg in it. Yep I checked out the pictures (after the meal, of course, why do you ask) and now I see what I want.  

Now it's your turn, my suggestion is for you to check out the pictures on Yelp of some of the dishes because they are hard to conjure up in "la tet" (the head) especially if you've no idea what Indonisian cuisine is all about like we were.  I liked the place, the service and the food so there you have it.
author: BellaLissa B.

description: Mie ayam was not bad. The restaurant overall is pretty good. Being an Indonesian, I can't really have many Indonesan restaurants to choose from. The menu is pretty extensive, from nasi, mie, veggies, soups, even traditional drinks they have it all. If you want to try a pretty authentic Indonesian food, you can try it here.
author: Fraya S.

description:
I headed to the City for a birthday dinner for a friend and we chose Borobudur, a place that no one in the group had been.  Billing itself as having "the best Indonesian food in the Bay Area," Borobudur didn't disappoint us as it served up delicious food, a pleasant environment and solid service.

For those who haven't had Indonesian food, I would say that Thai and perhaps Singaporean cuisine would come closest in terms of taste and style.  Though similar to those cuisine types, every dish we had was slightly different and the new flavors were part of the fun of eating here.

The interior is simple, yet elegant and we started the evening with a few drinks.  The young coconut milk drink was as expected, but the raspberry soda with condensed milk was an overly sweet Italian soda only sweetened further by the condensed milk.  An intriguing, but ultimately unsuccessful, combination.

Our dishes were as follows:

Roti prata - excellent and as good as any Singaporean restaurant.  Also served with a curry dipping sauce

Nasi Goreng - a wonderfully tasty fried rice that we got with chicken.  The portion size wasn't huge and it was literally gone in seconds

Lumpia Semarang - fried egg rolls that tasted different mainly due to the tofu, carrots, and slightly different dipping sauce

Bihum Goreng - tasty fried noodle dish also with chicken

Spicy Grilled Shrimp on Satay skewers - delicious shrimp with a nice kick of spiciness

Black rice w/ condensed milk - solid dessert

Overall, the food was quite good and the prices were reasonable.  Although many items seem to overlap with Thai and Singaporean cuisine, the flavors were slightly different to the palate, which made for a pleasant and novel dining experience.  Worth a visit.

BTW they take Amex!
author: Randy F.

description:
I was ready to hand out one star review of this place as I had to wait forever for the food.  One waitress, who was trying to service the entire restaurant, was failing badly.  An employee, on an off day, who stopped by to check how the new waitress was doing, saved the day.  He immediately took control of the situation and took care of all the needs.  Although I never complained, he knew what was going on and apologized several times and gave us 15% off.  He was a solid professional who should be praised.  

Food here was very good.  I need to make several more visits to try their other dishes, but both Sambal Goreng Daging ($10.50) and Gado-gado ($7.50) were very nice.  Sambal was a stewed beef plate, which reminded me of stewed dish I had at Tajine (http://www.yelp.com/biz/wtxKmaHAW2mdUSJQ6qBcvA).

I'll consider increasing a star if their service is better on the next visit.
author: トモ T.

description:
First of all, I have to admit that the food here is great and the prices are reasonable considering it's located in the Bay Area. 

I love southeastern Asian food and always want to try something new. And their food is authentic because there are always Indonesian customers coming. 

To my disappointment, the service is not as satisfactory as their food. I'm not being mean or picky at the waitresses, and maybe they were truly "out of hand" at that time. But for god's sake, seriously, they really should pay more attention to their service. We arrived at the restaurant at about 3:10 pm and we got seated at around 3:40 pm. It was not that bad right? However, after being seated, we just waited for another 30 minutes for the waitress to take our orders. At this point, neither a glass of water nor eating utensils were served. So we continued waiting for about 20 minutes and then finally, our soup came up, without any spoons or whatsoever. (Sorry we were so hungry that we finished our soup within 3 minutes :p) 20 minutes later, our appetizer, the Indonesian spring rolls came. So far I could still buy it because I've experienced even worse. What really made me angry is that they never apologized at all. It seemed that they didn't realize that they have succeeded extending our dinner unnecessarily longer. 

Ok, I'll stop here and making this comments super long. In short, their service is really problematic and keep this in mind: this restaurant is also an excellent place to train your patience and the ability of tolerance. Good luck!
author: Colin L.

description: Probably one of the best Indonesian places I've ever tried (I've been to many). The waitress was so nice and very accommodating for our large party. Don't be afraid to ask for recommendations! I'll definitely be coming back the next time I'm in town!
author: Teri N.

description:
Haha another Anita 1st reviewed place? Wow, I should just look at all of her 1st to reviewed places and try them out. Anyhoos, I thought Borobudur was really nice and the staff was very attentive as well. My friend and I tried out all sorts of items such as a stir fried noodle dish which is similar to mee goreng. It was good and full of flavor topped with cilantro and other veggies. 

We had also tried a sampler platter which consisted of bbq chicken, eggs, tofu, rice, shrimp chips and some beef. The sampler was not bad but the tofu was not good at all. It was either the sauce or the texture of it. The roti prata was a hit and did not disappoint. The cons about the place is that parking is bad in the area and you can spend countless minutes circling around to a point where you might want to go home. Overall, a pleasant experience.
author: Danster L.

description: The food is really nice here.  We have eaten at the restaurant at several times and felt the food was really delicious every time we ate. The ambience and service not so much. :)
author: Pepper T.

description: Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas with chicken ...  so good, just wish parking wasnt so hard to find or i'd come all the time.
author: Laura m.

description: Had the spicy borobudur fried rice! Was on the spicy side but that's just the way I like it. The roti was perfectly cooked and so crispy it was large enough to be an entree on its own. I had the coconut chicken curry as well. The chicken was perfectly cooked and so pleasant on the palate. My only regret is not trying their desserts cos we went too close to closing. The staff and very friendly!
author: Abhi B.

description:
I decided to be really adventurous and attend a Grub With Us event, this was the restaurant I chose. Aside from meeting some really great people I had a chance to partake in some seriously good food (and let's face it, this is really why I showed up!)

Our meal was served family style, which was perfect in breaking the ice and getting to know one another. 

Our menu:
Soto Ayam Soup (Lemon Grass, Bean Sprout, Egg, Chicken, Rice Noodle)
It was fantastic, very smooth, bursting with flavor, I LOVED IT.

Tahu Goregn (Fried Tofu with Hot Garlic Peanut Sauce)
I wasn't super impressed with this dish, the tofu was cooked well, but the breading was lacking in flavor, the sauce was decent, I don't love peanuts or peanut sauces so I may be bias. 

Rendang (Sumatra beef stew cooked with Spices in Coconut Milk Sauce)
YUM. The beef was pull apart tender, the spices were flavourful, not spicy and the coconut sause added a nice texture.

Tahu & Terong Balado (Egplant & Tofu cooked in Spicy Chili)
Boy was it SPICY, this dish had more then spice though, it had good, hot flavour. Sadly, the eggplant was a little overcooked in my opinion, the tofu was great.

Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak (BBQ chicken w/ spicy coconut sauce)
This was probably my favorite dish of the meal. The chicken was on the bone, booked perfectly, was super juicy and had a great, flavor and spice that was cut by the sweetness of the Coconut Milk Sauce.. WINNER.

Kari Udang (Shrimp & Veggies in Coconut Curry Sauce)
Here we had a very simple dish, I wish I had taken a photo because it was beautiful, colourful, bright, light, it was just so pretty! And it tasted wonderful as well. It was soft in flavor, the shrimp were not over or under cooked, the veggies where crisp yet soft and that coconut curry sauce was to die for.

Bubur Ketan Hitam (Black sweet rice w/ fresh coconut milk)
Wow... Wow... Wow... I could have eaten 5 servings of this. I loved that I was given a small bowl with the rice on the bottom and coconut milk on top and was expected to mix it myself, this allowed us to watch the transformation, the rice was hot and heated up the milk, once mixed it looked like chunky slightly melted chocolate and it was HEAVEN in my mouth. The Texture this dish had was really great, slightly chew, milky, pudding like as it started to cool down and the flavor was sweet, the perfect ending to a flavor filled meal!

Parking was easy on a Monday around 6:30PM, I nabbed a spot just a few blocks away.

Yep, I would totally go here again.
author: Meghan L.

description: The Roti Prata is delicious, DEFINITELY order it. We also got the Bakmi Goreng Kari (noodle dish) and Tahu & Terong Belado (tofu and eggplant). Kind of like Thai food, but not quite. It was flavorful and satisfying, but not particularly unusual -- they tasted similar to other Asian-cuisine dishes I've had around town. Also, service was VERY slow. So overall, not a standout, but fine and inexpensive. I'd go back just for the Roti Prata!
author: Gaelen X.

description:
Fortunately the restaurant has good decorations. That was great for me to admire, while waiting for over 15 minutes to have the menu delivered to the table. It was another 15 minutes of staring at the decorations and rereading the menu several times before my order was taken.

In comparison, the table next to us arrived about 5 minutes later, and received service immediately. They finished their meals when one of our main course finally arrived. We had five people in our party, by the time everyone's meal arrived, about one hour has already passed. By that time the other table were leaving, having enjoyed their food. Other new customers seemed to suffer similar or worse fate than us. 

The food that we ordered was authentic enough. Had it not for the preferential treatment to their repeat customers (just my guess from their conversation), I would recommend this restaurant for any new customers. As it stands, if you are a new customer, prepare to be ignored for awhile, and wait for over an hour for your meal to arrive at your table. 

In short, it was a very slow service (not a star), but the food was ok (three stars).
author: Freddy S.

description:
Service is horribly slow and inattentive. First they couldn't find my reservation, nor did they have a table. Since then we have been trying to get someones attention and food was also just so so. Right now, I am sitting here staring at the dishes from the previous course, not sure if I should start eating the dessert or beg for someone to clean the table.

And the hygiene. I guess there is a reason for their 85/100.

I am not coming back.
author: Arnie V.

description:
I admit it is hard to emulate authentic Indonesian food where you are not in Indonesia. Also, since Indonesia is a big country, one dish with the same name can be made differently in different parts of Indonesia (i.e. gado-gado, sayur asem). 

Anyway, here are some dishes that I would like to recommend to any first timer:
- Siomay Ayam (just like typical Chinese shu mai, but a lot more flavor)
- Veggie Sampler platter (a good option for vegetarians. While you can find any fried tofu in any Asian restaurants, I go for the fried corn fritter and fried tempeh. Dang! I miss my mom's)
- Lumpia Semarang (similar to its cousin from the Philippines, but with peanut sauce.)
- Soto Ayam 
- All satays
- Udang Bakar cabe
- Rendang
- Empal Goreng ( a must try)
- All rice plate, especially: Nasi Uduk lengkap (a must try. A good dish if you want to try different things in one plate), nasi rames, and veggie rice plate
- all noodles, especially: mie tek tek kuah in cold weather
- ayam goreng kalasan

Note: Some of these dishes may not be as authentic as you can get, but they are pretty good. Also, service can be mediocre, best to avoid going on Friday/Saturday nights.
author: Dhian Ayu R.

description: First time at an Indonesian restaurant so I don't have comparisons, but we loved the spicy fried chicken and garlic spinach. Prices reasonable. Weird 70s ballads on Muzak. Can't decide if that added to or detracted from the charm.
author: Rosemary G.

description:
Mouth O's! Walked in because the burger joint we wanted to check out next door was packed out the door. This place was busy too and were we surprised. I have no clue what good Indonesian food is, but I know what momma likes and momma likes this. 

Food: Few things in life are better than meat and chicken in rich, flavorful, spicy and curried sauces. We ordered the roti which is like a fluffed up, crispy, fried yet squishy bread that is similar to a Chinese onion pancake, but better. It was a huge portion that could have fed 4 if we weren't so damn hungry and natural gluttonous. It also came with a very pleasant curry dipping sauce. We also got an item that looked like egg rolls that were filled with beef, egg and onions. Not bad, but will pass next time. The stars of the night were the honey beef and spicy chicken curry. The beef was not as saucy or sweet as I had anticipated, but it was extremely tender and flavorful. Good because FANTASTIC after pouring that magic sauce from the roti all over it. That meat just soaked it all up and it was delicious. 

Someone please tell me what Indonesian food is known for where to get a good sampling of it. I'm just going on my taste buds and my taste buds are saying this is pretty damn good.
author: Vanessa Y.

description:
Great Spicy Soup! Great Tea! 

Friendly Staff. Would encourage anyone looking for Indonesian food to go here.
author: Chris C.

description:
I've gone to this place on multiple occasions and have ordered various things. I've never had something that I didn't like, but here are some of my favorites:

-HONEY CHICKEN is a must! This is the first thing I think of when I go to this place. I normally hate ordering chicken at restaurants because chicken is usually bland and not cooked right. However, the honey chicken is flavorful and tender. It falls right off the bone!

-I also like the beef rendang. It has always been tender and had just enough coconut flavor for my taste (I don't like too much of it, but I like to be able to taste it, at least).

-Roti prata is delicious! It comes out piping hot and flaky. My only regret is that I usually eat too much of this while waiting for the other food to come out.

Food has always been consistent; service has been variable.
author: Angela K.

description: I lived in SE Asia for 2 years, and really enjoyed Borobudur. It's inexpensive, solid food.
author: Dimple B.

description:
Not too impressed with the food and prices here. We ended up spending quite a bit on this meal. There are some hits and misses here. 

Ayam Goreng Kalasan/Fried Honey Chicken was so delicious that we needed two orders for our party. Mie Tek Tek is fire spicy and I personally love it. 

Ikan Bakar Samudra/Trout fish was not very authentic. I feel some of the spices are missing and the fish was not wrapped in banana leaves like most restaurants do. Lots of people raved about Roti Prata here, but I think it's just a meh since the curry dipping sauce is just bland.

The big complaint is they charged us $1.75 for each person ($13 for 7 people) for jasmine rice. We never asked for 7 orders of rice. They gave us 2 buckets of rice which is more than we ever needed, and we left the restaurant with half of the rice on the table. I'm sorry for the poor and homeless.
author: Saran R.

description:
3 1/2 stars!

This place reminds me of the south east asian joint called Lime Tree on Irving. The dishes are the same and it's not bad at all. I love how they honor the reservations. Our party of 10 got seated right away especially on a super busy night like New Year's Eve.  

Ambiance - lovely, ethnic, dimly lit, has a wine list, great for groups.

Service - Although the waitress don't know the menu by heart or by  what number, she was friendly and came around with water a few times. 

Food Galore - Below are the dishes that I can remember:

Lumpia Semarang -(Indonesian Spring Roll) . This is more like chinese egg rolls to me. It was decent

Sate Sapi - Grilled marinated beef on skewers served with peanut sauce . - Recommend it!

Rendang (Sumatra beef stew with spices in coconut milk sauce - this was the least favorite dish of the night. The chunks were too big and not so good.

Roti Prata - Love it. Bias as I love all south east rotis. Never had a bad one so far.

Bakmi Ayam Yamin Pedas  - Steamed egg noodle with spicy sweet soy sauce, chicken and vegetable - Yummy

Bakmi Goreng / Bihun Goreng     Stir fried (egg noodle/rice stick noodle) with egg & vegetables - very good
author: Kelly C.

description:
Easily one of my top 10 favorite restaurants after 8 years of living in SF. 

This place is a constant favorite for romantic dinners with my girlfriend. The service is excellent (not just efficient, but genuine), all of the very wide variety of food we have had there is exceptional, I never have trouble getting a reservation there, and the way the place is decorated is intimate, unique, and romantic (candle light!). Try the lemon ginger tea! The best tea I have ever had (disclaimer: I am American, not British.) The mango sticky rice is hella tasty. Decent wine selection at a good price as far as ordering wine in a restaurant goes. 

Take your honey here! She/he will love it.
author: Alexander W.

description:
B- bursting with Southeast Asian flavors and spices
O- original homemade family recipes
R- really dig the beef rendang
O- or the chicken satay skewers, delish!
B- bring a small group if possible, this  restaurant gets busy at night
U- umbrella, bring it just in case it rains in San Francisco
D- decent prices, $15-20 per person if you do family style
U- understand that your hunger will be borobudured in a satisfying fashion ;) 
R- ride the MUNI if you can, parking is scarce
author: Christine S.

description:
We spent the day on Saturday in San Francisco,  &  my wife remembered that she got a great recommendation for this restaurant, from someone the previ I us week at the Travel & Adventure show in Santa Clara.

The food here is very flavorful. For Indonesian food, it could have been a touch more on the spicy side, but all in all, the satay was very good, & the Thai ice tea was excellent as well. This is not a "one-time" visit- when we come back to the city, we will be sure to come back to Borobudur to try more items on the menu.
author: Chuck M.

description: My mom and I wondered in here while visiting San Francisco (we were staying at the Fitzgerald down the street). It was pretty tasty but the customer service wasn't amazing. We were in street clothes and were put in the corner at a rickety table because we didn't have reservations. The server looked at us weird and didn't smile (it was a bit funny). It was obvious after a while that they had put us in the corner on purpose because over half the restaurant was empty.
author: Annalise W.

description: I came here with a group of 8 people, so we ordered a lot of things on the menu. Every single dish we got was delicious! And the prices are very reasonable, too. The wait staff were very friendly and hospitable.
author: Rachel H.

description: Good food, horrible/rude customer service. There were two sets of couples: one that came before me and one that came after me. The employees saw that I was second in line but they ignored me and asked the four other people if they'd like to sit down. I went there to practice speaking Indonesian. When I urged them to assist me, they blew me off and didn't come back for 10 minutes. Finally, one person assisted me and spoke to me in Indonesian, but was impatient. The food was good but I hated the service!!!! Yes, they were busy but the fact that they ignored me to help the others when I was second in line is unacceptable.
author: Dee M.

description:
So I came up to SF with a few cousins, one of whom is originally from Indonesia. We're walking around Union Square and he asks if we could take a break from our 7-day streak of fatty (and I really do mean FATT-Y!) American meals and check out an Indo restaurant. 

Thanks to Yelp's handy Monocle, I found this place. 

We ordered four dishes, a chicken satay, and each a rice dish; mine was the Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak. I had to copy/paste this from Cherylynn's profile...whatever she did to recall this dish's name and its contents, props. 

It was OKAY.....great spiciness but the taste wasn't there for me...I thought the chicken was a bit bland, more like it was wearing the sauce instead of being marinated in it. 

The Satay dishes were pretty good. My cousin mentioned the spices not really being up to par; he said they were definitely substituted with some other variation of locally-produced spices that tasted more similar to thai than indo. 

If you have never tried Indonesian food, and you're in the area, I'd say this place is alright to try out.
author: Brian P.

description:
I recently came here for the first time for dinner on a Tuesday night; I made a reservation for 6pm just to be safe. Very glad I did, by 6:45 the place was packed. And for good reason! So incredibly delicious!

We got the pull apart layered bread (yum!) with an amazingly flavorfull dipping sauce. And the fried corn cakes to start our meal. Wow, just wow. So much flavor, the sauces were perfect. Everything was piping hot and brought to us quickly.

We also got the chicken lemongrass soup. Again, great flavor, huge portion and it tasted great the next day as well.

For our main course we got the spicy lamb curry, the lamb was tender and the curry was again delicious. And I chose the grilled trout. It was such a delicious treat, perfectly flakey the way well cooked fish should be, it had an excellent crispy edge and was coated in a delicious glaze. My mouth is watering just remembering the fish!

The service was excellent, very attentive and helpful, and when I told the waitress it was our first time there she insisted we return and I assured her that we would.

Overall this is one of the best meals I have eaten in a long, long time. Not a single complaint! The decor is modern and ethnic at the same time. You can tell they spent some time and money on their decorations. Even the bathrooms were very clean.

I will be coming back again, and soon!

(Ps. it wasn't cheap $90 for 2 apps, 1 big soup, 2 entrees, rice for 2 and 2 glasses of wine, but it was so worth it!)
author: Stephanie H.

description:
We lived in a hotel nearby during end of July for the SF marathon. I am so glad to find this restaurant to curb my southeast asian food fix!!! 
You see, I am from Malaysia. After 12 yrs of living in the States, I stopped looking for restaurants that serve Malaysian food because none of them are true to its authenticity. 

But Borobudur is close to what I have been wanted! We ordered the soto ayam (chicken) soup, grilled tiger prawns, grilled fish, mee goreng (fried noodles) and I don't remember what else but it is plenty for lunch!!!!  The food was delicious and best of all, the restaurant provided us the Sambal Belacan for additional flavor. I love sambal!!! 

I left SF fully satisfied that weekend.
author: Catherine Y.

description: The food is excellent!  The restaurant is very clean and bright. The service is very good. Enjoyed all of the food. It's a must visit while in the city.
author: Greg H.

description:
I'm extremely picky with Indonesian food since I consider my mom's to be among the best and have had my fair share of variations made by my aunts and other relatives so I was pretty skeptical after hearing all the rave reviews of this place.  

I was in the area for lunch and decided to try their famous rendang and roti appetizer.  WOW!  The beef was so tender, perfectly cooked, and as authentic as my mom's if not more flavorful (sorry mom)!!   Believe the hype with this place.  The roti was perfectly flaky and oh so tasty!  

My only gripe was that my tummy couldn't handle more than two dishes.

I'll be back and next time I'm bringing a small army to try everything!
author: Allison T.

description:
On a day that I had the blues about my weight, (Um, hello 20 extra pounds...), I considered going anorexic... and that idea got old after about 10 minutes so I headed to Borobudur to visit a dish that I have a huge crush on. We have only hooked up once but I can't stop thinking about him. So tender. Beefy. Kinda sweet. His extra juices taste so good mixed with rice. I knew that I shouldn't devour him entirely all in one night, but I did. I know, I'm terrible. I don't know how to stop when it's that good. 

Oh, the name of this dish that I have made a "him" is Rendang. It is a moist, tender beef dish with a little coconut flavor. Definitely get a little rice on the side. This is the only thing I have ever ordered here but I have tasted my BF's food each time and it was great too. 

The staff is nice. The prices aren't cheap but they aren't spendy either. The place is clean looking and cute. Their house wine is a pretty good deal (: 

I like Borobudur and I will be back many, many more times for the Rendang. Maybe someday I will order something else. Probably not though.
author: Liz M.

description:
We ordered the Rijsttafel  to try everything. We really enjoyed sampling everything, as it was our first time eating Indonesian food. The spring rolls and soup were amazing! There were 6 dishes that followed and I enjoyed them all. Two of these dishes had a peanut sauce, in addition to the peanut sauce for the spring rolls, so I though perhaps the veggies should have had a different flavor. But that's a small matter to the amazingly deliciousness of each dish.

And the black rice with coconut sauce as a dessert was a revelation.  

Would definitely recommend trying it out.
author: Kate A.

description:
I've been here twice, the food varies from good to mediocre depending what you get.
- Roti pratha: Very good (but pricey)
- Corn fritter appetizer:  Don't bother
- Nasi uduk (coconut rice):  Must try

Also the dishes they indicate as very spicy, were not at all - quite disappointing.

Service can be a little slow at times, and don't expect attentiveness; expect the typical mediocre/barely-sufficient type of service that seems to be common-place in a lot of smaller south-east-asian restaurants.  

Beer/wine list is very average, surprisingly they don't have Indonesian beer like Bintang.
author: Joey G.

description:
This was my first time trying Indonesian food, and I had no idea what to order. I thus asked for a recommendation from the server, and he suggested the Nasi Padang, which consists of Rendang (Sumatra beef stew), spicy tofu, chicken, vegetables curry in coconut milk. I thought that was a safe bet and turns out the server was right on the money.

All the items were excellent. I really enjoyed how filling the meal was, and the variety of items that the plate included. It reminded me of Indian thalis, except a lot more meat. The food and flavours were similar to Indian, and Thai cuisines. 

It is also a pretty good value for $10.95.
author: A B.

description:
Great Indonesian food in TenderNob!

I've been a diner at this spot for years and in that time I've seen it develop from a fairly divey spot to a nice neighborhood restaurant.  It's a bit more expensive than it was before and the menu has changed a bit, but the quality is still very good and I'm still impressed by the savory flavors.

While I usually go for the same things all the time (Beef or Lamb Rendang, which is meat cooked in spicy coconut milk), this time I went for the Empal Goreng, which is a tender, honey-marinated beef - so good!  I loved the combination of savory and sweet, plus that the beef was so soft...truly something unique.  It arrived with Lemongrass Coconut Rice that was so great and something special.

The service is friendly and attentive.
author: Ken G.

description: After eat here I can say that I am proud to become an Indonesian! We live in Houston and spent few days in SF for vacation. Once we saw the menu, we have one of those moments of "visual-taste-bud-familiarity" that made us order more than we can take! We ordered Tempe goreng, siomay Bandung, kangkung terasi, mie Yamin bakso, nasi padang, nasi uduk, gule kambing, ginger tea for 3 and we finish them all!!! The food came pretty quick with reasonable wait time. The taste is really authentic, can't complain for the service, strategic location, easy to find, great ambience with the traditional Indonesian decor. For those whom keen to try or craving for an Indonesian food, as native Indonesian, I highly recommend to try this place. Borobudur folks, Please keep up the good work!!!
author: Nurina P.

description:
I think the food here is OK. I ordered the rice platter with beef, egg, and shrimp chips or something but it wasn't mind blowing. Well, at least the interior is nicely decorated and seems to go well with the theme. 

And yes, it is a bit pricey.
author: Lily W.

description:
First of, I'm indonesian. But I'm a non-biased culture lover and I'll tell you, I'm pretty honest when it comes to writing reviews or otherwise.

There used to be more Indonesian restaurants in the city, but they all closed down. Borobudur is the last one standing. Why? Pretty straight-forward, they rock the town. The food is good - almost as spot-on and authentic as the ones back home. Service gets better and better - I remembered there used to be a phase when service wasn't very efficient and it takes a while for the food to be served. But now, they are picking it up - fast and friendly and of course, delicious. 

There are so many choices but my favorite will be their: 
- Stir-fried rice stick noodles with seafood (ask for spicy and they'll do the job for you)
- Mie Tek Tek (get the dry one, not the soup one)
- Roti Prata manis (their dessert pancake will blow you away)
- Sauteed water spinach with shrimp paste (or go with the garlic option, if you don't eat spicy)
- Borobudur fried rice with anchovies and egg. Hell yeah!
author: Rika P.

description:
I've walked by this place so many times and have never noticed it. i'm glad we came here for dinner.

The Rendang is so delicious. It is a beef dish/stew cooked in a coconut sauce. It is spicy but the meat is soooooo tender. We also got a couple of noodle dishes and they're both good. The Indonesian fried rice was standard, nothing special.

Don't get the string beans if you don't like fish paste. Although the menu only mentioned dried shrimp, the dish had a very heavy fish paste taste; it was also very salty, you'd have to have it with rice.
author: Terry C.

description:
Came here to Borobudur for a birthday lunch and we made reservations for 11:30am when it opens. Some of us arrived promptly at 11:25am but there wasn't a person in sight at the restaurant. We had to wait about 10 min before someone came to open the door and for some reason they didn't even know we had reservations. Bad sign. At least it was a cute, spacious place that was run by Indonesians (meaning authentic food) and the service was up to par.

Roti Prata ($7.50) - We got 2 orders of this and was served with a curry dipping sauce. The roti was freshly made and soft...the sauce was a delicious component with a hint of spiciness. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=AZNAiobzUo0iIAQ8SJY6lQ)

Siomay Bandung ($7.95) - I thought this was a strange dish comprised of chicken dumpling pieces, fish cake, and cabbage. The spicy peanut dressing came on the side and tasted fishy. Not my favorite dish. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=4Ku9cJ_RPamwrM8vNp78VA)

Nasi Uduk Lengkap ($10.50) - The was an interesting dish where the proteins were on separate mini dishes. The honey beef was a little tough to break apart but the coconut rice was tasty. I also liked the spicy tofu...reminded me of Korean banchan. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=1L8bs96LK4tUFPGbCZ2PtA)

Mie Tek Tek  ($9.95) - This stir-fried entree was too salty but had a nice amount of heat. It didn't have enough chicken either but I liked the type of chewy noodles they used. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=Ps1Fa-xhEiqzkJRHajU_VA)

Ikan Goreng ($13.95) - The bass was fried to perfection where the meat was tender and hot. The dipping sauce went well with it too so I thought it was a successful dish. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=WmaTxs3veXpfLWXiHhqudw)

Rendang ($12.50) - The beef looked like meatballs smothered in sauce when it came out. The pieces of meat were really big and were full of flavor. Yum! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=VsjtMgOLgThqPYpuWy5F0Q)

Ayam Bakar Cabe ($10.95) - This BBQ chicken was extremely tasty...the meat fell easily off the bone and it was seasoned perfectly! I would order this again. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=FSFiy0ghMkusnZ52o7jyJg)

With a group of 9, we had just enough food to fill us all up without leftovers. The flavors of all the plates were very different from one another so come with your friends so you can try a little bit of everything!
author: Karen Y.

description:
Several people have recommended Borobudur, and on a random Sunday, my boyfriend and I decided to grab a late afternoon lunch there.

We ordered:

Roti prata: OMG.  This was the closest I've had in the States to what I've eaten in SE Asia.  SO FLAKY, PIPING HOT, SO YUMMY.  I want to order like 5 of these and just sit in a corner and eat them by myself.  It was delicious.

Nasi goreng: Hmm, it was okay.  Flavor was spot on, and it is probably the best I've had so far in the area.  Tasty, fair portion.

Beef rendang: I like it a bit more coconut-y.  Maybe some people like it more like this, but subjectively, not my favorite restaurant beef rendang.  I like Bay Leaf in Sunnyvale's beef rendang better.

Tumis bayam bawang putih: spinach and tofu sauteed with garlic.  Hard to go wrong with spinach and garlic.  Kind of pricey in a price to quantity ratio, but I would order it again just to fool myself into thinking I'm being healthy by eating veggies at a restaurant.  

Coming from San Jose, I probably won't make the trek up to SF *just* for Borobudur, since we have a fair amount of SE Asian/Indo restaurants down here, but if you're in the area and want something a little different, give Borobudur a try.
author: Laura S.

description:
Generally good quality food but too much of it might be too heavy.

Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description: The food wasn't good at all. The service sucks and it was very expensive. Sad to say--it would be my first and last.
author: Emma Yna B.

description: I love eating here! Their food is delicious and I always get good service. Must try their Soto Betawi (Indonesian coconut beef soup) and Umpal (Honey beef).
author: M M.

description:
We came here with a large group for NYE dinner and the food was decent. It can be very difficult to find parking nearby so this restaurants seems to cater more to tourist in the area.

We ordered mainly different types of chicken and beef fried rice plates, fried flat noodles and skewers.

The skewers were definitely the highlight of the night and the rendang beef.

Food Highlight: Rendang Beef!
author: Rich L.

description: Brought my family (my mom was born in Indonesia) here and were pleasantly surprised. The meals were all pretty close to home. The service was a little hectic, but my mom said that it reminded her of actual Indonesian restaurants back home with a lot of screaming at each other going on. We had the chicken satay as an appetizer and they were ok but nothing to write home about. We didn't see any other satay options like beef, pork, or goat, though. The peanut sauce was ok as well, but could've used a little more zing. The rendang was also good but nothing great. Seemed to be the par for most of the dishes. All good, just not great. They all seemed a little toned down. Maybe that's for the Americans. The es cendol was fantastic, I will say that. Haven't had it in awhile and they made a great one. The nasi goreng was also kind of just ok. Maybe I just had high expectations. The fried bananas as a dessert were also a little lacking. Not bad, just not great. Usually I have pisang goreng with the really ripened bananas and these seem to have used fresher ones. It wasn't a bad experience and I would recommend it for people who might want to try Indonesian food or if you haven't had it in awhile and have a craving, it will get you through. I'll go back again to try some more dishes for old time's sake... maybe next time will be the rijstaffel.
author: Roger M.

description:
The meal was really an adventure for the taste buds and, from experience, seems consistent with flavors native to the general region.

I ordered the prix fixe menu (Rijsttafel, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rijsttafel), which was a very hearty quantity of food. The dishes came tapas-styled in small portions of a variety of dishes. Each dish had a very distinct flavor, and you can guess at the seasoning. 

The dishes certainly do not seem Americanized. My experience here made it feel like I've actually traveled to Indonesia and sat down for a meal there.

Conclusion:
- exotic, novel flavors
- wide range of spices and ingredients
- good value in quantity
- pleasing and tasteful decor
author: Sophie C.

description: Don't go. This restaurant was extremelly dull and disappointing. I ordered roti prata, lumpia semarang and mie tek tek, but food was truly awful. The service was non existence or worst. the waiter who is working there seems untrained and uncoordinated, they never checked on me and i had to ask to refill water to my glass, but they forgot, so my glass had never got refill until i was done. what a service! Hopefully another better Indonesian restaurant will be available soon in SF because the only option right now is unsatisfying.
author: Xena S.

description:
Fried tofu appetizer is like none I've ever had. The softest tofu with just a very light batter.

And the entrees are just as good. So good...
author: Camille R.

description:
I tried a rice plate called "Nasi Uduk Lengkap, aromatic rice  served with honey beef, fried chicken, spicey tofu, scrambled egg & shrimp crackers

yes the food was very good, but the portions were a disappointment, almost looks like an appetizer or child's plate because the chicken was just a small piece of a wing, they should at least give a whole chicken wing, but they only give part of it,  the beef was a tiny chunk about 3" in maybe two bites and the fried tofu was a just a 3" inch triangle about 3/4" inch thick with some chili sauce over it

the small bowl of rice was the only thing that was filling, for the price you get small portions, so you will need to order a few other items to have a satisfying meal, like an appetizer to go with it and the shrimp crackers were tiny child sized snack crackers about one inch in size

good food but they definitely dont give generous portions like other types of  asian restaurants
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: I'm not sure why this place doesn't have better reviews - then again, maybe I just lucked out (or everyone is ordering the wrong dish!) when I decided to go with Beef Rendang. I'm no Indonesian food connoisseur, but I did spend half my life in Singapore (which had Indonesian food aplenty) and I thought the beef rendang here was pretty damn authentic. The beef was tender and cooked just right. Next time, I plan on trying the roti... and maybe the Nasi Goreng!
author: Sarah B.

description: The food is so good here you won;t mind the curt service. Don;t get me wrong, they are nice enough, just very breif in their communication, very much to the point. I have never had a unsatisfying meal here and crave it if I don;t visit often. Yeh, its good!
author: Kari D.

description: We ate here twice in the same week and had great food every time. Indonesian is not quite like anything else. We had the sampler plate, yummy, and enough for two. They have good curry and Bami Goreng. The staff were friendly and attentive.
author: Adrian V.

description:
Fully expecting your typical Southeast Asian type of food (Thai/Malay/Singaporean), I was actually surprised by the uniqueness and complexity of Indonesian food. I'm also surprised this place only has 3.5 stars on Yelp, because it's definitely one of the better restaurants that I've recently tried!

As first timers to this type of cuisine, it was most definitely a difficult choice, but we managed to pick out a variety of things:

- roti prata: A must-have at any Southeast Asian restaurant. It is served in a fairly large quantity here and very tasty, as expected!
- otak otak panggang: BBQ fish cake wrapped in banana leaf. This was presented as small cylindrical fish cakes rolled into three small banana leafs, which were then bbq'd on a grill. Not the crab cake-like "cake" that I had imagined. It was my first attempt trying fish cakes, so it was a bit pungent on the fish smell and taste. 
- fuyunghai/Indonesian egg fu yung: We opted for the vegetables egg fu yung, which came out as a very large deep fried fritter speckled with crunchy veggies throughout. It was served with a sweet dipping sauce, which was a nice accompaniment but definitely overwhelmed the flavor of the egg fu yung when eaten together.
- tahu & terong balado: My fav dish of them all! The eggplant retained its bright purple exterior skin and contrasted so well among the tofu and green beans. The dish was visually stunning and equally tasty. However, be forewarned that this one is SPICY. The dish is doused with a chili sauce. Those two chili symbols next to the entree are no joke.
- nasi udak/aromatic rice: Instead of the typical white, brown, coconut rice options, we opted for the aromatic rice that was cooked with coconut and lemongrass flavors. It was most definitely aromatic and delicious! While the lemongrass was extremely apparent in the flavor, the coconut a little less so.

While we had no room for dessert, Borobudur was a fantastic experience in Indonesian cuisine! The restaurant is casual enough, yet ornate enough if you're thinking of taking a date there. Definitely go when the sun has set, because the restaurant has huge windows from which light pours in, so you don't fully feel the nice lighting effects until the place has darkened. I'll be back here in a heartbeat!

P.S. Make a reservation! The place was PACKED with a wait by 7pm on a Saturday.
author: Mansi A.

description:
Although Borobudor's food is deserving of 4 STARS, it's being downgraded to 3 STARS because of their service. 

We came to Borobudor as it came highly recommended from my co-worker and because my gf and I never had Indonesian food before. We came on Tuesday night at around 6:30 PM. There was no wait as there were only 2 other tables filled.

FOOD:
*Martabak Sapi (Ground beef with egg & onion in crispy dough): It was just meh. We expected something more of a samosa filled with stir-fried ground beef. What we got was a steamed Viet-like meatloaf wrapped in a wonton wrapper and fried. The filling itself was quite bland.

*Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak (B.B.Q. marinated chicken cooked with spicy coconut milk sauce): The chicken was very flavorful and was fork tender. What made the dish was the sauce. You can tell the sauce was a result of a slow reduction of the coconut milk and spices braising the chicken which produced a very flavorful and rich sauce. I love spicy foods, and this dish has the right amount of kick from the chili, ginger, and other spices. 

*Rendang (Beef cooked with coconut milk in spice): The BEST dish of the night. Normally, I'm use to Rendang in a coconut curry sauce. Borobudor's Rendang is covered in a very thick coconut spicy sauce. The huge chunks of beef were SUPER tender and broke apart easily with a fork. Just like the chicken, the beef was braised slowly in the coconut milk and spice concoction which produced a very flavorful, thick, and rich sauce which glued to the beef. This with rice....*Drool*

*Mie Tek Tek (Stir-fried noodle with chicken, egg and vegetables): We ordered this dish after all the rave reviews on YELP; but I have to say it wasn't as good as I expected it to be. It was basically Pad See Ew made with chow mein noodles. Although the dish itself had great flavor from the garlic, soy sauce, sugar, and other spices; the noodles were a bit mushy and the chicken breast strips were very bland and dry. 

SERVICE: Borobudor's service is slow, very very slow. We ordered at 6:45 pm and didn't get our appetizer until 7:18 pm. All this time while waiting for our appetizer, 5 parties who arrived and ordered AFTER us, all received their appetizers and main entrees before us. Ok, something is wrong with this picture!!! Needless to say, we were highly frustrated and was very close to walking out the door. 

After receiving our food, they never checked on us and we had to flag them down when we needed hot sauce or more napkins. 

Service can make or break your restaurant experience. Although I really enjoyed the food at Borobudor; I'm uncertain if I would return because of the very slow service. There's too many good Asian restaurants in SF with better service (i.e. FASTER) than have to deal with poor service at Borobudor.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
We came here for lunch and thought this place is a little over rated. The portions were small for the price. $7.50 for Roti is pricey, especially the roti was not well done (it tasted like the stuff you can buy at 99 Ranch) and the sauce was really bland. 

The honey friend chicken sounded good, but when it came it was like a stew chicken and not fried. The lumpia (spring rolls) were burnt and not that tasty. The salmon was very good, so was the kangkong or konshing (water spinach). 

Overall the six of us dropped $160 for lunch without drinks. Tips were already added to the bill and the service was slow and not prompt. The place had two tables and I had to ask for water refill. 

Would have given them three stars, but they sat us in the back of the restaurant next to the bathroom. By the time I arrived, most of the folks were seated, so I didn't want to be the guy that made every change their seats. During the middle of the meal several of us can smell the bathroom cleaner along with bathroom stench. Should have asked to change table. That's okay, I won't be going back.
author: J. Y.

description:
I went here for lunch after a seminar with a coworker and the food was oh so yummy! 

I would say Indonesian dishes are similar to Thai and Malaysian dishes.  I had the nasi uduk lengkap rice plate. The plate came with honey beef (tender, good flavor), fried chicken (I think it was seasoned with turmeric), spicy tofu (fried tofu triangle with a spoonful of chili sauce -- good but too spicy for me), scrambled egg (which was a very thing omelette, sliced) and shrimp crackers (fresh, crispy and not oily).  The aromatic rice was great (not soggy or dry) and it was serve with peanut sauce (bomb.coms). I definitely want to return and try the roti prata.

+ we were greeted and seated quickly 
+ reasonably priced for SF
+ it's a short 3 block walk from Union Square
author: Totran M.

description:
This place is a solid 4/5. 

Great ambiance in the restaurant, it is very clean, well organized, and has an updated look with traditional feel intact. I've been here a few times, the first time being about 8 years ago. This place has been around for a while, but they sure have remodeled well. 

Prices are a few dollars more expensive than I expected, but the fact that it's in SF, gives a generous portion, and serves very good food makes up for it. 

Traditional Indonesian food do not focus too much on food presentation, but this place certainly tries and succeeds very well at it. Thankfully the presentation doesn't off-set the generous portion sizes. I hate it when they try too hard to make the food look good, but then I walk out of the restaurant still feeling hungry and yearning for more. The taste of food is authentic with a mix of Westernized hint. You can really tell why when you look around at the tables around you. The customer base has certainly widened in diversity. Indonesian dishes are usually very extreme in taste and aroma. That being the case may not appeal to every individual out there. But Borobudur tries to find the balance. So in other words, it is a little "watered down." 

You still will not be dissatisfied. I guarantee that. Try something new when you go here. Don't just choose grilled chicken as a default dish. (Although there's certainly nothing wrong with their grilled chicken, fyi). BUT you know what I mean.
author: Andrew I.

description: Don't go.  Waited over an hour for the food to arrive.  Granted, the restaurant was fully packed but we noticed that many tables which arrived after us received food before us.  We asked the waitress and was told it was coming.  So we waited longer and still nothing arrived.  We asked the waitress again and got the same answer.  Eventually the food arrived after an hour and fifteen minutes.  Was it worth the wait?  No, it wasn't.  The Indonesian food was respectable but not outstanding.  If I was to rate the food on its own, I would give it three stars.  But with the wait factor, I had to downgrade it to a place not worth going.
author: Daryl D.

description: Even though I didn't have a reservation, the staff was happy to assist me and help me to a seat. The staff was extremely helpful as this is the first time I was at an Indonesian restaurant. I loved the Rendang and the seafood I got! It was really good! The waitress was extremely helpful with suggesting great foods!
author: Alex G.

description:
Here's what we had:
Roti Prata - Good. Unfortunately, it wasn't as crispy as other pictures posted on Yelp.
Fried Tofu - The coating on the outside has a weird texture and not palatable. The peanut sauce was very blend. Can't understand all the rave reviews on Yelp.
Deep Fried Chicken Dumplings - Not good. The stuffing tasted like processed meat; hotdog.
Chicken and Beef Satay - Beef was good, but chicken was very dry. Peanut sauce was too sweet.
Beef Rendang - The best dish of the day. Tender beef and explodes with aromatic spices.
Lamb Curry - Lamb cubes were terribly dry. Could not eat it.
Mie Tek Tek - Good flavor, but the noodles were overcooked.
Fried Honey Chicken - The leg was tasty and moist, but the breast was extremely dry.
Fried Banana - Doughy and uninteresting.
author: TopCat W.

description:
Originally headed to Pearl's for some burgers, but found they were closed, so we went next door to Brorobudur. A great find it was! You know everything happens for a reason and we were meant to eat here! =)

Nicely decorated so it's not too much, yet gives a very Indonesian feel to the place. They have authentic food that's simply tasty and won't put a dent in your wallet.

- Roti Prata: chewy, doughy goodness, sauce okay, but not enough curry flavor
- Ayam Bakar Cabe (#59): good, spicy chicken which was not spicy but was very flavorful, white meat was a little dry but dark meat was fantastic!
- Nasi Padang (#53): combination of beef stew, spicy tofu, chicken, vegetables, and rice so you get to try a little of everything. chicken was really good, everything else was just okay

Service was extremely slow. It took us 15-20 mins just to order our food, but we patiently waited since we saw that they were understaffed. The place gets busy so be sure to put your name down on the list when you first get there.
author: Linda C.

description:
Learn not to have to drive here unless you have a pocket full of change and the endurance of a sprint runner.  A trip to the laundromat down the street (with a nice yet scary owner) reconfirms this idea.

A group of us were here Saturday afternoon for an early surprise birthday lunch.  Little did we know it was going to take the birthday boy an hour to get there, so we ordered without him.  YAY!

The waiters were patient and brought out the food as they came (since we were starving).  The roti was really, really good, and so was the mie tek tek.  We also had a fish, chicken, and beef dish - see photos - since I don't really remember what we ordered.

All things considered, the meal was very reasonably priced and quite delicious.  Glad to check this off my bookmarks.
author: Jenny L.

description:
One of my personal favorites in the city. If you grew up on flavorful food (I'm Indian) and like spicy (be warned...spicy MEANS spicy), this place is a MUST TRY! Love the large portions, it's a great value for the price!

*Roti Prata - 4.5 stars
(Pan fried layered bread served with curry dipping sauce. $7.50)
-So good! The curry dipping sauce is delicious!
-The Roti is GIANT

*Tahu Goreng - 5 stars
(Fried tofu served with hot garlic peanut sauce. $4.95)
-I don't normally enjoy the texture of tofu how it is typically cooked, but this tofu was actually delicious.
-Be warned, this, like many other peanut sauce based dishes, was pretty heavy.

*Veggie Plate: 2 stars
(Combination of Java soy bean cake, corn fritter, vegetables in coconut curry sauce & steamed rice. $10.50)
-corn fritter was oily and hard, definitely do not get them individually
0soy bean cake was also not that great
-vegetables in coconut curry sauce were fine

*Bakmi Goreng / Bihun Goreng - 4.5 stars
(Stir fried (egg noodle/rice stick noodle) with egg & vegetables with mixed vegetables. $9.95)
-perfect level of spice and flavor
-they don't skimp on the veggies

*Service - 3.5 stars
pros:
-waiter happily provided extra curry dipping sauce to go
-speedy service
cons:
-sometimes have to wait a while to get attention
author: Neeharika B.

description: I love this place! I've been in too many times to count now and I am pleased to be right around the corner. I have never been disappointed with anything I've ordered and I love having this place in addition to the Japanese, Thai, and Indian/Pakistani restaurants. It's my default place to eat and writing about it now makes me want to go there tomorrow. Staff are always friendly and welcoming too. An easy 5 stars!
author: Liz M.

description:
The food was tasty, but in a city like San Francisco, I'm not sure what all the hype was about. Perhaps because it's good food at an inexpensive price? 

They offer a really good lunch special BUT after speaking with the waiter he helped me customize a noodle dish to the perfect amount of spiciness that I need!  They hit the spiciness, but not the wow-factor that i get from EVERY other meal in San Francisco.
