The black rice dessert is our all time fave & we always order at least 4 to go for our stash at home:)
author: Spooky E.

description: I was eager to try the Indonesian food here, as Boston does not have its own indonesian restaurant. The Roti Prata was delicious and fried just right. The accompanying sauce was also great. The Nasi Uduk Lengpak was also great and contained many different side dishes for you to sample. I really wish I had returned to this restaurant again when I was in SF.
author: Alan Y.

description:
Make sure to make a reservation if you plan to arrive after 6 pm.

Delicious, interesting, lively.  A Chinese/Indonesian friend of mine, from Jakarta, said go.  I did, and it was very nice.

I enjoy a lot of different Asian cuisines, and this one was very interesting.
Highly recommended.
author: Nemo O.

description: One of the most decent Indonesian restaurants in the Bay Area!!! Bihun goreng and ayam kalasan are the must everytime I go here. Love Indonesian food!!!
author: Carolina M.

description:
Came here for an early ('m talking 5) dinner on a Friday.  Had the place to ourselves.  The staff were incredibly friendly and helpful and the restaurant itself was cute and open.

We had an order of the roti to start, which was delicious, especially the sauce they serve it with.  We then shared an order of the Beef Rendang and the Oseng Oseng Tahu Tempe. The Rendang was delicious, very stewy, with a spice I've never tasted before. The Tempe was also great, with a meaty consistency (I love places that actually know how to prepare tofu...) and a very light heat.  We also got an order of jasmine rice to go with it.

Overall, the meal was great, fairly inexpensive, particularly for the area, and definitely think I'd be back.
author: Adam T.

description: I was first introduced to this place by an Indonesian friend. Holy $%^&*, this place has tasty food! I've been here twice now and just love it. I almost want to take away a half star for the gado gado being such a small portion and another half star for the restaurant being so good, but I can't really seeing myself giving it less than 5 stars. A favorite.
author: Dave H.

description: As a Dutchman, I grew up with Indonesian food. I was really looking forward to this meal but, it was only so-so. Maybe there's a factor of difference between what one is used to and something on almost the other side of the world but, I thought the kerupuk ("kroepoek") was a bit odd, the fu yung hai average, the nasi goreng below par, the drink selection very limited - and the service not very good at all. Slow, forgetful (we asked for Sambal and Ketjap Manis; they said yes, brought the Sambal after a bit but forgot the Ketjap; had to ask again), not attentive, rushed. The restaurant itself was a bit too cramped too; one could barely get in and out the front door because furniture was placed too close to fit more than 1 or 2 entering or leaving. All in all, not what I had hoped for and expected :-(
author: Con J.

description:
It physically hurts to review this restaurant poorly. I really wanted to love this meal, restaurant and staff. The food was pretty good and the servers were really lovely people, if overwhelmed. However, there were several problems that conspired to create a dining experience that was almost actively unpleasant. Firstly, it was *freezing* cold on the night that we went in, making it almost impossible to relax and enjoy the meal on any level. (I mean, nipples-cutting-glass cold.) We decided on the Rijstafel, which we were really excited about! We had it with the house white wine. It was ho-hum, but that's no big deal for house wine. 

Unfortunately, once ordered, the hot dishes arrived at a break neck pace on cold flatware. The warming trays they were brought on did nothing to offset the significant chill of the restaurant or the cold of the plates. We found ourselves trying to stuff down some seven dishes before they became cold to the point of inedible. Sadly, the food grew cold and much was left uneaten. Pretty much everything we asked for was not brought without multiple requests. This meal was far too expensive to be served so unceremoniously. 

Anyways, I wish Borobudur nothing but the best. It's clear from the warmth of preceding reviews that they can sometimes really pull it together. While I might be turned off enough not to return myself, I wouldn't feel comfortable telling a prospective diner not to eat here.
author: Delya S.

description: Visting San Francisco and being of Indonesian decent I thought I'd try this place out.   The food was tasty but the service was crappy.    The male server I had wasn't very friendly and seemed he cared more about his local clientel.   I had to wait several minutes before he took my order, then never saw him after I finished my meal.   I even had to get up to the other server ladies so I can pay my tab.   My tip to him is improve your service.
author: Rambo M.

description:
Finally! I went to Borobudur to satisfy my craving for Indonesian food!
It was a one-hour wait and they didn't have enough seats for people to sit on. I came with 6 people and we ended up waiting outside. After waiting for an hour, we got a table and started ordering. 
Very good choices on the menu! 

I love their "kangkung" and "rendang" the most. They were the two dishes that I miss the most from back home. Their desserts had a good variety as well. I love their black sticky rice! yum. 

All in all, it was good Indonesian Food. I won't say that it's the best Indonesian Restaurant in the Bay Area, but it's a decent place to try Indonesian Food.
author: Tessa A.

description:
I was really craving for some Malaysian/Indonesian/Singaporean food.  So searched on yelp, and found this place.  We made a reservation for dinner on a Saturday night, parking was an issue, but with a few rounds around the area, we found something. I was really hoping the 20 minute parking run for this place was going to pay off.  And, I am happy to report that it DID!!
We were a party of three, so we ordered a few dishes to share
Roti Prata- the roti was light, and sauce was truly delicious, not too salty!!
Udang Bakar Kecap - Wow, the tiger shrimp was huge, and grilled just right!
Gulai Kambing - loved that the lamb was not chewy, I've had a few curries in my life, but I really enjoyed this one.  
Mie Tek Tek (kuah/goreng) - Awesome spicy stir fried java nooodles. This was my favorite dish!!

All in all a fun night with authentic indonesian dishes!! In addition, the service was efficient and friendly!! You can tell that it is a family establishment, and they really care about their customers.  I am big fan of that, and will be going back to try some Nasi Goreng!!
author: Sravanthi D.

description: Surprisingly crowded at 6 pm on Saturday night. Perhaps with holiday shoppers?  The host squeezed us into the front near the door, turning the table for 4 into one for 6 (elbows rubbing together.) Roti paratha is a delicious crispy cloud with a rich coconut sauce.  The mie tek tek noodels are delicious, with a kick.  Nasi goreng with chicken is a classic, tangy goodness.  The spinach with tofu is flavorful and fresh.  Beef curry tender, in big chunks.  Accompany it with a $20 bottle of wine.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
I'll be the first to admit I'm a ding dong. I thought, "Wow this is really good thai food. It's not typical thai food." Then my friends corrected me by saying, "This is Indonesian food!!!" Duh!!! My bad!

Friday nights are pretty busy and Borobudur was our third choice as we made our way up Post Street. Without a reservation, we got a table within 5 minutes. The service was kind of slow but worked out in our favor since we had a leisurely meal.

Our dinner for 3 communal style consisted of:

Chicken Satay (good)
Lumpia Semarang (good but looked different in the high tech display in the window)
Soto Ayam Soup (I didn't have any but it looked good and it was plenty for 2 people. The soup bowls are the size of tea cups.)
Empal Goreng (Fried honey beef. This was really really good. It was soft and sugary.)
Mixed Vegetable Bihum Goreng Noodles (Just okay. We were full by then but the noodles weren't that great.)
Aromatic Rice (This blew the noodles out of the ballpark. So good! The rice had coconut flecks in it and was really flavorful. It went really well with the beef.)
Fried Banana (We opted for dessert here since there was nowhere really else to go. The bananas were kind of like doughnuts and we dipped them in powdered sugar. They were alright.)

We were stuffed after all of that. Borobudur is clean and nicely decorated. It was like a trip to the South Pacific. I'd definitely eat here again.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Is it obnoxious that I'm Asian, but this was the first time I had Indonesian food?  Let's just say I'm totally hooked.  It was truly delicious.

-Roti Prata the layers, ah the layers.  Dipping sauce was mmhh mmh good.

-Udang Bakar Kecap were grilled marinated tiger prawn in smooth honey sauce.   Doesn't sound unique, but it's nothing like I've ever tasted before.  Simple, but done well.

-Rendang is sumatra beef stew cooked with spices in coconut milk sauce.  O M G ...  OMG  ... O M G  this was super GOOD.  I loved this dish.  If  you're a beef stew type of person like me, this is a must.

-Tumis Bayam Terasi Pedas  is sauteed spinach with tofu, tomato, & spicy shrimp paste.  This was also very good.  Cooked very well.  Flavors everywhere.  If you don't like asian fish sauce or shrimp paste, you may not like this though.
 
Dessert was KICK BUTT too!!!  Mixed tropical fruits with shave ice, condensed milk, chocolate & raspberry syrup.  It's call Es Campur and is similar to Philipino halo halo or the Vietnamese desserts with red bean and coconut milk.

I would return again and again.  Surprisingly crowded for a weekday night, but you won't have to wait for a table.  Don't let the non-Indonesian crowd fool you.  Food was great and one of the peeps in our group used to go with a girl from Indonesia and he said this place is super authentic.  Ambiance is nice enough for a date or out of town guests.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Good food, terrible service. 

I came here with some coworkers last week. 2 of them had seen a recent episode of Check Please on PBS that featured Borobudur & they were excited to give it a try. You know me, I'll try anything so count me in! 

We arrived after the lunch rush at around 12:45. The place was full but people seemed to be finishing up so we didn't have to wait long for a table. Once seated, we perused the menu, each of us figuring out what the others were ordering so we wouldn't duplicate dishes. 

We started out with the Roti Prata which was a warm, flaky bread that came with a delicious curry dipping sauce. So far so good. Then we waited. The restaurant was emptying out. One of the folks at my table received their lunch. Then we waited some more. Then another plate came out...then more waiting. What was going on here? Lucky me, I was the last one to get my dish, after much prodding of the staff & manager. We got a couple of "Sorry"s and "It's coming right out" while we waited. We figured it was about 30 minutes between the first dish coming out & the last dish. If this were a classy establishment, they might have brought out something for me to munch on while the rest of my table enjoyed their food. Or maybe they could have comped us a dessert or an appetizer or something. No dice. 

I really did like my food (sauteed string beans with dried shrimp & a side of coconut rice) but I can't say I'll ever be back. There's plenty of good food to be had a few blocks down for half the price and friendly, attentive service to boot.
author: Erin S.

description: Borobudur is my favorite Indonesian restaurant in the city. Granted, this doesn't say much, since I can probably count the number of Indonesian restaurants in the Bay on one hand. However, what got me hooked up this place was there amazing Nasi Uduk (aromatic rice cooked with coconut milk and lemongrass). All of the dishes we ordered were decent, but what made them really good was the rice! I remember liking the roti prata, as well. Now, if only they would open a South Bay location!
author: Sarah T.

description:
Lunch:

Chicken dumplings - flavorless lumps, served barely warm!  The peanut dipping sauce was even less flavorful.  Terrible.  Skippy mixed with some chili flakes would have been better than this drek.

Lamb curry - even worse than the dumplings, and also served barely warm!  We love those curries which are so yummie that we use every scrap of rice to soak them up - not this greasy mess.  We love curries which inspire each mouthful to make you try to replicate it at home.  Not this limp sauce.  

Didn't even eat all of it.  Didn't even bother to have it wrapped for a homeless person (I'm too kind to subject them to such unedible slop)

I saw this place on Check Please.

My meal was so horrible that I said "CHECK PLEASE, and FAST!  I'm over this place"

PS -  health department score a icky 86 !  I should have checked before I ordered.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
I had high hopes for Borobudur, and though I had a nice experience and didn't eat anything unforgivably bad, I probably will never go back. 

My boyfriend and I tried the Rijstafel, which included an appetizer, soup, 6 entrees, rice, and a dessert. It cost about $27 each. 

The service was a little aloof and clueless. We had to remind our server about our waters and continually had to wave our hands for water refills. 

The appetizer was a lumpia eggroll with a very nice peanut dipping sauce. It was well cooked, well seasoned, and overall a good start.  The soup was a lemongrass chicken soup with thin clear noodles, potatoes, and bean sprouts. I enjoyed the flavors, but it wasn't that great. 

The entrees came with a BBQ chicken dish, stewed beef, curry chicken, chicken satay,  a tofu dish, and a "salad" with an extremely strong peanut dressing. I love peanut dressing, but the salad was way too much, and not that appetizing served cold. All the meat dishes were pretty good - slightly different flavors, tender cooked meat, and overall pleasant pairing with rice. The shrimp curry dish left a little to be desired; the sauce needed reducing. 

For dessert, I had the black sweet rice with coconut sauce, and I loved it. Other people may not care for it, but I'm a huge sucker for sweet rice and coconut. It's not a good sign when the highlight of a $50 meal is a bowl of sweet rice and coconut milk. 

I had a good experience, but for the price, the food was just not worth it.
author: Andrea B.

description:
Food was OK but "I've had better".

I had the prawns and while it looks really cool, it wasn't to die for especially for the prices.  They aren't sky high but the food quality doesn't match up.  Especially given how much good cheap food is around the area.
author: Z C.

description:
I came here with a large group who ended up in SF from all over the country, so we were looking for somewhere fairly inexpensive to eat and catch up. Borobudur was convenient to the hotels in the area - which was great, since we walked there in absolutely pouring rain! 

The service was very friendly, although it ran a little slow at times. It was not frustrating for us, though, since we were there to talk! If you needed to get in and out quickly you might run into a problem - then again, if you needed to get in and out quickly, you probably wouldn't be going out to eat in a party of 8. 

I don't have much to say about the food ... it was good, but nothing was so amazing that I would recommend it again. I had never eaten at an Indonesian restaurant before, but the flavors and preparations were very similar to Thai/Filipino food (although I did not have a chance to try them, I was excited to see lumpia on the menu!). The house wine was good (especially if you like sweet wines), inexpensive, and a VERY generous pour.
author: Laura S.

description: I've noticed a weird trend in SF restaurants that, when you enter a place, staff will ignore you until they decide they feel like seating you. Such was the case with this place, which put me off immediately. However, the dishes were really great and flavorful, and the Indonesian iced drinks were really nice as well. In the end the staff warmed up and became friendly. Maybe it's a cultural thing? I'd go back.
author: Adam R.

description: I really enjoy good Indonesia food (whether in the US, the Netherlands,asb or Bali), so I thought I'd try Borobudur when I was visiting San Francisco.  It was okay but not great--although there were a few special dishes.  I had the Rijsttafel, sort of an Indonesia smorgasbord with 7-8 small dishes.  The satay and the shrimp dish were memorable and so was the black rice dessert with condensed milk.  The rest, "Meh."  The service was friendly but not very attentive. That fact that several Indonesian families were there when I had dinner attests to the authenticity.  To be fair, I should return and try some of the unusual seafood dishes.
author: Michael N.

description:
I love their Kalasan chicken (ayam kalasan) and also string beans.... also their roti prata.... I think the Kalasan chicken is the best I've ever had. It is soft and feels almost boneless (you can even eat the bones if you want!). The roti prata's dip is too watery although it taste good. Food can be quite salty or too sweet sometimes for Indonesian food.

Can be crowded during dinner time so come between the traditional lunch and dinner time to get seated right away. This is by far my favorite Indonesian restaurant in the bay area.

Warning: service can be quite slow even if the restaurant is empty
author: Cliff T.

description:
I went to this restaurant this evening with my girlfriend while staying in the area.

When we arrived there were only a few people so we were seated fairly quickly. While service was relatively slow the food made up for it.

I had the Nasi Goreng with Chicken & Shrimp and was not disappointed. The serving was large and, if I'm honest, I probably shouldn't have eaten it all - but I just couldn't stop!

My girlfriend ordered a shrimp curry (I forget the name) and, while it wasn't as spicy as expected, it was still a very nice meal.

As I mentioned earlier the service was a little slow but the waitress was nice and I'd go back if I was in the area again and craved Indonesian.
author: Jordan T.

description:
The refreshing atmosphere here makes for a very nice meal, especially with the sun shining in from the windows on a sunny afternoon. The Thai Iced Tea was delicious, strong but not cloyingly sweet.

Roti prata as an appetizer wasn't disappointing, but the dough inside seemed to still be a bit raw. The curry dipping sauce however was quite good, if a bit salty.

The Nasi Uduk Lengkap surprised me when I saw it, because I wasn't expecting a bento-style presentation. It seemed quite representative of the cuisine at the restaurant, though, and was also what my friend and I enjoyed the least. The rice was too dry and well, not aromatic, and the meats didn't seem particularly special. There was also a dipping sauce on the plate, which puzzled us because it didn't seem to go with anything. The spicy tofu was good though - I liked the tomato-based sauce.

The Nasi Goreng Borobudur, the house special fried rice, had a good amount of spice and tang to it, perfectly balanced and delicious.

Perhaps not the most adventurous of choices on our part, but still a very decent lunch. Left feeling light and satisfied.
author: Lucia C.

description:
Funny thing was that my bf and I went to SF to go shopping at Union Square but he wanted to stop by Ryoko's for sushi but while we were driving around looking for parking, we saw this place..yelped it (I could've sworn I saw four stars) and decided to eat here. 

Maybe it was a really unexpected busy night for them (being Wednesday night) but they only had 2 servers and there were 50+ patrons. Service was terrible but we felt bad for them since they're constantly running around plating, taking orders, refilling drinks, etc. The servers were sweet tho, once the place calmed down a bit, they really tried to take care of us. 

Anyway, onto the food...we got the roti prata which was huge and the dipping sauce was great. Then we got the veggie soup, wonderful broth but wasn't too excited about the veggies. For our entrees, we got the combo seafood (fish, squid, and shrimp) with their chili sauce which was crap, the sauce was too tangy and salty that we couldn't really enjoy the seafood. The capcai was good tho, I loved the sauce they used. Our last dish was the beef cooked in chili sauce but it wasn't spicy at all!  I give a 3/5 since we ordered 5 dishes and 3 were satisfying.  

And because we waited so long to get seated and for our food, we couldn't go shopping afterwards.
author: Phuong H.

description:
Borobudur must've read the reviews on here saying their service wasn't that great because the service last night when a friend and I went there for dinner was very attentive and nice!  They were a little slow on getting us our check and packed food to go as we had a show to catch, but they were understandably very busy, and plus, I don't think we gave ourselves enough time to eat, enjoy and be on our way.  

The food was wonderful!  We ordered the Roti Prata (Pan fried layered bread served with curry dipping sauce) as other Yelpers recommended, and they were right, it was YUM-O!  I ordered the Bakwan Malang (rice stick noodle soup with beef, meat ball, fried wonton, chicken dumpling, tofu and vegetables), and that gets another YUM-O!  

My friend ordered the Rijsttafel (a complete Indonesian rice table dinner including appetizer, soup salad, entrees and dessert priced at 26.95 for one person and 25.50 for two).  I tasted some of it (delish!)as I was already full from my own meal - one order of the Rijsttafel could definitely be enough for two people! 

I can't wait to go back again to try some of their other dishes.
author: Maile N.

description: I went here a while ago. I tried Indonesian many times and regularly living in Autralia for some time and been to some restaurants in New York and this is probably the best Indonesian food I had to date in the US. the only draw back was there was a really long wait but I think thats a reflection of the quality of food you get. I wish we had more places like this in NYC. Alot are either take out indonesian or manly focus on the indian elements of indonesian cuisine.
author: Joe C.

description:
Been here 4 times now. First time, very good. Second, not quite as good. Third, ho-hum and last night... I won't be coming back here.

I love many different cuisines and this one was just plain boring. I've eaten a ton of lumpia and if any of these actually stayed on the fork, would have been good. They broke apart into a ton of pieces and made a huge mess. Sometimes, people prefer a variety. Every sauce that came with an appetizer or dish was almost completely peanut-peanut-peanut. And I like peanut. Nothing stood out except poorly. We got the fried honey beef (sounds good doesn't it?). COMPLETELY not what was expected. It was essentially beef jerky and really really tasted like it.

Other dishes were so-so and not that impressive.
author: Chris B.

description:
Indonesian food is good; it was my first time getting it. I'd like to branch out the next time I come here because one of my dishes, the Oseng Oseng Tahu (tofu and fried bean cake with veggies), I didn't particularly care for. The Bakmi Goreng, a pad-thai esque dish that actually had superior flavor and quality to most pad thai you'll get was a smashing success.

Parking can be rough in that area, but they validate for a garage on Geary one block over that is a real challenge to get in, but at least semi-conveniently located.
author: Brian B.

description:
After a seven and half hour flight from New York with only food-for-purchase available (I'll spare you the details of what was offered; suffice it to say that I decided against spending an outrageous amount of money for below-average food), I walked into Borobudar ravenous and slightly grumpy. I was craving something comforting and warm and filling. After browsing the menu (which was quite extensive), I settled on Mie Tek Tek with chicken, medium spicy, noodle soup. Since I was eating at an odd hour (around 4pm), there were only a handful of other guests and my order was filled quickly.

The noodle soup was in a generously-sized bowl and I could smell the warm, richly spiced, hearty soup long before it arrived at my table. The chicken was soft and tender, the lightly scrambled eggs slightly sweet, the vegetables crispy, the noodles chewy and filling, and the broth! Oh the broth was divine. I wound up coming back here two more times during my week in SF, ordering the Mie Tek Tek each time (what can I say? I am a creature of habit ^^). 

If you only go for one thing, get the Mie Tek Tek and you won't be disappointed!
author: Annie M.

description: Decent food, priced right. Service not the best but nice people.
author: J. W.

description: Great to find this open after bride parade! Food was good.
author: Kira B.

description:
It was a rainy Saturday night and we were looking forward to eating here. I haven't had the opportunity to eat Indonesian food since coming to SF, but I finally was going to get my chance. We walked in around 7pm. The place was packed. And from the looks of it, most of the tables had just sat down. We stood in the doorway for more than 5 mins. Not one of the 3 employees I saw greeted us. We waited patiently for those 5 mins. Just standing in the doorway, hoping to be noticed. I would have been fine with the subtle eye contact from one of the servers (this place has no host/ess) with a smile and the thought "I see you standing there and I know you're waiting to be seated. I'll be right there." But nope, we didn't get that. It was almost as if they were trying to avoid looking at us as if saying "if we don't look at them, maybe they'll leave..." 

Finally we walked over to the only available table. A waiter was passing us so I said "Do you mind if we sit here?" And he barked "HOLD ON!"  Did you ever watch Martin? You know Sheneneh? Well... I almost wanted to bust a Sheneneh and bob my head and snap my fingers and say "Oh no you din't...." 

The waiter breezed past us, seemingly angry. Eh... Whatever.. We sat down. He came over a few minutes later and put another place setting down for us, since our table only had one. He then slammed my fork and spoon down on the table... No idea why he was so angry.

We wait about 10 mins and no one ever comes to take our order. We finally flag down another one of the 3 servers. He was the saving grace for this restaurant. I think I've only walked out of a restaurant once. Working in food service has made me extremely patient and tolerant when it comes to dining out. But there's only so much incompetence I can take. When we flagged the other male server down, he was pleasant and kindly took our order. 

For food we had:

-Roti prata - Very good. Hot and flaky. I would have liked the curry to be a little thicker, seemed really watery, but it was very flavorful nonetheless. 
- Tempe goreng - after having this dish for the first time at an Indonesian place in Philly, I fell in love and have been looking for it ever since. Sadly, I was greatly disappointed in this dish here at Borobudur. 
- Spinach with tofu and tomato in a spicy shrimp paste - THIS was AWESOME!!! 
- Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak (B.B.Q. marinated chicken cooked with spicy coconut milk sauce) - This was a GREAT dish. The meat was almost fall-off-the-bone tender. Very good. 
- Indonesian Iced Coffee  - Very similar to Vietnamese Iced Coffee, but not as strong and very flavorful. 

Overall the food was great! The service was almost terrible. I would definitely come back here again, but probably for take-out...
author: Jen D.

description: Have eaten here twice so far. Food is good, but not excellent. Service is very friendly, but not very fast. I'll certainly go here again as the food is good, but it's not a place I'd travel a long distance to frequent. I'd say 3.5 - 4 stars, worthy of a visit.
author: Matt S.

description: Keep passed this place by whenever I visited SF. One day I was determined to try this (I was born in Indonesia, and love the food). I loved it! The flavor just brought back old memories. Service was fast and courteous. The gado gado was yummy and the ayam bumbu rujak was delicious. Nasi goreng Borobudur... as good as it gets.  Price is very reasonable. Parking it's a bit a nightmare (but where's not in SF?) A bit problematice to find the garage first , it's in Geary and not very conspicuous) but first hour was validated if you spent more than $35). Will be my favorite haunt whenever I visit SF!Thx Yunita!
author: Charles S.

description:
My date and I originally agreed to go somewhere new for both of us.  After conversing online, he told me he found a Hawaiian place, and when he picked me up, the truth came out: he'd been to that restaurant before, but in a different location.

So, I called bullshit and made him pick a different place that he'd never been to.  That's how we ended up at Borobudur.

We ordered:

-the veggie sampler platter.  The sauce is really tangy, but it makes the corn fritter really good.  He said that the corn fritter reminded him of PlayDoh, and I could see how the fragrance (not the taste) did indeed smell like clay.  It was good anyway.

-Ayam Bakar Cabe (#59), which was apparently highly recommended on Yelp (he did his research).  It's two pieces of chicken that's roasted in a spicy chili sauce, and the meat is tender and falls off the bones.  Good if you like sweet chili sauces.  And chicken.

-Rendang.  Super, super tender beef marinated and cooked in spices, and it was a bit sweet because of the coconut milk (I was somehow expecting a curry-like dish because I read 'coconut milk' but it ended up looking more like ..meatloaf).  Probably one of my favorites.

-some vegetable dish with water spinach and tofu.  The best part of this dish was that it came with these shrimp chips that I used to eat as a little Chinese kid.  Yum!  The sauce is very sweet and peanut-y.  Not a place for people allergic to peanuts.

-Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas (#57).  We chose to have it with chicken and shrimp, and it was spicy and yummy.  Definitely a fan of this too, since I like spicy food, and this was probably at a "medium spicy" level.

Service is good, but the restaurant was really empty for a Monday night.  I wonder if they're still just as attentive and nice when it's packed.  But it was my first time eating Indonesian food, and I must say, I'm a fan!
author: Tori S.

description:
I'm half Indonesian and I was really looking forward to eating at "The best Indonesian restaurant in the Bay Area", but I was disappointed in our meal at Borobudur.

The service was slow (our daughter's entree arrived a full 15 minutes after ours did) and uncaring (our response to "how was everything?" was a pregnant pause plus "it was okay", but the waiter just took our check without a reaction).

Food-wise, the bakwan jagung was good, the satay ayam was adequate, and the gado gado was absolutely drowning in sambal kacang.

Not recommended.
author: Geoff T.

description: I've had Indonesian food a few times here in the Bay, and this was by far the best!  Good vegetarian options all around and the food was delicious.  Our friend who had worked/lived in Indonesia was equally as pleased with her meaty-dish options, so we'll come back again!
author: Tarah D.

description: Came in with a big party and I have to say the food was mediocre and the service was bad. I have eaten a fair share of Indonesian food in Holland (they have good Indonesian there I swear) and I was excited to find a spot in SF. The food just seemed plain, no nuance and just slapped on a plate. We could not get the waiters attention, they filled our water glasses once at the end of the meal and all dishes and appetizers came out at different times, leaving people waiting and cold food. We joked at one point that maybe we should call the restaurant from our table to request more water.
author: E C.

description:
If this is your first foray into Indonesian cuisine, use the following as a recipe for success:

-- lumpia. A great introduction to the flavors of the meal. Any excuse to stuff our faces with fried!
-- rendang. Thick coconut curry stewed beef shank that flakes apart
-- eggplant and tofu. Fat slices of nightshade tossed in a sauce with a little bit of heat from sambal (red chili sauce)
-- water spinach sauteed with garlic. Light, yet flavorful with a satisfying crunch. 

Order this for two people, and you'll even have lunch the next day. Two meals, two people, $40. 

And the environment ain't bad either. Check out the unique puppets and carvings!
author: Ligaya T.

description:
VERY VERY HORRIBLE SERVICE!!! Me and my friend ordered 4 foods and I asked the waitress what is the recommendation from this restaurant and she asked me back," Where are you come from?" and I replied," I am from Indonesia." She asked me back," you are Indonesian but you dont know what to eat??" Excuse me!!!!! I am asking for restaurant recommendation.. she needs to learn english better!!!!

VERY BAD FOOD TOO!!!
We order rendang, satay combination, roti prata, and the last one is Kari Udang.
Kari Udang: the shrimp is so small and not fully clean!! I can see the $@!% attached on the back of the shrimp. 
Rendang: is just ok..nothing special. You just better buy Munik instant seasoning. much better!!
Roti Prata: The curry is so watery!! It is like drinking a 70% water + 30% curry...
Satay Combination: WAY TOOO SALTY!!!!!

Overall: Avoid this restaurant!!!!wasting your time! There are more better restaurants than this one!!!We pay $55 and I will not come back anymore!!!

And you called this is Indonesian restaurant without avocado milkshake!
author: Bryan L.

description:
so far, the best Indonesian Restaurant I could find here, in the country, is this one. As an Indonesian, their Cendol was the best. I had myself Soto Betawi, and I loved it!

I love the place, the area, the people who served it were so nice. Definitely come to this place again if I get a chance to be in San Fransisco.
author: Fina A.

description: The food and  atmosphere are okay. However, I like complex tastes and the food I tasted was a bit single.
author: Sam J.

description:
i love this restaurant...when i miss HOME and too lazy to cook for my self i go here... THEY ARE THE BEST  INDONESIAN RESTAURANT IN THE BAY ARE... I LOVE ALL THEIR FOOD, but my FAVORITE is BAKMIE AYAM ...

EVERY TIME I GO HERE I ALWAYS ORDER THE SAME THING. I GET LIKE 5 DIFFERENT THINGS AND THATS JUST FOR ME LOL...I BRING IT TO GO.  THIS IS THE FOODS I ALWAYS GET....

1. Siomay Bandung - The best ever
2. Bakmi Ayam with meatball & fried wonton - The best  & My favorite
3. Gado- Gado - very yummy ( for my hubby )
4. Empek Empek Palembang - the best ever !!
5. Es Cendol  - the best in the bay are.

all their foods are very good...they never dissapointment. i love their food n service...i even got to know the owner very well...ive been goin here since i was 11 years old. my mom used to take me here when i was a kid and when we still lived in reno nevada. now i take my own family here...  ive been goin here for almost 16 years...
author: Lily N.

description:
Thank you Check Please, Bay Area for teaching me about this little hidden gem!!!

My girlfriends and I shared everything family style. Most plates were hits with a couple unfortunate misses. But overall it's a great spot. For starters we had the Siomay Ayam (chicken dumplings) and Roti Prata (bread and curry sauce), both were great!! The curry sauce with the Roti was delicious!!! For entrees we shared the Udang Bakar Cabe (shrimp on skewers), Rendang (beef stew), Kari Sayuran (veggies in coconut curry) and Bakmi Goreng (egg noodles with chicken). My absolute favorite were the shrimp skewers which had a honey glaze. It's more like an appetizer than an entree, but I wouldn't go back without ordering it. The veggies in coconut curry were just ok, but I loved the egg noodles and the Rendang. The Rendang is a normal beef stew but cooked in coconut milk, so the flavor is totally different. 

For beverages there is a decent list of inexpensive wines, but since it was freezing out, we all had the hot ginger tea with honey which I could drink a gallon of!! It's delicious and has a little kick to it, but the honey balances out the spicy. 

Overall with tip we spent $23/person. It's a great cheap eats spot for a casual night out with friends. A group of 2 to 4 people is ideal because the place is pretty small. If you have more than 4 just make sure they seat you in the back where there's a little more room.
author: Kandace K.

description:
This is my first time at this restaurant.  It was packed with people.  We ordered the dinner for two.  Don't bother.  Get a recommendation from the waiter.  The meal was abundant but quite bland.  Two notable standouts: chicken soup: lemon grassy/herby and packed with chicken in the clear broth.  The deep fried rolls were good but I think that's because they were fried and the dipping sauce was tasty.  The filling was just so so.

My friend and I eat out every Friday.  Doubt we'd come back here any time soon.
author: Carlos R.

description: YUMMY!!!! This restaurant was super cute and there was super delicious food! While reservations are not necessary, it might be helpful. My husband and I had one appetizer and two entrees and it was the perfect amount of food. I can't wait to eat there again.
author: Michelle M.

description: We stumbled upon this restaurant because we were staying at USA hostel right across the street. The food is good overall, we tried the spicy fried rice. It had spicy curry powder on it and tasted great. Our waiter also gave us the yellow coconut curry on the side which added a nice flavor to the rice. The service was decent, nothing extraordinary. The dessert was the worst part and that's the reason I am taking off a star. All in a all, a place to try if you are in SF and want to have Indonesian.
author: Sanshit S.

description: Great Roti Prata to start for sure. Beef and chicken skewers were decent. Loved the Beef Rendang - another must. It was my second visit, and this time with a large group so we got to try more. I'd say nothing was a miss - baked salmon (several others' favorite), yellow noodle dish, lamb...there was almost too many options to choose from. Go Rendang & Prata in my opinion and add to your specific taste.
author: Austin N.

description: Service of food was sooooo slow. We waited 45 minutes before we got our food. But for some weird reason a table of 15 across from us got their food not even 5 minutes from the time they were seated. So either they were allowed to call in their food upon reservation or just cause they were also Indonesian they got a faster service, I dunno what the heck is up with the slowness?!  So unless you have all the time in the world & don't mind the wait, expect to be sitting there for a long while. Also the food tasted Thai. I told my friend we should've just gone to KING OF THAI & would've been outta there half the wait time. Ugh! I HATE WAITING!!!
author: Jays D.

description:
tried:
roti prata -- flaky, slightly too crisp on the outside, thin sauce but tasty.
nasi goreng -- shrimp fried rice, made me thirsty
ayam bakar cabe -- B.B.Q. marinated spicy chicken in sweet chili sauce, could be warmer, but was soft meat
glad it was authentic but not high on my return list
author: Rob C.

description:
In San Francisco we're fortunate enough to be surrounded by countless delicious Asian restaurants featuring Chinese, Thai, Japanese, and Vietnamese cuisine. Yet Indonesian food is a much rarer find; luckily Borobudur serves up authentic dishes that will introduce you to new exciting dishes and satiate the hungry customer. 

My companion and I shared the rijsttafel - a complete Indonesian rice table dinner for two (or essentially, a tasting menu). Dishes included Indonesian spring rolls, chicken lemongrass soup, coconut curry shrimp, BBQ-marinated chicken satay, and the peanut-laden gado gado salad. My favorite, however, was the beef rendang - beef stew tenderly marinated in coconut milk and spices. I've had this dish all over the world and this preparation nears the top of my list. The black sweet rice with coconut milk was also a good finish to the meal. 

The food is hearty, delicious, and authentic. Borobudur's faults lie in the somewhat indifferent service and decor, which could use a boost. Overall I'd give the restaurant a strong 3.5 stars for bringing me back to Indonesia with its traditional, tasty cuisine.
author: Britt M.

description:
I never thought that the Indonesian cuisine existed here in the U.S. I found this place through yelp and saw that it has many reviews. I am a big fan of Indonesian food.

The food was flavorful and delicious. We ordered the Rendang (Beef), Satays (Chicken Skewers), Gado-Gado (Salad), BBQ Chicken, fried rice, noodles, and dried shirmp mixed with vegetables. Were 5 people and we had a feast hahaha.

This place is a MUST EAT definitely
author: Motaz H.

description:
Definitely a fan. Was here with a four-some and it was great. Service, Food, Wine, all good. 

We started with a nice  mirassou Pinot  Noir ($20)

1. Siomay Bandung - 7.95
Steamed chicken dumpling, fishcake, tofu potato, cabbage & egg in spicy peanut dressing. Excellent and large portion.

2. Pan fried layered bread served with curry dipping sauce

3. Veggie Sampler Platter - 7.95
Fried corn fritter, soy bean cake, & tofu (Bakwan jagung +Tahu + Tempe goreng) 

Got another Bottle of the Pinot. Moved onto Main Courses.

1. Bakmi Goreng/Bihum Goreng
Stir fried (egg noodle/rice stick noodle) with egg and vegetables with 
Shrimp/combination of chicken or beef and shrimp - 9.95 

2. Ikan Goreng/Stripe Bass fish
Fried stripe bass fish marinated with exotic spices - 13.95

3. Ikan Bakar Samudra/Trout fish
Grilled fish with tropical spices served with Indonesian salsa - 13.50 

Everything was tasty. My only complaint if any was that the restrooms didnt feel all that clean (i didnt want to touch anything), and i'm not sure how that cascades to the kitchen. I couldnt find a clean score on them, but... all in all everything was good including the experience. I will definitely make my way back.
author: Adam X.

description: Meh - just okay food. Service is slow and the dishes are a bit on the pricey side considering its not that great.  There's tons of other places nearby that's cheaper and infinitely better.
author: Jake P.

description: Great food, casual atmosphere. A few good vegetarian options. It's been a place I can back to again and again for consistently good Indonesian at a very affordable price.
author: Eric O.

description: The food was terrific and the service was friendly and prompt despite being super busy. The only issue, and it's a BIG one, was that when I ate my leftovers that evening, whoever had packed them up had picked out all the shrimp from my entree.
author: Caityroo R.

description:
Almooost a 5!  Not knowing what Indonesian food is, I can't say if this is "good Indonesian food".  But it is DAMN GOOD FOOD.


The Place- Nice, clean, easy to find, probably terrible for finding parking.  We walked, so I wouldn't know :)  Small-medium sized, so I'm not sure how they would accommodate large groups.

The Service- Very friendly! First time having Indonesian food, and they were quite patient and helpful (even though it was right in the rush of dinner time) in helping us decide what to get.  I also liked how attentive our waitress was!  She thought we were Indonesian and started speaking to us in Indonesian, so I guess I can also safely say the place is pretty authentic!

The Food- First things first:  ROTI PRATA! First item on the menu, you MUST have this appetizer!  Flaky, delicious, definitely something that would come to mind every time I visited SF... Beef rendang is pretty good, tender and with delicious sauce, but ordering it once is probably enough for me.  I LOVED the honey chicken, and I don't even really like chicken- and our vegetarian's eggplant tofu dish had great flavor too (spicy though!) 

I especially like that there are SO MANY options- this is def somewhere I could keep coming back to (if I lived in the area XD)

I wish I could recommend more, but I've only been once (and I was so happy with the experience I just HAD to Yelp it!), but can't wait to go again and try all the other dishes!
author: Harn C.

description:
i never had indonesian food before so i don't have anything to compare it to. i hosted a large group here a few months ago and pretty much ordered at least half of the menu so i got to try out a lot of their food. everyone in my table liked their dishes and said it was good but they weren't in LOVE with it.

the food wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either- just standard. i really had high hopes because all my friends have been here multiple times and loved it. sadly, i wasn't totally impressed. i had an indonesian friend visit me last month and wished i could have taken her to borobudur just to see what her opinion on the food was from a native's perspective. i wouldn't mind giving this place another try but it's definitely not my go-to place if i am hungry or have friends in town.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description:
I went to school as a child in Indonesia, and have greatly missed the food since.  I have tried many Indonesian restaurants in California, and the East Coast, and I have to say this is absolutely my favorite.  

The food is very authentic, and not a "fusion" (with Thai or other SE Asian food).  

Fresh vegetables, wonderful seasonings, not oily.  

DELICIOUS.
author: Alicia I.

description: We called reservation but we still had to wait about 30 mins to get the seat. We got appetizer before drink. we didn't get even water. Food is ok but kinda small portion for the price.
author: Kawhom L.

description: Authentic Indonesian food. Great noodles, fried rice, curry. They also have a 9 course rijsttafle.
author: Larry P.

description:
I'd never had Indonesian food.  After seeing Borobudur on Check Please! I had to try.  I was the first of our party to arrive and scoping our everyone else's meals I was really excited.

We ordered a la carte - got a selection of noodle dishes, meats and something with rice.  Most of it tasted quite good - but it all tasted EXACTLY the same.

The only differentiated dish was the Roti appetizer which was AMAZING and I could eat 3 by myself (although then i might explode).

I'd go again and try the dinner combo - maybe if they help you select you can get better variety.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I've been here three times now. Love the variety of menu items and new tastes it offers. At the advice of an Indonesian friend, I order the siomay bandung appetizer every time (an interesting mix of fish cake + tofu + egg + other things I can never remember, or even distinguish on the plate once it's delivered, yet I love it and ignorantly re-order it nonetheless!)

Service might be slow or off depending on the night (i.e. might have to flag your server down once in a while), but the food is where it's at. Really, I've liked everything I've tried here -- no dish I've tried beyond that fav appetizer is an absolute single standout -- not sure how you can go wrong.

Atmosphere is nothing fancy... but it's comfortable, location is good (and just far enough off the Union Square tourist trail) and convenient for a bar crawl afterwards. And I''ve typically liked the clientele -- sometimes to the point I've nearly befriended another table...

It's cheap, too. I paid $25 (post-tip) last night and had half an appetizer, a filling entree and a 1/2-carafe of the house chablis all to myself!

mmmmm. Solid.
author: Daniel P.

description: Fresh, flavorful, inviting service & ambiance. I recommend Borobudur for dinner date if you are nearby. For me, it was too sweet. We were in the mood for something spicy, and we said so, but our dishes were as sweet as they were spicy. I added shameless amounts of chili paste.
author: Ria J.

description: Don't really know if this place is a 1 or a 5, so my 3 rating is simply a space holder till I go back.  OK, my bad.  Need to know what to order here...I didn't and chose a combination I cannot recommend.  That being said, each dish was well prepared, especially the tofu, but my selection was bland and turned me off.  They deserve a better look.
author: Howard B.

description:
#30 stir fry was amazing
#43 was very good
The beef in coconut milk is good!

#4 and 6 were good but the tofu was too salty
author: Christopher L.

description:
Borobudur.... Hmmm... 

I have mixed feelings about this place. I've been to 3 Indonesian Restaurants and I gotta say this one is my least favorite. Not saying that the food is not good though! But it's just I have tasted better. 
Everything was okay except the warm banana dessert. They were DIVINE! So soft, moist, sweet, DELICIOUS! I love it! 
It's like the perfect thing to eat when it's super cold outside and you wanna feel a LOT better.
author: Miss C.

description:
Yay indonesian food! We had the mie tek tek (spicy java noodle stir fry), which was really good... Bursting with flavor! And the empek empek palembang (fried fish cake with vermicelli) was also yummy. Beef rendang was just okay.

Tauhu goreng (fried tofu with hot garlic peanut sauce) wasn't exactly what we'd expected, unfortunately.

But I've been here before and remember their ayam bakar (bbq marinated chicken) was good.
author: Clarissa L.

description:
As someone who grew up in  Indonesia I believe I have a high standard for Indonesian restaurant ;)
Borobudur is my favorite Indonesian restaurant in the city.  Here's why:

Food quality.  Authentic.  What more can you ask, right?  It's the stuff that reminds me of my mum's cooking back in Jakarta.  Definitely not shy with the use of spices.  Don't ask me what you should get because it honestly depends on your taste.  Indonesian cuisine is comparable to its more-famous-cousin Thai in the sense that there's quite a wide range of options.  You can have noodle soup, curry, pan-fried vegetables with meat or a rice dish.  OK, if you must ask what my favorite is that would be 'mie tek-tek' which is a spicy 'street vendor style' noodle.

Price.  Prices range between $10-$15.  You can eat till you're bloated here and it won't break the bank.

Service.  They've got a very good ratio of waiters to tables, and the waiters are always running around like bees around a beehive ... that helps!

There are a couple of downsides:

No bar.  They serve beer and wine but no liquors.  

Decor.  It's dated.  This isn't a place to take someone on your first date.  It can also get a bit loud.
author: Andi H.

description:
It's Indonesian food, so it's definitely tasty, but I found it to be not as good as the restaurants I'm used to elsewhere on the Peninsula.  Roti Prata is good, but at $7, I think it's a bit expensive for what you get.

Service was great an there were plenty of people in there, but not overly crowded.
author: Sir B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  It smelled like all things holy and good when Jessica P. and I walked through the front door Friday early evening.  

The menu had a decent selection of vegan friendly options and we ordered the veggie sampler plate to start.

I should have known as soon as I saw the corn fritters that I was in for something sorta sad.  

Nothing will ever live up to my ideal corn fritter, which is at E&O Trading Company, where you can see whole kernels of corn being held together by a thin, crispy batter.  Every time I've gotten a corn fritter elsewhere I've been met by something that looks like a crab cake.  Shaved corn bits and a whole lotta bready meh.  

The tofu was decent but the soy nuggety things were...nuggety.  

My veggie rice plate looked promising, but it was cursed with more of those corn cakes (I should have known better) and more nuggety soy product that looked stir fried with unremarkable veggies.  The tofu that came with my dish was swimming in a sea of some sort of chili sauce that frightened me.

Oh, and there was also a little bowl of curried veggies.  The curry was oddly soupy and the veggies were shaved carrots and zucchini.  Weird.

I ate my rice and I ate the ok tofu puffs from the appetizer plate and called the rest of the meal a wash.

Two stars because our waiter was friendly, but I don't see myself coming back since there are other thai and inonesian places in this area to try.
author: Jen I.

description:
I'd been to this place years ago and remembered liking it. So, after fighting the crowds in Union Square for a few hours, I decided to grab take-out on my way home. I was just going to get one dish and was advised to go with the Beef Panang over the lamb stew. I am so glad I did because it was delicious! Huge chunks of braised beef (short rib consistency) melted into a flavorful spiced brown sauce. 

Though both dishes were way too much food, I couldn't turn down the Roti Prata either. And let's just say, it rocked. Perfectly crisp on the outside, this flaky fried bread pulled apart easily and was delicious dipped into the light curry sauce.

I can't vouch for anything else on the menu at this point, but I'm planning to add Borobudur back into my rotation. Yum!
author: Crissy G.

description:
Gotta get my fix of rarer cuisines from time to time, and Borobudur is great for the times when you think to yourself "I'm itching for some Indoesian."

This is good stuff. Drawback: perhaps its because we cruised in pretty much just as it had opened for lunch on Sunday (1p), but the food didn't feel fresh-out-of-the-oven. Despite this and the relatively small portions, the flavors are great. Had one of their combo rice plates and the honey beef and "aromatic" rice (rice cooked with coconut milk) really hit the spot.  

The choices of unfamiliar dishes were staggering, so I definitely want to come back so I can try a few more of their entrees.
author: Vince L.

description:
Definitely looking forward to coming back to try something new.

Went with the old man here, we got the Rijsttafel.  While a few of the main course dishes weren't really to my liking, the rest of it was amazing.  They start you off with the lumpia appetizer with some sort of peanut dipping sauce (yum!) and then the chicken lemon grass soup. Then the main courses come (albeit a little slowly) and it is pretty amazing.  Both chicken dishes and the beef were great, the seafood was pretty good, the tofu part was ok and the last one was meh.  Overall though, good good food.  And the black rice w/ coconut milk dessert thing was pretty tasty too.

It can get a little pricey, but it is definitely worth it.
author: Matt N.

description:
Indonesia, saya rindu kamu. 

So ... this is as close as it gets. 

Being a native from Indonesia, it's difficult to find a good Indonesian restaurant across the other side of the world, but I was pretty pleased with the food at Borrobudur.

My bf has never had Indonesian food so we tried their sampler menu for ~$25/person. The highlight of the dishes were: tempe goreng (fried soy bean cake) and gulai ayam (curry chicken). Two big disappointments were: 

1) Gado-gado - it was smothered in peanut sauce, did not taste like how I remember it back home. 
2) Soto Ayam - it was cold when it came, and I can barely taste the lemon grass!

For Indonesian food virgins try the rice plates: nasi rames, pandang, or uduk. It never fails. 

Also, please don't settle for vanilla ice cream for dessert ... you can get that at Safeway. Try bubur hitam (black rice pudding) with coconut milk ... oh yummm, brings back old memories ...

I was going to give it a 3-star for the food, but they were great with their service and our waters never went half empty. 

Terimah Kasi!
author: Enji L.

description:
As far as Southeast Asian cuisine is concerned, Indonesian/Malaysian food is seriously underrepresented in the city. (There's no shortage of Thai and Vietnamese though!) For this reason, I really wanted to like Borobudur. Having been here on several occasions, I've been able to try most of the appetizers, both soups, two shrimp dishes, two beef dishes, the sautéed garlic water spinach, the nasi goreng, three noodle dishes, and three desserts (see pictures). I was sad to find that nothing really wowed me, with the exception of two desserts. (I don't have much of a sweet tooth, so when dessert is the best part of the meal for me, it usually doesn't bode well for the savoury stuff!)

Of all the appetizers I've had, the three that I would order again are the roti, martabak, and empek empek palembang. The ROTI (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=rzkH1HTiuaZLCdv8H4PGEw) is crispy on the outside with soft layers on the inside, but at $7.50 is pricey for what it is. The MARTABAK (beef or vegetables, egg, and onion in crispy dough; http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=CwZcbd0CfcsM3dar3N2rgg) is great paired with the pickled cucumbers it's served with and I loved the crispiness of the dough. The spicy vinegar in the EMPEK EMPEK PALEMBANG (fried fish cake filled with egg in spicy vinegar, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=3losVCZodB6IIJcb7H-hMA) is yummy and the dish comes with a small amount of vermicelli.

Another dish I think is worth repeating is the MIE TEK TEK, both stir fried (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=KvHtA3u3MX7cpA_4CcEBnw) and soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=jMTY7M9VtzmSZ54qX_iqcA) versions. Both are flavourful and loaded with chicken and vegetables. While the coconut curry soup wasn't the best I've had, it's still worth a try. The other soups were also pretty good and I'll likely order them again (mostly because I can't find them anywhere else!), but I wouldn't repeat the beef or shrimp dishes I had.

For dessert, I love the BLACK SWEET RICE WITH COCONUT MILK and roti prata manis. The black sweet rice (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=cK_5RuC3hkPcLwPc8GWsZg) has a chocolate-y flavour and the bits of sweet rice add texture. It's better served hot so be sure to ask them to heat it up (it was barely lukewarm both times I got it). The ROTI PRATA MANIS (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=5bmpGbzPd-gfcUl6o5j7FQ&select=imC4Q1hWGKXTcDqOE5aWAQ) is filled with condensed milk, ground peanut, chocolate, and cheese. Yup, you read that right - cheese. CHEDDAR cheese, to be exact (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=uLo6Zw-XuCaIIunwSg6YBQ). Some people top their apple pie with a slice of cheddar, so I suppose this isn't that out there. Surprisingly, this dish worked out amazingly. The cheddar wasn't too strong but added a hint of saltiness along with the peanuts to balance out the sweetness. It also added a creaminess to the dish. Paired with the crispy/chewy roti, this is hands down my favourite dish here.

Stay away from the fried banana though! Instead of a coating that is thin and crispy, it's thick, doughy, and mushy (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VZwe5P-at3JYNCxOVSfe-g?select=kNCzXgZ0JJxc98Y5uB0Q7A). Yuck!
author: Steph L.

description: I give them 3.5 even though they had a "confusion" in the kitchen and never put my order in then forgot the broccolli I wanted added to my curry. They were nice about it made me happy by giving me a free beer and shrimp chips to snack on while I waited. On to the food, I ordered the chicken curry and the chicken was moist, the curry was real good, I liked all the vegetables in it. The Roti Pratha was real good and flaky and crispy on the outside soft in the middle. The lumpia was good with I think chicken instead of pork. I would go back to eat again.
author: Karen T.

description:
We don't have a dedicated Indonesian restaurant in San Diego so any time I travel I'm always on the hunt for one.

So that means Borobudur is always on my list any time I visit SF. And although I can get a home cooked Indo meal any day, it's nice to be able to go somewhere and have someone else cook it for you...especially when you're on vacation!

My favorite menu choice this visit: Roti Prata...yum!!

Until next time, Borobudur....
author: Jen D.

description: I'm visiting San Francisco on business and happened to come upon this place.  Although I only tried 2 dishes- Roti Prata and Bakmi Goreng / Bihun Goreng, both were delicious.  The service was understandably slow considering that the food is prepared fresh.  I would definitely check it again if I'm in the area.
author: Mila D.

description: The food is delicious and the decor and ambience make for a very comfortable dining environment.  The wait staff is very friendly and I must say, the waitresses are pretty cute!  One in particular caught my eye...I think her name was Gretchen?  Anyway, I would definitely recommend the Roti Prata.  Its very rich and delicious but you should also try everything else on the menu too!  I dont know what the rotund gentleman was talking about...
author: Victor H.

description:
Great restaurant. Come here for some unique flavors and very nice dishes. When it gets very busy the service can get slow and the dishes come out piecemeal, but don't let that stop you from going. I go here a few times a year and I ways kick myself for not going more frequently.  

Given how yummy Indonesian food is, I'm shocked there aren't more Indonesian restaurants out there. I feel the same way about food from Afghanistan: there needs to be more - it's too good.
author: A A.

description: Delicious food. The rice service was a fun way to sample all sorts of dishes, but it was a little pricey. The waitstaff are really very nice but are a little slow.
author: Amanda W.

description: Definitely one of (if not the) most delicious places in the Tenderloin; overall, the area around Jones and Post is littered with fantastic cheap eats. Everything ordered has been delectable, but the deduction of one star for the in-restaurant experience. It's a bumping place, so it's hard to get service in a timely manner, which is why I prefer to call ahead and take out. Not the cheapest, but the lunch specials are a great value. Top three favorites so far: roti prata, ayem bakar cabe and nasi goreng.
author: M S.

description: My mouth water just thinking about the roti prada.  What could be so great about a flaky dough-thing with a little dipping sauce?  Eat it, and you will know.  I live in Sebastopol, and I am about ready to drive to the city right now so I can eat here!  Other food is great too - rendang, yummy; nasi goreng; wonderful; water spinach, excellent.  I have been to Indonesia (as well as eaten countless rijstaffels in Holland, both good and bad), so I know what the stuff should taste like.  This place has the goods!
author: Doron A.

description:
After watching an episode of Check Please where they went to Borobudur and everyone liked it on the show, my boyfriend and I had to check it out for ourselves.  We were excited to try Indonesian food as we hadn't really experienced it before. 

This is what we ordered based on feedback from Yelp as well as Check Please: 

Roti Prata - this was excellent! It was like a fried crepe that was crispy and chewey all at the same time. This was probably the best thing we ate. 

Veggie sampler plattter - Only good thing on this was the corn fritters. Skip the platter and just get the corn fritters. 

Then we did the Rijsttafel to get a sampling of various items on the menu in small portions. OVerall we were disapointed here as well. There was a shrimp curry dish that was decent but everything else was not so good. 

When we got the Rijsttafel the dishes were cold and we had to ask them to heat them up. The service wasn't very attentive and they forgot to bring me my wine, I had to ask for it after they brought the food. Additionally, the food left me filling rather ill for the rest of the night. The Roti prata was tasty but I doubt I'd make a trip here just for that.
author: Lindsay A.

description:
I came here with my friend who lived in Bali for many years.  She had them cater a party once and it was amazing so I had to come to the place myself.

So after she ordered for us, couldn't understand a word she said, and had a laugh with our waiter, again not a word, she told me we were getting chicken and beef satay and a noodle dish.  Everything was delicious!  I can't wait to go back.  Service was quick and friendly but we weren't rushed.

We did park down an alley and up the street in a little lot, it's less sketchy then it sounds I promise.  Otherwise there is street parking.
author: Jessie M.

description:
This place is a Gem!  My first time eating Indonesian food, and I went with a friend who lived in Indonesia, she was also impressed.  They had many veggie and vegan friendly options as well as meat.  You do have to ask though, as they put shrimp paste in a fair amount of things.  We had two appetizers, the friend tempeh, and the bitter crackers.  The crackers were good and the tempeh was OK.  My feelings on the tempeh were more related to personal feelings then how it was prepared.  

We tried a few entrees a veggie rice plate which was tasty and beautiful.  It had 4 or 5 different types of things to eat so you were able to try different things.  We then had two main dishes, eggplant and tofu and something I forgot (oops).  We polished this off with dessert of black rice with coconut milk and palm sugar.  YUM!  The food wasn't as spicy as I expected but I think you could ask for extra spice.  

The service was great, and everyone was really friendly.  The only thing I suggest is make reservations or plan to wait.  I definitely  plan to go back again.
author: Courtney R.

description:
We're not even sure what we had, but our friend took us here last weekend and the experience was fantastic. You wouldn't have guessed that you'd find a four-star restaurant in the Tendy, so this is gem.

The roti (one thing we actually recognized) was really good. It's much thicker than the roti we're used to, but it held the curry sauce much better. We also had a string beans with a shrimp paste that was slightly salty, but also very good. 

Note: the portions aren't very big so you should order three dishes for every two people.
author: Kel S.

description:
I finally came here out of high recommendation from a fellow Indonesian friend.  Yup.  It was a busy Saturday night too.

Let's just get this out of the way though:  The service can be pretty slow.  I just assume that the place was so busy and there weren't a lot of servers to accompany the crowd.  So yes it will be slow.

Now, on to the food.  Instead of ordering the safe options (Roti Prata, Rendang, Satay), my friend recommended some other dishes.  For instance, I had Bakwan Jagung (corn fritter), Ikan Bakar Samudra (trout fish), Empal Goreng (honey beef).  To put this into perspective, I cannot eat peanuts.  So all of the dishes listed had no peanuts, and were pretty damn good overall.  Quality is top-notch and may be expensive, but it is definitely worth it.

I will definitely come back and try more Indonesian food.
author: Ren L.

description:
F A N T A S T I C.  Here's what we had:

1.  Sayur Asam: 
Spicy tamarind soup with shrimp paste, baby corn, cabbages, long beans, tomatoes, chayote and peanut 

Verdict: THE BOMB! Delicious!

2. Combination Satay (Chicken and Beef)

Verdict: EXCELLENT

3. 53. Nasi Padang:
Combination of spicy beef, tofu, chicken and vegetables curry coconut milk sauce and served with rice 

Verdict: FANTASTIC

This place is great - food is delicious and flavorful. Service is great, too.
author: Maren P.

description: Good family restaurant. Check out the Mei tek tek!
author: Radley A.

description: A good go-to when cravings for Malaysian-like dishes hit.
author: Aiko S.

description: great food! Loved the beef rendang and the egg foo young (which is huge, btw).  Gado Gado is also one of my favorites.  Didn't get the 5th star because it was a little noisy.
author: Michael N.

description:
was recommended by a friend who's been to this place quite a few times in the past. having been to indonesia and missing cuisine from that region, i was happy that my friend had chosen this place for lunch.

we had the otak otak for appetizer...the first and last time i had otak otak was in a hawker center in singapore...before i tried it it didn't look quite appetizing but the flavor was amazing, thus i wanted to try the ones at borobudur. my friend warned me that otak otak fr indonesia is different...and she was right. singaporean otak otak was more flakey and the ones we had here was more like fishballs and chewy. good nonetheless. then we had the Ayam Bakar Cabe, aka bbq chicken with spicy chili sauce...big YUM. the meat was VERY tender and flavorful, just the right amount of spicy, at least for me. 

and of course i couldn't pass on the ginger tea :) i def want to come back again and try the other items!
author: Jenny C.

description:
Went there recently for a friend's birthday and the large group really let me get a good sampling of different things on the menu. The only thing I was a little disappointed about was that even though I am Chinese, I was expecting to try some really exotic Indonesian flavors but everything seemed familiar to what I've had in Chinese, Malaysian or Singaporean cuisine. Not to say it wasn't delicious, I was just interested to try something new to my taste buds. 

Appetizers: 
Combo Satay- perfectly grilled, the chicken was tender and juicy, the beef was seasoned perfectly, the peanut sauce was creamy and yummy.
Lumpia - Egg roll was good but nothing special. I've had tastier lumpias in daly city Filipino dives.
Roti Prata - Tasty and the dipping sauce was good- a blend of curry and spices.

Entrees:
Rendang  - beef stew with coconut milk - the highlight of the evening in my eyes. The beef was super tender and flavorful and the broth was exceptional. I could eat four bowls of rice with this stuff.
Honey Chicken - The meat falls off the bone. Best part was that it wasn't dry and..... the marinade penetrated into the flesh of the bird. Usually the skin and top part of chicken has good flavor but as you get towards the middle the flavor is not evident. Not so with this dish as you can taste the flavor on all of the meat.
Grilled fish with Indonesian Salsa and tropical spices - the fish was perfectly cooked, and it was tasty, but the spices and salsa wasn't anything special. To me it was a dish I could make at home.
Sauteed veggies - ok I really wanted water spinach with shrimp paste but since it was out of season, the server suggested the sauteed veggies. Again it was cooked perfectly and seasoned right, but nothing special and something I could get at any Chinese restaurant in the Sunset.

Drinks: So I ordered one of their special drinks called Es Teler, which as their menu states is "mixed sweetened fruits with coconut milk & ice". It was $4.50 and I would say a huge waste of money. They just basically put in some canned tropical fruit, canned jackfruit, canned coconut milk and ice and called it a day. Order the Thai iced tea or Indonesian ice coffee instead as those tasted much better.

Overall I thought the food was good, around a 3.5, however the rendang pushed it up to a four for me. But for these prices I would rather just stick with the cheaper restaurants in the Sunset/Richmond area and probably won't be back unless it was someone else's choice.
author: Dom L.

description: Food was nothing special but acceptable.  Prices were in line for what you got.  The big let down was the service.  We got our chicken then 15 minutes later our appetizer and then another 15 minutes to get our rice.  And then the bill was incorrect.  We lived in Indonesia so know what the food is suppose to be like and yes it is authentic Indonesian food.  Again, can't really complain about the quality of the food but it was some of the worst service I have had in a restaurant in a long time.
author: Mike W.

description:
best Indonesian food i had ever had in north cal
roti -- Boom! 
any kind of fried rice or noodle -- Boom!
Rangoon beef -- small rockets, but still shoo-bomb!
drinks - sweet and salty and taste very indonesian -- good!
will definitely do take out when i am in the city
author: Kenny C.

description:
Wonderful. We started out with Lumpia Semarang , which is 
fried spring roll stuffed with tofu, bamboo shoot, carrot & chicken , served with a peanuty spicy dipping sauce. Very good. As an entree I had Soto Ayam, which is smooth lemon grass soup with bean sprout, egg, chicken and rice stick noodle. OK. Did not like the cellophane noodles but everything else in the soup was yum. We ordered fried rice which was delicious and something else with noodles and shrimp. If I were in the mood for Indonesian food I would go back to Borobudur.
author: Bleep S.

description: Great food. The ambiance is not great, but there's sufficient seating and good service.
author: Anand P.

description:
One word, blagh!

Of you like overcooked, dry, tasteless, over salted food, this is your place. You can have it, We'll not be returning.

No duck on the menu? This is an Indonesian restaurant?

No pork? OK, maybe they are Muslim and I'm cool with that.

They were out of things on the menu.

The service was less than stellar.

May have been an off night but .....

Yes, I am VERY familiar with Indonesian food.
author: GEO E.

description:
Five stars without a doubt... If you love Indonesian food this is the go to place in the bay area. What is good on the menu? EVERYTHING! If you have never been to Indonesia or tried Indonesian food, start with the Roti... you will be hooked. 
A few tips: If you want to eat here on a Fri. or Sat. evening come early and put your name on the list. We had to wait almost an hour for a table of two... Next time I will be bringing a sidewalk cocktail.
Also the service is excellent, but very reminiscent of dining in Southeast Asia: if you want something, get the waiters attention. If your done eating ask for the check... Don't expect the staff to ask you every five minutes if you need something.
author: Llama G.

description:
Hands down, my fav Indo restaurant in the city. The have this fried rice dish called Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas with a fried egg on top and it is super hot and super awesome! There is this table condiment called balancha or something and that makes it ultra smoking hot. 

I had a bunch of students that always wanted to meet up for lunch/dinner at this place so I know it's the bomb.

Service can be slow sometimes but it's all good b/c whenever I go, it's cause I'm jones-in for their food so it's worth the wait.
author: Brian C.

description: Had farewell dinner with some good friends. Loving the roti, noodle and nasi padang.
author: Rachel L.

description: This is my first time trying Indonesian food. It's surprisingly good.  I ordered #31 (some kind of stewed beef) and my girlfriend ordered #63 (some kind of grilled chicken). Both are good.
author: Kevin L.

description: Oh what a great restaurant .. The closest Indonesian meal I have had since Bali ...  My other N I split the Roti .. a veggie dish ..Ayam Bakar Cabe  ...Lumpia Semarang .. with sweet black rice and a ginger tea ... oh I loved every bite of it .. Service was very attentive, fast, and pleasant. I will definitely be back .. and soon
author: Anthony S.

description: Never had Indonesian food before and was a bit skeptical coming here (My Fiance wanted to try it out). I was pleasantly surprised with how good it tasted. Their food reminds me a bit of Thai but it has it's own twist to it. The highlight of our meal was their Soto Ayam soup,  lemon grass soup with chicken and also had potatoes and clear noodles in it. It was very tasty and flavorful. I added just a bit of hot sauce in it and it was perfect. We also ordered their chicken fried rice which was also good as well. Too bad its in the TL area, which is GHETTO! I think I'll be back for this one day when I build up the courage to fight off those bums!
author: Rosie W.

description: Amazing! There's such spectacular variety and I would recommend trying all of it! Family owned, cute place, good food, what else can you ask for?!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
ha! if i life around SF, will come to this restaurant every week!
good Indo food!!!!!!! no kidding!! :)
author: Wei Y.

description: Amazing Roti, Good Bakmi Goreng, reasonable prices. Service was somewhat slow but the restaurant was pretty busy on a Saturday.  Would go again, highly recommend reservations.
author: L. H.

description: I had the Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak (BBQ curry chicken).  It was EXCELLENT!!!!  The Gado-Gado was also very good.  To drink, I had the Soda Susu Gembira, Yum Yum.  I wish I had one now.
author: Melissa L.

description: Tasty and pretty convenient, I agree with the assessment that the style is very similar to Thai.  Service was very friendly but a bit slow.
author: Adam H.

description:
Oh yeah, yeah, yeah! Indonesian taste parade - I love you. Gracious service, elegant atmosphere and delectable food. I crave the following on a regular basis:

Lumpia Semarang - 5.95
Fried spring roll stuffed with tofu, bamboo shoot, carrot & chicken. Cut diagonally and habit-forming.  

Siomay Bandung - 7.95
Steamed chicken dumpling, fishcake, tofu potato, cabbage & egg in spicy peanut dressing. I can't even stand it - I have to have some tomorrow. I could eat this every day.

Nasi Uduk Lengkap - 10.50 
Steamed coconut rice served with fried chicken, spicy tofu, fried honey beef, scrambled egg and shrimp cracker. Hello? Did you get all of that? I mean seriously - this is special.

There is so much more to explore here. I am enthralled with the cuisine. I would love to go to Indonesia for an extended stay. But for now, I have Borobudur. And that's a very, very good thing.
author: wendella a.

description:
This is one of my new favorite places.  I've been here a few times, ordered different things every time, and have always loved what I've gotten.  Not only is the food delicious, but the prices are very reasonable for how good the food is (avg entree $8-$13). 

A few of my fav's so far is the Bakwan Malang (#49) soup, delicious flavor with lots of dumplings/meat/veggies/noodles; Tumis Bayam Bawang Putih (#36) They describe it was 'water spinach with garlic' but it is SO much more than that.  Mouth watering, has red bell peppers, garlic, a delicious sauce - also tried a few stir fry rice dishes that are excellent... 

Can't wait for my next trip there!
author: Amy W.

description: What is wrong with this city, why can't I find a friggin curry laksa soup anywhere?  I mean come on now, if anyone knows please feel free to ping me.  We gave this place a shot on a whim, because I thought I'd surprise myself and find a gem.  There was nothing that remotely perked my interest or taste buds, it was food for the sake of eating food.  The roti was actually good (not the usual super greasy type you get at a lot of places), but the curry sauce with it was too watery and didn't cling to it.
