Some fried rice, and apps and...not even worth it, the whole table was food that was a variation of the color tan and I kept thinking how this can't be good for the soul.  The search for non-pho soups continues...
author: A A.

description:
Long ago I was in Amsterdam, on a mission to eat my way through Europe. I wandered into an Indonesian restaurant and fell in love with Rijstaffel-I love being able to taste small bites of many dishes...yum!!! 
Since Amsterdam and that fateful meal, I have been hunting for good Indonesian food in SF, I think Borobudur is the light at the end of the tunnel. 
I came here for a quick lunch today and had the spicy beef in coconut milk....OMG!!!! It melted in my mouth, was perfectly seasoned, and yes...I caught myself licking the plate! The rice came in this cute little castle shape, which reminded me of making sandcastles...I love little touches of presentation like this. 
I wish I had more time to enjoy my food, but I will definitely be back to enjoy the Rijstaffel. Also, pretty cheap....my wallet is loving this place...my lunch cost me $8!
author: Bianca L.

description:
PAINFUL!!

As many others did, I caught the episode on Check, Please! and was quite intrigued.  I met up with a friend and we had lunch there last week.  What can I say ... it was a horrible experience!  The restaurant was quite full, but it seemed there were only one server, one cashier, and one cook!  WTF!!  (As we were leaving, after over an hour, a gentleman walked in with some grocery bags - he might have been another cook.  WTF!  Shopping in the middle of the lunch rush?  I assume they ran out of some necessary ingredients, but  that's just bad planning.  And gone for over an hour!)

The poor server was also bussing all the tables.  Cashier didn't help at all, maybe she was helping the kitchen as much as possible.  We grabbed our own menus, eventually got some water (not even trippin' about that) but couldn't even order - she said she'll be back - long wait ... finally ordered ... sat around for over 30 minutes ... finally ready to just leave or ask for it to go ... food comes out.  Quite good.

Needless to say, it wasn't just our table, it was the ENTIRE restaurant full of people that had the same horrible, no service, ridiculous long wait, experience.

Why do people even go into business?  Don't you feel sometimes they should tip YOU just for giving them business?  Hey Borobudur, your food seems great, why don't you straighten out your service issues, maybe hire an extra body or two during the daily rush!
author: Les T.

description:
I love this place. As I rarely eat Indonesian food, I decided to have the Rijsttafel, which was a complete 6 course dinner plus soup, an appetizer, and dessert. (Note: I am basing the dish names off the restaurant's website as I can't remember the names off hand. Apologies in advance for all incorrect statements.)

1. Soto Ayam - Lemon grass soup with bean sprouts, chicken, egg, and green onions. An excellent start to the meal. Just the perfect combination of ingredients to balance each other out. 

2. Lumpia Semarang - Fried spring rolls stuffed with chicken, carrots, tofu, and bamboo shoots. Cute appetizer. I would use the peanut sauce. Otherwise, the dish is a bit bland.

3. Chicken Satay with peanut sauce - Wonderful dish. Chicken grilled to perfection. The sauce is not necessary but definitely provides a different taste experience and should be tried by all means.

4. Sambal Goreng Daging - Beef stew in a chili sauce. This goes amazingly well with steamed rice. By far, my favorite dish of the evening. The extra kick of spice puts this item over the top.

5. Bean cake with assorted vegetables - Apologies. I can't remember the name of the dish. Nevertheless, it was my least favorite dish. Let's not mention it again.

6. Ayam Bakar Cabe - BBQ Chicken in a spicy chili sauce. The chicken by itself is fabulous. Very juicy and tender. When you add the sauce, my taste buds are overwhelmed with the different flavors. I recommend putting some sauce on coconut rice. This dish is up there with the beef stew (see #4).

7. Kari Udang - Shrimp with assorted vegetables in a coconut sauce. Not too bad. Wasn't "wow'ed" by this dish as with the others but enjoyable nonetheless.

8. I can't recall this dish very well. It was nothing to memorable...no pun intended. There were fish crackers/chips (similar to those served in Chinese restaurants) that went with fried pork (i think...) 

9. Vanilla ice cream - Pretty self explanatory. Ice cream was standard.

Overall, I enjoyed my time here. Dishes were pretty much a hit or miss for me, with mostly hits! For $30 (including tip & tax), I feel this is a great bargain. Service is excellent. Waiters are very friendly and helpful. I highly recommend this place to everyone and will be coming back again!
author: Jonathan L.

description:
FOOD: Delicious and savory.  If you are unfamiliar with Indonesian food, it's like a mix of south east Asian and Indian.  The beef renang was so ono!

SERVICE: During a busy weeknight with only two wait staff, we found ourselves waiting a while.  Wait was worth it as food were devoured within minutes.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
First off, I would say if you're planning a visit to Borobudur and are one of those people (like me) who gets super cranky when hungry, I say skip going here on an empty stomach or on a Saturday night, because you will have to wait.  They will make you wait.

I think the total amount of time we waited before being seated was somewhere between 30-40 minutes, though they told my friend (who got there before I did) that the wait would be 5-10 minutes.  We also waited quite some time before anyone came to our table to offer us drinks or take our order.  We waited some more for our food.  

See a trend here?  Oh, did I mention, we were having dinner on a Saturday night (not the smartest idea).

So we waited, waited and waited some more and were expecting something spectacular.  

Did we like our food?

Heck ya!  

The veggie platter rocked!  The peanut sauce they serve it with is uber delicious.  My favorite of the three finger foods was the soy bean cake, ooooh soo good!

For our entrees my friend and I ordered the kari sayuran and oseng and shared everything family style.  Once again we were not disappointed.  The oseng, which is basically tofu and soy bean cake in a tasty sauce was AMAZING!  I loved the fresh vegetables in the kari sayuran.

So despite the awful wait and mediocre service, not to mention god awful location, the food trumped it all and made our trek through the tenderloin and our close to hour long wait, all worth while.

This place serves seriously good food.  If you have to go for dinner, my suggestion is keep a snack on hand and be prepared to indulge in a heavenly meal when you finally get it!
author: Swetha G.

description: The food, first off, is very good. Service can be slow on some days, apparently, but it doesn't seem to be a terribly frequent problem. If you're tired of the run-of-the-mill Asian food that is so prevalent in this town--which is not to say that it's necessarily bad, just often uninspired--Borobodur has some surprises to offer. I especially liked the spicy squid and a delightful dish with tempeh, tofu, and green beans. Good options for vegetarians, though the food is not declaredly veg: many dishes contain non-vegetarian ingredients such as fish sauce, so do ask if it's important to you. The only true lapse I experienced here was a piece of plastic foil in the otherwise delectable black rice pudding; I wasn't charged for it but alas, it did dampen my enthusiasm to come back, at least for the time being.
author: Cult H.

description:
DELICIOUS! I've been to this place a few times and can't really remember what I ordered the first couple times (chicken, I'm sure), but I came again last night and loved this place.  We ordered #59, the chili chicken, an order of jasmine rice, and the vegetarian combo appetizer and the bill was only $30. Not too shabby.

I guess I would compare Indonesian food to Thai food.  That's what it reminded me of, at least.  We came in right when they were closing and they were still friendly and let us take our time.  We weren't planning on staying for a long time, but when two other tables walked in after us, the pressure was off to get in and out. 

This place is awesome, pretty cheap, and I can't wait to come back and try many, many other dishes.
author: Jenny W.

description:
I'm torn. I want to give this place four stars, but I just can't muster the enthusiasm. There was nothing wrong with the food, but it just didn't wow me. Maybe it'd be better on a different night. 

Anyway, I had the Nasi Goreng Borobudur, the restaurant's own special fried rice with anchovy, egg, and onion.There seemed to be too much rice and not enough chicken in my takeout box, and the flavor was good, but not distinct. 

The people were very friendly, though, and the atmosphere seemed very pleasant (if a bit quiet for a Sunday night).
author: David Z.

description: Small and cozy, the staff is friendly and the food is good.  The best thing I had was the honey chicken, it just fell off the bone.  The food is presented very nicely (shrimp on skewers standing up on the plate, etc.)
author: Caitlin K.

description:
I been here twice and those two times that I dined here
everything was great. I really enjoy the Teh Jahe Manis (hot sweet ginger tea)  this tea is REEALY good!!
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: It's legit Indonesian food, but in good conscience I cannot give this as high of a rating as Jayakarta in Berkeley. While this place is fancier and nicer looking, the same portions cost way more. At Jayakarta I was able to get an appetizer and three entrees with rice for about $40 after tax and tip. Here the same thing was $60 after tax and tip. But it's very good. I suggest the spicy fish cakes, the spicy squid, and the cendol for dessert. I'd come back, but I would order much less (it is quite filling I have to admit.)
author: Josh K.

description:
Good good good food!! Super tasty!! I've been here a bunch of times and everyone of them was a good experience. Their Roti Prata and the Beef Rendang are to die for...seriously!! Their grilled fish and the aromatic rice are pretty decent too. I haven't quite found a dish I haven't enjoyed.
My only gripe is super slow service....really really slow!! Can guess why- they are seriously understaffed! Guessing they don't want to spend money hiring someone.
author: Blue C.

description: Great food. Everything we had was amazing. The roti prata was really flaky and perfect and the sauce with it is great. It almost seems like a cross between Filipino and Thai food but with lighter more flavorful curries.
author: Scott P.

description: The Roti Prata was fall off your chair delicious, especially with the warm aromatic dipping sauce.
author: Christian E.

description:
First time in an Indonesian restaurant, so not sure what to expect. 
I echo much of what has already been written. 
Very good food, rich in flavor and texture. Interesting combos. 
The service was slow, as they seem understaffed, but the server we had was knowledgeable, friendly and seemed unrushed, even though she was scurrying all over. 
Ambience, not as noteworthy. But a relaxed, delicious meal. Worth trying.
author: Paul E.

description:
We came as a family of 4 (2 teen boys) with reservations on a Saturday night - glad we had reservations, the restaurant is very small.  The area didn't seem unsafe as other reviewers mentioned.

We did not get the ricetafel, and I'm glad we didn't. 

Our favorite was the beef stew Rendang.  Also got the appetizer of roti prata.  2 orders of the satay combination of beef and chicken (5 small skewers each), nasi goreng and the first noodle dish on the menu with chicken.  Every single bite was gone.  Only leftover was the black rice pudding which I liked but the kids did not.

All this plus a carafe of bad white wine was $100 for 4 people.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
The rendang is a must, also try the Roti Prata Manis for dessert, it will open your eyes to chocolate and cheese.

BTW, rice chocolate = chocolate sprinkles.
author: Morty P.

description:
They were a bit busy, so I'll cut them some slack for forgetting napkins & our friend having to ask after his honey chicken several times.
The food was closer to 'generic american/asian' than to the food we'd been lucky enough to have had in Bali and Java (less spicy, less flare, less presentation) but it was plenty tasty enough, and most of it came pretty quickly. The chicken, when it did come, was really good.
However! 3/4 of our table got the gnarly stomach cramps within an hour and the next day had what is euphemistically called 'gastrointestinal distress' or 'Bali belly' or 'los trots'.  Not sure what caused it, but its avoidable now.
author: James David W.

description:
Love Indonesian food, though Indonesian restaurants are hard to find in our neck of the woods.  So when in San Francisco, Yelped our way to Borobudur.  The food was fine.  If one has never tried Indonesian, or very rarely does, I can see one being bowled over.  The food bursts with flavor.  But frankly, even middle of the road Indonesian food will.  We were hungry, so went with quite a few dishes including the basics, to include Gado-gado, Nasi Goreng, Bayum Terasi, Kari Udang, and Rendang.  All were fine, even quite tasty, but again, if you've had Indonesian before, none of these dishes is likely to stand out.

But for the issues with service, discussed in so many other reviews, we might have tipped the scales and given them 4 stars.  Mind you, the waiter was very friendly and generally attentive.  But he was running all over the place.  What really irked us was that the many dishes were coming out piecemeal.  It took 30 minutes for us to finally get most of the dishes, and the Rendang - what we were looking forward to most - never came!  We had to ask for it as we'd finished everything else.  The waiter apologized, but at that point we were just ready to head back to the hotel.   It made for a delicious breakfast the next morning, but needless to say, it was not ideal.
author: Bethesda Family A.

description: Maybe it was all the hype. Maybe it's that I'm a vegetarian. I was underwhelmed by my dinner here. There were about 10 of us, all with varying degrees of fondness for Indonesian food. The service was fine, the food was just alright. I don't think I'd really go out of my way to eat here again.
author: Angela N.

description:
My husband and I really enjoyed the food here.  I have never had Indonesian food so I don't have anything to compare it to but it was really good.  We ordered the Rijsttafel which is the rice table dinner,  It included an appetizer, soup, main course and dessert.  The main course consisted of six, count them, six different dishes.  My favorite was the beef that was cooked with exotic spices and the shrimp & veggies in the curry sauce.  I love the use of coconut for curries,  Yummy!!!  We are planning to go back really soon.  I only have one complaint.  The place got packed really fast at dinner time and the staff never refilled my water.  I am a big water drinker when I eat  I forgive them this time since I was drinking an Indonesian soda like drink that reminded me of an Italian soda.

I recommend this to anyone that is willing to try ethnic foods.  We are definitely traveling the world via ethnic restaurants.  What's next?  Peruvian, Ethiopian?  They can wait a couple more weeks.  We want more Borobudur.
author: Karla B.

description:
For the 1st time in a long time, a restaurant that I've never been to that a friend recommended and took me to. We had lunch and surprisingly not packed.  Since my friend is Indonesian, I left it to him to order. We had the Empek-Empek Pa lembang, Nasi Uduk Lengkap and Nasi Padang. For a beverage/dessert we ordered the Es Teler which is like the Filipino halo-halo. You can look at the website and see the full menu. 

The food was absolutely delicious, flavorful and seasoned authentically Indonesian...according to my Indonesian friend. I will definitely go back!
author: Al G.

description: This place was GOOD!! Came here with a group of non- Indonesian friends a few weeks ago...I should have written the review sooner because now I forgot what we ordered! Surprisingly my non-Indonesian friend ordered (I don't usually go to Indonesian restaurants since my mom cooks Indonesian food and she is a GREAT cook!)  and everything he ordered was pretty good! Sorry, I know this is not a very helpful review haha...oooh the siomay bandung was REALLY good!
author: Natalia H.

description: Found this restaurant randomly. Interior decor is nice. Excellent service. Ordered the veggie plate. OMG! Best tofu I have had. 90% of the restaurants don't know how to cook tofu. Not this place. Will definitely visit again.. Recommend this restaurant.
author: Raghav N.

description: I was taken here by my Indo/Polish (don't ask) friend. He's the expert on Indonesian food in my mind so the fact that he chose Borobudur says a lot. I've had Indo cuisine before coming here but I don't think it was very authentic. We had the complete rice table dinner - I think we got one of everything on the menu. What stood out to me was the lemongrass soup & shrimp coconut curry. Black rice with coconut milk for dessert is surprisingly delicious :)
author: Sara P.

description:
I've traveled Indonesia, and this is the real deal!!

Everything is perfectly cooked.  My favorite is the spicy string beans with shrimp paste (tumis buncis pedas udang kering).  You can't be offended by the slightly fishy taste to LOVE this dish.  

On my most recent visit, I had the bbq marinated chicken with coconut milk sauce.  The meat was so tender, it just fell off the bone.  The sauce isn't what you think of when you hear 'barbeque'.  It's BETTER!   It's spicy, with complex flavors that our American palates are not accustomed to.  The roti prata is a perennial fav for an appetizer.   Lunch specials (Mon to Fri) are a fantastic way to experience new dishes, especially if you round up a few people.  

There can a be a little bit of wait on Fri and Sat nights, but it's worth it.  This is the best stop for dinner after happy hour bar hopping in the area.  Comfy booths are available for your party of 2-4.  

Next visit:  the rijsttafel!
author: Lily C.

description:
I've been to Borobudur Restaurant twice- once in 2007, and recently again in 2010. I lived in Indonesia for four years, and went with my husband who is from Indonesia both times, so our standards were high. 

We were not disappointed! Authentic, delicious, friendly, did I say delicious... this place is the place to go for Indonesian food away from home. YUM!!! The only downside is that the prices are of course much higher here than you would find them in Indonesia- we spent about $50 for a full meal, but it was WORTH IT!! 

The Veggie Sampler Platter is a great combination of yummy fried tempe, tofu and bakwan (corn fritters), along with a perfectly spiced peanut dipping sauce. This combined with Nasi Uduk (coconut rice) and Tumis Bayam Bawang Putih (sauteed spinach with tofu and garlic) put my stomach and taste buds in Indonesian food heaven. The husband droolingly chowed down on Nasi Padang (a spicy Sumatran-style rice combination platter), which he said was "Enak banget" (really good). Not to mention a plate of Emping (which the restaurant calls bitter cracker- don't let that scare you away, it's actually not bitter, and has that nice salty crunch that anyone who truly loves Indonesian food needs in addition to the other flavors and consistencies). To drink, we went for Kopi Jawa (coffee with sweetened condensed milk)- you can't eat any good Indonesian food without savoring a true cup of Java. If we hadn't completely stuffed ourselves, we most definitely would have ordered an Es Cendol (sweet iced rice drink), and Pisang Bakar (roasted banana). 

Our waitress was sweet, helpful, and almost everyone else eating at the restaurant was Indonesian. Which is a good sign. If we lived in San Francisco, you would find us here often. Go there! It's delicious. Forget Thai food, eat Indonesian!!!
author: Emilia J.

description:
I have to say that this place grew on me.  As an Indo transplant, I'm pretty critical about my Indo food.  This place has always been a little too Javanese for me aka everything is darned sweet.  With the new owner that came in probably about a year ago, things have changed, and the food are way spicier.  I definitely recommend this place, and would go back.

For newbies, this place is probably as good as it gets in SF.  There's another Indo restaurant a few doors down, but they're even way spicier.  In fact, I just went there last week for lunch, and they didn't disappoint me.
author: Rod '.

description: Having lived in SE Asia for 6+ months, my expectations for this place were low, yet I was still hoping in the back of my mind for an authentic Balinese meal. At least I was able to start off my meal with a Singha - this always makes me happy from the get-go. Note: the portions for food are very big here, so make sure you don't over order. We ended up getting two orders each of roti prata, chicken satay, nasi lemak, and mee goreng. This was MORE than enough for 7 of us. In fact, we could have just done with one order of the nasi lemak and chicken satay. I thought the roti prata was good, but not great. It was a little oily/heavy and we could have easily shared that one with the whole table too, actually. The chicken satay was not good, I would skip out. Nasi lemak was good, but it tasted a bit like regular fried rice and chicken -- it didn't have the Balinese flavor I was looking for. The mee goreng was the best thing by far, but it just felt like they added in a lot of spice to chow mein noodles. It wasn't like the mee goreng you'll find in Indonesia or Singapore. Overall, it was nice to have "SE Asian" food, but it's not authentic by any means! You'll be blown away once you actually go to Bali or Singapore :)
author: Priya G.

description:
My family's interest in Indonesian food goes back to when my dad covered Indonesian politics for the wire services in the early sixties, before I was born. He eventually was declared PNG by Sukarno's people and politely escorted to the airport. As my dad told it, Sukarno treated him like a naughty nephew, smiling but scolding, the last few times he met with him. 

We try to grab some Indonesian or Malaysian food at least annually, although options in SF are somewhat limited. Thankfully, Borobudur has great food and a helpful, pleasant staff.

I'm not going to bore you with a laundry list of what we ordered. I will tell you that the last time we went here, we had a large party and were served more than a dozen items, which we ate family-style. Everyone was pleased - I think my German uncle was in a little over his head with some of the spicy stuff, but he enjoyed it, thanks to a few bottles of Tiger beer. 

We'd asked for it hot, and they delivered. I could see them watching us and looking amused. But that turned into amazement when my mom, who is a petite African-American woman, whipped out a little Bahasa Indonesia on them. We ended up having a long discussion with the manager, who, like my father, had had to leave Jakarta in a hurry. He was of Chinese descent, and a successful businessman in Jakarta, when an economic downswing resulted in riots. This happens sporadically throughout Southeast Asia when people need an effigy. They go after the Chinese. Anyhow, here he was in SF, working two jobs.

Well - I wish him the best -- but Jakarta's loss is San Francisco's gain.

Terima kasih!
author: Karsten P.

description:
Food.  Not spicy.  Taste.  Decent.  Price.  Just fine.

Ok, done with that part.

So reading her reviews, Grace might strike you as having a G or even PG rated vocabulary.  

I mean, she uses terms like sh*t and a$$ in her reviews.  

Some might call her a classy broad.  

Given this info, I almost died of laughter when we walked into Borobudur.  

Let's just say Grace learned something about me roughly 2 seconds before we walked into the restaurant.  

A quiet, subdued, dining experience for the patrons already inside was savagely interrupted by Grace yelling the loudest "holy shit" I have ever heard.

If there was a DJ in here spinning, the record would have scratched and the place would have gone silent. 

The next hour was spent being stared and gawked at.

So, given the lack of spice to the Borobudur fare, Grace decided to add her own, as she usually does.

Potty.
author: Archie R.

description:
if u enjoy feeling heat in ur stomach, come to borobudur. i had the the following dishes and they were all good. spicy good.

ayam panggang bumbu rujak (bbq chicken)
rendang (beef stew)
soto ayam (lemongrass soup)
author: Bennet A.

description: Searched for mie tek tek in the city on yelp and was led here.  The stir fried mie tek tek was decent, but very moist. I think I prefer it drier and with a whole fried egg on top. The fried rice Borobudur special was GREAT though. Really liked the flavor (anchovies mmm!) AND there were TWO fried eggs on top! Also ordered the water spinach with shrimp paste. Very fishy, so if you're not used to eating fish sauce and other seafood pastes you may wanna pass on this because the entire table will smell like foot. I liked it though. Pretty satisfying. And the servers are pleasant enough.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I am addicted to the Mie Tek Tek here.   Spicy, noodly goodness that builds until it clears my sinuses and almost burns my tongue.  This is definitely not a place to bring someone who does not like spicy food.  But for the adventurous this is great and I must say I have liked every single thing I've tried on the menu.

Borobudur only gets three stars, though, because of the wildly unpredictable service.  I've been several times and if the service isn't painfully slow, it's because they've forgotten to bring something we ordered.  

I do keep coming back though - the food is great, the prices are decent and the service, while a little annoying, is usually quite pleasant.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
I love Indonesian food! I eat it almost everyday. Well, I am from Indonesia after all, but hey, I am not biased, k? ;p 
Borobudur is one of my favorite place to eat (when I am too lazy too cook). 

For many, Indonesian food is similar to other Southeast Asian cuisine such as Malaysia, Thailand, and Singapore, or even as far as India ('curry' dish is everywhere, isn't it?). However, to be fair, no cuisine from different country is exactly alike since different set of spices is used, thus giving the cuisine its unique flavor of that particular country. 

Why I like Borobudur? The food, of course! Decor is minimal at best, but for a delicious treat, who would care? (as long as the place is clean) The staff is curteous, and eager to answer your inquiries on the food or what to order. Sometimes it may take a while for your order to come out. It is almost random ... well, if you understand the Indonesian term for "rubber clock" then perhaps you could understand this better. ^^;

Ok, about the food here (geez... finally.... ). You gotta know what to order (doh!) especially facing a menu with strange names you never even heard of, let alone pronounced it. 

First, to appease your stomach while waiting for the dishes to come out, I'd suggest ordering the Kerupuk Palembang, a big fish craker (it looks like thick white noodles and round in shape, you will see it displayed behind the register area). It is served with peanut sauce and sweet soy sauce. Other appetizer you may want to try is Otak-otak (don't ask what the name literally mean, ok? Trust me it is far from that ^^), and Lumpia Semarang (Indonesian version of spring roll). And remind the server to serve the drinks first, .

Oh right, the drinks! You got to try the Es Cendol (my fav!). It is tiny-tiny green colored jello made from rice flour served in a glass of palm sugar mixed with coconut milk. 

I like to start with Empek-Empek, which is a fried fish-cake with egg inside, served in a bowl of spicy-tangy dark color soup. Guaranteed to increase your appetite!

Ayam Kalasan is very popular in Indonesia, and Borobudur offers a mouthwatering version of it. For beef dish, I usually order Beef Rendang. It is soft and juicy and infused with spices and flavor. Beef satay? Hm... I would shift away from beef-on-a-stick, for simple reason, most of the time it will be either too dry, or too cooked, and too chewy. Just stick with the rendang. 

For you spicy food lover, may I suggest Mie Tek-Tek? Be warned that their 'Mild' version of the this soupy dish is still considered quite spicy (even for me). I would order the 'dry' version because it is bearable (you can still taste other food you ordered after eating this) and easier to share with your table mates. 

When going there solo or you just don't feel like doing it 'family style' my suggestion is Mie Ayam (Chicken Noodle) or Nasi Uduk (fragrant rice).  

And to close your dining adventure in Indonesian cuisine: I know this might be weird for a lot of people, but keep an open mind (or tongue) ok? For dessert, order the Pisang Bakar. It is grilled banana, served with cheese, chocolate and condensed milk (what the????? ;p ) Yup! you got it right ^^ 
It is a strange combo or sweet-salty-fruity-chocolatey. It is a typical late-night snack for the young (and old) in Jakarta. (comfort food! mmmm.....)
author: Kat S.

description: Here's a quick review for the ADD crowd: Great food, decent prices, lousy service. 'Nuff said.
author: John D.

description:
Absolutely loved my first experience at Borobudur!  Every dish my friends and I ordered was on point and came together like a symphony of flavors in my mouth! I love spicy food and we ordered delicious items like roti with curry, lumpia, lamb coconut curry, shrimp with indonesian salsa, steamed veggies, and this really good beef dish (#34?) and all of them were so good!  My favorite was the really good beef dish that apparently takes 12 hours to cook!  

I've never had Indonesian food before, and I'm kicking myself for waiting all this time to try it.  It's a mixture of Thai, Indian, Filipino, and other Southeast Asian foods, all coming together with tons of spices and flavorful tastes.  

Not only did we get a great meal, but the manager and the hostess (the daughter of the owners) were really friendly and even sat with us for a while, giving us a history and geography lesson on Indonesia.  The manager, Jody, is really nice and even gave us career advice!  I loved the fact that it was a mom and pop restaurant, and it was definitely very down to earth.  

Definitely coming back here....
author: James C.

description: Thanks, Yelp!  If it hadn't been for you (I think it was Karsten's review that grabbed my attention) I wouldn't have found this restaurant.  My husband and I and our friends Nina and Larry came here for dinner after the 5:00 show at the Plush Room.  Husband and I shared a Rijstaffel while our friends had other dishes.  Everything was well prepared and beautifully seasoned.  There was a large  variety of dishes, from appetizers to dessert.  As we'd had plenty of alcohol at the show we opted for tea.  The guys had jasmine but Nina and I had ginger tea, which was unusual and wonderful.  Service was friendly and helpful.  Even though their dinners didn't include dessert Nina and Larry were given them because we had them.  As we were leaving the man at the register (maybe the owner?) encouraged us to try the seafood next time and we probably will do that.
author: Toni M.

description:
I've been to this place a few times, but this place is a disgrace to indonesian cuisine. The service is bad and super slow. And the food is just 'eh'. The only time I come here is when I crave indonesian food and the other indonesian restaurant on the next block is closed.

I was born and raised in jakarta, Indonesia. I know what good indonesian food is like. I agree with Erik C's review. Borobudur took cheap, humble dishes and slapped on the gourmet label and sell them at 100 times the price. Sure the ingredients are more expensive to buy here in the US, and it will never be the same, but I still think borobudur serves sub-par food at too-high price. The only dish that I think is good enough is the gado-gado (salad with peanut sauce dressing).

And don't even get me started on the slow service. Kiria B mentioned the "Indonesian rubber watch". It basically means indonesian people are slow and always late. But if you're in the service industry, that is NOT an excuse. I went with a couple friends and when we walked in, we were ignored for a good 5-10 minutes. I actually had to walk up to the counter and ask "are we gonna get a table or what??". So we were seated, got our menus, had to call someone so we could order, and the food took forever to come out. Lame.

Slow and bad service + sub-par food = no business from me
I don't care if they came from the same country as mine.

I still yearn for good, authentic indonesian food...
author: Ari C.

description:
Came here for my sister's birthday. I'm a huge Roti fan and so my biggest gripe was their Roti Prata dish. Not only is it way overpriced as an appetizer at $7.50 but the Roti was a little too flaky for me. Nevertheless the Nasi Goreng was pretty good and was served as a large portion. 

The service is spot on and are very accommodating which is always important. I'll probably come back here the next time I crave some Indonesian food.
author: Jason M.

description:
This is not a good place for cheap take-out.  

I think it's more of a place you'd go to on a special occasion or a date.  It's very nice inside, and there's a gigantic and detailed carving of some crazy Indonesian war (?) scene.  It's very nicely lit and quite beautiful.

I asked the waiter for something spicy, so he recommended this shrimp dish.  Little did I know that it was just 5 measly shrimp skewers on a bed of lettuce.  Rice was extra.  And while the shrimp were delicious, the seasoning just tasted like straight sriracha chili sauce.

Granted, they were jumbo shrimp, but at $16 total for a quick dinner, I'd rather go somewhere else.

----------

Update: Got a lunch special today, and it was much more my speed.  $9 for soup, salad, and two small main dishes.  The fried chicken and beef in chili sauce were both tender and quite good.  

Beware, however, I had to specifically ask for the lunch menu and I think it's only for weekdays.
author: Rocco B.

description:
My sister took me here and I must say that their food is delicious. Yes, a bit pricey than it should be but I think it's worth it. I've had Indonesian home cooking before and this place just reminded me of it. Although it wouldn't hurt if they added a bit more portion  to their dishes but if you're going to visit you must try their:

Lumpia Semarang - Fried spring roll stuffed with tofu, bamboo shoot, carrot & chicken 
Ayam Goreng Kalasan - Fried honey chicken 
Rendang - Beef cooked with coconut milk in spice 
Bakmi Ayam Yamin Pedas - Egg noodle with spicy sweet soy sauce, chicken and vegetable
author: Anna P.

description:
I was wandering around Union Square with a friend today and lunch time rolled around so we went on a quest for victuals. Since we didn't want to get tourist trapped I looked for the nearest public telephone (they do actually still exist) and was in luck to find a copy of the yellow pages still attached. A quick glance in the Restaurants section brought me to Borobudur: it was within a few blocks and better yet it was somewhere new.

This Inner Tenderloin ;) Indonesian restaurant is on a corner and at luchtime is bright with natural light. Having had rijsttafel in A'dam I was hot to try it again. Since it was lunch we ordered just one to share although we added extra soup and salad. We also ordered some emping (bitter crackers) for the hell of it (sounded interesting).

So here's the bottom line: the food was great but the service was a little slow although it did pick up as the meal went along. This is a great place to go for a leisurely lunch when you're not in a hurry.

One rijsttafel was more than enough for the two of us, especially with the added appetizers. The emping were crunchy fried crackers that were in fact quite bitter which wasn't so bad especially when munched along with the various dishes. The lumpia, soup and salad appetizers that came with the rijsttafel were tasty but the best was the little dishes served with the steamed rice as entrees. The Sate Ayma (B.B.Q. marinated chicken on skewers with peanut dressing) and Oseng-oseng Tahu Tempe (sauteed tofu and soybean cake in spicy sweet soy sauce) were especially yummy.

Dessert was included with the rijsttafel so instead of ice cream we had the Black Rice which is a type of sticky rice pudding topped with coconut milk and a sprig of mint. It was great--not too sweet but with a nutty sweet and salty flavor--although my friend ate a bite and grimaced (she doesn't like sweet and salty together or sweet bean stuff).

One of the best things about this place was that the people working there were sooo nice. The waitress said the restaurant really fills up for dinner but they do take reservations. We left Borobudur full and happy with our mouths tingling from new flavors and the hot chili sauce.
author: Nivek M.

description:
Oh my gosh.  Sorry, but I hate this place.  They have ABSOLUTELY the WORST service ever!  And I'm Indonesian, so it's not like they don't understand me!!  I walk in at lunch, and they hardly even notice me.  I come in and sit, they still don't notice me.  I wave my arms to catch the waitress, but she's too busy bringing A GLASS of water (not plural...) and then quickly walks back to the back where I see her playing her Nintendo DS.  Oh my gosh.  I'm hungry, and worst off...I'm super pissed.  So, I grab a glass from a nearby empty table that wasn't cleaned off yet, and I bring it to the register, spilling water all over the counter top.  Then I scoff and leave while the waitress is shocked wondering where the hell I even came from.  Must have fallen from the sky eh?  Or maybe she's just blind.  Geez....I know the owner of this place...hope she got fired already!

Childish, I know, but I was hungry, in a hurry, and pissed.  I demand good service.  Because even if the food sucks, if you get great service, you don't feel as bad for walking in. But if you're at a restaurant with HORRIBLE service and great food, I wouldn't come back because of the frustration of it all!
author: Jin B.

description: Excellent spicy food, great combo plates, reasonable prices, and great service. I always make a point of coming here whenever I am in Sf.
author: Dave P.

description:
Very good Mie Tek Tek gravy or dry, the problem was we were not asked how spicy we wanted, so they assumed very spicy, which is bad!
They have very good Soto Betawi as well, but very salty.
When we got the bill, they included 18% gratuity automatically even though we were only party of 4. I asked the cashier, she didn't say a thing, gave us a new bill without the tips. I'd say, they try to cheat you if you're not careful!
author: Widodo T.

description:
Great lunch specials!  For $10 you get a small peanut salad, soup, rice and 2 choice of entrees.  I chose honey beef and veggies/curry.  My order came out wrong but it wasn't the waitressess fault since we were a party of 17.   She still kept on smiling even tho we were all confused on what we ordered.

There is a temple icon on the menu and the neat thing is they use a special bowl or something to mold the rice into that same temple icon onto your plate.  The rice isn't special tasting but it's pretty darn different!
author: J B.

description:
Meat falling off the bone, interesting dishes, friendly waiter, and fresh tasting veggies are all reasons why the dishes here work very well. 

Less one star for being told "That dish is really for Asians, you won't like it."  Uh... hell-O?  Just because my friend is white doesn't mean that neither of us can't handle it.  Obviously we would not have thought of it if we did not think we would like it.  I know you want to be friendly and suggestive, but come on, it's not like we're ordering raw monkey brains (which we would never).
author: Tangerine L.

description:
Pricey for Indonesian food, unless..well I guess I'm in SF.

Martabak (mixed beef in crispy dough) appetizer is authentic, very yummy, recommended! Good choice for first timer dining Indonesian style. Lumpia is similar to spring rolls also very delicious and crispy.

Mie Tek Tek (spicy stir fried noodles) is also very good despite its authenticity, a bit on the spicier side on my Italian brother in law's tounge!! He still likes it though, the regular Bakmi Goreng aka fried noodles will be perfect. You can add the spicy red pepper oil to your preference (if you are sharing). The tofu and eggplant on chilly sauce is not like what I expected, but it's still good, more tomato saucy, in other word not very chilly saucy/spicy. I do make very good eggplant in chilli sauce ;) hehe... We also had Gulai Kambing (lamb curry) which was pretty good.

Rice is over priced. Good for take outs and cook your own rice at home :) Service is slow but our server was friendly, it was Sunday night, a bit empty. Food takes forever!! So be ready people.
author: Gabriele A.

description:
First time eating Indonesian food, and it was delicious, but not super amazing. I did especially like the Roti appetizer. The issues I have is that I am rarely in this neighborhood and not sure if it was enough for me to come back, the service was a bit slow, and the rice with limited coconut on top was $3 each and the portions were small. Rice should be free, but if you want to add burnt coconut on top, it should definitely not be $3 unless it is a huge portion. 

Otherwise, came on a Sunday night and all the tables were full. Prices are not too expensive, but also not cheap for the portions. I would come back if I was around, but again - not a place that is particularly memorable.
author: Leily P.

description:
Charming surprise here in Borobudur.  We were wandering up Sutter and it felt like a 'no room at the inn' kind of night -- each of the restaurants we tried to get into were booked solid for the night, not even bar seating. 

Round the corner, and came upon Borobudur, with a sign that suggested an exotic taste adventure.  We were game.
 
It strikes me as the kind of restaurant that may not be consistent from visit to visit, as even some of the area's better restaurants can be.  We were there on a weeknight, and ordered the sampler dinner (far too much food for two people!).  On this particular night, they were not too busy, and they got solid 4s. 

Good food, good service, good pacing, pleasant dining experience.
author: Theresa B.

description:
After reading all the wonderful reviews about "All About Herbs @Paris Cafe", I wanted to grab dinner there before a show at GAMH.  When we got there, there was a sign on the door saying that it is temporary closed until further notice.  By this point, we have hiked up Leavenworth and are starving to say the least.  I didn't feel like going to one of the other chain Thai place - Thai Stick or Osha Thai - and decided to give Borobudur a try since it's just one door down.  

I ordered Oseng Tahu Tempe (sauted tofu and soy bean cake in spicy sweet soy sauce).  The portion was generous.  The sauce was tangy and spicy.  The soybean cake has a consistency that was unfamiliar to me but nevertheless the green beans, tofu and soybean cake really complement one another in both color and flavor.

A surprise, vegetarian, last-minute find.  I would love to try Vegetarian Egg Fuyung on my next visit.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I actually went to Borobudur like 10 years ago before I even first moved to SF or had an affinity for South East Asian food. Then 4 years ago I went with my friend Vera who happens to be from Jakarta. Well I went to Jakarta and Bali this past fall and for some reason hadn't made it to Borobudur since I had been back. A friend & I had been talking about going here and so we finally made it this past week; coupled with some further reminiscencing I went again 2 days later. 

here is my take-away:

The first visit on Wednesday we had:
- Mie Tek Tek
- Empek Palembang
- Rendang w/ Nasi Uduk 
- Es Cendol 

The Mie Tek Tek was not that spicy to us, but we both LOVE prik nam pla so go figure. However, the soup is dynamite. I will definitely be ordering it again.
The fish cakes (empek Palembang) were pretty good, but didn't stand out. 
The Rendang beef is reallllllllllllly tender and very tasty and goes perfect w/ Nasi Uduk
The Es Cendol was very sweet and I liked it.
The service was not bad, and we didn't experience any crazy delay or lack of eye-contact.. I even threw out some of the bahasa that I knew and got some favorable smiles and reactions back from the server.

Fast forward to Friday..

My other friend is not so much into spicy stuff, so we skipped the Mie Tek Tek
- Roti Prata 
- Nasi Goreng w/vegetables
- Kari Sayuran
- Es Cendol and Es Kelapa Muda

The Roti is very good but kinda oily. but who cares.. use a fork if you are that worried about your hands getting greasy (when I was in Jakarta there were several meals w/ my friends where they dont use utensils at all, so when in Rome, do as the Romans do).. but if u don't want the oily bread, skip it
The Nasi Goreng was definitely slamming!! then mix that with the Kari Sayuran ... ohh mannnn .. 
The Kari Sayuran was good by itself, but I enjoyed it a lot w/ the nasi goreng dish
This time, the Es Cendol was just too sweet. I could only take a few sips of it and I was done. 
This time, it was more crowded, but of course, it's Friday night, prime time dinner slot. They had 2 servers though, and there was really no delay.. so I think it's a hit or miss folks.. but I tried it twice in one week, and there was not the same shift of staff there.

All I could say at end of both meals.. "Saya Kenyang!!"  (I'm full)

I really miss Indonesia and want to go back very badly.  Indonesian food  is some of the spiciest of any cuisine that I have eaten. Some other classic Indonesian dishes to try if you have never eaten Indo: Gadox2, Soto Ayam, Mie Goreng, Sop Buntut... ohh there is so much..  I wish that Borobudur had some authentic Padang dishes as that is known as some of the spiciest styles found in Indonesia

Check out this pic below of my first Sundanese/javanese meal on my second day in Jakarta. This is known as Gurami Fish.. you eat the tail and everything ;)

I am going to have to go try the other Indo resto 1 block down.

ADA APA!!?!??!?!

[IMG]http://i97.photobucket.com/albums/l217/kapshure/DSCF1157.jpg[/IMG]
author: j d.

description:
Roti Prata = Audrey's new favorite food.

Soooo good, soooo not on my diet...

I also enjoyed #50 on the menu. I would pass up the meatballs next time but the wantons and noodles were absolutely delicious. The noodles were perfectly seasoned. 

Definitely recommend this place. Great price, good portions, nice interior, delicious food.
author: Audrey N.

description:
The folks that run this place must be slow cooking their meats 24x7 every day - their meat dishes are impressively tender and flavorful. The rice combination dishes are a good way to sample a range of dishes - try the Nasi Padang ... the spicy beef and chicken curry just melts in your mouth and the crispy tofu in a sweet/sour chili sauce cuts through the richness of the meat. 

The BBQ marinated chicken dishes are truly to die-for - we even tried to wrangle the secret recipe from the waiter.....

Service is attentive and genuinely friendly here. 

Prices may be a little high, but you'll walk out of here satisfied considering the central location, quality and authentic Indonesian food...
author: Melissa S.

description:
You've got to order the Rijsttafel dinner when you come to Borobudur which is sort of like a massive sampler if you're at all unsure or curious because it's a great introduction to Indonesian cuisine.

We were actually recommended the Indonesian restaurant across the street by my boyfriend's boss who is Indonesian, but when we arrived it was closed so we checked out this one instead. The decor is elegant, though not too fancy. The service was kind, gracious and our waiter even helpfully moved us to a booth when we ordered the Rijsttafel since we would need the extra space for all the dishes. The food? Really good. Of the five or so entrees we got to sample, I think one was shrimp, one was beef, one was chicken, so you got a good mix of meat and they all varied in levels of spiciness, with the hot ones having plenty of kick not entirely overpowering the complex combinations of flavors beneath the heat. The shrimp was probably my favorite, though you don't get that many, so I would order that next time if I don't opt for the sampler dinner. We had tons of left overs for the next day, so don't be intimidated to order the Rijsttafel because it's probably more than you can eat during one sitting unless you're really hungry.
author: Chelsea P.

description:
I've lived in Malaysia and have made trips to Indonesia on a few occasions. Definitely the best Indonesian food I have come across  west of Indonesia. 

Highly recommended, thank you Monkia and Amy!
author: ad K.

description: The same group of us that do Filipino family style dinner together came here awhile back, and we loved the Indonesian food here. I think we opted for the pre-fixe meal and each had a chance to sample an assortment of delectables. Everything was scrumptious!
author: Sally M.

description: The Bomb diggidy!  I love this place.  So fresh. So vibrant.  Tastes like you never had before.  Get the special beef dish and thank me later.  It was sooo incredible.  Dreamy
author: Jordan S.

description:
The food was good - just good. If you want Indonesian food, come here. If you want Asian food in general, I'd go elsewhere.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
LOVE THIS PLACE. I've been coming here for years, but I have noticed of late that they are catering to a more upscale clientele than when I first walked in 7 years ago. The prices may have changed to reflect this, but I never look at the bill really anyways.

First off, you gotta try the roti--a fried bread appetizer with the spicy peanut sauce. Every dish I've ever tried here has been fabulous. I especially recommend the Mie Tek-Tek (it's a spicy noodle soup you can get with chicken or vegetarian). This is another place where you can just sit back, take your time, and drink a bunch of beers. I've been here more times than I can count. Grain of salt warning: this is the only place I've ever had Indonesian food.
author: SheRat R.

description:
The food at Borobudur is great!

I arrange a weekly office lunch for 35 to 40 people which isn't always as easy as you might think - especially if you have a lot of foodies on staff and want a lot of variety.  Added complication if you have a handful of vegetarians and one pesky vegan.  

Anyway - a lot of restaurants can't seem to grasp the concept of preparing buffet-style meals for large groups but Borobudor handles it with ease.

I approached them last week and asked them to come up with a menu for 35 people within a set budget.  They came up with a nicely balanced selection of 3 grilled or stewed meat dishes (chicken satay with a really exceptional peanut sauce) Rendang (a great beef stew) and Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak (BBQ marinated chicken in a coconut milk sauce) as well as 3 vegetable dishes - Tahu Terong Balado (eggplant and tofu in chili sauce - really good!) Kari Sayuran (mixed veggies in coconut curry sauce) and Bakmi Goreng (stir fried egg noodles with egg and veggies) plus plenty of steamed rice.

It was a nice representation of Indonesian cuisine.  The food was delivered hot and on-time in disposable buffet trays.  

We try a lot of restaurants since we do this every week.  Borobudur has joined the ranks of just a handful that we will repeat every 6 to  8 weeks.  Give them a try - whether for a large event or drop in for lunch.  It's a clean, pleasant room and easy to get to.

If you don't know what to order - ask for Yunita and tell her the kinds of things you like and let her decide for you.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Jon R.

description: You shouldnt leave without trying the most tasteful dessert i have had in my life : es Campur!!! Enjoy it!
author: Ane L.

description: Really good Bakmi Goreng and corn fritters.  Very friendly service.
author: David P.

description:
This place is a dream come true! All the flavors were deliciously uniquely Indonesian. I lived there when I was younger and as soon as I tried that mei goreng it brought me back to all of those amazing flavors. Thank goodness for Borobudur! I will definately be coming here as often as possible.

Things to try:

Nasi with Sumatra stew, spicy chicken and coconut curry
Mei goreng with chicken
Satay ayam
author: Kristen D.

description:
After recuperating from a Saturday night extravaganza, the man friend and I decided that we both wanted to "eat something good" and try a new cuisine. Sooo, after reading a blurb about Borobudor in the SF Examiner, we decided to give the place a shot.

The 2 dishes recommended in the SF Examiner were incredible- The Roti Prata (grilled Indian bread w/ curry dipping sauce) and Sate Ayam (Grilled marinated chicken & beef satay w/ peanut dipiping sauce). The satay was juicy and grilled to perfection and the Roti Prata's fluffy, crispy texture and curry dipping sauce were absolute heaven! We also added on the Nasi Uduk (coconut steamed rice w/ lemon grass) which was off the charts.

I was in awe of such outstanding dishes, however when it came time to dig into the main entrees, I was quickly disappointed. We had ordered the Mie Tek Tek noodle dish and the Sambal Goreng Udang shrimp & tofu dish, knowing that both would be spicy- which we both have high tolerances for, but I think I speak for us both in saying that the degree of spiciness for the 2 were insane! The spiciness masked both dishes of all flavor and left us both unsatisfied and reaching for our water/beer/soda between every couple bites to put the fire out. I was really hoping the whole meal would be satisfying, but this left a sour (or more like burnt) taste in our mouthes.

Minus 1 star for the yucky tablecloth stain that was there when we sat down.

Service was fine, but just included the basics- take your order, refill your water, & bring your check, w/ nothing over the top.

If I am ever in the mood for Indonesian appetizers & some tasty coconut rice, I'll come back soley for those, but as far as everything else... I'd rather skip out and spare my tongue.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I haven't had a solid Indonesian meal since the last time I visited Amsterdam and feasted upon Rijsttafel. I've been thinking about hitting this place for a while. Finally made it last night. 

Ordered the stir fried squid, fried whole seabass, and rendang beef. All accompanied by an order of Nasi Uduk (coconut steamed rice with lemongrass). The rice came out first and we tasted it straight up and it was scrumptious. Fluffy, fragrant & flavorful.

The rendang came out and consisted of about 4 or 5 large chunks of brisket-like beef.  The sauce was supposed to be coconut milk based, but if it was it was not dominant. This dish was good, but nothing mindblowing. Could have used more flavor, although the beef was pretty tender and shreddy.

Next up came the whole fried seabass. It was fried perfectly. I was hoping there would be more sauce though. It only came with a small side of sweet Indonesian soy sauce.  Tastey nonetheless.

Finally the squid came out. It was stir fried with a sweet chili sauce. My buddy wasn't too fond of the sauce, but I thought it was the best sauce of the 3 dishes. The squid was very tender and perfectly cooked. Definitely my favorite dish.

Overall the food was nice and enjoyable. I would like to try this spot again with a larger group so that we could sample more dishes. 

If you like Indian and Thai food, but prefer milder flavors you'd definitely dig on this. I like a bit more heat in my food so I ended up adding sambal to just about every thing (except the squid which was flavorful).
author: Brian J.

description:
Credits for this review:  traveled to Indonesia, an Indo bf, I think I've got a pretty good grasp of what is good Indo food, and there is no better place to go in SF than Borobudur.  Borobudur is authentic and delicious.  Missing one star due to their service.  Not necessarily bad service, but they only have 3 ppl working there and service can be slow when they are busy - and they are often very busy.  But they remain very friendly and try their best to serve you quickly.  Nice place to come with a couple of friends to enjoy the portions.

Favorites:
1. Beef Rendang (curry beef with hints of coconut)
2. Ayam Goreng Kalasan (a super tender,meat off the bones honey bbq chicken)
3. Gado Gado (salad with peanut dressing)
4. Milkfish
5. coconut rice
... there's a lot more, but these are the usual selections.

If you are new to Indonesian food and aren't sure what to get, I suggest the rice plates Nasi Rames Padang.

Damn, now I am craving for some Indo food...see you there!
author: Em M.

description:
I've been twice and was very satisfied and pleased with the flavors of  almost every dish I ordered. The first time my friend and I came in was about a month or so ago during the week and we had the eggplant and tofu, the grilled trout with Indonesian salsa, and the barbecued chicken. The eggplant was cooked perfectly (easy to screw up), the fish came whole and was scrumptious and had lots of meat on the bone, and the chicken was superb, tender, and full of flavor (this coming from someone who is extremely bored of eating chicken). We had very friendly service from the sweet older gentleman working there, and the young woman is nice too. 

I was surprised at how busy they were last night (almost a full restaurant at about 8 pm) because of how dead they were the first time we came in. This time we ordered the tender  sauteed spinach with garlic sauce and it reminded me so much of the tasty leafy green dishes  I used to eat growing up in Thailand. My friend and I cleaned the plate. We ordered the white sea bass this time and it wasn't as impressive as the trout and was rather dry and lacking the plumpness I would have expected. We also ordered the shrimp and veggies in curry which was very mild and not as flavorful as I would have hoped but still I wouldn't say it was disappointing, just not my favorite but still pretty tasty. And of course we ate all of this with the coconut rice, why would one ever order jasmine rice if coconut rice is available?! I must eat at Bamboo Village again before I say which one I prefer, as its been years since I've been there. But overall its a great, relaxing place to come with a date, a friend, or your family.
author: Heather U.

description: Nice little restaurant in the TL.  Came here with a bunch of indo friends so of course I felt out of the loop not being able to speak Indonesian.  They ordered and I liked pretty much every dish.  Honestly, i cant tell you what we ordered.  The ambiance is nice and quaint.
author: Alex G.

description: Never had Indonesian food, thank you for the wonderful introduction to it.  Thoroughly enjoyed dinner, all was delicious.
author: Simona D.

description:
One thing I've realized is that Indonesian, Malaysian, Singaporean, and Thai food are very similar.

That being said, I was a bit underwhelmed by this place, given the simple elegance of the restaurant's interior and its perpetually filled with customers.  The roti prata is very delicious, but the other items I ordered - rendeng, and noodles - were familiar and indistinguishable from any other standard Asian meal I've had.  The food was satisfactory, though not memorable, filling, but not what I had expected given the veil of strong yelp reviews on here.
author: Michael P.

description:
I had an overall pleasant experience at Borobudur, and the food was really good, but there were some hiccups throughout the meal that made it a 3-star experience for me. 

We (a group of 6) had reservations on a Friday night but still ended up waiting a good 15 minutes outside because there weren't any tables ready. This is understandable since the restaurant isn't that big and they're popular, esp on Friday nights, but usually if I make a reservation I expect to be seated maybe within 5-10 minutes. 

Second is that their timing on the food needs some work. One appetizer came out a good 10 minutes before the other, and throughout the meal half of the food came out well before the other half..... I would've loved to enjoy the last dish that came out more but by that time I was stuffed. 

Other than that, we had some great food.....except their stir fried noodles can be  a little overly salty. We had roti, fish cakes, beef rendang, fried milk fish (you can eat the bones!), fried rice, string beans, bbq marinated chicken. All were tasty, except nothing truly jumped out at me and makes me want to go back ASAP. I would recommend it to people who want to try Indonesian food, if they want an alternative to Thai, and can take some spice! 

The service was very nice, and we celebrated a friend's birthday with cupcakes there too. But atmosphere is more casual overall.... 

Reservations are highly recommended, esp for big groups on busy nights! Prices came out to be ~$25 per person. Reasonable for a dinner in Nob Hill.
author: Peggy W.

description:
I ate at two 3-1/2 star places today, and this is one of them. As followers of my reviews may know, I tend to hold off reviewing 3-1/2 star places until they resolve up or down.  But it was eating at two 3-1/2 star places in the same day that led me to my own resolution, round this one down and the other one up.

The corn fritters app was actually pretty good, with a slightly spicy peanut sauce. Well on it's way to a 4.

But the vegetable curry didn't have much flavor. And baby corn wins no favors in my book.

So, 3.

Service is friendly.
author: Charles B.

description:
I've been to this restaurant since they were on Geary Blvd (now Tawan's Thai). 

Two foods you folks must try;
Mie Tek Tek Kuah spicy
Nasi Goreng Terasi Babat spicy.

I've tried everything else, they are great too.
author: Wid S.

description:
OK, who're you trying to fool here??  Just because you're selling your food to them Americans you can jack up the price like that?  Come on Borobudur, you can do better!

Anyway, the food here's pretty okay... for people who've never tried the real thing that is.  Just so you know, the food they serve here are "originally" served by folks who wander around the neighborhood with small carts to cook them food on, or by folks who pitch tents right by the street with dust and all the roadside glory.  This garners "the dirtier it is, the better it tastes" motto for the food.  Ooo yeah, Indonesians... the people with stomach of steel.

Now, Borobudur here is smart.  It takes the food of humble origin and slab on the gourmet label on it, and voila, you got yourself the $$ sign for price range (read: overpriced, big time).  But of course, the wealthy yuppies, yippies, and hippies of SF wouldn't mind, would they?

But I'm telling you this: WE KNOW THE TRUTH, BOROBUDUR!
author: Erik C.

description: I'm part Indonesian, and this restaurants tastes just like my mom's food. I even took her here and she was amazed at how good it was :) Any time I want mom's cooking, I just need to come here. The Rendang is phenomenal, yellow curry, spicy nasi goreng, the loempia, I could go on forever. And we can never leave without chendol! yuuuuuuuummmmmmmm.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
Oh man...... I liked this place a lot. It was good. The food was tasty. The ambiance is nice.

We went during the week for lunch and got there just as it opened. It wasn't terribly busy while we were there.

I would definitely go again.
author: Reese W.

description: Oh my oh my!  I didn't know what kind of culinary experience I was going to have since I have never had Indonesian food but I was glad that a dear friend suggested we try Borobudur!  It is was a flavor and culinary adventure for my palate!  We started with Gado Gado and I knew I was really going to enjoy the other dishes we ordered-Beef Rendang, a noodle dish that I can't for the life of me remember name wise, string beans with shrimp paste.  I liked the Beef Rendang and the noodle dish but the string beans with shrimp paste were a bit on the strong side so I wouldn't order that on a return visit.  The service was excellent as the waitress constantly filled up our waters, tea  and so forth.  I am looking forward to trying other things when I am in San Fransisco.
author: Grace C.

description:
YUMMMMM!

the latest installation of my dining club brought me to borobudur for a deeeeeelish indonesian dinner.

the bread with curry dipping sauce (roti prata?) was AMAZING...as was the vegetarian appetizer (the tofu and rice cake were delish)....we also had the honey beef (amazing but maybe a little sticky and dry), some noodles (the highlight) with chicken, spicy spicy spicy fried rice with chicken, bbq chicken with amazing curry sauce, as well as spinach with garlic and tofu.

everything was amazing!  The service was good although minus one big fat star for the timing of the dishes.  We were basically done with our entrees by the time the spinach with tofu came out....i mean really does it take that long?  The bathrooms are a little, lets just say, questionable.

All in all a solid meal and a restaurant I would most certainly go back to! Our dinner for 6 was only $100 and we had a ton of food....but were  being good little girls on a weeknight and didn't have any booze or wine....

YUM
author: Brooke M.

description: This is the first time I have eaten Indonesian food. The food was good and was similar to Thai food.The roti was so delicious and the sauce I literally was going to drink it. I would just go back for the appetizer and the Tumis Bayam Bawang Putih (spinich with tofu and garlic). The chicken dish we ordered was extremely spicy and dry to me. I only could have one bite of the chicken. Even the food was generally good, I do have to say the service was terrible. The waiter was slow to take our order and serve us food. Next time I will just call in an order and eat at home.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Southeast Asian food has a soft spot in my heart. After all, I spent 14 years of my childhood in Malaysia. Although there are many restaurants in the Bay Area serving up Malaysian, Indonesian, Singaporean, or of the like, Borobudur definitely has some of THE best food around. Their rendang is the absolute best I've ever tasted and that is truly saying something considering I have dear friends who make killer versions. Friends who have been to Borobudur, and who are knowledgeable in Indonesian food all proclaim it excellent. Try some of the more traditional dishes (ask your server for suggestions). If they have otak otak, give it a go, it's my absolute favorite. It's fish meat mixed with herbs into a paste and cooked wrapped in a banana leaf. Decor isn't fancy but who needs decor when the food is THIS good?
author: Anita L.

description:
I would rate this a 3 star, but I took off a star for getting chicken when I asked for veggies only.  It took me a few bites to notice.  yuck.

Anyways, the food here was just okay.  Service was a little slow.  Not as slow as bamboo village, but they're a lot friendlier and the food is better there.  The staff didn't seem as attentive either, and not just because I got the wrong food.  It took them a while to notice me waving them over.  And then for me to get a replacement.  Not exactly trying to make up for their mistakes.

Not really much reason to go back.
author: Nessie V.

description: I got the Nasi Uduk Lengkap. I've had Indonesian food a few times and this seemed similar and equally good. I'm eager to try some of the other dishes from here, particularly since I see recommendations for several dishes that I didn't get. I liked what I got, but we'll see in the future if I can love it.
author: Ken L.

description:
Okay, I've seen all the reviews and even heard from some very knowledgeable foodie friends about the wait at this particular establishment and I was prepared for it.  I came armed with my iPod and a dining companion.  Luckily, neither was used to a large extent *ha*.  Perhaps, this stems from the fact that I eat a rather late lunch.

The food is delicious, but I do have a complaint, the portion size is rather small.  Even from a "small plates" or "tapas" standpoint, the appetizer portions are quite miniscule.  The food packs flavor, but I ordered the  Pangsit Goreng Ayam appetizer and was shocked that there was actually more won-ton than chicken mix. In addition, the boyfriend ordered the Kari Ayam and the same "where's the meat" inquiry was issued.  The  Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak was actually adequately seasoned and portioned.

For the price, I was expecting a more robust meal and must admit that we left a bit disheartened by what we had ordered.
author: Hiromi N.

description: The 5 stars are for the Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas with chicken... So delicious I think of ordering 2 at a time...  It's sodium overload, but worth all the water I have to drink afterwards to flush it out!
author: Robyn B.

description:
Went here for lunch.  I really liked the food here although I don't have anything to compare it to as I've never had Indonesian food before.  Kind of similar to Thai, Malaysian, and Chinese.  The food wasn't amazing, but it's pretty good.

As other people have mentioned, the corn fritters are yummy!  We had the grilled fish in sweet sour sauce and the lo mein type dish.  Both were good.  Service was good too but then again I went during lunch and there was hardly any people there.  I would recommend this place to friends and I will def be back.
author: C A.

description:
Service was a bit lacking but this was compensated but their good selection and quality of food.

Reasonable price too.

For those who are not used to spicy food, beware, it cam get pretty hot!
author: Jason C.

description: Terrible terrible service. Food was cold. Ordered was put in wrong. Waited for almost two hours for the WRONG order. Waitress never apologized and accused me of not ordering correctly. Well, that's what you get for NOT writing down my order. You forget. She thought I ordered roti prata instead of roti prata manis. Even if she didn't hear the "manis" part, I had asked for extra condensed milk. Why the hell would I want that with the curry sauce that comes with roti prata. After realizing they gave me the wrong togo order, I went back. They asked me to give back the roti prata. I think they used it for another order. Gross! I opened the package to see if I had the right order and touched it. They didn't care. On top of that, they asked for more money because RPM is more expensive than RP. After waiting for almost two hours for my food and this togo order, they had the nerve to charge me. I was furious! They were never apologetic either. I'm not coming back here for a very very long time. The food is overpriced. Service is slow. They only have one waiter each shift! The food is getting greasier each time I come here. Ugh. I would not recommend this place to any of my friends.
author: Ela A.

description:
I came here last June for a dinner with some friends and colleagues. Having never had Indonesian food, I was quite pleasantly surprised by the dishes I ate. 

Rendang - sumatra beef stew with spices and coconut milk
Mie Tek Tek - goreng. Spicy Java noodle stir fried with egg and vegetable with chicken
Ayam Goreng Kalasan - fried honey chicken. 

The stew was similar to Indian curry, but creamier and the flavor was perfectly balanced by the coconut milk.  The noodles were fluffy and soft, and the chicken was sooooo good.

Plus very reasonably priced! I should make it a point to come back here soon.
author: Aaron F.

description:
Every once in a while I meet up with my friend Dave to have dinner in SF.  He picks the restaurant since he lives there and I'm always confident the place he picks will satisfy my hunger, palette and wallet.  Borobudor satisfied all 3.

I started out with the Lumpia Semarang.  Cubes of chicken, tofu and vegetables tightly packed in a lumpia wrapper and deep fried.  I drizzled the slightly tangy, spicy, nutty sauce on my first helping.  I drenched the second helping.

I couldn't decide on one dish so I ordered a combination rice plate of beef, chicken, tofu and vegetables.  The samplings offered different flavors and spices and I savored every bite.

The staff was friendly and the atmosphere was clean which is a big contrast to the neighborhood it sits in.  All in all, I had a good meal with good friends and I'd definitely go back again.
author: Bernard F.

description: The atmosphere and service was seriously lacking but the food was good. This roast or bbq chicken we had was so tender and moist, just delicious.  There was this interesting peanut sauce potato salad like thingy that seemed to oddly work.
author: Scott M.

description:
First off, I must've come to this restaurant on a really, really off night, because my overall experience was terrible. It was very hard to think highly of this place and just focus on the food when the service is so noticeably bad and lax, there doesn't seem to be anyone overseeing the waiting of tables and seating of people (in fact, a hostess here would be a god-send for this place IMHO),  they sat us at a temporary folding table with dirty linens, and there were two babies crying almost continually the whole time we were there.

My bf and I did enjoy some of the food - we had the veggie sampler platter (he's a vegetarian) and we both thought that the soy bean cake and tofu were really good. The sauce that came with it all really elevated what could've been really boring fried corn and tofu. This was followed by gado gado, a really yummy salad with a really great peanut dressing. We had coconut rice (which was lovely) with bakim goreng and the spicy eggplant dish. Indonesian food has many assertive flavors; going from extremely sweet to incredibly spicy. So, be careful when you order your food. When I began to eat the spicy eggplant, it was such a shock to me because everything before had been pretty sweet. In fact, that kind of ended the meal for me, and didn't leave me feeling too well.
author: Jen E.

description:
I've had my fair share of Indonesian food when I was living there during my first two years in High School.  Indonesian food has never caught on here in the states, but my recent trip to the City and the restaurant Borobudur gives promise that almost-authentic Indonesian food can be had.  Once I heard all the Bahasa Indonesia from the staff, it brought a nostalgic feeling with me.  From the smells, the noise, the furnishings,  I actually thought I was back in Jakarta.  Which leads us to the food...

Get the Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas.  This is Fried Rick with shrimp paste and it ROCKS!!!  This dish alone made me come to the conclusion that this indonesian restaurant is the real deal.  The Empal Goreng also had a nice taste if you like nice tender beef.  

There is valet parking behind the buildings.  Borobudur validates for 1hr if you spend $30 or more.  Not bad at all.  If you're in the City, I highly recommend this place.  Moderate/reasonable prices for delicious food.

I want to try the Rijsttafel the next time I'm up there and if I'm real hungry.  If any of you have tried it, please let us all know how it is.

Cheers!
author: Edmund I.

description: I've been here 2 times and Indonesian food is not for me, unlike Indian, Chinese, Thai and other Asian cuisines Indonesian food just does not taste goodl, it has no identity and the flavors do not pair with one another.
author: N A.

description:
I found an OPEN STAPLE in my rendang while having dinner there with my husband and six friends after my 10th yr. high school reunion.  It was my idea to go there in the first place, and I am still shocked that this happened.

The wait staff did not apologize upon being told about what happened, and seemed to disbelieve me.  

Terrible, terrible, terrible.  And Yelp, I understand that this is a very negative remark, but it is completely true.  Please do not remove this post, in the spirit of public opinion and SAFETY.
author: Ariana H.

description:
My pal Marisol and I hit the place at around 7 and beat the rush by fifteen minutes or so.  Like a lot of folks here, I caught the rave review on Check Please Bay Area.  We're both pretty adventurous eaters and neither of us had tried Indonesian food.  Extremely nice staff including the waitress who served us.  No frills decor, but I've come to expect this from a lot of Asian restaurants and it doesn't bother me a bit.  

We ordered the tamarind soup with tomatoes, jackfruit, and chopped up corn on the cob (yes, pieces of cob) as well as baby corns and peppers.  It was pretty good and really hearty.  Next we ordered the green beans with dried shrimp (which was recommended on the show as well as here on Yelp) and the lamb curry.  I wasn't all that crazy about the sweet, fishy taste of the shrimp.  Again, not offensive or anything, just not my thing.  Finally, the lamb was extremely tender but also very dry.  Nothing in this meal really popped for me.

Did you ever go out with someone and she's nice enough and she's cute enough and you have a decent enough time but there's just no spark there and neither of you calls the other again?  That's pretty much my experience with Borobudur.  This was my first time both at Borobudur and eating Indonesian food.  It's always tough in a situation like this since I don't know if I'm just not that crazy about the cuisine or the restaurant's food.  

(This is my first Yelp review and I'm sort of upset it's so middle of the road, but hey, I've got to call a spade a middle of the road spade.)
author: Cory B.

description:
I was born and grew up in Indonesia, and I like this place very much.  My mom is still my favorite chef.  But if you cannot travel 20 hours to taste your mom's cooking, this restaurant will do.

My friends and I have been to the Borobodur restaurant several times, and every single time, I wasn't disappointed.  The best way to enjoy Indonesian dishes is to share with your family, friends or that special someone.  That way, you can taste different dishes.  If you dine solo, then try their rice plate dishes (nasi rames, nasi uduk lengkap or nasi pedang) or noodles dishes (bakmi ayam).

Well...that's all for now, and I hope you enjoy Indonesian dishes.
author: Adriana Y.

description:
I forget how much I really love Indonesian food. I also love it when we can't decide what to order because that means there are so many great things on the menu.  My favorite kind of stress! 

So our friends from Bali were visiting the city and requested to have Indonesian food. Naturally we took them here and they were both very happy with the food.  

For starters we had the roti prata (layered bead) w/ curry dipping sauce and it was delicious and gone within minutes.
