Next came the tempeh goreng (fried soybean cake) w/ spicy peanut dipping sauce and that too quickly disappeared. I could eat these by the bucket. Probably the best tempeh preparation out there. Who knew tempeh could be so addicting.

Then came a genorous portion of the bakmi goreng (stir fried egg noodles w/ chicken & veggies). Our little guy loved slurping up those fat, yummy noodles and so did the rest of us.

The rendang (tender spiced beef cooked in coconut milk) was amazing. This was the one dish our Balinese friends were longing for and they nailed it perfectly.  Definitely a must with every visit from now on. 

The bbq'd chicken was moist and spiced just right.  You get half a chicken per order w/ a spicy/sweet sauce on the side. 

We also had a couple of the lunch plates (L1 &L2) and found it the best way to sample more of their offerings. Nice presentation, great combinations and tons exotic flavors fighting for your attention. 

The service from start to finish was very good, friendly and casual. Spacious room w/ nice large windows.  We left very happy, satisfied and wished we were all in Bali again.
author: Jane F.

description:
I'll perface by saying I've never met an Indonesian restaurant I didn't like--nay, LOVE.  That said, Borobudur is charming and delicious.  The peple who work there are happy to strike up friendly conversation, even giving me tips on my lifetime search for the best beef rendang recipe.  THAT'S love.

I was only in for a snack, so I can only vouch for the roti (paratha) canai, but it's splendid!  They use fresh ingerdients for the curry (as opposed to Indonesian curry powder), and I literally drank the curry out of the bowl with a spoon.  Okay, I'll fess up, I'm known to do that in Indonesian/Malaysian restaurants, but still...YUM.

Next time I'm trying the rendang and the soup.
author: Sara L.

description: Borobudur provides authentic Indonesian food in a pleasant, sit-down atmosphere. It's the only bay-area purely Indonesian restaurant, and they do a solid job.  However, their food is somewhat overpriced and small-portioned, and some of their dishes clearly contain MSG.  But if you want to eat Indonesian, it's the way to go.
author: Joaquin E.

description: Went here for the first time. Never really had Indonesian food before. It was good. Ordered a noodle dish, the shrimp curry, and tried to chicken satay with peanut sauce. The place is fairly clean, but service was so-so. I'd need to try more Indonesian restaurants and to experience better service before giving them 4 stars.
author: Julie T.

description: my Indonesian friend told me here has the best Indonesian food in SF. the portion and the quality is consistent. we came on a Sunday afternoon, it was packed with people! my favorite is "em pek pek"(pretty sure I spelled it wrong:/ )
author: Babybabe S.

description:
Came here recently for dinner, there was a line of people which is always a good sign.  I have never had Indonesian food before and must say that this was definitely a good first experience! The service was a bit strange as they had about 3 or 4 different people come up to us one right after another asking how many people we had in our party. (there was only 2 of us, plus another table of 4), finally when we were seated, he gave us our menus, and our plates, only to take our plates away and give them to another table.  Then he moved us over to another table across the room. Oook...

We ordered the Mie Tek Tek noodle dish & this other combination dish that i don't remember now what it was called, but the noodles were phenomenol. just the right amount of kick without being overly spicy, the portion was generous and we wolfed it down in minutes.  The combo dish had spicy tofu, lamb, marinated beef, coconut rice and veggies. A very interesting and flavorful dish to get a little taste of everything. 

All in all, i would definitely come back to this place and try another dish along with the Mei Tek Tek!!
author: Lulu C.

description: Went there once because I was told by many people to go. It was dinner time. The food was ok, and not as great as I thought. Reasonable price and was lucky to get a table (as it is small and there was a crowd after we had just sat down)
author: Dilip R.

description:
7pm Saturday night - we were the first one there.  A little worrying.

Then people started showing up and the place was 2/3 full when we left at 9pm.

The food was great.  The service was very good and prompt (the place was only 1/2 full and empty for most of the time we were there though).  And our party was already talking about coming back here for the next meal - I think that's the sign of a good restaurant, no?

It's always a little weird to talk about what you are going to order next time when you still haven't finished your current meal.  You start spying on dishes other people are ordering and eating.  You get a business card.  You ask for the manager's name.  You try to see what where would be the 'secret' parking location.  You look foward to the left over fried rice...

If you like Thai or Malay food, you wil like Indonesian food and Borobudur does a good job with it.  I lived in Malaysia for 3 years and so I had exposure to all sorts of SE Asian cuisine.  This is good stuff, reasonable price ($80 for four people, with tips, and probably enough food for 5 people).
author: Hanson L.

description: not a bad place to get your roti prata and beef rendang fix.  service is on the slow side.
author: Clara H.

description:
Came here on a Friday night, my bf made reservations, but still waited like 15 minutes. Not because there was no tables, just no one were cleaning the dirty tables. Anyways, we had a table in the front, which wasn't that great, since there was like a lot of people waiting around my table. 

So for appetizers, we got the roti prata. Best roti I had in the city. 

I ordered the Mie Tek Tek, thanks to other yelpers' recommendations =). It was really good! I feel like there was not enough noodles, but it did come in a really big bowl full of soup. 

My boyfriend picked the Nasi Padang. Which was good also, but I felt like it was a really small order as well.

We really wanted to order more food because I was still quite hungry, but wow..i have to say..the service is SO BAD!!!!! We asked for a bowl, at least 3 times, and it never came...fine. We asked for chopsticks..never came as well..ok whatever. I ordered a drink, asked for it at least 5 times, and it finally came at the end of the meal. 

Even though service is bad, I will forgive them because the food is GOOD! So I will come again, but just not when it is super duper busy. Or maybe they need to hire couple more workers on busy nights.
author: Willa L.

description: I can't decide whether I like Borobudur better than Indo Cafe in LA, but this place kicks ass!! Get the roti pratta, sate ayam, and beef rendang and watch all your troubles melt away. They actually serve wine there and the choices aren't bad for an Indo place, but you can also byob with no corkage. Last time I was there, we brought a bottle we had just gotten from wine tasting in Sonoma and it was the perfect addition to our meal! Highly recommend!
author: Duncan G.

description: Excellent Indonesian food. Get the rice table and you won't be disappointed! It's a lot of food, but for that you get to sample a lot of dishes and you get their beef rendang. It was stewed fatty beef in a spicy tomatoey coconutty sauce. I'm not sure what goes into it, but it's soooo good with white rice. Everything tasted fresh and had a slightly sweet slightly salty twist.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description: Great tasting, fairly authentic (albeit a tad greasy) Indonesian food. Service was quick and the staff were friendly. Well decorated and the ambience was overall quite nice, except they were playing some Sirius XM station that seemed like it was titled "Hits of the 70's, 80's, and 90's". I'd much rather not listen to Cher when I'm enjoying a fantastic Indonesian meal, thank you.
author: Ravi S.

description: We were expecting this to be a hole in the wall with the decor to match, but it turned out to be surprisingly spacious and comfortable.  The food was almost uniformly excellent.  The chicken satay was not nearly as good as the beef satay, but to be fair, the waitress had warned us that was the case when we ordered.  The Nasi Goreng Borobudur (house fried rice), Bakmi Goreng Kari (curry stir-fried noodles), and Tahu & Terong Balado (spicy eggplant and tofu) were items we would order again without any hesitation.  But with such a large menu, I'm not sure we'd be able to avoid the temptation to try other things.
author: John H.

description:
If the food here is Indonesian, it must resemble what one might find at a very bad Indonesian cafeteria.  A large group of us recently had dinner, ordering at least 10 dishes.  Flavors were exotic, if ones definition of exotic goes no further than sugar, salt, and inferior oil.  Most of the dishes were bland, oversalted or oversweet, tasted rewarmed, and completely lacked distinction.  
One of the less offensive dishes was the Rendang, which tasted merely tired, but an eggplant dish was oily, super sweet, and scarily bright red.  Green beans were overwhelmed by salt and fermented shrimp, a noodle dish was sticky and very sweet, and even simple steamed rice was over-starchy and flavorless.  A spinach dish was only slightly abused, and passible.
Two curries had almost no curry flavor.  If there ever had been a spark of brightness in any of the ingredients before they reached our table, it had been clubbed lifeless.
The waiter had that racketeering condescension with which people who work in such places protect their self-pride--if the customers are willing to eat food this bad, they deserve what they get.
Borobudur must rely on an unending stream of innocent tourists.  I can't imagine that any self-respecting local would eat here twice.
author: Jim S.

description: Delicious Indonesian food and cozy atmosphere.  Will definitely be back.
author: Rebecca S.

description:
I have to give this place 5 stars for a couple reasons. 

1. I'm Indonesian
2. That means I demand high quality from Indonesian restaurants and this is probably one of the best I've been to outside of Indonesia (contending w/Toko Rame in Artesia/Bellflower aka So Cal)
3. I had a great time for a "surprise" occasion with friends (all of whom have been to the country and experienced the sensation that is Indonesian food)

So what did I have... well let me tell you that variety at this place was not lacking. I ended up ordering the otak2 (which is basically fish cake wrapped in banana leaves served w/peanut sauce) as an appetizer and the nasi rames dish, basically rice with chicken, beef, tempe (Indonesian soy cake thing) and a chili egg. I don't eat beef, so I passed that along to others but everything else was much like eating with family at home, minus the part where I have to pay. I also took the liberty of ordering cendol drink. The drink was a little too sweet for my liking, but other than that fine.

Saturday night was busy, quite busy for any Indonesian restaurant I've tried to be honest! Which was a good thing, and plus it gave an excuse for slow service (if you have been to many Indonesian restaurants, you'll notice that service is slow no matter what! Yes even if the restaurant is empty!!). Price wise, this was the most expensive Indonesian restaurant I've seen, but I guess I'd pay more to get authentic food over something otherwise. The server was nice, and everyone had an enjoyable time, so it's not a place to be missed.
author: Yosie G.

description:
excellent, authentic food. my roommate is indonesian and she introduced me to this place. 

love the grilled trout, the roti prata, the honey chicken is INCREDIBLE, it melts in your mouth. the sayur assem soup is also very tasty. 

service could definitely be improved but the food is delicious, portions are big and it's very well priced.
author: Jae C.

description:
Haven't been recently but every time I have it's been damn good. 

My Mom's parents lived in Indonesia for about ten years, right before she was born, and my Mom said Borobudur's Bakmi Goreng (which I probably spelled wrong) was even better than her Mom's...a compliment that doesn't mean anything if my grandma couldn't cook.

Keeping it short: I've been a half-dozen times and have never been let down, and that's hard to do, because I always find something to rub me the wrong way. 

Woulda given it five stars, but sometimes the wait for a table is really long even if you've made a reservation. Otherwise the service and food are great.
author: That Was A Good Drum Break ..

description:
I'm not an expert in Indonesian food, but I have been to several Southeast Asian restaurants all around the bay area so I'm merely comparing the flavors here to other restaurants I've been to.  I noticed on the menu that you can order a set meal, sort of a prix-fixe dinner.  It comes with soup, an appetizer, an entree and dessert.  The other dishes were family-style, so we just decided to order from the menu.

We started off with the roti prata and deep-fried tofu.  The roti prata was delicious, but the sauce was watered down.  The tofu was in perfect bite-sized pieces and the peanut sauce that accompanied it was the perfect blend of sweet and nutty!  For dinner, we had the shrimp curry with vegetables, which was good, but a bit bland. They didn't ask about spice level, so I assumed it would be somewhat spicy, but it wasn't spicy at all!  We also had the string beans with shrimp paste, which had just the right amount of everything!  The dessert menu looked good, but we just didn't have room to try any of them.

As with most restaurants in this area. it's not a big restaurant, but they do have space for a group dinner.  I would probably come here again to try the other dishes.
author: Jeannette S.

description:
I believe one of the beauties of this city is the food. Everywhere you go you're always bound to find some place you've never tried. I had never had Indonesian food until my friend helped me discover Borobudur! An experience of dining I will never forget. 

Indonesian food reminds me of Thai food, which some of the dishes are fairly similar. So if you like Thai, you will most likely like Indonesian. Infused with peanut sauces, spiciness here and there, and very flavorful meats! They offer a course meal which includes a good amount of dishes (appetizers, main plates including rice, plus dessert). Which runs roughly about $25 per person. Well worth it, until I realized how full I was. It was a lot of food for two, and the dessert was even amazing (a red bean rice with coconut milk..the right amount of salty and sweet put together in a bowl of creaminess!). 

The waitress was very nice, and helpful. She even named off each plate as she brought them and answered any questions we had. The waiter with the water was awesome, and overwhelmingly refilled my cup with water constantly. 

There was plenty of seating for a quiet and relaxing dinner.

I had a great experience, and can't wait to return & share the yumminess of Indonesian food with my friends!

P.S. I went with an Indonesian friend, and he loved it. Therefore you can't doubt this place at all! ;)
author: Catherine O.

description: Oh, the corn fritters! Very yum. The rest of the food was tasty, but not particularly memorable. Each dish seems dedicated to one single flavor, texture, and color--which is bit much to take in a single setting. Some variety on the plate would be good. Still, I'm glad to have another dependable restaurant to visit when I'm downtown, and I will be back.
author: Brian W.

description:
Very affordable. Never crowded. Honey chicken. The roti otherwise known as the pancake doughy stuff with gravy is...yum. yum. 

Don't get the dessert ice cream shake thing unless you know what it really is.
author: Kris O.

description:
A pleasant lunch-time Indonesian restaurant, just a few blocks off the beaten path. Their lunch fare is comfort food (if you include the occasional four-alarm hot dish as comforting), the service is efficient and friendly, and the place has decent ambience. 

I wouldn't go out of my way to eat lunch here, but I will come again when I'm in the neighborhood.

ATTENTION, RIJSTTAFEL FIENDS (you know who you are) - yes, they have it, though I didn't have the opportunity to try it. It's a $25/person prix fixe dinner.
author: Pat T.

description:
I went to the actual Borobodur in Indonesia, and the rice on my Nasi Padang plate came in the shape of the stupas at Borobodur, so cute!

The Nasi Padang tasted great, but just like in Indonesia, the portions were kinda small. The Roti Prata appetizer was a miss though. Excessively doughy and the sauce just wasn't great.

Staff was great and very attentive. Prices were OK. I had a hard time coughing up $18 bucks for something I remember paying $1.50 for in Indonesia. Oh well. It is a nice change of pace from Thai food (which I love!)
author: Rocky K.

description:
I guess we weren't the only ones who saw the Check Please! Bay Area episode feature this place. We got there at about 6:30pm and go seated fairly quickly at the last available table. It got crowded from that point on.

Great food and presentation. Everything was well prepared and full of flavor.

I'll be back here.
author: Simon S.

description: OMG; terrible disappointment. Sorry Lo for picking this place. It was so highly rated on Channel 9's Check Please. Then I read what Yelpers were saying and got excited. Food and service deserve no more than one star. Satay was cooked over a gas burner and you could taste the gas, string beans were mealy and tasteless, the bread and curry were pretty good, the chicken dish was nothing but pieces of legs, tough and very difficult to eat even with a knife. They took our order and then some guy with rubber gloves on delivered the food. I had to practically beg for another Tiger beer, and we did not see the waiter again until he brought the check.  Empty for a Thursday night in the City.
author: Gary J.

description: Excellent melange of flavors. Do the sampler platter for one and share it. You won't be disappointed. You can too easily spend too much money here and the ambiance is lacking somewhat, but the uniqueness of the food makes up for it.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Another winner in the TL.  

I brought my San-Francisco-is-so-expensive parents here for an affordable pre-theater-dinner.  So affordable, in fact, that I brought along two friends to distract the parents and we ordered a Gluttonous Feast:

:: The roti was a deep-fried crowd-pleaser of layers to tear apart and dip into spicy goodness.
:: Spring rolls were snatched up so quickly I can't be sure we actually ordered them.
:: Empek-Empek Palembang, a "deep fried fish cake filled with egg in spicy vinegar sauce" demanded to be ordered for the name and the sheer impossibility of the description.  Interesting flavor and texture combination, if you're into fish cake.  
:: Gado-Gado was ordered for the same reason (potato noodle salad?), and was the big winner of the night for me.  It's a mish-mash of things common sense says not to combine that I could eat every day.
:: The java noodles were also a big hit, and we all coveted the noodle dish on a neighboring table.
:: The string bean with shrimp paste was loved by everyone but me (maybe shrimp paste isn't my thing), but the shrimp curry was a fantastic mix of coconut milk and spices and came with more shrimp than we, being sane people, could reasonably eat.
:: The spinach with garlic and the bean sprouts with tofu and salty fish were good, but not wow.

If only it were closer...
author: Dana S.

description: This review is specifically for people with food allergies.  In terms of the food, I thought this restaurant was average at best, but not terrible.  Unfortunately they do not make up for average food with friendly service.  This restaurant is extremely unfriendly to people with food allergies.  The server was unhelpful and slightly rude when I explained that I needed to confirm that the dish I had selected didn't have soy sauce or wheat flour in it.  I thought I had picked something that would be safe, but unfortunately it was not.  I had to ask for the menu back and tried to pick  it out quickly but the server was already gone and he didn't come back until minutes before the rest of our dishes arrived.  So everyone was almost done by the time my dish arrived.  I will not be going back.
author: Martha K.

description:
Just went here for dinner.  The food is great-- though a little less intensely spiced & flavored than the real thing in Indonesia/Singapore.  Likely to better fit the American palate.  

I had the roti prata, spicy beef rendang, and spicy nasi goreng.  All were delicious -- though I had to ask for extra chili.  Wait staff is very nice, but they are definitely understaffed.  Would definitely come back her though as I'm a big fan of Indonesian food.
author: Wojtek K.

description:
I've passed Borobudur countless times on my trek home. I would peer into the window, see a few diners inside; while never crowded or ever near capacity, seeing Asian patrons bode well of the restaurant's authenticity. Tonight I finally ventured in to satiate my curiosity. And I wasn't disappointed.

Greeted warmly, we were seated in one of many booths that lined the perimeter of the restaurant. The room was aglow with candle light and made for a very pleasant evening meal. Glancing at the menu, our eyes widened at the first page - Rijsttafel. Unpronounceable, we still marveled at the list of foods included in their prix fix. For about $27, one can enjoy - lemongrass soup, fried spring roll, chicken satay in peanut sauce, cucumber salad with shrimp chips, stir fried tofu, beef rendang, bbq chicken in chili sauce, shrimp and vegetable curry, jasmine rice, and dessert. The food presentation was quite marvelous. The main dishes and rice came out in individual bowls atop of a long rectangular double deck tray, the bottom tray full of tea lights to keep the food warm while you eat. How cool is that?

10 courses allowed us to get a taste of Indonesia. Favorite savory dishes from the set were the salad in peanut sauce (cool crisp, nutty flavor) and the fried tofu (slightly sweet and soft). The other dishes were good too but not necessarily extraordinary. The dessert of black rice with coconut milk (Burbur Ketan Hitam) was delish though. We couldn't get enough of the chewy rice, with the sweet milk. 

So on top of all that food, we also sampled the Roti Prata ($7.50), which is a pan fried layered bread served with curry dipping sauce. Oooh sooo good. This was the biggest, flakiest roti I've had. We also ordered the Mie Tek Tek ($9.95), spicy stir fried noodles with chicken and vegetables. It comes extra spicy so be sure to ask them to temper it to your tastes buds. Would definitely order both of these dishes again.

All in all, a fabulous dining experience. Borobudur is a new find!
author: Cindy W.

description:
Indonesian food, highly underrated and sadly ignored by the culinari-rati of San Francisco for the most part.  Sigh, what to do?  Aside from trying to start my own Balinese restaurant, which is what I need to do just like I need a hole in my head- I wander out sometimes hoping to find an Indonesian resto  in any US locale that will do justice to the wondrously diverse and incredibly colorful palette of ingredients that originate from  this exotic Southeast Asian archipelago.  
Borobudur, well, you do have some good things some memory.  Not much energy, up there on Post street, its always so darn quiet in there.  But the service is nice and I like to order a bit in Bahasa Indonesia- because I love to speak food in many languages, I feel its my duty to know.  Engage me in any other subject and surely you will see me struggle, but my vocabulary seems to be filled with food terms from many languages.  Its pleasant to use them at times.
I like the tempeh goreng here.  Simple nutty fried pieces of tempeh with a simple sweet chili dipping sauce.  The young jackfruit soup, nice and vegan, kind of watery but the jackfruit stands on its own to make a meal.  You certainly won't mistake it for Tom Yum.  I've had the roti here and its pleasant.  I will come back and trip down memory lane, and report my findings.  I certainly think of this place often.  If it was more vibrant, I'd crave, but i don't- unless I  am feeling all vegany- then it makes lots of sense.
author: Kevin M.

description: This is the only place in san francisco to get good indonesian's food.  Don't  trust the indonesian/thai.  Fake! yuck!... okay, back to Borobudur.  I guess Borobudur was named after a temple in indonesia.  The name said it all.. It's a temple of good indonesian's food.  let's see.. i had the chicken's curry (Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak) Excellent! and for appetizer, i had Empek Empek Palembang.  Fishy..not really good, but hey it's indonesian's food.  okay! the last complaint that i have is the Free 1 Hour Parking Validation if you spend more than $35.  cmmon! how can we enjoy your good food if you only give us one hour to enjoy your food.  geeez! cmmon.. but 5 stars for the food.  my rating is all about the food.
author: Mikey D.

description:
I had one of the soups for dinner earlier this evening. 

I was quite delighted and pleased with what I ordered. It was one of the spicy soups. You could have it as soup or stir fry; I had it as soup. There was a good variety of tastes! The chicken and the noodles were nice and tender. 

I think I'd have to go again before giving it 5 stars though, since I only had one dish. 

'Til then Borobudur!
author: Aromy X.

description:
We attempted to get in on a weekday night but would have to wait for one hour. So we decided to go there at 5:30 to have an early Saturday dinner and we got seated right away. 

We liked their Lumpia Semarang, more flavors than the regular spring rolls. The Oseng Tahu Tempe was OK only and the soy bean cake wasn't very impressive. Nasi Goreng seemed to be a must for every table including ours.   It tasted good. Tiger prawn in honey sauce was pretty good.

By the time we were trying to order dessert, there was already a long line at the door. So the young waitress tried to talk us out ordering any other desserts except two were readily served. So we had to go with the layer cake. It was good though. They obviously didn't want us to sit and hold the table for another 30 minutes just for a few bulks dessert. 

Many people went there after the TV show including us. But it wasn't as fantastic as we expected for its food and service.  It's somewhere between 3 and 4 stars and ended at the lower end due to its pushy service.
author: Ile F.

description: Very good food. The waitress was nice. Seemed a bit nervous but was very polite. We got skewers, egg noodles with chicken, shrimp curry, everything was prepared very well, and tasted excellent. Recommended.
author: Christopher F.

description:
We visited this restaurant during the Thanksgiving break. I really had high hopes for this place because of the incredible reviews. It's sad but it was a very forgettable meal. 

Here is what we had between 6 adults:

1. Grilled Trout with chili lime sauce - this dish was decent... the sauce needed a punch. 
2. 2 orders off the Lumpia (eggrolls)  with a peanut dipping sauce. Again very average.. . I guess I have been spoiled with amazing Vietnamese eggrolls. The fillings to the eggrolls tasted dry.. needed some fat. And the dipping sauce was too rich and heavy for me. 
3. Shrimp curry - Again missing that wow factor.. was extremely mild. I like my curries strong and complex. I was comparing it to the wonderful Thai curries I love. 
4. Fried noodles.. with egg, chicken, forgot the name . This was my favorite dish.. You can't really  mess up fried noodles. It was my comfort dish for the night.
5. Lamb curry - My father enjoyed this dish. He said that the lamb was tender. I did not try this dish because I do not eat lamb. Most of the table enjoyed this dish
6. Spicy Chicken - By far the worse dish! This was actually a rec from the waiter. It was just a big thigh/drum stick fried and smothered with some chili /syracha sauce. It appeared to be a safe dish they would rec to people that are trying Asian food for the first time. Mild and non offensive. Very very disspointed with this dish.  It was a dish you make at home with leftover chicken and just toss hot sauce on.
7. Beef Stew- Rendang? I was really looking forward to this one becuase I have had it at another Indonesian restaurant before. The meat was very tender, but it was SO Salty!!!! I could not get over how salty it was.. it tasted like they poured ina whole cup of salt in it!!!!

For dessert we shared:

Fried Banana with Ice Cream -  I was expecting a crispy crust and soft banana inside.. it was dense and tasted like old oil.

Sweet sticky rice with coconut milk - I enjoyed the glutinous rice and combination of the coconut milk

Service was impeccable.. they were very attentive.. always filled our glasses full of water and cleared out the plates when we needed them to without asking. 

Maybe I ordered all the wrong dishes? Or maybe we just have better Thai/Indonesian restaurants in So Cal.
author: Karen H.

description: A great find in the TL. We had the Sumatran beef, Spicy BBG Chicken and Roti.  All three were amazing!  The meat was fork tender and the flavor was amazing. We lived it and will definitely be back.
author: t m.

description:
Warning: i'm reviewing this place a few weeks after coming back from amsterdam and sampling the best indonesian food in the world and I'm grading Borobudur on a curve.
Nice place, very friendly staff. The food was good, not great. We tried the rijsttafel. Some of the things were a hit, others, just ok. The peanut sauce with garlic that came up with the spring rolls was the highlight of the meal! Rendang was good as well. Looking around, the rijstaffel wasn't a very popular item so next time I'll probably stick with a la carte. I would certainly go there again.
author: Rayid G.

description:
Who could resist indonesian food?  I was walking down the street  Indonesian just sounded like something new, hopefuly tasty and possibly exciting.  The food left me with major mixed feelings.  Some of it was really tasty, some of it was mediocre.  While i think this place has great potential, i have some misgivings about it.  Maybe if i had better knowledge of what to order it would of gone better for me. 

If i recal, #32 was really good, #34 was ok.
author: Herbert S.

description:
Super spicy! Make sure you order a milk based drink to put the fire out that will ignite in your mouth.  

Totally my mistake, we should not have said "make it hot!".  Good eats otherwise.
author: Bhumika K.

description:
I don't know if my review is biased because I was pretty drunk and starving by the time my group ended up here.  I have always walked by and thought it looked good but never have been.

We had a big group and were seated right away, we also were there pretty late and the staff was really nice not trying to rush us out or anything.

I had the honey chicken which was amazing, I sampled some of the honey beef and it was also tasty.  My friend and fellow yelper Jenny S. Got these spicy noodles, I think they were called Java something, and they were ridic.  So spicy that it numbed your mouth, but in a good way.

Lots of food to go around they also had a lot of platter options that came with rice and a few different things which looked cool.  Oh yeah one thing I did not like was a shrimp chip, which some people may be into but, to me it tasted like fish food smells.
author: Katie M.

description:
A solid Indonesian restaurant. I went here for lunch with a team from work on a random Thursday. It was completely empty when we came in, and only a handful of customers materialized the entire time we were there. Which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it tells you people aren't clamoring for Indonesian in the tenderknob.

Overall, the menu was as expected, the flavors were mild yet satisfying. As usual with most Indonesian places, the soup and the roti prata stole the show. Both were very good.

Unfortunately, Borobudur just doesn't have anything that makes you say "I want to come back to this place". The food is OK, the service and decor are OK...but everything is just OK...not memorable in any sense.
author: Tolga E.

description: It's a very small but bustling restaurant. We were here for a birthday celebration so we ordered the set menu which came with loads of food: soup, rolls, chicken skewers, maybe like 6 entrees total with rice...their roti is pretty good. It's a cute corner Indonesian place!
author: Jamie T.

description:
Delightful restaurant close to our hotel. 

Satay was generous and well cooked. Rice and noodle dishes were carefully prepared, nicely spiced, and served in a timely fashion. 
Service was friendly and prompt. Given that this was San Francisco, the prices were quite reasonable for all dishes. The decor was simple and the establishment spotless.

Highly recommended.
author: Mark F.

description:
After hitting the first Thursday at 49 Geary and polishing off a few at Tunnel Top, I was about to fall over from hunger. Katie M. had been wanting to try this spot for awhile, so I was in like Flynn. 

I ordered some noodles, but I can't quite recall the name. They were flat noodles with chicken, some veggies and a spice-dawg sauce. I love spice. Bring it on. I may have taken it too far this time. I should have known better when the waited warned me, "This spicy". It was like going to an Indian restaurant and asking for super spicy. They were the most delish noodles I've ever had, but my mouth burned for hours. It was well worth it. My mouth is actually watering right now just thinking about those damn noodles! Katie ordered the honey chicken and I must say it was a tasty treat. I suggest this spot if you're in the mood for mind numbing spicyness. Yum!
author: Jenny S.

description:
The food was definitely worth the wait. I think the service could have been a little more prompt but they had a full restaurant. 

I tried the spicy noodle soup and the server suggested that I calm it down. I like my food spicy, which it was, but also full of flavor. It was an enjoyable meal and I will go back again soon.
author: Carolina H.

description:
As one of my first experiences with indonesian food, I have to it was pretty good.

Had the roti prata, which was really good. Nice and fluffy, with a goo sauce. The fried sampler platter was okay, the corn fritter was good, but the tofu and soy thing were just okay.

Had the chicken noodles, as well as the eggplant/ beef, and shrimp with potatoes. The chicken noodles were actually really tasty and good. The other two were good, but tasted very similar with similar sauces. 

If I had a craving for the roti prata, I would go here again!

3 and 1/2 stars
author: Eddy N.

description:
Hmm... don't want to disappoint anybody, but my food wasn't all that good. At least not as I am used to due to the spices in the food were, I thought... kind of weak. I ordered the veggy rice plate, but my husband ordered Nasi Uduk Lengkap and he said that it was awesome and loves it.  And, I also thought that they are a little pricey for the portions they serve. So, maybe I'm just picky because I know how the real authentic tastes like since I am Indonesian.

Anyway, when we were there, the place was full and it looked like they couldn't manage the crowd! 

But, I would for sure come again and will try the family style.. maybe that would pick my taste buds better!
author: Daisy S.

description:
I've been here about five times and I would say it's the place to go for Indonesian food in the City.  I live across the street from Bamboo Village on Geary and their beef rendang is tasty, but I prefer Borobudur's food.

First off, the roti pratha alone gives this place 4 stars in my book.  It's the flat, Asian, fried version of a buttery croissant, with a light curry dipping sauce.  Their #62 chicken is tender and flavorful and even their nasi rames is plated beautifully with a nice selection of food.  They plate their rice in the latter in the form of a mini wat or temple of some sort.  It's a nice detail that wasn't lost on me.  I haven't felt compelled to throw down for the rieffstaffel yet, but it's nice to know that I have that option.

So, if you're even in the neighborhood to check out Huf, hike a block down the hill and fill yourself up with the warm, rich flavors of Borobudur!
author: Mariss D.

description: Bodobudur has become my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. It is authentic, and I have the proof to back it up, since my roommate is Indonesian and he loves going there. I often order the spicy tofu and eggplant with chili sauce which is one of the most delicious dishes I have ever had in my life. I've gone with groups of friends multiple times so I've sampled many of the dishes and it's all good. The only negative thing is often they do not have enough servers when the restaurant is full and service can get glacially slow. But the excellent food makes up for it. Prices are reasonable for what you get. I'm a vegetarian but one of my meat eating friends said that the chicken egg rolls were amazing.
author: Eric v.

description:
*** 4.6 STARS ***

I just moved to the City a couple months ago and I quickly realized I had quite the gastronomic journey ahead of me.  One day, as we were BBQing in Dolores Park, I asked a good buddy of what her FAVORITE restaurant in the city was.  I expected the typical "Oh, I dunno...there's a bunch".  Instead, without hesitation, she mentioned it was an Indonesian restaurant around Civic Center.  

My interest was piqued. Indonesian food is my FAAAVORITE.  Mom and Grams cooked it all the time growing up, stuffed my face with it whenever we visited the fam in Jakarta, couldn't get enough of it when I went to school in Indonesia!  I've always been curious as to why Indonesian food has not reached the same level of popularity here in the US as Chinese, Japanese, Thai, Vietnamese food.

I took my family there when they came up to visit.  The verdict? 
Good ol' fashioned comfort food for the Southeast Asian-inclined! You could tell from all the Bahasa Indonesia being spoken around us that I wasn't alone in this sentiment. Throw in the cleanliness of the place and the friendly staff and it's definitely a winner in my book. 

The Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas (fried rice w/ spicy shrimp paste) is an absolute must! The Ayam Bakar Cabe (BBQ spicy chicken) is wonderfully tender and flavorful. Get the Empal Goreng (fried honey beef) for its sweetness and texture. The Capcai (mixed veggies) was okay, but I'd skip it next time. 

For more discriminating palates (e.g. my parents), the dishes were simple but fairly authentic.  For me, a kid who's simply glad to be taken back to his childhood days, I am hooked!!!  I cannot recommend this place enough.  Come early!
author: Nathan I.

description:
This place has a comfortable atmosphere with some interesting sidewalk viewing if you allow your attention to wander. The wait staff is not super savvy, but down to earth and they get the job done. 

The food is, as I should have begun with, Y-u-mmy. I'm partial towards spicy ethnic food, so Borobudur had a good head start. The chicken and beef satay with peanut sauce hit the spot and the tofu and eggplant dish (with the 2 chili peppers menu notation) knocked the socks off of my meat-loving, Puerto Rican, spice fiend friend. That's a good thing. 

We out drank our food bill, which ensured a good time. They serve Singhas, a personal favorite and proven winner in a recent blind beer tasting in Southeast Asia. 

Back to the atmosphere -- it was comfortable enough of a place to enjoy good food and a handful of beers, a place I'd go back to when passing through the neighborhood.
author: Karina K.

description:
Go Roti yourself.
You heard me, go Roti yourself.

It's the first thing you should order for the table.  A great appetizer flat bread that is crispy & doughy dipped in curry sauce.  The food is very close to authentic but I only say that because if you've been to Indo you'd understand.  When the place get packed the service suffers just a bit due to only 3 servers but it's worth the very minor mishaps for the flavorful (peanut sauce, curry, honey glaze) and spicy food.

If you don't know what to order I would recommend ordering the set dinner for one and ordering another dish.  That way you can get a taste of many different dishes.

Go Roti yourself.
author: Po L.

description:
The food was great but the service was very slow!  They need more people to handle their customers.  

We had the Siomay Bandung (Chicken Dumplings) for appetizers that was pretty good.  The peanut sauce was amazing which tells me the satay would be very good.  

We also had the Sayur Asem (Tamrind soup).  The soup was amazing.  It tastes nothing like soup but more like a curryish soup.  

The Rendang beef was tasty!  Spicy, aromatic and wonderful.  

The Ayam Bakar Cabe (BBQ Chicken) was so flavorful.  It was one of the best bbq chicken I've ever tasted.  

The house special fried rice was interesting.  If you're not a fan of anchovies then I would not suggest going for this dish.  It definitely has an anchovy taste.  

We ended with the Pisang Bakar Kaju which was not sweet to say the least.  Stay away from this if you're looking for something sweet to end your night.  This was the only dish in the entire meal that I did not like.  

If they improved their service they would do so much better.

Happy Eating!
author: Rosh C.

description:
I took my family here in an attempt to showcase my shiny new "I'm-a-big-city-girl-now-and-can-take-you-to-get-awesome-ethnic-food-you've-never-tried-before-because-I'm-cool" mentality. I think it worked!

The roti prata was delicious like everybody says it is. Though I was scared about the service from the other yelp reviews I've read, they were attentive and friendly during my visit. The rest of the food was pretty dang good, good enough that I'll be back to try different dishes for sure.

The restaurant is in my 'hood, so I'll for sure be back in.
author: Tara O.

description:
i was excited to come here just because i had never tried indonesian cuisine.  i'm not so sure i got an authentic experience as each dish we had tasted like a dish from else where in the east and southeast area of asia.

we started w/ roti pratas and the corn fritters (bakwan jagung).  the roti was too oily and lacked flavor but the fritters were pretty tasty and crispy.

for mains, we shared chicken satay, grilled tiger prawns (udang bakar cabe),  bbq spicy chicken (ayam bakar cabe), and stir fried veggie rice noodles (bihun goreng).  the satay was as good as satay can get.  the tiger prawns were cooked well and tasty.  the chicken was moist but a lil lackluster flavor wise and the noodles were straight up like pad thai.  the dishes that had indication that they were spicy (prawns and chicken) were anything but that.

the service here is insane and hectic to watch.  with the close quarters of the dining area, i felt that our table was gonna get trampled at least 5 times.  they get the job done but it's just stressful to watch.
author: Swarup B.

description: Just went here for dinner with the hubby and was indeed impressed with the food we had. We started with the roti prata as an appy (beware it's uber filling!) and we had the beef rendang, sauteed spinach and the cocunut flavored rice. All accompanied by some Singha beer (would've preferred some Bintang!) I thought all the dishes were tasty, made well and, to the least of my knowledge, pretty authentic. I was skeptical about ordering the rendang as it's a hard dish to pull off and I've even been disappointed with some rendang IN indonesia - but it was good! Beef was cooked slowly so was tender. The sauce was
author: Nicola B.

description:
Great atmosphere. A couple of us had dinner here before a show. Friendly service. 

1) easy to get a table
2) great portions
3) Coconut rice rocks
4) the huge fried shrimp chip in peanut sauce was very good.

Go! Try it out!
author: Improv S.

description: This was my favorite Indonesian Restaurant in SF and very close to my apartment when I lived there (which didn't help with the more than required indulgence). It's a bit pricey, but good for a once in a while meal. My recommendations are Roti prata, Nasi Goreng and Bakhmi Ayam.
author: Samyuktha K.

description:
4.26.2007
8:30 PM

Whenever I try a new restaurant that I've never been to before, I ask for the server to point out the restaurant's specialty dishes and some of their favorites; they work there and see/eat the food daily.....

...so you'd think they would know what was up.  

I ordered Siu Mai (hoping it would somewhat resemble it's Japanese cousin) and let the server select two other dishes.

The siu mai was good...served luke warm.
Their signature dishes: friend rice and a giant fried pancake folded up like a napkin...that tastes like an undercooked croissant that never rose to the occasion.

Nothing to write home about...
author: William R.

description:
6/16/08-
I got to go again last week and it was still very tasty!  I ordered a spicy noodle/beef dish that was delish.  The place was packed on a Monday night - it's got to be good!

4/8/2008-
4.5
I was pleasantly surprised by this restaurant.  I had never had Indonesian and this place was a great first experience.  I haven't been since early April of 08, but I am excited to go back and try more!
author: Rise G.

description:
Went there for a lunch get together with my mother, and I'm glad we did, after a long walk from the union square- I was pretty much starving .
The staff are friendly and accomodating, eventhough they were curios why I wanted to try different the  "sauces" that are available. We ordered the Grilled Tiger Shrimp and it was very  very tasty , and succulent, not to much spicy (which is what I wanted). We also ordered the spinach with tofu - that one I prefer  a little bit more flavor, although it was already with garlic sauce. I also ordered the Nasi Goreng with Chicken, that one maybe I could request a sunny side up when I return...the Nasi Goreng is something I would come back for and the shrimp, altho I will try something else next time, Thai Iced tea - pretty good too. Thank you for the kind service ;)
author: Bing.kay B.

description:
Summary:  Nice ambience, decent wine selection, average food - poor value.

Roti prata appetizer was good, though not distinctive.  The dishes I sampled included Ikan Salmon Balado (Salmon cooked with Sumatra chili sauce, $16.50), Ikan Bakar Samudra (Grilled fish with tropical spices served with Indonesian salsa, $13.50), Bihum Goreng (Stir fried rice stick noodle with egg and vegetables with mixed vegetables, $9.50), Gulai Kambing (Lamb curry cooked with coconut milk sauce, $12.50), and Oseng Oseng Tahu Tempe (Sauteed Java soy bean cake with vegetables & tofu, don't remember the price but under $10).

The salmon was distinctly fishy and unfresh, and the sauce, which rated two chili peppers but had no bite at all.  The trout was a bit difficult to eat because of the number of bones; it was dry but pleasantly seasoned.  Lamb curry was served with small cubed potatoes; flavors were delicious but very, very mild.  Rice noodles were unmemorable but a large portion.  The sauteed soy bean cake was much stiffer than I would've imagined (not at all like tofu in texture); although I didn't enjoy it much I can imagine it being an acquired taste.

In general flavors were tasty but very, very mild.  Lots of wines in the $10 - 30 range, but didn't feel like they paired well with the food.  The decor was very nice for a restaurant in this price range.

Still, generally disappointed with the quality of Southeast Asian food in the Bay Area.
author: BChizzle C.

description: good food...but really need to improve their service...if their service is good...this place will be so awesome....
author: Pikachu P.

description: My friends and I dined here our first night in town.  I ordered Roti appetizer as a main course, and that was delicious.  I sampled my other friends' food, which were some curries and meat dishes, all good too.  The prices are reasonable, and the service was good to boot.  The waiter was very personable and interested in hearing about where we were from, what we were doing in San Francisco, etc.
author: Rona H.

description: If you are looking for a place for an INdonesian food in San Francisco... you go to Borobudur.  For people who have never had Indonesian food before- the waiter and the waitresses will be able to explain all the different type of Indonesian food. I love getting the Martabak sapi as an appatizer, and the ayam cabe with Jasmine rice "Nasi" with the water spinach "kangkung". Its right in downtown SF- and you can normally get walk in service without too long of a wait!
author: Erma N.

description: I got the Roti Prata  mmmm mmmm GOOD. i could have just ate this.. it was so good. and it was a lot.. so of couse I took it home .  For my main dish I got Nasi Goreng .. OMG this was my first time having Indoneisian fried rice.. it was the best.. I am now a fan. will definenlty try more food like this.. The price here is not that cheap.
author: Attaicus C.

description:
3.5 stars

great food, ok portion size, friendly service, nice atmosphere, but also slow and disorganized service (we did go for lunch on V-Day, but still!)

I would like to go back and try it while sitting in a booth rather than in the doorway (cold breeze on my lower back). We enjoyed the food greatly, but it was just a little small in portion. We were absolutely starving, so we would have to give that another shot.
author: Katy W.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant of the year within walking distance of my apartment.  I really wanted to try their Roti Prata, but the server said they were out.  However, she recommended the Martabak Sapi, which is like ground beef in a filo dough.  It was good enough that I soon forgot I wanted Roti.  Next, we ordered chicken and beef satay with peanut sauce.  Another great dish because the peanut sauce wasn't some bland spoonful-o-Skippy's.

I love hot, spicy food, but felt the Sambal Goreng Daging, beef with special chile sauce, wasn't hot enough for me.  Tumis Buncis Pedas Udang Kering, spicy string beans with shrimp, was perfectly hot, but I think I would have liked it even more without the dried shrimp.  Maybe too shrimpy, like cat food shrimpy.

I'm a ginger candy addict, so I loved the hot, sweet ginger tea.
author: Naomi N.

description:
AMAZING INDONESIAN COFFEE - thick, hot, robust, strong, flavorful. The best Indonesian coffee I've had. It definitely isn't even on the same level as the Thai/Vietnamese coffees offered in the neighborhoods around here.

Can't remember the name of the dish - but it's the noodle soup with chicken, vegetables, eggs, in a peanut-chicken broth. I think this is the day I came to understand the complexity of peanuts and the art of chicken stock. Let me just say that the first time I ate this dish was like a freakin revelation. I had no idea how a finely roasted and ground peanut paste can intensify and enhance without overpowering the taste of a sauce or a soup. What I tasted in this broth was a int of heat from chili, a faint sweetness from the peanut, a faint roasted/almost bitterness from the peanut, and savory salt; then there is the big, robust roasted scent and HUGE chicken flavor that was previously unrivaled by anything anywhere. Then there are the perfectly chewy wheat noodles swimming in this golden-colored broth. Perfectly cooked vegetables - peppers, onions and scrambled eggs. Juicy, poached, sliced chicken pieces, all white. AMAZING.

I've had other dishes here, too. Great lumpia, although tiny and a bit dry, if there's any flaws at all. Dessert is OK, I'd bounce over to somewhere else. Great braised dishes including my favorite - the chili braised cubes of beef. SO DAMN GOOD. Tender as can be, spicy, just a great medly of this tomato/chili/coconut/lime/green onion flavor. This place has it down.

Great waitstaff, and I am not sure why the restaurant is never full, but it's got nice lighting and is a cozy place to dine. Highly recommended (do NOT walk over to Thai Stick across the street. It's NOT WORTH IT. more on that later...)
author: Y K.

description:
Many-a-time, while on the swanky 27 bus, I've passed Borobudur and seen the cute little beaded lights in the windows and said to myself (in my head, not aloud like many of the nutters on the 27), I need to check that place out.

Friday night I went with a friend for dinner and while I give the ambiance 4 stars, the food didn't do much for me.  I like to cook and sometimes I catch myself thinking, I could make this recipe and do a better job of it.  In point, the corn fritters we had for appetizers.  The flavor was not lacking however the texture said "I was fried, not well-drained, then microwaved".  (Note, I did not see a microwave being used, this is only my way of explaining the chewiness of the texture, where one would expect crispy-chrunchitiness). 

My friend had the No. 47, with chicken and shrimp, and while she was happy with the dish she did mention the noodles were a bit on the mushy side.  I tried her dish and while I didn't notice the texture being off I did detect a smokey/sweet flavor that I didn't care for.  I had the satay chicken skewers and they were fine - hard to screw up.  I did add some of the red pepper sauce to the peanut sauce because I wanted more spice.

The ambiance makes Borobudur a nice date spot and I think if I'd been more adventurous with my dinner choices I may have been pleasantly surprised.  The place was packed, so clearly they are doing something right, and who's to say that I didn't pick the wrong menu items?

If you're in the neighborhood, Borobudur is worth a shot - just don't order the corn fritters.
author: MJ P.

description:
For this kind of cuisine, I heard it was suppose to be the real deal from others who have tried this place. I would definitely agree. The roti prata was an excellent choice for appetizer. Had the Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak which is this chicken cooked over spicy coconut milk. I thought this too was an great choice. However, the sizes of the chicken pieces were huge. Their prices weren't so bad and neither was the service. 

Overall, I'd come back to this place, even though i'm not big on this type of cuisine. 

Forgot to mention the design wasn't so bad. Looks great on the outside as well as the inside. Seatings weren't bad. Which is always a problem in city restaurants.
author: Sally d.

description: Borobudur's noodle plates are incredible and filling, and you can get a pretty good meal for around $8. My only issue with them is the slow service -- even if there are only a couple people in the restaurant, they'll take their sweet time to finish your order. It's still worth it, though!
author: Finn G.

description:
Food - Good
Price - Not so good

I've been here 3 times cause I missed Indonesian food. I love their beef rendang and empek2 palembang (fish cake). The food is actually good, but very pricey. Service is kinda slow even when it's not busy. 

Most of their food don't include rice, and we have to order extra on the side. Rice should have included, cause thats how you eat in Indonesia. I saw some people who ate beef rendang or chicken without rice, and I was like.. man you're missing out, you need rice to balance the flavor.
author: Sendy K.

description:
This place is overpriced. Portions are very small, food is nothing special
not sure if they even like to stay open with their staff's attitude...
author: Katarina N.

description: Food is good here. I had the pineapple chicken fried rice with the chicken skewers. The fried rice was my favorite. Service is a bit on the slow side, but other than that, its pretty ok.
author: Emir T.

description: I haven't been in a while, so it was a treat to catch up with my old favorite! Delicious food, super attentive service, crisp thai beers, and all the bitter melon crackers I could eat. Yay!
author: SisterMable S.

description:
I discovered this place through my boss, who brought the staff there to celebrate my birthday and an officemate's bday as well. That was my first Indonesian culinary experience. And I immediately wondered why it took me so long to try Indonesian food.  

First thing I noticed on the menu was the similarity between the Indonesian and Filipino ingredients. Being Filipino who LOVES Filipino food, I was intrigued and excited. It was like Filipino dishes with some twist. 

So to make the long story short, I've been there at least 5X by now - dine-in's and take-out's. And so far, here are my recommendations:

**Nasi Goreng Borobudur - House special spicy fried rice with anchovy, egg, and onion, with shrimp and salted fish. (Note: if they ask "spicy?" and you say yes, you better be up for some really tongue-burning experience. I suggest you answer "mild", at least on your first visit, just to see how things go.) 

**Nasi Goreng Terasi Pedas - Spicy shrimp paste fried rice with egg, onion with shrimp and salted fish.

**Bandeng Presto/Milk fish - Fried marinated boneless milk fish

**Roti Prata - Pan fried layered bread served with curry dipping sauce

Prices range from $5 for appetizers to $17 for a main course dish. So you could say it's not cheap. But it's worth it. Excellent service too. The servers tried to explain the Indonesian cuisine, and were prompt, especially when I asked for water over and over again to put off the fire on my tongue.
author: Ryan M.

description: After a trip to Indonesia last year, I was excited to try for some good Indonesian in SF. Was definitely disappointed. The two dishes we tried- one veggie dish, one noodle dish tasted distinctly like run of the mill Chinese food- which I know Indonesian food does not. Bummer.
author: Silent A.

description:
I have actually been to Borobudure and traveled all over Indonesia so I am familiar with the style of cooking.  While the food at the restaurant would get it at least 4 starts, maybe 5, the service leaves A LOT to be desired.  They seem to only have two people working the whole dinning area so it took us a while to get refills on water and FOREVER to get the table cleared and our dessert ordered, it really made some of the meal unpleasant since I was brought for my birthday and we wanted to get the table cleared so we could do gifts.  It is really to bad because the food was REALLY delicious.  The appetizers were to die for, particularly the friend bread with a curry dipping sauce (n. 1, I forget what it was called) and the fried spring roles (n. 10).  Careful, when they say spicy they mean it!  We all had to take a break and chew some ice to get our mouths cool enough to eat some more.  

I swear, this place could be AMAZING if they hired one more waiter...
author: Amy P.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. I LOVE there Gado-Gado. I am Dutch, where Indonesian food is quite common and my mother use to cook gigantic Indonesia feasts when I was a kid. The food at Borobudur reminds me of those times. Yummy!
author: Paul d.

description: The second time I went was less than great.  Loved the service, but we ordered shrimp that was not de-veined.  EEK!  But, the restaurant owner quickly took care of the plate and appologized with a cheerful smile and peace gesture.  Fun people there.
author: Kim J.

description:
If you're a couple, order the set dinner (on page 1 of the menu). Add on an order of Roti and you've got an impressive meal for 2. If you're really hungry, order a noodle dish as well. The food was so good, and there was so much of it... we couldn't stop eating!

This is my new favorite restaurant in SF. Awesome food, service, and atmosphere.
author: David S.

description: I was in the mood for Indonesian food after a hotel guest said she just came back from Borobudur and loved the food there. So, i gave it a try.The place is very clean and comfy. I started off with the -Roti Prata (pan fried flakey bread w/ dippin' sauce)very good! I ate too much while I waited for the (Sate Kombinay) The peanut sauce was awesome...skewers were tasty and by now I was getting full.Then came the (Bakmi Goreng) spicy noodels w/shrimp.Not bad--Not great. I was soo full I took the rest to go. A little costly ,but fresh n hot....I'll be back and try other items.
author: Ken F.

description:
I go to Borobudur on a weekly basis for lunch, and I am always pleased with the truly authentic Indonesian flavors. The Gado Gado is a great way to start off a meal as the tofu, vegetables, shrimp crackers, and the light peanut dressing blend in so nicely. For a different take on fried rice, try the Nasi Goreng Borobudur; fried rice cooked with savory shrimp paste and tiny anchovies as the base mixed with sauteed onions, eggs, sambal, and your choice of beef, chicken or shrimp. It's spicy, delicious, and very addictive. 

The Nasi Uduk Lengkap is a traditional coconut rice dish served with tender pieces of honey beef, spicy tofu, and scrambled eggs. I could have this dish for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. Their curries are all very delightful as well with their straightforward yet balanced flavors emanating from the coconut, kafir lime leaves, and aromatic spices.

Consistency and quality are what this place represents in the food, the attentive yet not overbearing service, and the subtle Indonesian decor displayed throughout the restaurant.  A friend of mine from Indonesia recommended this place to me awhile ago, and I can see why.  If you are looking for something new and exciting to your meal, then you will find it at Borobudur.
author: Kevin W.

description: The food here is hit and miss.  The service is friendly but SLOW!  It was a long time before they took our order, then a long time waiting for the food, then another long wait for dessert.  There were two extra place settings that never got removed... And the table was crowded so it would have helped.  The dumplings were dry.. And even thought there were 4 of us, there were 3 on the plate, which I thought was kinda cheap.  The honey chicken was tender and flavorful but a little dry, beef was dry too.  The rice dish was good, the stir fried noodles were great and the squid in spicy sauce was awesome!  Both desserts, the plantains and the roti were great.  So, take your best guess on the food, and they really need some server training!
author: Lori M.

description:
With extensive world travel, It is easy to put Indonesian food at the top of the rankings.

Indonesia's best/most famous food is "Padang" food. It comes from a small city in western Sumatra. That's why you can get Padang food everywhere in Indonesia. It is made up of spicy curries and chili sauces served in small dishes with various meats, tofu, vegetables and seafood.

Padang food is hard to find in the states. Order Borobudur's "Nasi Padang" plate and you will understand what I mean. Pour the sauces on your rice and enjoy. Rendang beef is one of the best dishes in Padang food's arsenal-slow cooked beef in a coconut sauce and other spices. It will blow your mind. 

Borobudor's Nasi Padang plate was excellent and less than $10.
author: Rod C.

description:
i've been going to this restaurant for years; however, lately the service is horrible. A young gentleman that always work on weekend night is an a**.  No smile, not very friendly, whereas the other old short man is the opposite. The older shorter man is very funy and friendly. That's how service should be...

Therefore,

Good version:
1.)good food
2.)nice atmosphere

Bad version:
1.)Bad service from the young guy

my recomendation for the foods: roti prata, nasi goreng sambal terasi, mie tek tek, and roti prata manis.
author: Cell S.

description:
The server gave me and my girl friend a funny look when we ordered rijstafel dinner... at 11.30AM.  Defiantly, I gave him the "What, you've never seen any ladies with a healthy appetite before?" look.  

They have the real Indonesian chili sauce so spicy that it made my skin crawl when I tasted them for the first time - so impressed that this thing exists in the Bay Area, I took one home in a container.  

Rijstaffel dinner (or to us, lunch) is a perfect introduction to Indonesian food, as it allows sampling of a variety of little (tame), more popular Indonesian dishes such as the beef rendang (spicy curry beef), gado gado (Indonesian salad with peanut dressing), chicken satay, and soto ayam (lemongrass chicken soup), among others.  Otherwise, roti prata (which may be on the pricy side @ $7.50) and bakwan jagung (corn fritters) would make good appetizers, and one of the rice plates (favorite being Nasi Uduk Lengkap - coconut rice with sides) would not disappoint.
author: Ange L.

description: The spicy noodle soup is excellent! (It's in the noodle section with 2 red peppers by the name of the dish.)
author: Wakako U.

description:
I'm Indonesian & I guarantee you'll find authentic Indonesian food in Borobudur!!!

I have many favourite food that so damn good. OK I'll try to remember them.

1. Nasi goreng terasi pedas
2. Udang bakar cabe
3. Ayam bakar cabe
4. Ayam panggang bumbu rujak
5. Tahu balado
6. Martabak sapi
7. Tumis kangkung terasi pedas
8. Tumis bayam bawang putih
9. Siomay Bandung
10. Soto Betawi
11. Roti Prata manis
author: Natalie S.

description: The rijtaffel is excellent and the Ginger hot tea is superb... Definitely recommended
author: Dario L.

description: I'm in love with this place. Seriously, I think I picked my new apartment because of its proximity to Borobudur. Excellent food, very inexpensive...fast. Even the ambiance is pretty decent. My mission is to try everything on the menu. At this rate, I'll be done by September.
author: Monika M.

description:
I just went for a birthday dinner to this place. I really recommend the Roti Prada. You can feel the dough melting in your mouth and it's so fresh and yummy. I also tried the sate which was good and I ordered the Bakmi Goreng/ Bihun Goreng COmbination Noodle dish which was delicious. I would definitely order it again and recommend anyone to order it if they like noodle dishes. 
THe reason why this place didn't get a 5 star was because of the dessert. We ordered a dessert because the bday girl wanted something similar to the dough in the Roti Prada.  So they made something with Hazelnut, Chocolate sprinkles and (don't laugh) cheddar cheese. It looked like the shredded cheddar cheese that you buy at safeway. We talked to the waiter about it and he said that it's similar to the dish in Indonesia but the dough was different. This was a big shock. So if you guys really want to stay here for dessert, stick to the traditional banana desserts instead.
Bottom line: I will definitely come back to this place as it's only a 5 block walk and it's right next to Pearls.
author: Nir B.

description:
I've been coming to this place for lunch with some business associates and let me tell you, this place is DA BOMB!!

Yelpers, you've all got to try this place out and please, I beg you please....you must try the BBQ Honey Chicken (tender quarters of chicken cooked to perfection). To be quite honest I have not even tried anything else in the menu. I'm all about the adventure of trying new things and exploring the extent of my palate but dang....they have perfected the art of, fall off the bone, succulent, don't even need to chew, clicking your heals saying there's no place like Borodudur, drooling for the next bite, forgetting your in public, high fiving the waiter while hugging the cook.....sorry, sorry, I'm rambling again. But really, TRY THE CHICKEN...and coconut rice. 

Only 4 stars because I have yet to try anything else on the menu other than the Roti, BBQ Honey Chicken and Coconut Rice. Excuse me yelpers while I place my order to pick up some of that BBQ Honey Chicken......YYYYUUUUUUMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM!
author: dave s.

description: i love their food...gado gado and bihun goreng combo is one of my favorite dish from this place. the only thing i cant stand from this place is the services. wether is busy or not they always take forever to greet and brought the water, or even take your orders.
author: nita d.

description: Hands down the best Malaysian restaurant in SF. The roti prata is nirvana. Satay was tender and delicious. Service is fast and friendly even when very busy. I have been a fan for past five years and quality has been good each time with friendly service.
author: Master B.

description: The Rendang was one of the best things I've ever eaten. If there was bad service or something, I didn't notice.
author: Munaf A.

description: love the food, the ambience, and the price of the food is reasonable. Parking is a little difficult  but typical SF.
author: Elisa D.

description:
We've eaten here twice and so far, so good!

We definitely want to try the other choices on the menu as our previous orders have been great. They serve yummy fish crackers and oooooh the desserts are FAB.

Make sure you go here when not too hungry as the orders do take some time.
author: Rv G.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised when I stepped into this neighborhood Indonesian restaurant.  I thought it would be a dive, but it was actually quite airy and clean inside.  

We had the roti prata, which was pretty authentic.  It was actually quite a good sized portion.  It came with a nice mild currry dip.  We were so hungry that we inhaled the roti prata, and I was feeling already full after the appetizer.  LOL!

We also tried the beef rendang, kangkong (a type of green leafy vegetable), and the honey beef.  The rendang and kangkong hit the mark, but the honey beef was very dry and stringy.  I think they cheaped out and used the cheap cut of beef for this receipe, which really called for a tri tip or a more tender cut of meat.  Instead, they used a tough cheap cut of brisket or something or another.  And the meat was dry and stringy. 

Overall, this restaurant was a little bit of a touch and go for me.  But I have to say the spiciness hit the mark!  Very authentic there!
author: Hoola H.

description: Had an early dinner here and it was excellent! got there about 530pm and it was empty. Maybe 2 tables. By 615pm it was full! chili chicken was very tasty. seafood dumplings. eggplant and tofu. noodles were all excellent and tasty. Would definitely go again!
author: Kahau M.

description: The menu is quite extensive but the servers were more than willing to help us make our decision as we've never had Indonesian food before.  The food was excellent and prices were very reasonable.  We ordered 2 appetizers, 2 entrees, and 2 sides of rice; with our restaurant.com coupon (which cost me $2) our entire meal, including tip, cost $26.  This is the perfect place to get a bite to eat before a movie!  Order the Roti Prata, it's sinfully delicious!
author: a e.

description:
Delicious food!  3 of us shared a rice plate with vegetables (can't remember exactly what it was called, I think it had a rice cake, tofu something, cool tower of rice), the spicy eggplant tofu dish, and the vegetable Indonesian Egg Fu Yung.  Great vegetarian options!

We also tried the Indonesian iced coffee, which was good, and the Thai iced tea.  Normally I love Thai iced tea, but this one wasn't as good as usual.  It seemed to lack the spices and flavor that I'm used to.

Service was really, really slow.  That and the thai iced tea knock it down to 4 stars.  Still delicious, unique food though.  I plan to go back!
author: Rachael S.

description: Great for a change of pace.  I especially like the lunch special where you can sample a couple of dishes at a quite affordable price.  Quite a find!
author: Kara H.

description:
I wanted to try this place because I LOVE the Indonesuan  place in Berkeley, the Check Please  segment intrigued me, and I thought it might      be a cool     place for a dining group meetup that I belong to.    

Was   going to go for dinner, but was in the neighborhood at  lunch time,   so   went then instead.         There were a few people there, but it wasnt'  crowded.  There was a  bit      of a   language barrier  about where I wanted to  sit.  We worked it out, and the    waitress was attentive without     being annoyng throughout the   meal.  The restaurantt woud work ok with    a group with a few people in  wheelchairs.    Not the  best, but can be   done.   Not a place for a "quick bite"".  You wil  wait awhile. 

Anyway,  I  had the rice with  chicken,   beef, egg and here tofu.  It was really    good, but just not quite as   great as the place in Berkeley.  I did really like the sauce the eggs came in.  Kind of like Marinara, but with     a      bite.  The tofu wasnt  my thing, but then again   it   never            is, lol.  I also  got a coconut    drink which      tasted really weird, but maybe it was  my   bad   ordering and not    the drink being bad.
So  at this point I was thinking that it wasn't  quite as  tasty  as the Berkeley     place, but  if I needed   an Indonesian    fix, and  was in SF  I would  be  back.  I thought a group of aout 15 to 20 coud fit   comfortably.  They   have this rice place thing  at a decent price for groups, so was thinking about  all of this. as I  was digesting my      food and  getting ready to go  .
Im not a huge fan of Asian desserts, so would      never think to order   one.  Besides I had spent enough on food anyway.  So when the    owner I think  came to ask me if I had room  for a little something sweet i decllined, said everything was great,.  Then he  asked if it was free if I would want it.  Well accept for Indian, I would     never say no to free food.  Of       course I effouseively (sp)  thanked him.  The dessert  hot cocunut  maybe milk with    black    beans that tasted a  bit  like chhocolate     was  actually really, really good.  Being the   piglet that I am, I ate it all.
I will definitely  be back, but won't expect a  free    dessert, lol.
author: Sascha B.

description: I haven't eaten here in a couple of years, so maybe that discredits me, but this WAS my favorite Indonesian restaurant outside of Indonesia. Just exceptional food.
author: Michelle V.

description: Nothing special. I liked the Indonesian restaurant across the street much better.
author: Joshua S.

description: Had tickets for "Normal Heart" and 55 minutes to eat.  Was planning Max's, but it's no more.  Hustled over to Barobudur with my friend.  "where are we going?"  "Indonesian place"  "What's that like?"  "I don't know how to describe it.  You'll find out"   Sat down told the waiter we were in a hurry.  Ordered the Rijsttafel for two.  Had it before and liked it.  She did, too.  Loved the soup and the beef dish.  Grabbed the check and shoveled in the black rice dessert, good!   Ran to theatre, sat down just as the lights dimmed.  Success.  Hunger removed and a bottle of Chilean Sauvignon Blanc in the belly, we were good until the intermission cocktails.   I'd do it again.  What happened to all the Max's.  Was it the food poisoning I got from the happy hour dishes at the Opera plaza location?  We still don't know how to describe Indonesian food, other than tasty and different from other SE Asian cuisine, maybe close to Vietnamese?
author: Ken S.

description:
So Archie R and I have "dinners".  That's "dinner" - - + S - which makes it plural.
On one night.
 
And this is not the first time we did this.
One time, we did Bar Crudo, had a feast - - and then hit up House of Prime Rib.  No joke.  
 
On this particular evening -  he had just returned from a trip around the east coast of the US, but due to being in such high demand and such - - he had apparently not had a chance to eat spicy foods.  So starting from mid-afternoon, he began texting cuisines from most countries in Asia and even a couple from Europe.  We were getting nowhere - - quickly.  Finally - we settled on Indonesian food, which I haven't had in some 30 years since I last lived in Djakarta - reserving the option to throw in some Japanese food afterwards.
 
"SOME" is a relative term.
 
I had suggested a place called "Indonesia Restaurant" (so original) near my place - but reading Yelp, he found a more highly recommended place:  Borabudur, which is right on the adjacent block.
OK.
 
No offense to Yelpers - - and not having tried the first restaurant yet, you still might be accurate - - but what's so great about this restaurant?
So many of you claimed their stuff was SO spicy - - - and of the 5 dishes we ordered - 3 were meant to be the spiciest they had based on their menu AND Yelp - - and only ONE was moderately spicy.  We had requested EXTRA spicy on all of them!
 
Forgive me for the abomination I am about to do on the names of the food:
- Roti:  bread... more like croissants... but freakin' fabulous, oily, and if you look at it long enough, you begin to gain pounds right then and there.  Yeah, we shredded that thing to pieces.
- Tempe:  Ever since living in Indonesia, I loved tempe and still do.  This place fries the stuff and hands it to you w/ a peanut sauce of some sort.  Forget the sauce, just devour it and savor the flavor of the fried soybeans.  I love, love Tempe!!
- Bahk Mi: Now, from the days of living in Indonesia, I remember my FAVORITE dish as being something I called, "BANH MI".  Let me explain, in case one of you people actually know what I am talking about and can tell me where I can find this dish.  They were steamed noodles, wrapped up in a banana leaf that came delivered w/ a piping hot soup on the side, and you would unwrap your noodles, put in the soup, add tons of hot sauce - and eat like it's your last meal.  Even as a 5 year old, I could not get enough of this stuff.  It's like Indonesia Pho, on crack.  Anyone know the name of this or where I can find it?  Because what I ordered here was NOT IT.  It was a stir fried noodle of sort, too sticky and too gooey, served w/ a bowl of soup on the side.  Now that broth was similar to what I remember as "banh mi" - but those noodles?  Oh helllll no.
- Shrimp Paste Fried Rice:  not too shabby.  It had a distinct stench to it - - but not too bad, and it dissipated w/ time.  In fact, we had most of this leftover so I got to bring it home, and when I had it the next day, most of the stench was gone and it was quite tasty.
- Mie Tek Tek:  I think that's what it was called.  This was the only dish that was actually spicy.  Thick udon-type noodles, stir-fried.... loads of flavor and quite good, but frankly, it could have been even spicier.
 
We also had two beers - -  his was a Tiger Beer (Singapore) and I had some beer from Thailand that tasted like Korean beer.

I found service to be a bit slow but quite friendly and all in all, good enough.  No complaints.
 
I'm glad we tried Borabudur.  It's only 2 blocks from where I live, and I'd go here again for the tempe.  However, if I'm on a SPICY-KICK (which is every single day of my life) - - this is not the place.
 
So that was the end of dinner #1 for the night - - and while we had entered as two starving individuals, hunched over, and our stomach linings stuck to our backsides - - -we walked out stuffed to the gills, mumbling something about how on earth we'd eat more, while we walked our way to the next dining establishment:  SUSHI RIKA.
author: Grace K.

description:
