What a nice spot! My friends and I totally stumbled across this gem by accident while looking for Osha. Hunger got the better of us and we went inside of an eventful and tasty meal. We lucked out because they sat us next to two Indonesian women who gave us thumbs up and thumbs down on our menu decisions. For our apps we had Siomay Ayam(chicken dumplings) and Corn Fritters. The fritters were just OK but the dumplings were enjoyable. They look like Japanese Shu mai but the taste is definitely Indonesian. For dinner we chose a couple proteins and a rice dish  I love to pick items with long but vague descriptors so I went with the Shrimp served with  special spicy exotic sauce. After our table side friends approved my selection we ordered it and it did not disappoint. The shrimp were served butterflied on a skewer, shell on. The shell came off easily and the shrimp were cooked to tender perfection. It had just the right amount of heat for my spice sensitive friends, but I could have taken it full Indonesian strength! We also ordered Ayam Bakar Cabe (chicken in chili sauce) that was so tender you could pull it off the bone with your fork! I'm not sure where the chili works into the equation as it wasn't spicy at all but the quality of the dish supersedes the lack of spiciness in my opinion. The last thing we ordered was Nasi Uduk Lengkap which was  a suggestion of our Indonesian pals. This dish is unique as it is served as a deconstructed rice dish. We all took a piece of fried chicken, beef, tofu, shrimp cracker and coconut rice and dug in! Each element was cooked perfectly and each flavor complimented the next. 
  This is the first Indonesian spot (out side of Indonesia) that I have enjoyed the cuisine. The service was great, the food was perfect and I'm glad we had willing table side meal consultants! Definitely stop in and give Borobudur a try!
author: chelsea b.

description: Loved the food and the service. Everything we ordered was brilliant
author: C C.

description: The roti prata here rocks my world.  It's this pile of doughy, kind of flaky Indian bread.  The menu says it's grilled, but it's so greasy it may as well be fried.  It's served with this watery curry dipping sauce.  I wouldn't recommend it to the health conscious, but for gluttons like me it's A+ hedonistic Indonesian comfort food.
author: Lauren C.

description: Talking about Indonesian food, we are left with not many choices. This is the place where we always come to kill our cravings for hometown food. The service is slow, and the portion is small. My friend had the lamb curry ( gulai kambing, lamb curry rightt?) well it is good, but not satisfying. I like the chicken dishes better~ they are all good to me. And make sure you know that siomay ayam is completely different with siomay bandung, omg I was so stupid! Can't even tell u Im indonesian. If I am not an Indonesian I might not loving this place, But since I am I'm LOVING IT!
author: Marlis T.

description:
We went this past Tuesday to Borobudor because we had seen a clip from the show "Check Please Bay Area" and they all gave great reviews. So I was really excited to experience Borobudor. But here are some tips to keep in mind if you are going to eat there: 
Tip #1: If you are going there for lunch, YOU have to ask specifically for the lunch menu. It felt as though our waitress was trying to manipulate us into ordering from the dinner menu only, instead of the lunch menu (we got there 10 minutes after it opened for lunch). She tried to sum it up as a mistake, but everyone else who came in for lunch was only offered the dinner menu, not the lunch. 
Tip #2: Look at your seat before you sit down, along with your silverware and tablecloth. No explanation needed.
Tip #3: Keep track of what your entrée cost because it will conveniently cost more when you receive your tab. The originally prices had been crossed out and the "new" price of the entrées were written on the menu, but when we received our bill it was much higher then what the menu quoted. When I brought it to her attention she said that they were in the process of changing their menus and prices. I told her that I would only pay what was quoted on the menu. 
I feel that their way of doing business is very shady. Even though the presentation of their food was beautiful - it doesn't always guarantee quality ingredients.
author: Priscilla S.

description: Excellent food at excellent prices! Recently went to a birthday dinner here and my palate was very pleased with the authentic flavors. I especially liked the gado gado salad and a laksa dish that was lip-smackingly delicious!
author: Deb I.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE!  The portions are really big and everything I've had here is so good.  Try the Es Stellar drink - a concoction of coconut and fruits.  The salmon is amazing.  There is a random dessert though - inside a paratha theres condensed milk, chocolate sprinkles, cheese, and peanuts - not for the faint hearted - well I love it!
author: Ramoners D.

description:
The location is a bit of a turn off, but what can one expect from a seedy San Francisco neighborhood?  But - don't let that get in your way !!
Food at Borobudur is pretty darn tasty and the servers are pleasant.
The best value is lunch for under $10 which comes with assorted dishes, albeit small servings. Emphasis on family style insists that one does not dine alone or with one other person because sharing is the way to go.  Rijsttafel (translation: Rice Table) is a wide range of plates representing the food of Indonesia and delicious.  I love the lemon grass chicken, lamb curry, green beans with shrimp paste and corn fritters. When in San Fran for business I frequent this place because of the worthwhile overall experience - food, service and price.
author: Chloe M.

description:
cute little restaurant. service was ok.

siomay bandung - very good. intense, complex flavors. yum.
i had the bakwan malang - it was like the standard pho or beef soup noodles at viet / thai places, but different in a subtle fragrant way, some kind of herb or maybe lemon flavor. i really liked the tofu in the soup.
bf had kari udang - not bad, but pretty boring. mild, sweet, it tasted like any anonymous americanized curry on a thai/indian/singaporean/etc menu.

it helps that this place is practically across the street from my apt.
author: Dana D.

description:
Mothers day 2009.

Packed restaurant.

2 servers, who doubled as bus staff. 

Endless delays.

I saw the wait staff grab dirty glasses by reaching into them and hauling them away, then, without washing up, deliver food to tables. 

That combines with the delays (45 minutes after order no food yet) made our party of 5 decide to get up and walk out. We weren't the only ones.

Maybe this would be a great experience with enough staff, but that sure wasn't the case today.
author: Bobo B.

description: Food was decent and the portions were enormous. However, unless you have 3 or 4 hours to kill while eating dinner, I wouldn't recommend eating here.
author: Justin F.

description:
It's official: I'm an Indonesian food fetishist. Borobudur is a revelation for weary eaters craving a departure from the standard Thai and Vietnamese fares that have come to almost wholly represent Southeast Asian cookery for many of us simpletons. Flavors brought to our neck of the woods from this exotic archipelago of a thousand-plus islands offers cleaner, deeper, and subtly yet superbly more aromatic complexities to the palate than what we get at those greasy noodle haunts or even those chic bistros to satisfy our Southeast Asian hankerings. 

Tasting this stuff for the first time at Borobudur sent pangs of regret that I hadn't explored the amazing spectrum of flavors that make up Indonesian cuisine sooner. Sweet, spicy, nutty, and floral, our dinner had us slurping, licking, and scraping down to our very last bites. The chicken lumpia started us off with perfectly fried little egg rolls that shattered cleanly like delicate glass at our bites containing tender, well-seasoned diced chicken and vegetables. Mie tek tek was satisfying and hearty with slices of chicken, chewy egg noodles and assorted vegetables swimming in an addicting peanutty-sweet-spicy broth that was hearty yet light at the same time. I had wanted to try the rendang but instead opted for Sambal Goreng Daging, pieces of beef stewed in a spicy, silky broth with al dente green beans and red peppers galore. To salve the absence of coconut from opting out of the rendang, we had an order of coconut rice, which packs a punch of an intensity previously known to my buds of coconut rice. 

Everything was delicious and eye-opening, albeit a bit sweet. I feel that this fare tries to put more of a direct focus on the sweetness instead of just using it as a foil to accentuate the saltiness of many savory dishes of other Asian cuisines, most of which, especially in restaurants, contain a lot more sugar than we'd like to think. What results at Borobudur out of this are flavors that start off as pleasantly mild and tunnel into a complexity that surprises and tantalizes.

Service, contrary to many reviews, was top-notch; we had multiple servers doting upon us and had a lovely dining experience. Out of this, I would suggest a late dinner at Borobudur to avoid the 7-8:30 dinner rush.

I thank Borobudur for opening my eyes to territories previously unchartered in my mouth, but would like to date other restaurants (like, say the cheaper and closer Jayakarta in Berkeley) before entertaining any ideas of exclusivity.
author: Nuri K.

description: This has been my first indoctrination into Indonesian food and I am hooked.  Everything I ordered was amazing from the Thai Iced Tea to the main course of lamb curry (sorry I can't remember the exact name of the dish) to the black rice pudding dessert with condensed milk.  My buddy and I didn't have any issues with the service and they actually warned my friend about the spiciness of a dish he ordered so that he could request they tone it down a bit.  I'll definitely be back and I found the prices quite reasonable compared to the so-so Thai place across the street.
author: Jill D.

description: I really enjoyed the appetizer roti with a yummy curry sauce and the fun coconut & mango frozen drink.  However, the tempeh and tofu and string beans dish had the grossiest tempeh ever.  Even the tofu was not good and I like fake meat products.  There was a short wait when we arrived on a Friday night.  The decor was simple and nice.  I liked the fact the tables weren't all jammed next to each other like some restaurants in the Tenderloin.
author: Cara J.

description:
Delicious!

With so many options in this neighborhood I went almost 5 years without trying this place. Finally one day while on a date I strolled by and decided to stop in. 

This place was fantastic! I had a combination plate with some chicken, some beef, some tofu, all with different spicy sauces and curries. Everything was tasty and affordable, and the staff was very nice.

Would dine at again!
author: Brian S.

description:
Love this place!!!

Went there with a group of 8 people, so we decided to be adventurous and pick off the menu rather than take 8 orders of the Rijsttafel.  We tried: 

* Rendang Beef - tender and flavorful.  excellent!  the crowd favorite
* Roti Prata - better than at Singaporean places I've tried (more flaky and fluffy
* Nasi Goreng (fried rice)- good, but not terribly exciting (but perhaps it is not supposed to be?)
* Gado-gado - very tasty and fresh
* Gulai Kambing (lamb) - very good
*  Tahu and Terong Balado (spicy eggplant and tofu) - spicy and delicious!
* Kari Udang (shrimp curry) - shrimp were well prepared
* dessert:  Es Duren (layer cake) - light and delicious
* dessert: Pisang goring Ice Cream - also well prepared

The plate presentation is also great.  A word of warning to big groups: get there early!  I'm not complaining, but it did take 45 minutes to get seated with 8 people, which is to be expected on a saturday night.
author: t c.

description:
So one day I asked my girlfriend whose Indonesian for a recommendation on authentic Indonesian restaurants, and she came up with her two favorites, Jayakarta in Berkeley, and Borobudur in San Francisco. So one day on a whim we decided to drive all the way to San Francisco from Fremont, and we went to Borobudur.

Indonesian food takes pretty long to prepare, and since my girlfriend and I were planning on only staying for about an hour, she suggested that we called and ordered. We gave them our arrival time of 1pm, which is during the busy lunchtime, yet we were still accommodated.

So we ordered the Gado Gado, which is a warm salad consisting of steamed vegetables, tofu, eggs and shrimp crackers all mixed in a tasty peanut sauce. This is a great dish to get someone who doesn't usually eat vegetables to eat some because the way they prepare it is excellent. We also ordered the Ayam Bakar Cabe which is barbecued marinated spicy chicken with a red chili sauce. The inside of the chicken was a little dry, however, the flavor is unbelievably good. We also got Rendang, which is basically beef brisket cooked in a coconut milk sauce which plenty of spices. This was excellent as the flavor was present in the entire dish, not just the top layer. We also got the Gulai Kambing, which is Lamb cooked in a curry and coconut milk sauce. This was by far my favorite. The curry taste was not overpowering, the lamb, which is usually a strong tasting meat was not overpowering and the entire sauce goes very well with rice. And finally we got the Tumis Kangkung Terasi Pedas, which is just water spinach that has been cooked in a spicy shrimp paste and spicy chili. This totally beats the chinese style that is cooked in just msg and garlic. This is flavorful and for once I was able to finish my vegetables. For drinks we got the Es Teller which is just mixed fruits in a coconut milk and Es Kelapa Muda which is basically just Coconut milk. Both were very refreshing to go with the spicy Indonesian food. And finally for dessert my girlfriend had to order the Es Duren, which is an Indonesian layer cake, where according to my girlfriend, they bake one layer of cake at a time and then they pound it really thin, then they bake another layer and then pound that really thin and layer it again. I guess Indonesian people like food that takes absurdly long to prepare, but I definitely am not complaining =).

Our total bill came out to be around 80 dollars; 100 dollars for 2 people including tip. Which is not so bad considering I had a lot of food left over and we got drinks and dessert. If your not looking to spend that much, I recommend trying their lunch specials.
author: Allan H.

description: My family is Dutch Indonesian so I have been eating Indonesian food my whole life, I know what it should taste like.  I've tried many different indonesian restaurants in the Bay Area and this one is my favorite!  The service is great, the atmosphere is beautiful, and the food is YUM YUM YUM!  The prices are VERY reasonable and the presentation of the food is impressive.  Screw the whole Thai food craze, go to Borobudur for authentic, flavorful, and spicy Indonesian food!
author: Jacquelyn M.

description:
We made the mistake of going to this place not long after the airing of the Bay Area Check Please! episode in which this restaurant was reviewed.  It got glowing remarks from the guests, and the restaurant was instantly slammed thereafter.

Truth be told, I'd like to try it again, because even though we had to wait the better part of an hour to be seated, the food was pretty good.  Usually when a restaurant is that slammed, we worry about the food quality slipping for the evening.

Now that things have probably slowed down, it may prove to be a good go-to place.  The night we went, we weren't knocked out by the food-- we thought it was good, solid Indonesian food that was almost indistinguishable from good Thai food.  But this place is probably worth another look.
author: Dave N.

description: Very good dining experience!! My friend really wanted to celebrate her birthday here with a group of close friends and she chose this restaurant because she had heard a lot of good things about it. It also happens to be owned by the brother of one of our friends. My friend took over the ordering of the food and chose a great selection of food for us. My favorite was the roti prata (bread) and the crispy honey chicken which was cooked perfectly. Everybody was very nice at the restaurant and I really appreciate them putting up with our very boisterous and loud group of friends. I definitely would want to go back again : )
author: Lisa M.

description: just 3 stars.  I would say this place is overrated, maybe because my food buzz is spoiled after 4 years of intensive of wine and dine in SF.  Eggplant looks delicious but tasted just a okay. We also had #62, Ayam Panggang Bumbu Rujak, which is soaked in coconut sauce, and it's lack of flavor.  i love the special ginger tea, but $2.95 for a small cup that is nonrefillable, it's a little pricey, huh?
author: Sophia L.

description:
We sort of happened upon this place as we were walking from the theater district and it was an unexpected excellent find.

The restaurant has a very nice ambiance,  it is elegant and decorated with jewel tone light shades.  The food is delicious, beautifully presented and the flavors are so delicate.  If you are used to Indian food which can be quite spicy, here what you have are these unexpected, delicate flavors that really let you explore the spices without the heat.  It was a great dinner experience.  Do order desert, it was a bean pudding which was unbelievably tasty.  And I am not usually a fan of anything bean.
author: Localista I.

description: had my first indonesian food experience and it was great! :) we had family style and ordered a bunch of things from the menu and everything was really good! I loved the Roti Prata for the appetizer~ mmmm and the Bakmi Goreng noodles were so yummy! plus, the waiters always made sure that your beer glass was full and kept asking us if we needed more -- yes please! :)
author: Lucy C.

description: As an Indonesian, I can say that the foods here  taste ok.. Not really authentic like the foods that you can eat in Indonesia, but I think it's because  Indonesian foods really need a lot of different spices, and maybe it's hard to find in the US. I recommend you to try pempek ( Indonesian fishcake... Really yummy ) and rendang!  Don't try their ayam goreng (fried chicken), because it's not Indonesian style of ayam goreng and it's taste weird. Honestly, I came to Borobudur to support people from my country to open more Indonesian restaurant and introduce Indonesian foods to people here in US, but my GREATEST DISAPPOINMENT of this restaurant is their BAD SERVICE. I've came twice, and every time I came I got really bad service. The waiter and waitress are not friendly at all. When we came, they just busy chit chat and didn't greet us or ask us to sit down. They also never asked us how was the food and didin't refill our water.  I wonder was it because they knew we are Indonesian and think that we won't give big tip OR their service are just BAD. But seriously guyss you really need to improve your service. Just be nice and friendly to your customer...
author: Cutie B.

description: We had the Rijsttafel, and it was great.  Its nice to be able to get lots of variety, and generous but not gluttonous-sized portions.  The service was really attentive and it felt like a real homey place.  I only wish that the food would have been spicier.  I guess next time we'll have to ask for the non-wimp version.
author: Jo Anne G.

description: I live few blocks from Borobudur, I always used to wonder why this place is crowded, of course not until I had food here. My first experience was awesome. Roti parata is heaven, that's the first thing I order, everyone should. They have got great fried rice items. Their house wine is good too. If you like your food spicy, just ask them. Service is slow sometimes, but food is good.
author: Ritesh G.

description:
I am Indonesian, and my mum is the best cook, so I have a really-really high expectation on Indonesian food. Of course I have been here thousand millions times before, so I know exactly what is the "must-try" items. 1) ayam kalasan (honey and soy sauce baked chicken) hmmm.. it is marinated well, so you can taste the sweetness in the meat, not just the skin. 2) Mie Yamin pedas ( the spicy chicken noodles). It is really SPICY. But at the same time, so tasty :D ask for meatballs! 3) Nasi goreng terasi ikan asin ( shrimp paste fried rice with salted fish) I love it. But my friends think its too salty and of course SPICY. But if you order something else less tasty and share it with ur friends, it will be perfect. Also save your stomach for prata manis (pancake with chocolate, cheese, condensed milk, and peanuts). It taste almost like martabak (the authentic pancake back in Indonesia) but it is still GOOD :D
If you like tea, you should try their ice tea too, they use Indonesian tea which is more flavourful. Others are pretty descent :)

Writing this review really makes me hungry. I cant wait to visit again soon.
author: Etika T.

description: One of the beef dishes smelled a bit like Alpo. Definitely USDA Prime. But my dessert was tasty and amusing - fried banana topped with chocolate, condensed milk and shredded cheese. It tasted like something that Hostess might market in SE Asia and I mean that as a compliment. Other diners food ranged from "pretty tasty" to "this is really boring."  I agree with T-Bone that knowing what to order might be the key here.
author: patrick g.

description: Pleasantly surprised. Looked al fancy from the outside but was definitely the right price for a bunch of dancers. Good food even if the food wasn't brought all at the same time. Next time I am in the loin, this will definitely be a place I'd suggest.
author: Alexis B.

description: Delicious, interesting ethnic food for a reasonable price!  This place may appear to be a fancy, expensive restaurant from outside, but I urge you to come in a be surprised!  I ordered the fried rice which was quite delicious!
author: Scott G.

description: Sorry. The food was tasteless and colorless. Nothing like you get in Indonesia. We had Chicken and Shrimp Nasi Goreng (only 4 shrimp, dry chicken, beige rice, and no flavor), Chicken Satay (very small pieces of chicken which were over cooked) and Chicken Curry (very watery with little food).  Ambiance is nice here though. I have traveled Indonesia extensively and was looking forward to this food, but it didn't even come close to the flavor or color. Would not go here again.
author: Smart Shopper G.

description: The food was very salty and for me almost inedible.  Their version of beef stew was heavy and uninteresting.  The soup was a mismatch of flavors with the meat in it being chewy and full of cartilige
author: margaret r.

description: Great food, great location, sloppy service. The waiter attempted to take our order by memory, and we ended up not getting two of the dishes we ordered. Although it ended up being a good thing since we were stuffed, it's still shitty service. Overall though, the food was great (yummy noodles), so I don't care too much about the oversight.
author: Chris B.

description: Went with a friend for dinner.  We started with the  Roti Prata cuz who doesn't like fried dough with fragrant curry dipping sauce?  Yum!  Next was the Sayur Asam (tamarind soup).  It was good, but I prolly won't bother filling up precious stomach space on soup.  Had the Tahu and Terong Balado (eggplant and friend tofu dish).  The spicy heat from the dish was a bit surprising, but not unbearable.  The eggplants was delish, but the tofu, not so much.  I want to say there was a noodle dish, but I honestly can't recall.  Last was a chicken dish, sadly the name escapes me as well.  All-in-all a good evening of eats.  The portions are HUGE so be prepared to bring home lots of leftovers.
author: Anonymouse C.

description: Delicious food!!  Indonsian food is hard to come by, and when my friend brought me here, I was super impressed! If you want to try something new and exotic, this is a fabulous spot!!
author: Rachelle C.

description: If you haven't tried Indonesian food....you are missing out. Borobudur is seriously a great place to start. Inexpensive and low on the decor front...the food is the treasure. The Redang is some of the best I have every had. This is a hidden gem and should not be missed.
author: Michael H.

description: Since my family is from Indonesia, I often try Indo restaurants in my travels as there are none in Honolulu.  Borobudur is in a busy part of downtown SF.  The restaurant recommends parking in a lot on a street one block down, but there's actually a small hidden lot behind the restaurant off Jones (Borobudur is at the corner of Jones and Post) that's quite convenient.  There were people waiting at the entrance, but I had made a reservation and got seated almost right away.  The ambiance was satisfactory if unremarkable.  I ordered the rijsttafel, which is a full course dinner that includes soto ayam (chicken soup), gado gado (salad), a shrimp dish, satay (meat on skewers), beef rendang, ayam panggang (chicken in a marinated coconut sauce), tempe (a soybean cake and tofu) and dessert (either ice cream or a sweet drink with jelly bits).  The dishes were served on various hot plates, and the food was very tasty, reminding me of home cooking I enjoyed with relatives in Surabaya and Jakarta.  In fact, it was more than I could eat in one sitting so I had stuff to take out.  If you're ever in SF and want to try Indonesian food, I would recommend Borobudur.
author: Roy T.

description: I love Indonesian food, but can't get it where I live. So while I was in SF, I thought it would be nice to eat some. I got the nasi rames plate. It was pretty great, although the components ranged from good to utterly fantastic. The beef, which promised to be spicy, was not, and could of used a thicker sauce, but overall good. The tempeh was pretty tasty, but maybe I wouldn't order a plate of just that for dinner. The egg was great, I don't really understand what was going on there, but something like a deep fried hard boiled egg in sambal. The fried chicken, though, was magical. I'll go back next time I'm in the neighborhood, I'd like to try more of their dishes.
author: Lydia M.

description: We went here last Saturday and I was a little reluctant...I was unsure what Indonesian food was like and if I would like it.  I was definitely impressed!  With so many Asian restaurants to choose from in the area, this one stands out as memorable.  We came back again after 3 days!! Try the roti with curry dipping sauce (#1) and the spicy chicken chili (#59).  The meat literally falls off the bone and is oh so good.  Definitely a fan and we'll be back soon.
author: Britt B.

description: Let me preface this by saying that this was my first experience with Indonesian food.  I loved the beef skewers, roll appetizer and their dipping sauces, but the meat in a friend's entree had a bad texture.  I would definitely give this place a second chance.  I have a feeling that I just don't know what to order.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
I wanted to give this place a 5 star soo bad but then I remembered the service in this restaurant n I decided 4 star it is =) just to warn u to be extremely patient during the weekend if u decided to come to this restaurant..allow an hour extra to ur schedule since the service is slow. Other than that I know for sure this restaurant is one of the BEST INDONESIAN restaurant in SF! now there are several in the cities n I'm Indonesian myself..so I do know good indo food when I eat some.

I love my spicy indo food so I love to order MIE TEK TEK which contains veggies, chicken n eggs with some bell peppers...if ur a brave soul who loves spicy food then u could make this dish extra spicy! we Indo ppl always say that "ur really not Indonesian if u don't eat spicy food..."
But Hold on...there is hope for all of u non-spicy food eaters....please order the AYAM KALASAN which is basically a honey sweet roasted chicken..it is soo flavorful!!! n u can order Nasi uduk on the side which is coconut rice..its a great combination with the chicken n my other favorite dish is BIHUN GORENG which is the fried angel hair noodles with veggies, chicken or do a seafood combo if u like..its ur choice. Trust me when I say to order these foods when u go there cuz I have taken my friends who are latino, white, black, n other nationalities n they all love the foods that I ordered. u will not be disappointed...I know the service is pretty slow but hey a satisfying tummy is more important isnt it?? n as far as ur wallet goes...I'm sure it won't be complaining any time soon =)
author: Rika K.

description: Cute/good place, but not great.  Food was above average, service good, ambiance so-so.  Everything here needs more "umph" to bring it up a notch.
author: John W.

description:
It will always be hard to resist going into Pearl's Deluxe Burgers instead of Borobudur, since it is literally right next door & one of my favorite burger places in SF, but I'm glad we had the willpower to try Borobudur.

We decided to have a "light" meal, so only ordered the following: 

1. ground beef, egg, & onion murtabak - This was pretty disappointing, it was very different from what murtabaks actually are in Southeast Asia. Borobudur just uses a huge eggroll wrapper to wrap the meat in & then deep-fries it, so it is basically a flat, crispy eggroll. Murtabaks are supposed to be more crepe-like, soft & pan-fried. 
2. Nasi Goreng Terasi Peda (shrimp paste fried rice with salted fish, & we also asked for shrimp) - I was pretty delighted to see stinky shrimp paste dishes on the menu!!! I thought the combination of shrimp paste & salted fish would be too salty, but it worked out quite well in this dish. None of the ingredients overpowered the other. 
3. Ayam Panggang Bumbu Ruja (bbq chicken in coconut milk) - Mmmm, this dish was tasty! It wasn't really a standard American bbq dish -- it seemed more like a chicken curry dish, but it was damn good! The chicken was really tender & the accompanying sauce wasn't too sweet (which is what I expect from most coconut curries). 

All in all, a great place, but I wish they had laksa on the menu!
author: Ruby H.

description:
Nothing is better than the original, but Borobudur offered some relief to my memory of Indonesian food.

You should come here just for the food and forget about the service or the decoration. A lot of people complained about these things, but they don't realize that's usually what you get when you want authentic food. Otherwise, they could just skip to Slanted Door or Ponzu for some fake Americanized Asian food.

What they offer here is the real stuff, not the ones they compromised to adjust to the American taste. Try the empek2, Ayam Kalasan, Nasi Goreng, and Beef Rendang for a start. And don't forget the ice chendol.
You will soon get hooked on it!

I wish they'd bring back the ice Durian, bcs buying a real fruit would mean spending the whole night in the basement to contain the smell!
author: Tania R.

description: After living in Indonesia for a good chunk of my life this is the only place I go to get Indonesian food in SF because the flavor and selection is so legit. Try any of the Ayam bakars or Ayam Goreng Kuning if you like chicken.  I have yet to be dissapointed with this place....the flavor and spices are great....and if your into some extra spice ask for some sambal terasi....I dare you.
author: David H.

description: Listen to Kiria below and not the suckas that have not been to Indonesia.  This is good stuff and while the joint isn't great looking, the food is legit and pretty good.  The nasi ayam was tasty and even the satays weren't too dried out as satay tends to be.   The fried rice dishes are great too - big servings you can take home and eat the next day for lunch.
author: Rob K.

description:
so this place is kinda spendy for indonesian food. we had roti for $9, and really all i could think about was the uber delicious roti at banana island that i get for $2.95. don't get me wrong, it was tasty, but would have been soooo much tastier if the price was slashed by $5. right? 

so afterwards, we all go to watch the other boleyn girl. i don't want to ruin it for you, but i found this movie to be unintentionally hilarious. i think once you get over the bad acting, you can really get into the choice lines like "did you lay with him?" and "will you bed me now?'  awesome.
author: eve l.

description:
I liked it.

Didn't get the rifsten whatever that is because we had enough people to try everything (and it felt like we did).
Service was pleasant. On to the food:

THE REALLY GOOD
- Kerupuk Palembang Sauce -- fish cracker. This was great. Cool texture, pretty to look at it really tasty.
- lumpia - good if you like egg rolls.
- Mie Tek Tek  spicy noodles -- you can get this in soup or stirfry form. With our group, we chose stir fry. tasty, nice spice.
- bbq chicken. I don't remember which one we got but it was half a chicken (in 2 quarter form) and was really good. tender. moist.
THE BETTER THAN AVERAGE
- beef rendang. some pieces were more tender than other. tasted like pot roast.
- lamb curry: my least favorite but others really liked it. So i guess it's better than average.
THE AVERAGE
- eggplant and tofu. Sometimes the eggplant was yummy, sometimes just not cooked enough. I'd eat it again but I wouldn't crave it.
- roti dessert. weird. just. weird. one bite was more than enough.
THE SUB PAR
- whole fried fish. really not great. dry. (and surprising that it came from the same kitchen as the super moist chicken)
- grilled banana w/ cheese and other crap. weirder than the dessert roti. REALLY not my thing (or anyone else at our table).

Would definitely get less food next time but would go back.
author: Margie L.

description: Should never have gone back, first visit some months ago was positive. On this visit the food was simply not fresh, i.e. the ingredients had no life to them, tasted like left overs. Sorry, these are nice folks but the kitchen let them and us down.
author: Charles C.

description: This is the only Indonesian food I've ever had so I have nothing to compare it to, but Borobudur has always kept me coming for more. I recommend the "Ayam Bakar Cabe" (B.B.Q. marinated spicy chicken in special chili sauce) and "Ayam Goreng Kalasan" (fried honey chicken). Going family-style with friends is the way to do it...more variety and more fun. Would've given 5 stars but the service could be better.
author: Mike L.

description:
This restaurant got rave reviews on Check Please Bay Area, but I was terribly disappointed and won't be going back. There were four of us in a booth that really was kind of tight. There were only a couple other tables filled but the service--if you can call it that--was less than slow. It was like they didn't care. We had to wait until we were finished eating before they finally got the correct menu to us to order our fruit drinks and shave ice.
Food was just ok. We ordered the Lemon grass, and chicken soup. It was ok, but not warm enough and we had to serve ourself (most Asian/Cambodian restaurants will serve it for you. And it was difficult to dole out.) The vegetable sampler was just fair -- corn fritters so-so. The tofu was very good though. Not much else we had was very interesting. (My friends didn't want spicy food which cut out a lot, but still there should have been more interesting flavors.)
Although it was a warm November night, the restaurant got freezing and uncomfortable. 
The decor is dull, not quaint or simple, just uninspired. 
The cost was too much for what we got. S100 without tip- 2 glasses wine, 2 ice drinks, fish cake in banana leaves and veggie sampler appetizers, one soup, shrimp curry, grilled fish (this was ok but way small), chicken satay, Portions were small, service was sporatic. On Check Please they said everything was fabulous but I beg to differ.
We will never go back again. There are much better asian, cambodian, malaysian restaurant.s.
Sorry. I wanted to like it but felt bad that I suggested it to my friends. We could have walked anywhere nearby and found something better.
author: Ima G.

description: a life saver whenever i crave for Indonesian food, my favorite is their nasi goreng terasi pedas with tripe and salted fish, also sayur asam yummmmm so freshhhh
author: Puteri H.

description: solid indonesian food. nothing to die for, but nice family run joint with good curries and good fish cakes. tried the bbq fish cakes, pretty good, and a spicy chicken curry w coconut milk. ordered it extra spicy. very tasty.
author: Paul R.

description:
went here last night with the family cuz one of my brothers really likes the restaurant and recommended it. i'm open to new things, but because i'm unfamiliar with indonesian food, my palate may not be the best to judge this place.  

we were a group of six and ordered fried rice, noodles, chicken and beef satay skewers, fried and steamed fish cake, spinach and garlic, fish wrapped in leaves, fried fish, green beans, fried beef with honey?, some other beef dish, the fried roti bread, fried plantains and ice cream, and the layered cake. 

i liked the spicy peanut sauce that came with our fried and steamed fishcake, but the fishcake itself was nothing special. the fried roti bread came with a curry that didn't quite complement it in my opinion, so i ate the bread with the spicy peanut sauce instead.  the fried beef with honey? tasted like beef jerky that wasn't all the way jerkied. the fried fish was nothing special and the green beans had an odd flavor to them. the fried rice was pretty good and the best dishes were definitely the beef skewers and the noodle dish (altho i wouldn't eat the skewer with the sauce they brought it with either). 

if i were to return, it would be solely for the noodle dish and the beef skewers (and ask for the spicy peanut sauce that came with the fishcake). the layered cake was interesting tho.
author: ML N.

description: I like their layered bread a lot..The one of the must-order appetizer in my list..
author: Julie H.

description: So a non-yelper friend and I wanted to eat some Indonesian food before we went to see Jersey Boys last night.  We came here when we found out the other Indonesian restaurant down the block was closed on Tuesdays.  It was pretty empty when we walked in but was packed by the time we left.  The service was pretty quick for us and they were attentive.  We only ordered three dishes - roti, satay, and a beef stew.  The beef stew was spicy!!  I soooo cannot take spicy foods and there wasn't a little chili pepper next to this item on the menu!  I can only imagine what the spicy dishes taste like.  It was about $30 for the three dishes, which I think is a little pricey.
author: Kris L.

description: This place was surprisingly empty for a Thursday night.  The food was fairly priced, and the vegetarian entrees seemed to be their forte.  They had a string bean plate and a eggplant dish that were really good...and I normally do not like purple plants.  We did have a crispy chicken/beer/coconut rice dish, and the servings were pretty small.  Nice atmosphere.  The service was great, and they serve wine and beer!
author: Mark D.

description: I have always wanted to come here. It was good. Not as good as the food I had in Bali, der, but good none the less. Roti prata and beef rendang yum.
author: Rikki D.

description:
Not as good as the Indonesian food that I had in Amsterdam, but I'm still giving it four stars, because it was good and I'm just happy to get Indonesian food at all in the States (and definitely not from my home town, Denver).
I had the Rijsttafel, which was way too much food, but it was very tasty. The Rijsttafel is about ten courses and usually comes in little bowls so that you can taste a little bit of everything. The Lemon Grass soup wasn't that tasty (but I have this thing against hard boiled eggs, which they had chopped up in the soup). 
Everything else was great. The spring roll, Lumpia Semarang, was super good and had almost a barbecue flavor. I knew already that I loved Beef Rendang already, but I also found that I really liked the Tahu Balado, the fried tofu in chile sauce. And I don't know what was in the dessert (they said it was black rice with coconut milk), but it was super good as well: not super sweet, but just a somewhat sweet and a delicious end to the meal.
Overall, it was super yummy and I will be back when I'm back in town.
author: Tina F.

description: Mmm, it was a tasty dinner, and I thought service was friendly and perfectly good.  Highlights were the lumpia and the chicken on a stick.  Rijsttafel is lots of different delicious items for your supreme enjoyment.  I'll be back.
author: Leo C.

description:
is heaven a place on earth? does it come on a plate served at this restaurant? i think i answered my question.

nom nom nom nom nom nom
author: Yan Biao B.

description:
Wow, I had a really good meal at Borobudur restaurant on saturday night. The ambiance is so nice, and the wait staff friendly and attentive. I ordered the trout and my friend ordered the Tiger prawns, spiced pretty hot. My fish was to die for. A large portion of very fresh fish, and it was blackened. Yum, yum. Her prawns were good, too, but the portion could have been better. 

White rice with coconut milk was very tasty. ..but I was disappointed that they didn't serve my favorite Thai iced tea, and the iced coffee I ordered was way too sweet! 

On a saturday night, it was crazy busy, and we waited quite a long time. ..ended up ordering while we waited, cause we had a show to go to. Next time, I will check out their chicken dishes. They sure Looked good! Will definitely be returning to this place. 

One last thing. This place was Noisy! Did we have an especially loud crowd there that night, or was it just that sound carried a little too much? Who knows.....
author: Ellen N.

description: I love Indonesian food, they are tasty, sweet yet spicy, their desert was amazingly good.  The bad is that just like any other indonesian restaurant in the city or any other place in california, their service are very slow cuz I think the owner are to cheap to pay extra helper.  Anywayz, if you wanna try Indonesian food come during the low peak hour and about the choice of food, choose your dish with care so you can actually taste 'em
author: Albert W.

description:
not bad, not bad.

after having dined at indonesia restaurant for a couple of years now, we decided to change things up and make the leap to borobudur.  well, it wasn't such a huge leap.  more like a skip and a hop, since they're just across the street from each other.

all in all, i liked it.  they have a pretty simple menu with all the indonesian classics - satays, rendang (beef stewed in coconut milk and spices), gado gado (salad drowned in peanut sauce), nasi goreng (fried rice/noodles, i can't remember which).  the satays were a tad dry, the fried rice was SUPER spicy but oh-so-tasty.  i don't know what it is about indo spice...it doesn't make your mouth burn so much as it makes you sweat from the top of your head.  literally, i've seen friends' heads steam while eating indonesian food.

like indonesia restaurant, the food here is quite good - certainly a nice chill sunday night dinner quality- but service, parking, and ambiance make me prefer to just pick up the food and take it home to eat.

also to note, my indo friends prefer indonesian restaurant...the food is more authentic there, they say.  but i'm just  a chinese guy, it all tastes good to me. =)
author: brian w.

description: I always walk by this place and some time before the holidays me and two friends decided to try it out. I've not had Indonesian cuisine before so I played it safe and chose a simple noodle dish. The service, setting and food was good but the wine was kind of mediocre.
author: Frances L.

description: This is real Indonesian food! Food is tasty and staff is friendly. You pay a little more than in an ordinairy Asian restaurant but it's reasonable. Roti Prata (appetizer) is delicious! I had the Vegetarian entree with tofu and spring beans (forgot name), which is really good. I understand why some people say that the service is bad, but I guess it really depends on when you go, I've been lucky with the service. If you don't want to take the chance of having bad service, order take out, cause the food is really irresistible.
author: Helen D.

description: Food is ok.  Service is awful.  Got there on Sat evening around 6.  It took the staff 15 minutes before I was acknowledged.  This place is small, so there's no way they could have missed me.  Took them a long time to take our order.  Our food took a long time to come out as well.  It was only 3 of us, but it took us more than 2 hours to get out of that place, with the majority of that time waiting.  We ordered the complete rice dinner and roti.  Roti was ok, had better.  This version was way too thick and dense.  The best part of the meal was the egg roll and the black rice dessert.
author: Denise W.

description: Best Bandeng Presto I've had in a very long time.  Bravo!
author: Angelique S.

description: Its good Restaurant and ambiance is really good. The food tastes ok, but I don't think I will go again..The sweetened black rice dessert was the best..
author: Nifty G.

description: The food was borobu-bomb!.  Let me put it to you like this:  my family who only ventures as far as chinese food and California rolls were very delighted to have experienced Indonesian food as prepared by Borobodur.  A must order is the Roti + Honey Glazed Chicken.  Their dishes have a bit of spice but nothing that's intolerable!  It's that Asian spice, you either love it or you don't.
author: Brian F.

description:
went here on Saturday with a group of 12. staff were very accommodating, but then we did make things easy for them and ordered two of everything, apart from the dessert (more about that in a mo)

the roti was good, though some of the diners preferred it to be thinner and crispier. this is more doughy than the Malaysian roti, but the curry sauce was lighter and more ginger. i guess its down to personal preference and i was liking it. the corn fritters were okay, a little heavy so was thankful that there was enough for one per person, cos more than that would have been too much... dipping sauce was nice and thick

for main: forgive my lack of names, but will describe... BBQ chicken, sweet and spicy salmon, grilled trout and chicken noodles. All were good, nothing too exciting (well, the salmon had a good kick)

dessert- THE BEST PART!
Indonesian layer cake- wow- thin slices of dense cake- very labor intensive- how long it must take to make is beyond me

chengdol- erh- Vietnamese version better, but still decent

plantain and icecream- light and not greasy

plantain, condensed milk chocolate and yes, cheese- apparently this is an indonesian dessert according to the waiter, I figured my two favorite foods are here- what can go wrong? it was strange, savory and sweet, but not a clean taste... not something I'd try again, I'll stick to a cheese sandwich and slice of chocolate cake on separate  plates please!

all in all, because Indonesian food is so similar to Malaysian, it was hard to pick out anything too outstanding.... apart from the cheese and chocolate dessert of course!
author: Sushi Y.

description:
this place really is the BEST INDONESIAN in SF. 
great service w/ very attentive waiters/waitresses 
AWESOMEEEEEEEEE FOOOD that is sooo damn spicy
AWESOMEEEEEEEEE ATMOSPHERE
the other indonesian places around cant even compare to this level of deliciousness
author: R Y.

description: I really, really like this restaurant.  I've been here 3 x's (that's my rule before I rate a place) and each time the service has been attentive with a sense of humor and with information.  The food has always been great (especially the melt in my mouth honey beef), timely, and good portion size, neither too little or too much.  I love their assortment of rices, their curries are subtle and spicy and their desserts are excellent.  Personal favorite: black rice pudding - auh - grrrr - yummm!  They've also got a great bread they deep fry and it's all flaky and garlicky and fabulous.  Good location for if you're bar hopping in the area and it's ridiculously inexpensive.  Me & my 5 girlfriends went there after quite a few drinks at Bourbon & Branch and neither had to wait nor were we ever disappointed in the quality of the food.  We were STUFFED and the whole bill came to $80 or so!
author: Kate C.

description: This restaurant was my favor.  An old gentleman used be working here who was very friendly and I loved his good services.  Since I don't see him anymore, I still eat here because food is good, reasonable price and it nearby my apartment.  Few months ago, I had to wait my food about 45 minutes. It was Saturday night and it was packed. It seems like they forgot my order. Well, everybody made mistakes so I just let go. One night, I made a reservation for two but I still had to wait about half hour. I'm kind of upset because what reservation for it? But I don't want to try another restaurant to start over so I ate there. On another night, my friend and I didn't make a reservation, they told me to wait to half hour so we did. After we waited 45 minutes, two Caucasian ladies came and said they had a reservation. The owner of this restaurant served them right away. I complained what just happened but the owner keeps saying that they have a reservation. What about when I had a reservation? It was very unfair. So I haven't used this restaurant a little while until today. I decided to order TO GO. The lady told me I need to wait to 15 minutes. Only one family sit one table and a man came to the restaurant at same time with me.  There were only two customers and one group (4 persons). The restaurant was very slow today but I waited half hour for just two orders. I asked the lady about my food. She said "Oh, one of our chefs was on break. Can you wait few more minutes?" I said "NO". I can't believe they not start cooking yet. A man who came about same time with me, he already has his foods and eating. So I canceled my order. After they canceled my order, they had a bad attitude with me. How they treated me was unacceptable because it was their mistakes. It is so sad that a good restaurant turned into a bad restaurant. The food is still good there but they have horrible service now. I never come back again.
author: Kitty C.

description: you can add a star if you do the Rijsttafel remove  a star if you eat ala carte. it is just that simple.  the Rijsttafel is a nice clean version of indonesian style food and makes for a fun date night, I find the rest of the menu just ok if not less then... wish there was a place that did Sumatran style food.
author: Ricote F.

description:
This was my first visit (heard about restaurant on Check Please, Bay Area).  We liked the ambience and decor and were equally pleased with our choices.

We ordered two appetizers (roti, deep fried egg-roll like with eggs) and three entrees (shrimp nasi goreng, shrimp curry and noodle with shrimp).  Everything was delicious and the staff was very helpful and attentive.  

We would definitely return and wouldn't hesitate to recommend.
author: Katy B.

description: Very authentic, delicious indo food in a pretty setting. The gado gado, otah, and noodles with chicken were FANTASTIC. If we could have fit more in our stomach we would have. Definitely going to go back!
author: Gigi H.

description: I am now officially over Thai food.  Service was just fine.  Food blew my frickin mind!
author: Robert S.

description:
My hubby and I have a hobby of finding great, local, affordable restaurants.  There are a couple that we love so much, that we simply become extended family.  Well, the kind of extended family where they intimately know your odd eating habits and requests...and can pretty much order for you, but wouldn't know your name outside the restaurant. 

Out of all the loin gems, Borobudur is probably the one we go to most.  Partially from living in SE Asia for a few years has instilled a healthy craving for Indonesian spices, but mostly because when we feel like having a decent meal with lots of healthier (read not saturated with cooking oil and thick msg-filled sauces) veggie options, this is the place to go.  If you are vegetarian, you'll find lots of options here--even tempe for your protein.  

What keeps us coming back is the consistency of the food and that it's one of the only Asian restaurants in the city--vegetarian places included, where you can get super-tasty, non-greasy, crisp vegetable dishes that are full on flavor and light on salt and heavy sauces.  Even their vegetable curry is delicate sheer and savory--not pummeled with an over-sugary thick sauce.  Service is sometimes slow, but always friendly.  

My Indonesian friend says it's not completely authentic but still really good.  Not being 100% authentic isn't an issue for us.  We come here because it's close to home, always friendly (at least the night crew) and it satisfies our cravings in a healthy affordable way.  And we can get a Tiger beer or decent glass of wine with dinner without breaking the bank.  Our favourites?  Hmmm.  Try the honey beef, honey chicken, beef rendang (of course), kang kong garlic, veggie curry, and an eggplant-tomato dish that has a slight Italian flavor (could be garlic with the tomato?) 

Note:  It's a great, affordable place to go with a group and eat family style.

Also note:  I was torn about whether to give 4 stars or 5.  I decided on 5 becuase it is pretty damned good for a restaurant in it's class.  And how could I give it any less if we frequent it so much?!
author: Nette J.

description: It was a birthday lunch for my friend who is half indonesian prices good (He is milking this birthday thing, We also had dinner to go to that night a party at the house brunch on sunday...blah blah blah. Wait till he is in his 30s he is sooo going to not want to remember the years ticking by but any whoooo)we thought it would be fun and i always am down for a good meal....I loved it. Flavors mmm I love thai food but it kind of kicked its butt.
author: Patricia K.

description:
The restaurant's decor, food presentation and service were pretty cool, but the food here wasn't impressive by any means.

We ordered the siomay bandung for appetizer. It wasn't spicy as we had expected; because it was noted in the menu with 2 peppers, we had expected it to be more spicy. The peanut sauce wasn't as flavorful as the ones we had back in Indonesia. The siomay wasn't as chewy too.
We also tried the Nasi Padang and bakmie ayam w/ meatballs.
First of all, Nasi Padang is supposed to be spicy. It's a very vital component! But the one we had in Borobudur was not spicy or flavorful. The rendang tastes like something we could've cooked ourselves using the seasoning available in Asian supermarkets.
Bakmie ayam was  also tasteless... They put in very small chicken pieces and even less veggies in it.
The soup + meatballs that came w/ the noodles were appalling. The soup had no taste at all... and the meatballs were horrible in terms of taste and texture.
We also had banana w/ cheese & choc for dessert. It didn't taste like Indonesian food. And the cheese wasn't properly melted...

We were very disappointed. Borobudur would fare better if they don't claim that they have authentic Indonesian food...
author: Roland R.

description: Mediocare food, mediocare to poor service. Would not recommend.
author: S T.

description: Ehh.. Borobudur isn't all that great as people make it SEEM to be. I highly prefer & recommend Indonesia restaurant on the next block (better prices & better tasting food!). Their nasi goreng borobudur taste WEIRD and so does their roti prata (AND I LOVE ROTI PRATA!). When I went there I told them to make my order extra EXTRA spicy (because I LOOOOVEEE SPICY FOOD) but when it came out it was not ONE BIT spicy.. I was like WTF? Anddddd their menu is a little PRICY.. not even worth all the hype.
author: Sarah E.

description: I LOVE LOVE LOVE Borobudur. They have the best Mie Tek Tek (it's the noodle soup with chicken, vegetables, eggs, in a peanut-chicken broth) in the world. Make sure to order extra extra spicy!! I tried all Indonesian restaurant in San Francisco, and as an Indonesian, I gotta admit Borobudur is one of the best.
author: debora t.

description: try the delicious drink Es Cendol! finally i got to drink it here in SF.love it :)  ayam panggang bumbu rujak and pempek palembang are delicious!
author: Reni S.

description:
What happened with this restaurant? Did they change the owner? They used to be good and affordable, but all the sudden after they renovated the restaurant, the food was going down hill and the price increased by $1.50-2.00? 

I used to dine here with my girl-friends after work because it is close by to our office but we changed to other restaurant since they increased the price and the food is not worth the price.

The last time i tried their nasi goreng terasi, it was only a huge amount of rice but not well seasoned and bland with a little bit of beef, that's about it and it cost around $9.00, and the service is kinda slow, too.
author: sofie W.

description:
Love this place. After numerous visits, this has become Staple Food for me- I crave their vegetarian Mie Tek Tek at all hours, and have been known to get an order to go when I try something different from their menu, because if I leave here without some I'll be cranky. I now drag all out-of-town friends here when they come to visit, and usually have them in love by the time they finish their roti.

While the servers might not hover over your shoulder, they are unfailingly polite and friendly, and, honestly, I can really do without another "we're old friends even though we just met" waiter encounter like at other restaurants around town.
author: Eric S.

description: I came here last Saturday before my friends and I went out clubbing. This would be my second time eating Indonesian food. The service was great, but the food took a long time to come out. I was hungry but my friends and I didn't care as much. We just continued talking and passing time. Once the food came out I was impressed. AlI of this spicy goodness right in front of me. Mmmmm!!!!! I devoured it in 10 minutes flat. I don't remember what number I ordered, but it contained peanut curry sauce, meat, and this chile sauce as well on top of the meat. You gotta try it.
author: Jainee L.

description: I've been going to this place for years and enjoy it very much.  As far as appetizers, they are good portions.  Try the one with fish cakes and cabbage.  I usually get the satay skewers and one of the rice plates.  Save room for dessert, they have a fried banana with vanilla ice cream - very good and should be split by 3 people.  Also they have a banana covered in cheese (I believe) that is very exotic and tasty.  Plus, the prices are reasonable and a very good date place.
author: Dan A.

description: I had the trout, which was pretty solid.  Very juicy -- cooked very well.  No brown rice available.  Atmosphere not particularly impressive.  I'd like to try some other dishes before I really make a judgment on this place, but that was a good start.
author: Luke P.

description: I visited Borobudur on a Saturday night with friends.  We were seated right away, but the restaurant did fill up quickly.  The booths were a little tight to squeeze into, but the place seemed clean.  The gado gado salad, a savory fare, was one of my favorites.  It had steamed vegetables and was smoothered in peanut dressing.  A plus if you like peanut dressing, otherwise you might want to skip this one.  I also really liked the indonesian fried rice which was full of flavor.  Also notable was the roti prata which was slightly crispy on the outside, fluffy and chewy on the inside.
author: Winnie F.

description: After seeing it on check please! I thought I would give it try. They have a bargain lunch special for $9.95 where you get a soup, rice, salad and 2 dishes to choose from. The soup had noodles and egg in it which was ok , the rice was good but I must have picked the wrong items as my main because the beef was bad, spicy but bad and the fried spicy tofu was not very good either. My friend had the beef coconut curry which was easily the best thing (although not that great, just mediocre) and the bbq chicken which was also OK. The quality of the meat and the chicken was not the best and the texture of the tofu was mysterious... Also, we certainly did not appreciate the fact that we got there before 3 (they have lunch specials until 3) and they just brought us the regular a la carte menu, We had to specifically ask for the lunch specials so that they would say "of course"  and hand us the lunch menu... Hmmm
author: Chris D.

description: Mediocre food and lousy, slow service. We had to flag down a waiter any time we needed something, and they also forgot my entree. I'd pick another place to eat next time, I was unimpressed.
author: Steven G.

description: The food here is GREAT. The service is hit or miss. They make a kick ass honey fried chicken that just falls off the bone.
author: Chris B.

description: Consistently tasty! When I go here with friends and family, we always eat our plates clean. Not tons of vegetarian choices, but the food is great, and a welcome variation from other cuisines. Reasonably priced as well.
author: Micah K.

description: The grilled trout was awesome and the honey BBQ chicken as well. Great to find a restaurant where you can buy a bottle of wine at a reasonable price. I would recommend reservations as they are busy and my only complaint was there were only two servers for  a full house so ordering and prep to table time was very slow. I was with a friend I hadn't seen for awhile so we happily gabbed away while we waited for a meal that WAS worth waiting for. I am a first timer but I will be back
author: kathryn h.

description: Oh wow! This is awful. When msg dies it comes here! Had noodles with some kind of gravy... tasted and smelled like sewage. Smelled the water glass and it reaked of old sponge. Thought it was my friends bad breathe. I wish it was. I love indonesian, burmese, thai, indian, paki, afghan, but this is the worst place ever
author: ralph m.

description: The roti and bbq chicken were nice but it was a bit too starchy for my liking.  I wouldnt go back but might be worth a try if you want to explore an indonesian cuisine.
author: Mishi S.

description:
Okay, if You plan on only focusing on the good reviews to go to this restaurant, DONT.
Listen up yelpers, I have never been so offended by a waiter um in awhile.
So i thought taking my mom here for Mother's day would be a great idea since she never tried Indonesian food, but boy was that a BAD idea.
It took them 15 mins to seat us when there was clearly a table ready for us but we had to wait for them to seat us since it was a full house and they only have 1 1/2 waiters there. There's this overly exuberant,loud yet moody male waiter with glasses and a quiet yet nice female waitress who practically only handles the credit card transactions.
So after we were seated it took us 20 mins. to have someone take our order. But get this, I flagged him down THREEE times so he could take our order but all he did was do this thing with his hand, like shooing a fly out of his sight. CAN I SAY RUDE? Of course i completely understood that he was SUPER busy handling a restaurant of fifty people by being a host, taking orders, giving people their food, and being  a busboy all at once. For Fifty people. [I wouldn't be surprised if he was the cook.]
So i knew he CLEARLY had his hands full and wasnt going to be a b*tch about it. We ordered,waited another 20 mins for our food. Everytime we asked for water or refill on our hot tea we got a response like "Okay, i'll be back" Don't get me wrong the food is good (except the lemongrass soup) but no one wants to put up with a rude waiter who clearly cant handle a whole restaurant to himself, if they hired 2 more waiters  this place wouldn't be so bad. But our party was clearly frustrated since we didnt feel we deserved to pay him any tip since our bill came out to $90, for what? having to flag him down 10 times to get a simple glass of water? and we never got a refill on our hot tea or the Thai Ice tea that never came but we were double charged on our tab? All in all, we were there for two hours. we spent an hour trying to flag down our waiter,no kidding.
This restaurant is OVER-HYPED and WAY TOO OVERPRICED.
author: sarah p.

description: Haven't been here in the past year, but boy was it tasty the last time I sampled their fare. I bring out-of-town guests here if they're Indo-food virgins. Love the beef rendang, the greens with shrimp paste, the roti, and all the other Indo staples. I think we'll revisit soon!
author: jennifer s.

description: Indonesian food is not commonly found in the area.  My mother is dutch and indonesian cuisine was pretty familiar growing up.  Theirs is pretty authentic and some years back the place used to be extremely inexpensive.  I'd recommend it and have always wanted to try Indonesia restaurant less than a block away but never seems be doing as good business as Borobudur.
author: Christian W.

description: If you like coconut/ and or peanut, you need to get yourself over to Borobudur. I am pretty sure that most every single dish coming out of their kitchen has one of these two ingredients. I was invited to eat at Borobudur with a few of my Malaysian friends (Malaysian food is similar to Indonesian food but lacks some of the spiciness). When most of us had arrived, we were seated at a table in the back, and began to order some dishes- we started with a few appetizers including the roti with curry dipping sauce as well as some fried corn cakes, steamed fish cakes, chicken satay, and lemon grass soup. While I cannot comment on the fish cakes, the roti was absolutely amazing. Lila was a decided convert to this new treat, and wouldn't shut up about how delicious it was for the good first part of the meal. Indeed, this flaky, airy, and twisted deep fried bread was most likely the highlight of our dinner; the curry dipping sauce a nice companion. Most of the other dishes had some kind of peanut/ coconut sauce so after a while I could not distinguish one from the other. The chicken satay tasted very similar to the Thai counterpart- and we also ordered an entire dish of chicken in this peanuty sauce served with a garnish of pickled cucumbers. After devouring the roti and some of the chicken dishes, I was feeling quite full but the more dishes kept appearing- a never ending feast! There was a nice vegetable dish which was described as a salad- sauted cabbage and carrots served in more peanut sauce and topped with light and airy crispy rice cakes as well as a tempeh and green been dish with a darker sauce. All were tasty, and all were consumed. The night wore on an we had probably been there for 3 hours, but the more dishes appeared. By the end of the night we were so stuffed we could not manage to finish the dessert- a coconut cream base with black glutinous rice- very similar to thai "mango sticky rice" but lacking the mango. The flavors were the same- sweet with a bit of salt. Overall Borobudur offers some delicious and rich Indonesian food (and coming from the Malaysians, quite authentic too). The service was a bit on the slow side, but if you are in good company with entertaining conversations, you will definitely be in for a treat.
author: Kate A.

description: a bit more expansive than cheap, but really good alternative to thai
author: Cass M.

description: We were hopeful, but disappointed. Super nice server, but it took 45 minutes + for the food to come out, at lunch with only 1/2 the tables filled.  The server was swamped running the register, and the tables.  The food was basic and Chinese tasting. We did not eat everything which is rare for us, and went away hungry. The fried rice was bland, the vegetable dish was really a pile of spinach stir fried with  a pepper thrown in. Maybe dinner is better with a different chef?
author: SomeWhereInTheWorld C.

description: not a bad spot at all, dropped in with a few buddies to try it out. the ginger tea was delicious and surprising. the apps were damn good. the roti was fantastic! best thing we ate all night. the bbq fish cakes and and chicken satay were also quite good. we then split a nasi goreng, lamb curry and whole trout. all were good but not nearly as good as the apps. the roti set us up expecting big, cant say everything else lived up to that at all. but a damn good expierence and plenty more menu to be explored
author: Rich B.

description: i just wasn't all that impressed.  nothing wrong, just nothing spectacular.  tried 6 entrees and 4 appetizers between a big group, and only one or two things stood out as above-average - the trout, and spicy eggplant and tofu, the roti.  hard to get excited to make the trip across town back there, but if I were nearby I would have no qualms about going again.
author: James R.

description: Very high quality and authentic Indonesian food. My favorite is the salted fish spicy fried rice (Nasi goreng pedas). Dont try it if you cannot handle spicy food. And for dessert - try the very richly flavored Indonesian layered cake - the Kueh Lapis. Service is great, atmosphere a little dimly lit but cosy.
author: Sajid B.

description:
i used to go to borobudur everytime i need an indonesian fix. these days borobudur slided down the road. with the new interior design, new menu and new price made me thinks twice to go there. the worse experience is parking.. duh ! we have to go around and around more than 15 min just to looks for a spot. mie tek2 taste weird the last time i went there. the waitress is a little funky and forgetable easily. we have to wave couple times to remind her that we need more water. yes! my tounge was on fire because of the "medium" spicy mie tek-tek. so if you want to order mie tek-tek, make sure to tell the waitress not to spicy or less than medium spicy. i been ordering the same things over and over again. for apetizer i always order martabak telor goreng or otak2. the price on this food is a little pricy, though i still order the same thing anyway.. 
one of my biggest concerns is they took out avocado juice from the desert menu. man! thats what make me go there... big mistake !!!
author: sherly A.

description: went here with a couple of friends, the food was good but oily, which is to be expected cause we ordered the roti parata...cant resist. the rendang was delicious. the nasi that we got was not as good as other restaurants that we have had it at, the chicken lacked flavor. i would go here again but probably change up my order some.
author: Naureen H.

description: awesome place for authentic indonesian food, gotta to try their roti pratta, fish cake, honey bbq chicken, and many more. i've been here quite a few times. i try to stop by everytime i'm in the city. the roti pratta is the best i've had so far anywhere..
author: John C.

description: I've been to Indonesia (West Java, Solo, Yogja, Bali, Borobodur, Bandung, etc.) and thought the food here was pretty authentic, but the dish I ordered was not incredibly interesting.  It was okay.  One day I tried to go for lunch but the servers were really confused and not working efficiently, so I called for take out the next day.  I dunno - the reason I gave it three stars instead of two is that it really does taste like food one might get in Indonesia and maybe I was more up for something spicier like Thai...  could be me, not them.
author: Andrea P.

description: this is a terrific place and the people waiting in line know it. there are reservations even for two. the food is the best indonesian food going. the place was slammed, but that seems to be normal and the wait staff know how to cope. try the rice table with six different entries and not a weak entry among them all. the black rice dessert was the winner. we had ordered the vanilla ice cream, but they were out and the real winner was the black rice dessert. i think this is terrifc value and the people waiting also think so.
author: susan w.

description: this was my first time eating Indonesian food, so i don't know how authentic the food was, but i enjoyed everything i ate for what it was.  i love spicy food, so the Sambal Udang Balado is my favorite dish.  the roti prata was delicious, especially that dipping sauce.  basically anything with sauce was gooooood (if you like peanuty sweet/spicy types of flavors).  i didn't try any of the noodle soups, but i noticed the Indonesian customers around me all had an order of one of the noodle soups.  i'll definitely try one of those next time!  the desserts were decent.  not too sweet. i had the Es Duren (Indonesian special layer cake) and the Burbur Ketan Hitam (Black sweet rice with coconut milk).
author: Soph I.

description: The food is ordinary and normal. If you are hungry and are in the neighborhood and don't feel like walking  or pondering too much, you can safely walk in here. You won't  be greatly disappointed and at the same time you will not be greatly satisfied either.  It is also very clean.
author: Kingshuk g.

description: I recommend Bamboo Village slightly over this establishment.  But this place has better Telur Balado and Soto Ayam.  Their sambal terasi is not as good as the one offered in Bamboo Village.  The Sop Bumbut is also not as good here.  But it usually is a hard choice to make between these two star indonesian restuarants.
author: Toto T.

description: Went here yesterday (based on the rave reviews on here) we purposely arrived at 4.30, after lunch before dinner.Should have known something was wrong when 5 of the 8 tables were still siiting there with menus on the table..Seated right away,given menus and water,then had to wait over 10 mins to order.There was no busboy,so the waiters had to clean tables, take orders,serve food,all the while setting up extra tables,pushing tables together.There were only two of them,so they were rushed off their feet.Ordered the rice table,26 bucks,not cheap for the ammount of food you get,if I pay 26 for food at an asian restaurant,I expect to take home at least enough food for one good meal.Nothing left over and had to have a burger a few hors later,and I am not a really big eater.The quality of the food was fine,having lived in Amsterdam for 5  years, I have had the rice table many times and this one was about average.Took another ten minutes after my ricetable to get my final dish of desert.All in all just under 2 hours to get a meal   for two people, I like to take my time,but this was too much.Maybe I caught them at a bad time,was pretty busy,god knows what it's like at 8 on a saturday night.I can live with the slow service and mild cahos,cannot take small portions.They really need a busboy or two. First and last time.Also first time I have been disappointed with a yelp pick.
author: terence r.
